title: The Vedas & The Puranas
story: It was the time of sunrise, at Badarikāśrama, in the area of the Himalayas. Sage Vyāsa just took his bath in River Sarasvati. Then, he offered his prayers and sat alone to meditate. Being a great saint of spiritual vision, he could see the past and the future with his divine eyes. It was the end of Dvāpara yuga. Kali-yuga was approaching soon. In his meditation, Vyāsadeva saw various faults in the people to be born in Kali-yuga. Vyāsadeva is an incarnation of Lord Śrī Krsna. Desiring to benefit people, he thought, The people of Kali-yuga will have less lifespan, short memory, and poor intelligence. The Vedas contain great knowledge that gives the right direction to humanity. So, I will give them the knowledge of the Vedas in a simplified form. Vyāsa then planned to write the Vedas. Previously there were no books. People used to learn simply by hearing from a powerful guru, and they would remember easily. This is because they had sharp intelligence and good memory. But people of Kali-yuga have poor memory. So, Vyāsadeva wanted to put the Vedic knowledge in written form to benefit humanity in Kali-yuga. At the beginning of the creation, Lord Brahmā spoke the four Vedas with his four mouths. The mantras of these Vedas were mixed like an unsorted collection of various types of gems. Together they were known as one Veda named Yajur-Veda. Vyāsadeva separated these Vedic mantras into four divisions, just as one sorts out a diverse collection of jewels into various piles according to their color or size. These divisions are the four Vedas -Rg Veda, Yajur Veda, Sāma Veda, and Atharva Veda. Thereafter Vyasa had written the Puranas and the Mahābhārata to teach morals to human beings through stories. Thus, the histories and stories in the Puranas are called the fifth Veda. Vyāsa then instructed his disciples, Please become professors of the Vedas and propagate this wisdom Sage Paila took charge of the Rg Veda, Jaimini Sāma Veda, Vaiśampāyana - Yajur Veda, Sumantu Atharva-Veda, and Romaharsana took charge of the Puranas. These scholars divided the Vedas into smaller sections and spread that excellent knowledge through their disciples and grand disciples.
quotes: Great sages, by dint of their purity, can visualize the past and the future.
trivia: The Four Yugas: By the arrangement of God, seasons keep changing, bringing about different climates. The cool winter changes, the hot summer go away, inviting the wet monsoon. Similarly, the yugas(ages) also change cyclically like these seasons. There are fout yugas: Satya yuga, Treta yuga, Dvapara yuga, and Kali yuga. Each yuga has a different characteristics. As the yugas change from the first to the last, there will be degradation in people's mentalities and habits. Of all the yugas, the most degraded is the Kali yuga, in which people are quarrelsome and hypocritic.
activity: Share your expeerience of being helped by someone when you were in need.
lesson: A Lesson On Compassion: Everyone works for one's well-being. But compassionate work for everyone's well-being. Sage Vyasa wanted to benefit the world through his books that provide guidelines for leading a responsible life. Such selfless sages are the real friends of humanity. They are willing even to take personal inconveniences to help people in general. Learning the spirit of compassion from such sages, we should also try to help others to the best of our ability.

title: From Confusion to Clarity
story: Why is my heart dissatisfied? Vyāsa pondered very deeply, sitting in an isolated spot on the bank of the Sarasvati River. Then, he said within himself, I followed all my spiritual practices properly. I perfectly worshiped the Vedas and the gurus. I have divided one Veda into four and wrote the Mahābhārata, by which even naive people can get benefited. But still, why am I feeling so incomplete? By such honest self-examination, Vyāsa could figure out the cause for his dissatisfaction. He thought, This may be because I did not adequately describe the enchanting activities of Lord Krsna and the process of bhakti in my books. Bhakti, or loving devotional service to Lord Krsna, is the natural activity of all living beings. The path of bhakti is most pleasing to the pure devotees and the Lord Himself. As Vyasa was thinking thus, his guru, Närada Muni came to his hermitage. Vyāsa stood up respectfully, welcomed his guru, and worshiped him. Närada knew the situation of Vyasa and the cause of his dissatisfaction. So, he smiled and said, Dear Vyāsa, in the books you have written, you have not sufficiently stressed on the glorious path of bhakti. And you have not adequately described the glories and pastimes of Lord Krsna. Please do it now; only then will your heart be satisfied. Even imperfectly written literature is appreciated by saints if they describe the wonderful and superhuman activities of God. Vyāsadeva identified the reason for his dissatisfaction by introspection, and Närada Muni reconfirmed it. To inspire Vyāsa, Närada narrated his past life, I was the son of a maidservant in my previous life. But by the holy association of great devotees called the bhakti-vedantas, I was inspired to perform bhakti. Thus, I became Närada Muni and attained a spiritual body. The results of the sincere practice of bhakti are eternal. By bhakti, one can attain the supreme shelter of God and be relieved of all miseries. Bhakti transforms even sinful people into virtuous persons. So, please write Śrimad Bhagavatam, emphasizing the path of bhakti vividly. Nārada brought great clarity in Vyasa's thoughts and gave him specific direction for his further writing work. Having thus advised Vyāsa, Närada Muni departed. Närada Muni personally experienced the power of bhakti. Thus, he had inspired Vyasa to write the glories of bhakti and historical narrations of those transformed by bhakti. After that, Vyāsadeva sat to meditate in a devotional mood. In his vision, he saw Lord Krsna and māyā, His illusory energy. He also saw people suffering due to the influence of mayā. He knew that the solution to this suffering was bhakti or loving service to Lord Krsna. Thus, to vividly explain the path of bhakti, he compiled Śrīmad Bhagavatam, in which he described the activities of Lord Krsna, His incarnations, and His dear devotees. His heart was then fully satisfied. Later Vyāsadeva taught the Bhagavatam to his son Sukadeva Gosvāmī.
quotes: It's a very satisfying experience for the heart to hear, read, write or speak the pastimes of Lord Krishna and His devotees., However great one may be, one could get bewildered at times. Therefore, one needs the guidance of mature persons to overcome confusion and attain clarity., One who is benefitted from bhakti desires to share it with others as well., An intelligent person takes advantage of the timeless wisdom of the sacred Bhagvatam for a enlivering social and spiritual life.
trivia: Parampara Of Srimad Bhagavatam: Lord Krsna originally spoke Srimad Bhagavatam to Lord Brahma at the beginning of the creation. Brahma later spoke the Bhagavatam to Narada Muni, who later taught it to Vyasadeva. Vyasa taught the Bhagavatam to his son Sukadeva Gosvami who later narrated it to King Pariksit, Suta Gosvami and others. Suta Gosvami spoke the Bhagavatam to the sages of Naimisaranya, headed by sage Saunaka. Thus the Bhagavatam descended in a chain of authentic teachers and students called parampara. In this bona fide parampara, all the teachers are the representatives of Lord Krsna, because they transparently transmit the transcendental teachings of Krsna, without any deviation or imagination, for our transformation. Therefore, by sincerly hearing Srimad Bhagavatam from an authentic teacher, we can develop a love for Krsna, and be freed from all sorrows, confusions, and fears.
activity: 1. Recollect a situation in your life where your honest introspection helped you in understanding your problem. 2. Mention an incident where a senior's guidance helped you or your friend to come out of confusion and attain clarity.
lesson: A Lesson On Guidance: Everyone needs a teacher. Well-wishing gurus guide their students on the right path. Although Vyasadeva was very exalted and accomplished, he took guidance from his guru Narada. When we think we know everything, we are limited only to what we know and remain confused in certain situation. But when we are open to learn from experienced teachers, our knowledge increases, and we overcome confusions.

title: The Price for Frivolity
story: Long, long ago, there was a Gandharva known as Upabarhana. Gandharvas are a category of devatās in heavens, who are extremely beautiful, and skillful in singing. They live on their planet called the Gandharva-Loka. Upabarhana was very handsome with an attractive face and well-built body. The other Gandharvas respected him. He was a playboy, expert in decorating himself with flower garlands, sandalwood pulp, cosmetics, and ornaments. He was most pleasing to the women of his city. Once the residents of heaven organized a spiritual gathering to glorify the Supreme Lord Krsna. Several devatās, including the Gandharvas and Apsaras, were invited for this spiritual event. Upabarhana also. went there surrounded by many women. Unfortunately, instead of glorifying God, he became intoxicated and sang some mundane songs inappropriate for the occasion. The members of the festival became upset with inappropriate conduct. The prajapatis who oversee the affairs of the universe, cursed him, You need to be punished for your misbehavior. May you become a low-class person, devoid of beauty. Being thus cursed, Upabarhana fell to the earth planet from the elevated heaven. He was deprived of his exalted position as a Gandharva and took birth as the son of a maidservant on the earth. He lost his beauty for which he was so proud.
activity: Recall an incident, if any, where you acted frivolously and ended up in a trouble. How does this story inspire you to cultivate better behavior?
lesson: A Lesson On Behavior: Humble and respectful behavior attracts blessings from great souls. But proud and frivolous behavior attracts curses from them. One's behavior generally depends on one's attitude. Therefore, we need to cultivate proper attitudes and behavior in the company of good people.

title: A Child's Humble Service
story: As a result of the curse, Upabarhana took birth as the only son of a maidservant. She was simple, poor, and uneducated. Yet, she was fortunate enough to get an opportunity to serve noble-hearted brahmanas. She did menial services for the maintenance of herself and her child. She had no other relative apart from her only son. She bound him with the tie of great affection. She wanted to look after the boy's maintenance properly, but because she was so poor and dependent, she couldn't do much for the child. The boy was also dependent on his mother's affection and had no experience of different lands or people. He always believed that she would never leave him. When the boy was just five years old, he and his mother lived in a brahmaņa school. Once, some great sages called the bhakti-vedantas came there. They were sinless, learned in the Vedas, endowed with all good qualities and were pure devotees of Lord Krsna. They all decided to stay at that place during the four months of the rainy season. At this time, both the maidservant and her son rendered their various services. When the bhakti-vedantas were discussing the pastimes of Lord Krsna, the boy would attentively hear them. Thus, his taste for hearing about God increased gradually. Just as some diseases are contagious, bhakti is also contagious in a good sense. In the association of bhakti-vedantas, the boy became 'infected' with their purity and developed all good qualities and especially bhakti unto Krsna. The boy was disciplined, humble, and obedient to elders. He had no attachment to frivolous sports. He was not naughty or talkative. The sages were impressed with his conduct and blessed him. Although the boy was very young, the son of a maidservant, uneducated, he still became a great devotee of Lord Krsna, Slowly, be became greatly attracted to the path of bhakti, which constitutes bearing about Lord Krsna, chanting His names, and remembering Him. The boy fixed his mind on Lord Krsna steadily and engaged his body in serving the Lord in various ways. For example, he bowed down in front of the Lord and His devotees, carried a water pot with his hands, heard about the Lord with his ears, and so on. Thus, his ignorance was fully destroyed, and he became enlightened in Krsna consciousness. Thus, during the monsoon, in the association of sages, the boy developed prema, or love for Krsna, the ultimate aspiration of all beings. When the sages were departing, they mercifully taught the boy Srimad Bhagavatam even though he didn't ask for it. They initiated him in the path of pure bhakti unto Lord Krsna. This is the reward for his humility and service.
quotes: Devotion to God cannot be attained by age, caste, wealth, beauty, scholarship, and other material qualities but can easily be achieved by the blessings of pure devotees., Ignorance is like darkness, and spiritual knowledge is like the sun. Wherever there is light, there cannot be darkness.
activity: List at least three benefits of associating with good people.
lesson: A Lesson On Association: The association we keep shapes our desires, personalities, and qualities. Good association is the breeding ground for good qualities. Such association uplifts us from our shortcomings and unwanted habits. Further, it inspires us with dedication and determination to attain one's goals. The little son of the maid was transformed in the association of devotees and was also empowered to transform many others. He became the celebrated sage Narada Muni who was the guru of several other devotees like Prahlada, Dhruva, and Mrigari. Such is the power of good association.

title: The Boy Who Became A Sage
story: After the departure of the great sages, the boy continued to live with his mother. He was overwhelmed with the stroke of inspiration he had just received in their wonderful company. He continued to meditate on their noble teachings. One day an unexpected incident happened in the boy's life. His poor mother went out of the house to milk a cow in the evening time. While walking along the path, she touched a snake with her foot, and the snake bit her leg. She died on the spot, and thus the boy lost his affectionate mother, his only caretaker. The boy was mature enough to see the hand of God even in this tragic incident. He thought, The Lord is the supreme well-wisher of His devotees. It is His mercy alone by which I am put in this situation. So, he decided to travel towards the north. Because the boy's mother served the bhakti-vedantas, the Lord must have given her a good destination, and her son is now kept fully under the shelter of the Lord. The boy passed alone through many cities, towns, villages, farms, A mines, agricultural lands, valleys, gardens, forests, hills, and mountains. He got an impetus in spiritual life and did not waste time for a single moment. He continually meditated on Lord Krsna during His travels. He came upon reservoirs of water filled with beautiful lotus flowers, surrounded by bees and singing birds. He traveled through huge fearsome forests dense with reeds, cane, clumps of grass, and hollow bamboos, the playground for snakes, owls, and jackals. Still, he was not fearful, as he constantly depended on the Lord. Thus traveling, he felt tired, both bodily and mentally. He was both thirsty and hungry. He saw a river, took a bath in it, and drank some water. He was thus relieved from exhaustion. He sat under the shade of a big banyan tree. He then began to meditate upon Lord Krsna with great love. He fully concentrated his mind on Paramātmā or the Supersoul situated within the heart, as taught to him by the sages. While the boy meditated on the Lord with great emotion and love, tears fell from his eyes, and Lord Sri Krsna appeared in his heart. The boy could experience the fragrance of Krsna's body, the sound of Krsna's ankle bells and the beauty of Krsna's face. He was thus absorbed in an ocean of ecstasy and was covered with goosebumps erupting so much out of intense love. While in such bliss, he suddenly lost the vision of the Lord. He couldn't see the attractive form of Krsna anymore in his meditation. He was agitated from the sorrow of separation. He became despondent, like someone who has lost a treasure. He desired to see the Lord repeatedly and tried to meditate with great eagerness but couldn't see the Lord. He was thus dissatisfied and very much aggrieved. The sun rises on his own, and the Lord also reveals Himself to us when He wants. Pleased by seeing the boy's attempts in that lonely place, Krsna mercifully spoke to him to encourage him. The Lord said, In this body, you cannot see Me anymore. I am invisible to those who are incomplete in service and who still have impurities. I showed Myself to you once, just to increase your desire to see Me more. By serving My devotees and Me even for a few days, one attains firm devotion for Me. You will soon become My associate in the spiritual world after giving up the present body. Then the Lord stopped speaking. Since then, the boy repeatedly chanted the Lord's holy name. He traveled in this world, being humble, satisfied, and non-envious. In due course of time, he was absorbed in Krsna and became detached from all material taints and met with death. Quitting the material body, he received a spiritual body, befitting an associate of the Lord. In his next life, he became the great sage Närada, a pure devotee of Lord Krsna. In the next creation, when Lord Brahma was creating the universe. this boy appeared as the son of Brahmā, in a spiritual body. He was called Närada Muni, the best among the sages. The Lord gifted him a musical instrument called vind. While playing that vind, Narada travels unrestrictedly both in the spiritual and material worlds, singing about the Lord and spreading the path of bhakti. As soon as He chants, the Lord at once appears in the heart, as if called for. Närada Muni is a great teacher of bhakti and is the guru of several devotee kings like Dhruva, Prahlada, Priyavrata, and others.
quotes: Although devotees sometimes face difficulties in life, they don't give up their faith in the protection of the Lord., One who has complete faith in the Lord's mercy does not fear any material difficulty., One must meditate on God as taught by scriptures and gurus, not according to one's imagination., we cannot demand the Lord to be present before us, just as we cannot demand the sun to rise whenever we like.
activity: 1. Cite any two scriptural personalities who became successful by the blessings and sincere endeavors. 2. Share your personal experience in a situation where your good conduct made an elder happy, and you felt encouraged and blessed. 3. Try to do some service for your teacher today, and note how they felt and responded. How does it feel?
lesson: A Lesson On Endeavor: When divine blessings are coupled with sincere endeavors, we become successful in attaining our goals. Although the maidservant's son was not so advanced in his age or social status, he was still blessed by the sages for his excellent conduct. And with his sincere endeavors, he was successful in attaining God's grace. So, we should try to please elders by our behavior, receive their heartfelt blessings, and sincerely try our best to succeed in our goals.

title: A Mother's Soft Heart
story: Aśvatthämä was the son of Dronācārya, the military teacher of the Pandavas and the Kauravas. Aśvatthämä was a friend of evil Duryodhana and sided him in the Kuruksetra war. He fought against the virtuous Pandavas. With the assistance of Lord Krsna, the Pandavas won the battle. While Arjuna killed several warriors, Bhima killed the ninety-nine brothers of Duryodhana and defeated him in a club fight. Aśvatthāmā desired to please the defeated Duryodhana. So he went to the military camp of the Pandavas and killed the five sleeping sons of Draupadi, the chaste wife of the Pandavas. He then came back and reported this to Duryodhana. But Duryodhana disapproved of this heinous act and was not at all pleased. Realizing that her five sons had died, Draupadi cried piteously with tears in her eyes. Here heart was utterly broken. How could the heart of a loving mother tolerate the death of her dear sons? Seeing Draupadi's lamentation, Arjuna tried to pacify her, I shall behead that fallen brāhmaņa Aśvatthāmā, and wipe your tears. Guided by Krsna as his charioteer, Arjuna then equipped himself with armor, bow, and arrows, and set out to chase Aśvatthāmā. Aśvatthāmā realized that Arjuna and Krsna were coming towards him in great speed. He had already seen their powerful combination in the Kurukşetra war. In great fear, he fled away. But Arjuna relentlessly pursued him. Seeing his life in danger, his horses exhausted, and finding no alternative, Aśvatthāmā released a brahmastra, the ultimate weapon. He couldn't understand that the brahmastra could destroy the world. He didn't even know how to withdraw it. Yet, he thoughtlessly released it just to save himself. Thereupon, a glaring light spread in all directions indicating a great danger. Bewildered at this, Arjuna took shelter of Krsna and said, My dear Lord. You make Your devotees fearless. I don't understand the reason and source of this dangerous effulgence spreading everywhere. Lord Krsna then explained, Dear Arjuna, Aśvatthämä released a brahmastra out of fear for his life. He doesn't know howto retract it. Only another brahmastra can counteract it. Please release your brahmastra and retract both the brahmastras. Hearing this, Arjuna circumambulated Krsna and cast his brahmastra. By the blessings of Krsna, Arjuna at once retracted both brahmastras, Arjuna, his eyes blazing in anger, then bound Aśvatthāmā with ropes, took him to the military camp and entrusted him to Draupadi. Draupadi was a kind-hearted lady and an exalted devotee of Lord Krsna. She was not comfortable seeing Aśvatthāmā bound by ropes. With deep compassion and respect, she spoke to Arjuna and the Pandavas, Please release him. After all, he is a brahmaņa. His father Dronācārya had mercifully taught you Pandavas all military arts. Although Drona had died, now he is being represented by his son, Aśvatthāmā. We kṣatriyas are supposed to be respectful to the brahmaņas, who are naturally our gurus. Draupadi demonstrated her respectful attitude for the brāhmanas, and exhibited her empathy for another woman. She said, Drona's wife Krpi is still living. I know the pain of a mother who had lost her son. I am experiencing the agony of the death of my sons. I don't want to give similar pain to Krpi. Please don't make her cry like me. Draupadi's words were filled with mercy, empathy, forgiveness, honesty, and justice. Yudhisthira Mahäräja supported her arguments. Nakula, Sahadeva, Sātyaki, Arjuna, Krsna, the ladies and others all unanimously agreed with her. But Bhima disagreed with them, and strongly recommended killing of Aśvatthämä. Yet Draupadi wanted to save him. To prevent both of them, Lord Krsna manifested two extra arms. With two hands, Krsna was trying to stop Bhima, and with two hands, He tried to stop Draupadi. With a smile, Krsna spoke to Arjuna, A brahmana shouldn't be killed. But if he does a criminal act, he can be killed. O Arjuna, please fulfill your promise to Draupadi and satisfy Bhima and Me. Arjuna heard these contradictory orders of Krsna and responded intelligently. Arjuna took his sword and cut both hair and jewel from the head of Aśvatthāmā. This lifelong punishment of insult was symbolic of his death. He had already lost his bodily luster due to infanticide (killing children). Now he lost his strength due to the loss of his jewel. Aśvatthāmā was then unbound and driven out of the camp. After that, the Pandavas and Draupadi overwhelmed with grief, performed the necessary rituals for their departed relatives.
quotes: Evil people do not hesitate to perform any ruthless activity to satisfy their egos and revengeful attitudes., Selfish men think only of their safety and do not acknowledge how their activities trouble others. But noble people take responsibility for the welfare of others., A kindhearted devotee, although personally experiencing pain, doesn't want others to suffer like oneself. This is empathy.
activity: 1. Recall an incident in which someone troubled you with their words or actions, and it was difficult for you to forgive them. Share your thoughts on that incident after reading the story of Draupadi. 2. Does forgiveness imply that one shouldn't take any action to correct a wrongdoer? Explain.
lesson: A Lesson On Empathy: One may not be able to acknowlege other's pain when one is personally experiencing pain. But empathetic people can do so. Empathy is to put oneself in the situation of others and see what they undergo. In this story, although Asvatthama's act deeply pained Draupadi, she could empathize with his mother and excuse him from punishment. Learning from the example of Draupadi, we should also try to empathize with others as much as possible., A Lesson On Forgiveness: Great people can tolerate personal suffering but cannot see other's suffering. They do not wish to harm even those who have harmed them. Taking inspiration from them, let us try to forgive others, at least for their small and unintentional mistakes, to begin with. Of course, if it's necessary and unavoidable sometimes the wrongdoers must be punished. The Pandavas did so in the Kuruksetra war, under the guidance of Krsna, to establish dharma. But while punishing offenders, devotees do not hold any grudge, hatred, or envy.

title: The Boy Who Saw God Before Birth
story: Lord Krsna assisted the Pandavas in various ways in the Kuruksetra war. The love of the Pandavas for Krsna is unparalleled. Even after the war, Krsna continued to stay at Hastinäpura to pacify and encourage the Pandavas, who had lost their relatives in the war. Finally, after some time, Krsna took permission from His relatives and prepared to go to His city, Dvārakā. He exchanged greetings with the Pändavas and the brahmaņas there and sat on His chariot to depart. Suddenly, Uttară came running towards Krsna, seeking His protection. Uttara was the wife of Abhimanyu, who died in the battle of Kuruksetra. She was pregnant at that time, with the last heir of the Pandavas' dynasty (Parīksit) growing in her womb. Uttara realized that some fiery arrow was coming towards her. Although her powerful fathers-in-law, Arjuna, Bhima, and Yudhisthira were present there, without a second thought, Uttara ran towards Krsna for she was naturally dependent on Krsna in all circumstances. Uttara prayed to Krsna, O Lord, no one else can protect me except You. A fiery arrow is coming towards me fast. Let it burn me personally, but not kill my unborn child. Being a noble mother, Uttarä loved her child more than her own life. Krsna understood that shameless Aśvatthämä had again released a brahmāstra to kill Uttarä's embryo. He was determined to wipe out even the last descendant of the Pandavas. Krsna instantly entered Uttara's womb, in a thumb-sized form with four hands. He wore a shining crown, earrings of molten gold, a yellow cloth as good as lightning, and eyes blood red with anger. The child in Uttara's womb was astonished to see the glowing Lord. Krsna vanquished the heat of bralumastra just as the sun evaporated a drop of dew. Then He disappeared from there as the child wondered. While Krsna was present inside the womb of Uttară in a small form, He was also present in front of Uttara in His chariot. Overwhelmed with gratitude and devotion, the chaste queen Kunti, mother of the Pandavas, praised Krsna: O Lord, You are the Supreme person. I am fortunate to see Your beautiful form. You have protected my sons from various dangers. Proud people cannot understand You, but humble devotees can easily see You. Your birth and activities are inconceivable. The prosperity of this kingdom is only due to Your grace. So, let my mind constantly flow towards You exclusively, as the Ganges flows towards the ocean. After some time, Uttara gave birth to her noble son Pariksit. The boy was born when all signs of the zodiac were favorable. His grandfather Yudhisthira had brahmaņas such as Dhaumya and Kripa recite mantras and perform his birth rites. Moreover, Yudhisthira gave charity to the brahmanas profusely. The brahmanas predicted the future qualities and activities of Pariksit: This child will be known as Vişnu-rata because Visnu has protected him. He will have all good qualities. He will be as good as Lord Rama in being true to his promise. He will be like Arjuna amongst the bowmen. He will increase the reputation of his family. He will be as strong as a lion and as merciful as Lord Siva. He will become a great devotee of Krsna like Prahlada. King Yudhisthira felt very happy hearing these predictions. Parīksit was fortunate enough to have the darsana of Krsna right within the womb of his mother. He wondered who the Lord was. After his birth, he constantly searched for the Lord whom he saw before his birth. He examined everyone he saw to find if he were the Lord. Therefore, his name was Pariksit, one who examines. The royal prince Parikşit luxuriantly grew up under the care of his grandfathers, like the moon during the waxing fortnight. After Lord Krsna disappeared from this planet, the Pandavas enthroned Parīksit as the emperor and retired. King Parikşit ruled the kingdom under the guidance of brāhmanas. He married a princess named Iravati. He had four sons, of whom the eldest was Janamejaya.
quotes: A devotee's dependence on Krishna is as natural and as spontaneous as a child's dependence on the parents., Envious people always try to trouble devotees. But the devotees take shelter of Lord Krishna in all difficulties., Krishna is omnipresent, i.e., He can be there at multiple places at the same time., Lord Krishna is very affectionate to His devotees. He saves them from all dangers., Krishna's form is so attractive that one who sees Him once desires to see Him always.
activity: 1. Does dependence on God imply that we don't put any effort into solving our life's problems? Share your understanding. 2. Identify at least two personalities, from the scriptures and/or real life, who prayerfully took shelter of the Lord in difficulty.
lesson: A Lesson On Dependence: Uttara's spontaneous dependence on Lord Krsna is just like a child's natural dependence on the mother. Lord Krsna is always attentive to the needs of such dependent devotees. When we proudly think that we can save ourselves solely by our strength, we cannot feelingly take shelter from the Lord. The Lord reciprocates with His devotees to the degree of their dependence. The stories of great devotees inspire is to seek the shelter of Krsna, apart from being what is possible from our side.

title: The King Who Saved A Cow
story: Once, Emperor Parikşit heard unpleasant news that Kali had entered his kingdom. Kali was the personality representing the current age called Kali-yuga. There are four ages or yugas, namely Satya-yuga, Treta-yuga, Dvapara-yuga, and Kali-yuga. As yugas appear in this order, the life span and good qualities of people will reduce. Parikşit took up his bow and arrows and prepared himself to conquer Kali. As a courageous ksatriya king, he was not at all afraid of fighting. As he traveled on his well-decorated golden chariot, accompanied by his troops, the rulers of different places offered him tributes. At many places, Parikşit heard the glories of his ancestors, the Pandavas and their intimate relationship with Lord Krsna. Thus traveling, King Parikşit reached Kuruksetra, on the banks of River Sarasvati. At that place, a cow and a bull were conversing. The cow was none other than Dhara, earth personified. And the bull was Dharma, morality personified. The bull had lost his three legs and was trying to stand only on one leg. The cow had lost her bodily luster and had tears in her eyes. The bull asked the cow, Why are you aggrieved? Are you sick? Or are you sad seeing my state, having lost three legs? Are you lamenting for yourself, being exploited by the meat-eaters? Are you unhappy that evil persons mistreat children and women? Are you worried that unqualified teachers are mishandling education? Are you sad seeing the exploitation of people by greedy kings? Or are you morose because Lord Krsna has disappeared from this planet? Are you missing Him? The cow replied, O Dharma, Lord Krsna has concluded His pastimes here and has gone back to His eternal abode. In His absence, Kali-yuga has spread its influence. I am very sorry to see this. I lament about -myself, you, the devotees, and all the followers of Dharma. When Lord Krsna was performing pastimes on my surface, Krsna had relieved me of the burden of the atheistic kings. I was beautifully decorated with His divine footprints, and my hairs (grasses) stood on end. I was the most fortunate planet in the universe at that time and was prosperous in all ways. Because He incarnates on this planet to establish Dharma, you were also greatly fortunate in His presence. But now that He went back to the spiritual world, I am suffering, and you are also suffering. As the cow and the bull were thus conversing, king Parīksit reached there. He saw the cow and the bull and Kali next to them. Although unqualified, Kali was dressed like a king and was beating the cow and the bull. The poor cow was crying, distressed, and hungry. The bull was terrified. He was standing on one leg because Kali had destroyed three of his legs. The pitiful condition of the cow and the bull indicates that in Kali-yuga, the earth would be miserable, and the sinful people of this age would heavily compromise Dharma. Seeing the condition of the cow and the bull, Parikşit questioned Kali in a deep voice, Who are you? You appear strong, and yet you beat helpless animals under my protection! You dress like a king but are acting like a low-class man. A culprit like you deserve to be killed. Pariksit then reassured the cow and the bull, Do not fear this man. Please do not cry. As long as I am living, you will have good fortune. O bull as white as the white lotus, you are certainly Dharma. In Satya-yuga, your four legs were established by the four principles of austerity (tapa), cleanliness (sauca), mercy (daya), and truth (satyam). Now three legs are broken due to pride, bad desires, and intoxication. You are now standing only on one leg (truthfulness), but this Kali is also trying to destroy that leg too. Previously, the Lord relieved the burden of the earth (cow). But nov she laments her future, ruled by lower-class men, posing as kings So shall kill this sinful rascal. King Pariksit then took up his sword to kill Kali at once. Seeing his imminent death and having no ability to fight, Kali gave up his kingly dress out of fear and fell at the feet of Pariksit. Parīksit did not kill Kali but spoke to him, Because you are seeking my shelter, you need not fear for your life. But you can't remain in my kingdom. Because of you, adharma or immorality will prevail. And people will become victims of greed, falsehood, robbery, misfortune, cheating, quarrel, and vanity. So, get out of my kingdom immediately. Trembling in fear, Kali petitioned, O king, where can I go? Everywhere is your kingdom. So, please fix some permanent place for me under your shelter. Parīkşit then said, You can reside in places where there is gambling, intoxication, animal slaughter, and illicit relationships. Kali replied, O Parīksit, such places do not exist in your pious kingdom. Please give me another place. Thoughtful Pariksit then said, You may live where there is gold. Because gold or wealth gives rise to falsity, intoxication, evil desires, envy, and enmity, Kali was thus allowed to reside in these five places. As a considerate person, Parīkşit chose places suitable to Kali's nature But at the same time, as a responsible king, he ensured that Kali could not perform his immoral activities. He engaged all the wealth in his kingdom in devotional activities and re-established the lost three legs of Dharma (austerity, cleanliness, mercy). Thus, he improved the earth's situation and didn't give any chance for Kali-yuga to progress. There is another important reason why Pariksit didn't kill Kali. He sawsomething good in Kali: In Kali-yuga, auspicious acts bear good results simply by intending to do them, whereas sinful acts bear bad results only by engaging in them. Also, Kali is fearful for the less intelligent but not for the self-controlled devotees. Considering this, Pariksit took special care of the foolish people.
quotes: The cow is like our mother as she gives us milk. The bull is like our father because he helps in agriculture by which we get grains to eat. Therefore, to beat or kill cows and bulls is a great offense., A king's main duty is to protect the innocent and punish the miscreants., Those who desire their well-being should avoid gambling, drinking, animal killing, and bad association.
activity: 1. What, in your opinion, are the qualities and responsibilities of a king or a leader? 2. Have a group discussion among your friends on the topic - Why should the cows and bulls be protected? And what are the effects of killing innocent animals? 3. What are the four legs of dharma? What would you like to do to uphold those legs in your life?
lesson: A Lessson On Responsibility: An ideal king takes responsibility for everyone in his kingdom without partially or discrimination. He protects his citizens in all possible ways. He cares for not only their physical survival but also their spiritual inspiration. Therefore, such a king is considered a bona fide representative of God in the Vedic times. His protection is not restricted to human beings but is extended to innocent animals too. Especially cow and bull are like the mother and father to human beings, and a virtuous king should not tolerate any offense caused to them. We should also learn to respect cows and bulls and serve them as much as we can.

title: A Severe Punishment For A Small Mistake
story: Once King Pariksit went on a hunting excursion. Wandering in the forest for a long time, he became tired and thirsty. In search of water, he came upon the hermitage of a sage called Samika. The sage was covered with deerskin and matted locks of hair. He was in deep meditation. Pariksit asked the sage for some drinking water. But the sage didn't respond because he was not in external consciousness. Pariksit felt unwelcomed and neglected. He became momentarily angry due to hunger and thirst. He found a dead snake near the hermitage, picked it up with his bow, and placed it on the sage's shoulder. He did this as a sign of return for a cold welcome. He then left for his palace. Pariksit didn't purposely insult the sage. His anger was circumstantial, and he cdidn't have any bad habits or qualities. He never disrespected brahmaņas before. Šamika Rşi had a five-year-old son named Śrngi. While playing with other boys, he heard about the king's offense to his father at their hermitage. Śrngi had brahmanical power both by birth and by training But he was inexperienced and immature. He didn't have proper culture and tolerance. Further, he was very puffed up with his brahmanical power due to the influence of Kali. Śrngi proudly said, Oh! Just look at the sins of these arrogant kings They are like crows and watchdogs at the door. And brahmanas are their masters. How can they expect to enter the house and dine with the master on the same plate? So now that Krsna had disappeared, I shall punish them myself. Just see my great power! Then, with eyes red-hot with anger, Srngi cursed Pariksit, On the seventh day from today, a snake-bird will bite that wretched king who insulted my father Pariksit made a mistake, but it was small Yet short-sighted Srngi thoughtlessly gave him severe punishment. Srngi returned home and saw the dead snake around his father's neck and cried loudly. Hearing his son crying, Samika Rşi opened his eyes and saw the dead snake, and threw it off. He didn't pay much attention to it. Finally, he asked Śrngi, Why are you crying? Did someone harm you? Śrngi then explained what had happened. Hearing that Śrngi had cursed king Parikșit, Samika was upset with his son, Oh! You have committed a great sin. For an insignificant offense, you have given a great punishment. You are so immature. The king is the best among men. Citizens live in prosperity, being protected by such a noble king. A king is a representative of God, and he rules the kingdom on behalf of God. When such a king is abolished, the world becomes filled with thieves, and people will be unprotected, and will be injured and killed. We shall be responsible for all these sins. Emperor Pariksit is a pious and saintly king (răjarsi) and has performed many sacrifices for the welfare of humanity. He does not deserve to be cursed when fatigued by hunger and thirst. You have misused your power. Śamika then prayed for his son, May the Lord pardon this boy, whe had foolishly sinned cursing a sinless devotee. Samika thus regretted his son's foolish and impudent behavior. He didn't take the king's offense seriously.
quotes: Due to arrogance and anger, people misuse their power and harm the Innocent., A punishment should not be disproportionate to the mistake committed., Power without self-control and discrimination can be disastrous.
activity: 1. According to you, what should have been Sringi's response after hearing about Parikshit's insulting his father? 2. Recall an incident, if any, where you overreacted to someone's mistake and scolded them disproportionately. How does this story help you understand the effects of such a reaction on others? 3. What will you do in the future if someone makes a mistake that makes you upset?
lesson: A Lesson On Tolerance: One's greatness is estimated by one's ability to tolerate provoking situations. Scriptural characters teach us what not to do in life. One should not be arrogant and impulsive like Sringi. But one must try to be patient and tolerant like Samika. Sometimes people may cause us some inconvenience unintentionally, under the heat of circumstances. One shouldn't take such occasional disturbances seriously but try to be tolerant. One should wisely use one's power and not misuse it like Srngi to unnessarily harm others.

title: The Boon In A Curse
story: King Pariksit returned to his palace from the forest. In the forest, he had placed a dead snake around the neck of sage Samika for not receiving him properly at his hermitage. Parikşit reflected upon his act: I have performed a heinous offense against a faultless brahmaņa. While he was in meditation, I kept a dead snake around his neck and insulted him. Therefore, I must be punished for my misconduct not to commit such an offense again. And I don't want my friends and relatives to suffer for my mistake. Pariksit never intended to disrespect the sage, but he felt ashamed for his unusual behavior. As Parīkşit was thus repenting, a student of sage Samika named Gauramukha arrived at the palace. He informed Pariksit with deep embarrassment, Dear King, you have been cursed by sage Samika's son, Srngi, to die in seven days. Please make necessary arrangements before you die Hearing this, King Pariksit didn't become disappointed, hateful, or revengeful. Although his offense was minor and the curse was very severe, he still didn't become angry with Srngi or his father. He was powerful enough to counter curse Srngi, but he didn't do so. Although Pariksit was ashamed of his offense, he didn't go to Samika Rși to beg forgiveness. Because Samika sent the news of the curse very regretfully, Pariksit felt that if he apologizes, that will further embarrass the sage. And Pariksit never desired the negation of the curse. Parīksit retired from all his duties as a king and entrusted the kingdom to his son Janamejaya. He went to the southern bank of the River Ganges and sat on a straw mat there. The devatās, praising his actions, showered the earth with flowers and beat celestial drums. Finally, he decided to fast until death and take shelter of Lord Krsna. Lord Krsna personally protected Parīkşit when he was in the womb of his mother, Uttară. So then why didn't He save Parikşit from death now? Because- (i) Krsna wanted to take Parīksit to the spiritual world, the place of eternal happiness, and (ii) by putting Parikşit in such a situation, Krsna wanted to give Srimad Bhagavatam to all of us. Hearing the news about Parīkşit, many great sages arrived on the bank of the Ganges from different parts of the universe. They included Atri, Cyavana, Saradvān, Aristanemi, Bhrgu, Vasistha, Parāśara, Viśvāmitra, Vyāsadeva, Narada and many others. Parikşit welcomed all of them. Parīkşit respectfully received the sages and bowed his head. Although one brāhmaṇa cursed Parīkşit, he didn't hate all the brahmanas. After the sages sat comfortably, Parīksit humbly stood before them with folded hands and said, I am very fortunate to see you all. It is God who has appeared in the form of brahmana's curse. I have taken the Lord into my heart. Let the snake-bird bite me at once. I have no fear. I only desire that you all sing the glorious deeds of Lord Krsna. Even if I again take birth in this world, I just desire (1) attachment for Krsna, (ii) association of devotees, and (iii) friendly relations with all beings. The sages happily expressed their approval for Pariksiťt's decision and said, It is not surprising that you have given up your royal throne to attain the Lord. We shall all wait here until you go to the spiritual world, the supreme planet of Krsna. Parīkşit was not fearful of the snakebite or death. He only desired to hear the glories of God in whatever time he had before his death. Pariksit asked the sages two questions, What is the duty of everyone in all circumstances? And what is the specific duty of a person about to die? At that moment, by the will of God, Śrila Sukadeva Gosvāmi, the glorious son of Vyasadeva, arrived there. He looked sixteen years old and with a bluish bodily hue like that of Lord Krsna. He looked charming. The sages honored him by rising from their seats. Parīkşit welcomed Sukadeva Gosvāmī with great respect and gratitude. Sukadeva sat on an elevated seat, surrounded by sages. He appeared like a moon amidst stars. He was intelligent and ready to answer any question. Parikșit folded his hands and said, O great sage, by your presence, you have purified us. Simply by remembering pure devotees like yourself, our houses become sanctified. What to speak of seeing you, touching you, washing your holy feet, and offering you a seat? Just by your mere presence, even the greatest sins of a person are vanquished at once. Lord Krsna has accepted me as one of his relatives to show His affection to His cousins, the Pandavas. So, he made this arrangement that I get to meet you. Otherwise, how have you voluntarily appeared here to bless me? Generally, you hardly stay in the houses of men long enough to milk a cow. After thus praising Sukadeva, Parikşit politely asked his two questione - How to live in this world? How to leave this world at the time of death? In response to these two questions, Sukadeva Goswami spoke Srimad Bhagavatam. Pariksit, whose death was only a week away, sat amidst great sages and eagerly heard the entire Bhagavatam. After one week, Sukadeva departed, and Parīksit sat on a seat of darbha grass, meditating on Lord Krsna. Then the snake-bird Taksaka came there in the disguise of a brāhmana. After reaching Parikşit, Takşaka bit him, and the body of Parīksit immediately got burned to ashes, Everyone was astonished. The Gandharvas and Apsaras sang, and the demigods showered flowers and spoke words of praise. Thus, Pariksit went to the spiritual world. The brahmaņa's curse acted as a boon for Parikşit who attained the Lord.
quotes: An honest person doesn't justify one's mistake but tries to rectify it and sincerely regrets it., Wherever there is power, there's a great responsibility to utilize it. properly. A devotee doesn't misuse one's power to take revenge on others but uses it for the good purposes of serving the Lord and His devotees., Whatever God does is good for everyone because He is the supreme well-wisher of all living beings, His children., For one man's mistake, one should not hate an entire community., One who has complete faith in God's protection has no fear in any situation of life., A devotee sees God's merciful hand in every situation of life.
activity: 1. Write three points on a devotee's response to difficulties in life. 2. It is natural to expect punishment. when you commit a mistake, but will you desire a punishment? Explain.
lesson: A Lesson On Faith: In difficulty, sometimes one might lose faith in God's protection, but devotees like Pariksit wouldn't. Lord Krsna saved Pariksit from the attack of brahmastra when he was in the womb of his mother, Uttara. But Krsna didn't save him from the curse of Srngi. In both cases, Krsna was merciful to Pariksit, and Pariksit had faith in Krsna. Devotees know that nothing happens without the sanction of the Lord, who is their well-wisher. Instead of misunderstanding or blaming Him, they accept His decision and come closer to Him in difficulties. The Lord makes such devotees as instruments in His divine plans for causing welfare to humanity. Through the medium of Srngi's curse, Krsna took Pariksit to the spiritual world and gave us Srimad Bhagavatam.

title: A Discourse From The Deathbed
story: The Kuruksetra war has just ended. The virtuous Pandavas won the battle over evil Duryodhana and his supporters. They were guided and supported by their dear friend Lord Krsna in many ways. After the war, however, King Yudhisthira was overwhelmed with guilt and grief. He felt responsible for the death of thousands of men in the battle. Vyāsadeva, Dhaumya, and other sages tried to pacify Yudhisthira by speaking philosophy. But no one could console him. He lamented, I am most sinful. My heart is full of ignorance. I have killed many thousands of men in the battle, including the brahmanas, friends, brothers, and gurus. I shall surely go to hell and will not be relieved from hell. But Yudhistira thought, I sinned killing so many people, only out of greed for a kingdom. I cannot counteract the pain I have given to so many women whose husbands and sons have been killed in the war. Even Lord Krsna tried to counsel Yudhisthira, by explaining that there was no sin on his part. But Yudhisthira was not pacified. Then Krsna inspired Yudhisthira to meet Bhismadeva, the grandsire of Kuru dynasty. Thus, the Pandavas, accompanied by Krsna, and sages like Vyasa and Dhaumya went to the battlefield of Kuruksetra where Bhisma was lying on a bed of arrows. In the war, Arjuna's arrows pierced every part of his body, and since then, he has been lying there. Bhismadeva, the illustrious grandfather of the Kuru dynasty, was a life long brahmacari (celibate) and a great devotee of Lord Krsna. He loved the Pandavas and protected them in various ways. Unfortunately, although being valiant and vastly learned, he had to fight on the wrong side against the virtuous Pandavas. It was because Lord Krsna wanted to teach the world the following important lesson through Bhisma. And Bhīşma played his humble part in the Lord's divine plan by fighting on the side of Duryodhana. Bhisma, however, always had affection for the Pandavas as they were righteous. Bhīṣma always wanted to see the Pandavas happy and prosperous, but because of Duryodhana and his associates like Śakuni, Pandavas were put into several troubles. Now that the Pandavas have gained the kingdom and became prosperous, Krsna brought them before Bhisma so that he could be happy in his final moments. Also, Lord Krsna wanted Yudhisthira to be enlightened by Bhīşma. That is the reason for Yudhisthira's not getting pacified by anyone, including Krsna and Vyāsa. Krsna thus wanted to show Bhīṣma's great knowledge to the whole world. Further, Krsna wanted to make His pure devotee Bhīşma happy by giving him darśana at the time of his death. Bhisma saw the Pandavas very aristocratic and felt happy. The Pandavas and Krsna bowed down before Bhisma. At that time, great sages from all over the universe, like Parvata Muni, Narada Muni, Bharadvāja, Paraśurāma, Vasistha, Gautama, Atri, Śukadeva Gosvāmī, Kaśyapa, and others had assembled there to see glorious Bhisma. Their disciples also came with them. Bhisma welcomed all of them properly as per his ability. Because arrows pierced his whole body, he couldn't even move. Still, he received all the guests assembled there with his sweet words and hearty expressions. Bhīşma especially worshiped Lord Krsna, knowing Him to be the Supreme God. Seeing the Pandavas overwhelmed and silent, Bhīşma had tears. He encouraged them, Oh, what great injustices you good people had to face! Still, you all were saved because of your devotion to the brahmaņas, dharma, and Krsna. Kunti also suffered greatly due to Pandu's death and faced many difficulties raising young sons. Even in the presence of Yudhisthira - the son of Dharma, Bhīma - the great club fighter, Arjuna - the expert bowman, and Krsna as your direct well-wisher, there were many difficulties! I consider all this to be the Lord's divine plan. So, accept it and follow it. You should rule the kingdom and take care of your citizens, as the Supreme Lord Krsna had desired. After consoling the Pandavas, Bhisma spoke about Lord Krsna, This Krsna is moving as a member of Yadu dynasty, like one of us. But He is the Supreme God. Only pure devotees can understand His greatness. You all thought of Him to be your cousin, friend, messenger, and so on. But He is the Supersoul (Paramātma) in everyone's heart. Although He is equal to all, He is especially inclined to His devotees. So, He has mercifully come before me now at the last stage of my life. May He await me with His pleasing smile while I am quitting this body. Yudhisthira then inquired from Bhisma about various dharmas. And Bhisma explained to him about the duties of different members of human society, the responsibilities of kings, and the responsibilities of devotees. At that time, the auspicious time of uttarāyana had arrived. Bhisma then withdrew his mind from everything else and focused only on Lord Krsna, who stood before him, in a four-handed form, which was Bhisma's favorite. Bhīşma then offered his heartfelt prayers to the Lord, My master Krsna has mercifully come to me in my last moments. Let me offer Him the gift of my loving thoughts and emotions. Let me have a love for that friend of Arjuna (Vijaya-sakha). His glittering yellow clothes shine in the sun, and curly locks of hair surround his lotus face. Let my mind go unto Śrī Krsna on the battlefield, whose flowing hair was covered with dust raised by the horses, and whose face was wetted with sweat. let when My sharp arrows wounded his skin, He enjoyed it. Bhīşma continued, May I have a love for Pārtha-sārathi (the charioteer of Arjuna), who stood with a whip in His right hand, and the reins in His left, carefully protecting Arjuna and his chariot. At the Rājasūya-yajña conducted by Yudhisthira, I witnessed Him being worshipped by great kings and sages as the most exalted. Thus meditating on Krsna, Bhīşma left this world and entered a Vaikuntha planets, where Lord Krsna is in His form of Pārtha-sārathi (Arjuna's chariot driver). Celebrating this event, the devatās praised Bhīṣma and showered flowers from the sky. Then Yudhisthira performed funeral rites for Bhīşma and was overtaken with grief. Yudhisthira, along with Lord Krsna, went back to Has inapura and consoled Dhṛtarāşra and Gandhārī. King Yudhisthira then ruled the kingdom in an exemplary way, according to the teachings of Bhīṣma and Lord Krsna.
quotes: A noble kshatriya king who fights against his evil enemles doesn't incur any sin because he fights for the right cause of protecting the Innocent citizens, not out of greed or envy., Vice cannot conquer virtue regardless of who tries to execute it., Krishna takes pleasure in fulfilling the long-cherished desires of His devotees., Guest reception is an essential part of our culture. One should do so to the best of one's capacity., Even amid difficulties, devotees do not give up their faith in God. To show this quality of His devotees to the whole world, sometimes God may temporarily put them into some difficulty. But ultimately, He only saves them., God reciprocates with His devotees in the forms and moods that they particularly like., Some devotees serve the Lord in a chivalrous mood and give Him the pleasure of fighting. Naturally, the Lord enjoys such kind of worship too.
activity: Why does Krishna arrange difficult situations in His devotees' lives? Discuss with your friends and come up with at least three reasons.
lesson: A LESSON ON INTENTION: Actions are seen, but the intentions behind those actions are often hidden. One may doubt genuine devotees like Bhişma, seeing their external activities. But Lord Krsna always knows their intentions and never misunderstands them. It is He who sometimes engages them in uncommon activities to teach important lessons to this world. And it is He who reveals their greatness at the right time. Krsna revealed how knowledgeable and devoted Bhisma was just before his departure. And Krsna personally came to give His darśana to Bhisma as he was departing.

title: A Blessing In Disguise
story: Once upon a time, the state police were chasing some thieves. Searching everywhere, they caught the thieves who had concealed themselves in the hermitage of a sage named Manduka Muni. The policemen arrested all the thieves and also Mandūka Muni and presented them in front of the magistrate. The magistrate decided punishment for the thieves and even Mandūka Muni. He ordered that Mandūka Muni be killed by piercing him with a lance. This is called śūla-dandana – the punishment of piercing a man's rectum with a lance that passes up to his head, thus killing the person. When Mandūka Muni was just about to be pierced with the lance, the news reached the king. The king at once came there and stopped the punishment, considering that Mandūka was a sage. The king begged forgiveness from Mandūka for the mistake of his men. Mandūka Muni then immediately went to Yamarāja, the lord of death. Yamarāja is the appointed authority that prescribes the destiny of the living beings. He punishes all sinful people in hell. Mandūka Muni questioned Yamarāja, Why was I mistreated in this way? What was the reason for arranging such a punishment to me? Yamarāja replied, My dear sage, in your childhood, you had pierced an ant with a sharp thorn. For that reason, you are now put into this difficulty. Mandūka Muni said, How could you fix such a severe punishment for an act I did out of childish innocence? It is quite unwise on your part. I curse you for being born as a low-class person for your unreasonable judgment. The curse of the sage was powerful. Therefore, Yamarāja took birth as Vidura, the son of a maidservant on this earth. Although Yamarāja was a great devotee of the Lord, he was still cursed in this way. This apparent punishment was also a reward for him. Yamarāja is always busy in his official service of punishing sinful beings in hell. When he became Vidura through Mandüka Muni's curse, he got the opportunity to participate in the pastimes of Lord Krsna in the Mahābhārata. Vidura was one of the prominent personalities in the Mahabharata. He was born by the mercy of Vyasadeva, from the maidservant of Ambikā, mother of Mahārāja Pändu. Thus, Vidura grew up as the younger brother of Pandu and Dhrtarästra, who were also born by the power of Vyasadeva. Although low-born because of the curse, Vidura was a mine of good qualities and great wisdom. He was also an ardent devotee of Lord Krsna. Vidura was considered a part of the Kuru dynasty and was lovingly treated by Bhismadeva, the grandsire of the dynasty. Dhrtarästra gave him sufficient property. Vidura was attached to Dhrtarastra. He acted as a reliable advisor to Dhrtarästra and always tried to guide him on the right path. Vidura was fortunate to hear Srimad Bhagavatam from a sage named Maitreya Muni. Vidura himself became a great teacher of moral and spiritual knowledge. He had later inspired Dhṛtarāstra to take up to the spiritual path. After spending about a hundred years on the earth as Vidura, Yamarāja went back to his abode and resumed his duties. As long as Yamraja on the earth as Vidura, a devta named Aryama occupied his post to punish those who committed sinful acts. Aryama was one of the sons of sage Kasyapa and his chaste wife, Aditi. Aditi and Kashyapa had twelve sons who were known as Adityas, and Aryama was one of them. Therefore, he was capable of taking charge of the office of Yamraja during his one hundred years of absence in the form of Vidura.
quotes: For great devotees, even curses are blessings by which they get special spiritual privileges.
activity: Even our Innocent actions sometimes have serious reactions-mention two examples.
lesson: A LESSON ON VISION: Curses are painful, and blessings are palatable. But curses also can act as blessings. Sometimes, the Lord showers His blessings upon His devotees through curses too. If only one can develop the vision of seeing the hand of God in various situations in life, every moment helps us connect with God.

title: Turning Crisis Into Opportunities
story: Dhrtarastra, the blind king of Hastinapura, had one hundred sons. The eldest of them was evil Duryodhana. Duryodhana had great greed for the throne of Hastināpura. In various ways, he tried to kill the noble Pandavas, the five sons of Dhrtarästra's brother Pändu. Dhrtarăştra supported the unfair desires of his sons and never stopped them. Duryodhana had once set fire to the lacquer house where the Pandavas stayed to burn them alive. Duryodhana ordered his younger brother Duhśāsana to disrobe Draupadi, the chaste wife of the Pandavas publicly. Duryodhana had cheated the Pandavas in a gambling match, took away his kingdom, and sent them to the forest. Proud Duryodhana didn't even respect the good advice of Lord Krsna, who came with a peace message. He boldly refused to give the rightful share of the kingdom to the Pandavas. These are some atrocities done by Duryodhana and his wicked associates, supported by Dhṛtarāştra. One day, Dhrtarăştra's brother Vidura met him. Vidura was acting as a loyal minister of Hastinapura and was advising the king in various ways. Now he spoke to Dhṛtarāstra, Please return the rightful share of the kingdom to the Pandavas. They have tolerated so many of your offenses. Otherwise, revengeful Bhima, who is breathing like a snake, will attack your sons. And Lord Krsna is personally on their side, and all the kings and the Yadus are with Krsna. Dhrtarästra thought that his son Duryodhana would be able to oppose the Pandavas and Krsna. Guessing such an argument from him, Vidura said, Get rid of your wicked son Duryodhana for the benefit of the family. He is offense personified. He is envious of God and causes inauspiciousness. Duryodhana then arrived there and heard Vidura's advice to Dhrtarästra. He became furious. Swollen with anger and his lips trembling, he insulted virtuous Vidura: Who called this son of a maidservant here? Although subsisting on our mercy, he is always siding with the enemy's interests. Get out from this palace immediately, with only your breath as the only possession. Duryodhana's sharp words struck Vidura. Although Vidura was elderly and a respectable uncle of Duryodhana, and a responsible minister of Hastinapura, still proud Duryodhana dared to disrespect him. Vidura's brother Dhritarästra didn't stop Duryodhana from his arrogant misbehavior. He was a victim of his fatherly affection for his evil son Duryodhana. As a father and a king, he was supposed to guide Duryodhana on a good path and correct him when he made mistakes But Dhritarastra didn't do that. He just supported several of his son's misdeeds. He is an example of a bad father. Vidura then placed his bow at the door and left the palace of Hastinapura. He didn't feel sorry but saw the hand of God in this situation. The same incident had two different types of impact on Duryodhana and Vidura according to their moods. By insulting Vidura. Duryodhana was heading towards his ruination. He was at a loss by banishing a wise person who could guide him on the right path. But Vidura headed towards an enlivening spiritual journey. He went away from all the political issues at Hastinäpura to immerse himself in wonderful pilgrimage. That's how he converted this crisis as an opportunity to elevate himself spiritually. Vidura was pure and pious, yet he thought that he had become impure by the association of the diplomatic Dhrtarăştra and Duryodhana. Therefore, he felt that he was not fit to associate with Lord Krsna at once. Thus, although Krsna was present in the world at that time, Vidura did not approach Him. Instead, he decided to travel to holy places and purify himself. Vidura traveled alone, thinking of Lord Krsna with pure devotion. He saw many holy places where many deities were situated. As he was on his pilgrimage, the Kuruksetra war had happened. In that war, Duryodhana was defeated by the Pandavas, and king Yudhisthira gained control over the earth. When Vidura reached a place known as Prabhāsa-kşetra, he came to know that many of his relatives had died in the battle. He silently proceeded on his pilgrimage.
quotes: Selfishness makes one shameless in seeking one's enjoyment at the cost of others' suffering. One should not be selfish and greedy., Proud, stubborn, and self-centered people do not accept even well-intended advice. Thus, they bring ruination upon themselves., Undue and sentimental affection for one's people can make one lose discrimination at times.
activity: Analyze the character and behavior of Duryodhana and Vidura in this incident, and list two lessons that you have learned from their activities.
lesson: A LESSON ON POSITIVITY: Situations are often not in our hands, but our response is. Insults, failures, and difficulties are common in this world. But if we have a positive outlook, we can convert such a crisis into opportunities to enrich ourselves. Although ungrateful Duryodhana banished Vidura, Vidura was not discouraged for being insulted. He positively saw it as an opportunity to go for pilgrimage and seek God's shelter.

title: When Two Great Men Meet..
story: Being insulted by proud Duryodhana, noble Vidura left Hastinapus and went on a pilgrimage. He visited eleven holy places on the bank River Sarasvati. He also visited many temples established by grea devotees. He took darśana of several deities of Lord Visnu. Passing through various provinces, Vidura finally reached the bank of River Yamuna and met Uddhava there. Uddhava was a cousin and great devotee of Lord Śrī Krsna. He was also a disciple of Brhaspati, the guru of the devatās. Uddhava was an intimate associate of Krsna and used to stay in Dvārakā, the city of Lord Krsna. Vidura affectionately embraced Uddhava, and asked him, Are the Lords Krsna and Balarama doing well in Dväraka? How are Krsna's parents Devaki and Vasudeva? How are Krsna's sons Pradyumna Samba, and others? How is Ugrasena, the grandfather and king? How are Krsna's associates Akrūra, Aniruddha, Hrdika, Carudesna, Gada and others? How are the Pandavas and their mother, Kunti? I simply pity Dhṛtarāstra who drove me out, although I am his sincere well wisher. But I am happy traveling now. When Vidura inquired about his beloved Lord Krsna and His devotees Uddhava became emotional. He couldn't reply immediately. He was a great devotee of Krsna since childhood. When he was a child, he was 50 absorbed in worshipping Krsna's deity that he did not wish to have breakfast even when his mother called him to eat. Although Uddhava has become old now, his love for Krsna did not slacken. On the contrary he was overwhelmed by the remembrance of Krsna hearing Vidura's questions and remained silent for some time. Vidura could understand that Uddhava went into a trance. Uddhava came back to external consciousness after a muhūrta (48 minutes) and then spoke to Vidura, Lord Krsna appeared in this world to cause welfare for all of us. But now He has ended His pastimes and disappeared from this planet. So what can I speak about our welfare? Vidura didn't know about Krsna's disappearance and was astonished to hear it. Uddhava reminded Vidura, You have directly witnessed the great auspiciousness of Lord Krsna. All the devatās assembled at the Rājasūya-yajña concluded that Krsna is the most beautiful personality. The gopis of Vịndāvana would always be absorbed in seeing and remembering Krsna's beauty. Although Krsna is unborn, He mercifully appears on this earth when Demoniac people harass his devotees. By killing demons, Krsna mercifully gives them liberation. He liberated even the envious Śiśupāla who always blasphemed Him. He gave the position of motherly nurse to the witch Pūtana, who came to kill Him with her poisonous milk. Even the soldiers who died in the battlefield of Kuruksetra while seeing Krsna attained His abode. This was because they could see the beautiful form of Krsna while dying, and the arrows also purified them of Arjuna, a great devotee. How shall I take shelter of anyone more merciful than Krsna? No one is equal or superior to Krsna. He is worshipped and honored by the great kings and devatās, who touch their crowns to His feet. Having thus described the glories of Krsna, Uddhava then briefly narrated the pastimes of Krsna right form His birth. He said, Krsna was born to Vasudeva and Devaki at the request of Brahma, for the welfare of the earth. Out of fear of Kamsa, Vasudeva brought Krsna from Mathura to Vrndāvana. Krsna stayed at Vrndāvana with Balarama for about eleven years, under the care of Mother Yasoda and King Nanda. In Vrndāvana, Krsna performed pastimes with the cows and the gopas, in the beautiful forests and on the banks of River Yamuna. Kamsa had sent several demons like Pütana, Trnāvarta, Bakäsura and so on to kill Krsna. But Krsna effortlessly killed them all just as a child breaks toys while playing. While herding the cows and bulls, Krsna played on His wonderful flute and enlivened everyone. Krsna drove away from the envious serpent Kaliya from Vrndāvana. He also inaugurated Govardhan-puja, lifted the Govardhan Hill, and protected His people from the devastating rainfall sent by Indra. Krsna also lovingly danced with the gopis (rāsa-lila) in the moonlit autumn night. After describing Krsna's Vrindavan pastimes, Uddhava then narrated pastimes in Mathura and Dvaraka: One day, a minister of Kamsa named Akrüra came to Vrindavan, and took Krsna and Balarama to Mathura. At Mathura, Krsna killed Kansa and saved His parents Devaki and Vasudeva, and many others who were troubled by cruel Kamsa Krsna then went to the school of Sandipani Muni and learned all the Vedas and fine arts. He also brought the dead son of Sandipani Muni from Yamaloka Lord Krsna later kidnapped Rukmini-devī at her request and married her. He also married seven other women namely Jämbavati, Satyabhāmā, Nāgnajiti, Mitravindā, Kälindī, Satyā and Laksmaņa. He also killed the demon Narakāsura and married the 16,100 princesses that Narakāsura had kidnapped. The Lord expanded Himself into 16,108 and received service from His 16,108 queens. He begot in each of these queens ten sons exactly like Himself. To please His dear wife Satyabhāmā, Krsna brought the pārijāta tree from heaven. He also enabled His devotees to kill demoniac people like Kālayavana, Jarāsandha, Śambara, Dvivida, and others. He had arranged the Battle of Kuruksetra and caused the death of many other miscreants in the war. He then established Yudhisthira as the emperor of the earth. After that, Krsna departed from this planet and went back to His eternal abode in the spiritual world. Before leaving, He gave Me profound spiritual teachings and told me to go to Badarikāśrama and give His message to the sages there. Now I am on my way to Badarikäśrama. Vidura then requested Uddhava, My dear Uddhava, you are a pure devotee. Lord Krsna has personally taught you. I wish to accept you as my guru. Please give me the spiritual knowledge that Krsna had given you.Humble Uddhava was not ready to accept the elderly Vidura as his disciple. Vidura was of the age of his father to Uddhava. Therefore, Uddhava said, My dear Vidura, When Lord Krsna was giving me spiritual teachings, a great personality named Maitreya also heard them along with me. So you may please take lessons from the learned sage Maitreya. Uddhava spent the night, which passed like a moment, on the bank of the Yamuna and then departed in the morning. Finally, Vidura reached the bank of the Ganges and met sage Maitreya, a friend of Vyāsadeva. Vidura then humbly requested Maitreya to speak about the pastimes of the Lord. And Maitreya very eagerly and respectfully taught Vidura several enlivening spiritual topics. Sage Maitreya spoke several spiritual subjects to noble Vidura. Maitreya first described how the universe was created. He then narrated the birth and activities of Lord Brahmä, the pastimes of Lord Varahadeva (Boar incarnation) and Lord Kapila, the characteristics of Vaikuntha and the family life of Devahüti and Kardama Muni. He also the narrated the stories of popular kings like Sväyambhuva Manu, Daksa, Dhruva, Prthu, Anga, Vena, Präcinabarhi and the Pracetas. After receiving profound teachings from sage Maitreya, Vidura profusely thanked Maitreya and offered his humble respects. He then proceeded to Hastinapura.
quotes: Devotees are always eager to know about God from other devotees., A devotee can understand the greatness of another devotee., Even in separation from Krishna a devotee feels His presence through His remembrance., A humble person wants to learn even from a younger person., A humble person, although qualified, doesn't become eager to instruct a senior., A sincere student is always grateful to one's glorious teacher.
activity: Share an incident where you learned something good seeing or hearing from a person younger than you.
lesson: A LESSON ON LEARNING: Only a humble person can learn. One must be willing to learn from even a younger person if they are qualified. Vidura was elder to Uddhava, but knowing Uddhava's superior knowledge and devotion, Vidura was eager to learn from Uddhava. However, Uddhava was not eager to teach his senior Vidura but humbly directed him to sage Maitreya. This is the culture of receiving and sharing knowledge., A LESSON ON ABSORPTION: When one deeply loves a person, one naturally remembers and speaks about them enthusiastically. The devotees naturally absorb themselves in discussions about Krsna's pastimes and qualities because they love Him more than their lives. Seeking inspiration from such wonderful devotees, we could also try to discuss about God when we meet our friends. Such absorption brings one closer to the heart of Krsna. Thus, individually and collectively, we become Krsna conscious.
