title: Giving Vision To A Blind Man
story: After Vidura heard several spiritual topics from Sage Maitreya, he decided to visit Hastināpura. His intention was not to stay comfortably at Hastinapura but to enlighten his brother Dhṛtarāştra. Dhrṛtarāstra was not only physically blind but was also spiritually blind. He had led a life of attachment and selfishness so far. He was greedy for the kingdom and desired to have his evil son Duryodhana sit on the Hastināpura throne. In the Kuruksetra war, Dhṛtarāstra had lost all his sons. Yet he continued to stay in Hastināpura amidst royal comforts, being respectfully maintained by the virtuous king Yudhisthira. Vidura wanted to inspire Dhṛtarāstra to take up to spiritual life. With this sole purpose in mind, he went to Hastinapura. At Hastināpura, King Yudhisthira, his mother Kunti, and all others became very happy to see Vidura after a long time. They all hurried to receive him. They greeted Vidura, embraced him, and cried out of affection. King Yudhisthira offered him a sumptuous meal. Vidura took some rest and then sat comfortably to exchange talks with the relatives. Mahārāja Yudhisthira then spoke to Vidura, My dear uncle, you always have been very kind and affectionate upon us. You protected us from many calamities like a bird protects her children with her wings. During your travels, how did you maintain yourself? What all holy places did you visit in your pilgrimage? Devotees like you are as good as holy places personified. You purify the holy places because you carry the Supreme Lord within your heart. Yudhisthira continued, You might have seen or heard of our relatives at Dvārakā. They are always rapt in the service of Lord Śrī Krsna. Are they living happily? Vidura answered all the questions of Yudhisthira, except one. He didn't speak about the disappearance of Lord Krsna and His Yadu dynasty because he knew that it would pain the hearts of Pandavas who loved Krsna more than their life. Vidura, respectfully treated, stayed at Hastinapura for some time. One day Vidura spoke to Dhṛtarāstra sarcastically addressing him O King! Dhṛtarāstra wasn't the king at that time! Vidura spoke strongly, Get out of here immediately. Are you not ashamed of living here? You tried to kill the Pandavas by fire and poison, and even insulted their chaste wife, Draupadi. You have stolen their wealth. But now, you are being maintained by them! There is no need to live on the charity of those whom you offended in many ways. You are living like a household dog, taking food from Bhīma. Don't you realize that death is approaching you soon? You have already become old. You were blind from birth, and now you are deaf, with shortened memory, and loose teeth. Your digestion is weak, and you are coughing up mucus. Still, you are so attached to the royal life and comforts! By the power of time, everyone is forced to give up everything, including wealth, honor, children, land, home, and even one's life. Your father, brother, well-wishers, and sons are all dead. Why are you still so attached to this degraded life? Please quit and take an interest in spiritual life. An intelligent person takes shelter of God. Being thus enlightened by Vidura, Dhṛtarāstra became inspired to take up spiritual life. He decided to retire from family life and give up the kingdom and royal comforts. He left home to set for the Himalayas to pursue the path of liberation. His chaste wife, Gandhārī, followed him at her own risk. Vidura's purpose of visiting Hastināpura has now been fulfilled. So, he also departed from Hastināpura. As Yudhistira was anxious, Narada Muni arrived there. The Pandavas respectfully welcomed him, and Yudhistira asked him, I do not know where my two uncles and ascetic aunt have gone. Can you please guide us? Narada Muni then appeased Yudhisthira, My dear Yudhiştira, please do not lament. Just as a child sets up his toys and disperses them by his own sweet will, God brings people together and separates them by His supreme will. Yudhistira was concerned: How will Dhṛtarāstra maintain himself? What about the danger of animals? Nārada Muni said, You are now thinking of how your relatives will exist without you. But please understand that God is the supreme protector of everyone. The Lord provides for everyone's maintenance. Narada then revealed the future movements of Dhṛtarāstra, Gāndhārī and Vidura. He said, Your uncles and aunt have gone to the Himalayas, to Saptasrota, the place where the Ganges was divided into seven for the satisfaction of the seven great sages (sapta-ysis). There, Dhṛtarāstra is now engaged in yoga by controlling his mind and senses. He gave up all his thoughts about family and became absorbed in Lord Hari. Five days later, he will give up his body by the fire generated from his mystic power. He will thus attain liberation. Gāndhārī will also enter in that fire and will leave this world along with her husband. Vidura will go for pilgrimage. So please do not worry about them. Please focus on your responsibilities. Saying this, Narada Muni departed. Thus, by the able guidance of Vidura, Dhṛtarāstra was transformed and took an interest in spiritual life. And by the good counsel of Nārada Muni, king Yudhistira gave up his lamentation and focused on his important duties.
quotes: Many people bathe in holy places and dump their sins there. When pure devotees visit those holy places, the holy places become purified of those sins., Difficulties and distress come on their own. A kind person shouldn't unnecessarily propagate unpalatable and unbearable events that cause others grief., It's a great fortune to have a genuine well-wisher who advises us when we are in ignorance.
activity: Will you share bad news with your friend if you know that It pains them? If so, under what circumstances will you do that?
lesson: A LESSON ON FRIENDSHIP: Many of us want to keep the company of people who say and do what we like. We may consider such people our friends. But what we like need not always be beneficial to us. So, a real friend advises us for ou good, although the advice may not be so palatable. Vidura acted like a good friend for Dırtarastra. Formerly, Dhṛtarāştra didn't hear Vidura's advice, mainly due to his undue affection for his evil son Duryodhana. Even when Duryodhana insulted and banished Vidura, Dhrtarastra didn't stop him. Sti Vidura continued to act as a well-wisher Dhytarastra and enlightened him in spiritual lif Finally, Dhrtarästra took benefit of the advice Vidura, his true friend.

title: Creating the 'Creator'
story: Did you ever wonder how this whole universe came into existence? The story behind the creation of the universe is very interesting. Lord Maha Visnu, lies on a gigantic ocean called the Karana Samudra or the causal ocean. Therefore, He is also called as Kāranodakaśāyī Visnu. When He exhaled from His bodily pores, millions of material universes emanated. He then expanded Himself and entered into each of those universes in the form of Garbhodakaśāyī Visnu. After entering a universe, Lord Garbhodakaśāyī Vişnu found it empty and filled half of the universe with His perspiration. That perspiration formed a great ocean called the Garbhodaka ocean. Garbhodakaśāyī Visnu lied down on the Garbhodaka ocean, on Śeşa-nāga, His divine snake bed. A lotus sprouted from the navel of Garbhodakaśāyī Vişnu and illuminated everything within the universe. Within that gigantic lotus, Lord Brahmā took birth. He was the first created living being in the universe, and he had four heads. Not seeing anyone around and finding himself within the lotus, Brahma curiously tried to search for the root of the lotus. He entered its stem but couldn't trace out its root. Giving up his unsuccessful search, Brahmā came back to the top of the lotus. Inspired by Lord Visnu from within his heart, Brahmā meditated on the Lord for one hundred years. Brahma could then see the gigantic body of Sesa. Upon the Sesa bed, he saw the effulgent Lord Garbhodakaśāyī Visnu lying alone. He looked splendorous with His shining body, ornaments, moonlike toenails, yellow cloth, a mark called Śrīvatsa on His chest, and so on. He had an enchanting smile on His charming face. That smile vanquished all distress. Seeing Garbhodakaśāyī Vişnu, Brahmā became very happy. Brahma's service was to populate the universe with various types of living beings (souls). The souls are eternal, and they are never created. They all are children of God. What Brahmā had to create were only the different species of life. The souls enter the bodies of different species according to their past activities. For example, someone accustomed to eating flesh enters the body of a carnivorous animal like a tiger or a lion in the next life. Because it was the beginning of the creation, Brahmā, the first living entity, has to create all these species. By Lord Vişnu's grace, Brahmā could understand that his service was to populate the universe with different living species. Brahmā wanted the necessary strength and empowerment from Lord Visnu to carry out his service. Therefore, Brahmā began to offer heartfelt prayers unto Lord Garbhodakaśāyī Vişnu. Brahmā prayed, O Lord, You reside within the hearts of Your devotees who love and serve You. You reciprocate with their service in their favorite forms. Please empower me with the necessary intelligence to create. Please protect me from the false pride of being the creator. May I not get deviated from the Vedic teachings. You are very merciful. Please bless Me by opening Your lotus eyes. Lord Visnu replied to Brahmā, Do not be anxious. I shall favor you. By meditating on Me, you will know everything about creating various aspects in this universe. I will quickly fulfill all the desires of those who pray like you. You may now start creating various bodily forms of the living beings. Having said this, Lord Visnu had disappeared. As advised by Lord Visnu, Brahmā meditated for 100 years and thus acquired spiritual knowledge. He then entered into the whorl of the lotus. He divided the lotus into fourteen divisions. He thus created the fourteen worlds (planetary systems) suitable for the stay of different types of living beings. Thereafter, Lord Brahma created four children, popularly called the four Kumāras. He asked them to create progeny. But the Kumāras wanted to devote themselves to the Supreme Lord Vasudeva. They did not show interest in marriage, household life, and getting children. Instead, they wanted to remain as celibates (brahmacārīs) forever. They even wanted to stay as five-year-old children forever. So, they refused Brahma's request. When Kumāras rejected Brahmā's order, Brahmā became slightly angry, but he tried to control it. Yet his anger came out from between his eyebrows in the form of another child in blue and red complexion. The child cried anxiously. So, Lord Brahmā named the child 'Rudra' and designated eleven places for his stay and also offered him eleven wives called Rudrānīs and asked him to create progeny. Lord Rudra then created progeny similar to himself in strength, form, and furious nature. They attempted to devour the universe instead of expanding it-this scared Brahmā. Brahmā then asked Rudra to stop such creation and perform austerity instead. Rudra agreed and went to the forest. Lord Brahma then created ten sons from different parts of his body. They include Vasistha, Daksa, Bhrgu, Kratu, Pulastya, Angirā, Atri, Marici, Pulaha and Kardama. All of them were engaged in creating progeny and populating the universe. Brahma's another glorious son was Nārada Muni, who remained a brahmacārī. His main work is to inspire people in spiritual life and take to bhakti or loving devotion to God. After that, Brahma created the four Vedas, the four legs of dharma, various fine arts, sciences, and Vedic meters. In this way, by the mercy of Lord Visnu, Lord Brahmā created various sciences and prominent personalities in the universe.
quotes: If we are eager to serve the Lord, He will give us the necessary strength to serve.
activity: What is the role of empowerment & blessings of parents and teachers in your lives? Share your understanding in three points.
lesson: A LESSON ON EMPOWERMENT: We get the ability and intelligence to do things by God's grace. Without His sanction and empowerment, we cannot accomplish anything. So, we shouldn't be proud of our activities but be humble in our service to God. We should utilize our God-given skills in the service of God and godly people. One who is always eager to serve the Lord with determination receives all blessings and empowerment from Him.

title: The Beautiful Boar
story: Once, Lord Brahmā reflected that his ten powerful sons, including the sages, did not sufficiently increase the universe's population. While he was thinking like this, a man and a woman appeared from his body. They were Svayambhuva Manu and his queen Śatarūpā. Svāyambhuva Manu respectfully addressed Lord Brahmā, My dear father, you are the father of all living entities and the source of their sustenance. Please instruct me how I may serve you. As a son, I have to abide by your instructions. Therefore, I shall act to the best of my capacity to fulfill your orders. Seeing the obedience of Manu, Brahmā felt encouraged. He appreciated Manu as an ideal son as he said, All blessings unto you both. I am pleased with you because of your genuine submissiveness unto me with no reservation. A sane person adores and accepts the instructions of a superior with great delight and executes it to his full capacity. Praising Manu in this way, Brahmā gave him three instructions, (i) Beget children similar to you in quality, (ii) Rule the earth virtuously, and (iii) Worship Lord Visnu through sacrifices. By doing so, you will do the highest service unto me, and Lord Visnu will be pleased with you. Manu respectfully replied, My dear father, I shall abide by your order But I see that the earth, residence for all living beings, is now merged in the Garbhodaka Ocean. Please retrieve it. Brahmā was surprised and thought, While I am creating, the planet earth has been inundated. How to raise the earth? Let the Almighty Lord direct us. As Brahmā was thus thinking, a small form of Boar came out from his nostril in the size of a thumb. Within a moment, it grew gigantic in the sky like a great elephant. Brahmā and his sons wondered, seeing the Boar and thought, Is this gigantic Boar the Supreme Lord Himself? The Boar was Varāhadeva, the Supreme Lord who appeared in this form to support Brahmā and Svāyabhuva Manu in their service. To enliven Brahmā and his sons, Lord Varāha roared tumultuously, which echoed in all directions. Hearing the all-auspicious sound of the all-merciful Lord, the denizens of the upper planets chanted mantras from the Vedas. Then, hearing their praise of His qualities through the Vedic hymns, Lord Varāha entered the Garbhodaka ocean playing like an elephant. The Lord's resounding roar is an open threat to all demons, but to His devotees, it is a reassuring boon. Lord Varāha then flew in the sky, with His tail slashing and His hard hairs quivering. His glance was luminous like the sun and the moon. He scattered the clouds with His hooves and white tusks. He imitated the actions of a Boar and searched after the earth by smell. He then entered the water and dived deep into the Garbhodaka ocean. Cleaving the water with His sharp hooves, Lord Varāha found the planet earth and lifted it on His white tusks. He appeared splendid with the earth on His tusks. Lord Varāha was so huge that all the oceans could submerge into His bodily pores. With the earth on His tusks, He appeared like an elephant holding a lotus flower with its trunk, a huge mountain decorated with clouds. The earth is considered Varaha's wife. Thus, Varaha and the earth appeared like father and mother together. The residents of the upper planets, namely Jana loka, Tapo loka, and Satya loka, were purified by the auspicious drops of water that sprinkled from the shaking of Lord Varaha's body. The Lord then placed the earth on the water and departed for His own abode. Brahma was thus relieved from His anxiety. Svāyabhuva Manu made the earth His residence and began his service of creating population in the world.
quotes: The Lord engages His devotees in service and also supports them when they need help.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? MANUS & MANVANTARAS: Manu is the father of mankind. The word 'man' or 'manusya' is derived from 'Manu.' He is the first human being from whom all the other human beings appeared. He is the ideal human being who has given guidelines to humanity in his book called Manu Samhita. Lord Brahmä's one day lasts for 1000 divya-yugas. One divya-yuga is a combination of the four yugas, namely Satya, Treta, Dvāpara, and Kali. Its duration is 4,320,000 years. Thus, fourteen Manus rule the earth in one day of Brahmā. The reign of a Manu is called Manvantara, which lasts 71 divya-yugas. The first Manvantara in the current day of Brahmā is called Svāyambhuva Manvatara, which is reigned by Svāyambhuva, the first ManuDID YOU KNOW? TWO VARAHA AVATARAS: 1. Ādi Varāha or Śveta Varāha, the divine white Boar who appeared from Lord Brahmā's nostril in the Svāyambhuva (first) Manvantara. 2. Rakta Varāha or Nīla Varaha, the transcendental red Boar who appeared in the Caksusa (sixth) Manvantara, and killed a demon named Hiranyākṣa.
activity: All of us have some goals to attain. In this connection, what. can we leam from Lord Brahmä's attitude and activities?
lesson: A LESSON ON COMMITMENT: The greater our goal is, the more are the impediments that come on our way. However, when we are committed to our purpose, the Lord helps us overcome all obstacles in achieving our goals. The support we get from God in various situations of life is our hope. Lord Brahma was so committed to his service of creation, and the Lord appeared as a Boar to help him. Seeking inspiration from Brahma, let us be committed to our services and goals.

title: The Devotees Who Became 'Demons'
story: Sanaka, Sanatana, Sanandana and Sanat-kumāra were the first four sons of Lord Brahmā. Together they are called the four Kumāras. They travel throughout the material and spiritual skies. Although they were the first created personalities in the universe by Lord Brahmā, they always look like five-year-old children and wander naked. Once the Kumāras desired to go to Vaikuntha, the eternal abode of Lord Visnu. In Vaikuntha, all the residents render service to Lord Visnu with great love and devotion. They all look similar to Lord Visnu. The forests in Vaikuntha are filled with beautiful desire trees that bear flowers and fruits of all seasons. The men and women in Vaikuntha fly in golden airplanes adorned with precious gems like emeralds. They constantly praise Lord Hari without any distractions. In Vaikuntha, all women are as beautiful as Lakṣmī, the eternal consort of Lord Visnu. These ladies are sometimes seen sweeping the already clean marble walls in Vaikuntha to receive the Lord's grace. They worship the Lord in their own gardens with Tulasi leaves. In Vaikuntha, there are beautiful birds like the cuckoo, parrot, swan, peacock and others. Although they have sweet singing voices, they all stop their own singing to encourage the bee that makes a humming sound praising Lord Hari. Even the Vaikuntha plants are non-envious. Although amazingly fragrant, flowers like lotus, lily, rose, etc., greatly respect Tulasī and encourage her to serve Lord Visnu. They all know that Lord Hari likes Tulasi. The four Kumāras reached Vaikuntha and attained great joy. They crossed six gates and reached the seventh gate, where they saw two doorkeepers named Jaya and Vijaya. They both looked similar in their age and form and were well decorated like Lord Visnu. But they appeared somewhat agitated seeing the four Kumāras. The Kumāras entered the seventh door without asking the doorkeepers, just as they had passed the previous doors. Seeing them, Jaya and Vijaya blocked their way. The Kumāras' desired to see Lord Visnu, but now they were stopped by Jaya and Vijaya. Their eyes turned red with anger, and they spoke to the doorkeepers, Why are you stopping us? Why do you suspect us? Where is the possibility of an enemy entering Vaikuntha? You both are in the highest position of service to Lord Visnu, but you have developed such a harsh mentality! You must be imposters. We curse you for leaving Vaikuntha and going to the material world. That is the right punishment for your mentality. Understanding that the terrible curse of the brahmanas cannot be counteracted, Jaya and Vijaya became fearful. They fell at the feet of the Kumāras and spoke, We have been disrespectful to you sages. We accept your punishment. But we pray that we don't forget the Lord even if we go to the material world. Please be compassionate on us. Seeing the genuine repentance of the doorkeepers, the Kumāras also repented for cursing them. Jaya and Vijaya were the dear devotees of Lord Visnu. The Kumāras' act of angrily cursing them was an offense. However, inner humility was aroused in the hearts of both the Kumāras and the doorkeepers. Both parties repented for offending each other. Understanding this situation at the door of Vaikuntha, Lord Vişnu arrived there along with Laksmī. He wanted to stop further aggravation between the Kumāras and His doorkeepers. He also wanted to fulfill the desire of the Kumāras to see Him. The Kumāras were afraid that the Lord might be angry with them for cursing His devotees. Jaya and Vijaya were lamenting that they would have to be separated from the Lord due to the brāhmanas' curse. The Lord pacified both the parties by His pleasing face and affectionate glance. The Kumāras saw Lord Visnu for the first time directly. He was blackish in complexion. He wore a yellow cloth, a fresh garland surrounded by bees, a charming necklace, and a Kaustubha jewel. He rested one hand on the shoulder of Garuda, and with the other, He twirled a lotus. The beauty of His cheeks enhanced the beauty of his fish-shaped earrings. His nose was prominent, and He wore a gem-studded crown on His head. The Lord's face was auspicious and pleasing, showering blessings upon everyone. His glance touched their hearts. When the breeze carrying the aroma of Tulasi leaves from the Lord's lotus feet entered the nostrils of Kumāras, they became pure devotees, They became greatly attracted to Visnu's form and saw His face, smile, and lotus feet again and again. Overwhelmed, they offered prayers to the Lord. O Lord, Your transcendental form can be seen only by Your mercy. Wherever we may be, let our minds be engaged in Your service, may our words always speak about You, and our ears hear about You. Understanding the fear of the Kumāras, Lord Visnu spoke to pacify them, I love brahmaņas and cows. I am displeased with those who disrespect them. My doorkeepers have offended you. Their offense is factually My offense. So I seek forgiveness from you. I approve of the punishment you have given them. But please let them come back to Vaikuntha soon. Being a responsible master, the Lord apologized to the Kumāras for the offense of His doorkeepers. But factually, He was not happy with the Kumāras' act of cursing His dear servants. The Kumāras were astonished and said, O Lord, You respect the brāhmaņas just to set an example for others. You are most worshipable to the devatās and the brāhmanas. You are the Lord of the three worlds and the maintainer of the universe. Your submissive behavior does not reduce your potency; and rather, it is Your divine pastime. We have cursed two faultless persons. We accept whatever punishment or reward You ordain on these innocent persons or also upon us. Lord Visnu replied, I sanction the punishment you have given them. But, unfortunately, because of your curse, they will become demons. But they will be absorbed in meditation on Me in anger and will shortly return to Me. The Kumaras circumambulated Lord Visnu and departed with His permission. They did not enter Vaikuntha but saw the Lord only at the gate. Although sometimes. brahmaņas and yogis go to Vaikuntha, they were not meant to stay there; they come back. The Lord then spoke to Jaya and Vijaya, Go to the material world but do not fear. Though I can nullify the curse, I shall not do so. Laksmi-devi foretold your departure. Once you stopped her from entering the gate, when I was sleeping, and she became angry. Although you will be in the material world as demons, you will always meditate on Me in anger and come back to Me shortly. DID YOU KNOW? GOD'S FIGHTING DESIRE The Lord is the source of everything. Anger and fighting spirit also exist in Him. But in Vaikuntha, the Lord has no enemies to fight with because everyone serves Him there with love. So, the Lord sometimes sends His devotees (like Jaya and Vijaya) to the material world and makes them temporarily act as His enemies. Only the devotees can satisfy the Lord in every respect, including giving Him the pleasure of fighting. So, the Lord comes as an incarnation, fights with them, and fulfills His desires. While doing this, He also gives several lessons to all of us. I shall experience the happiness fighting with you (vira-rasa) when I descend as three different avataras. Due to the curse of the Kumaras, Jaya and Vijaya appeared as demons in three lives as Hiranyakşa and Hiranyakaśipu, as Rāvana and Kumbhakarna, and as Sisupāla and Dantavakra. The Lord fought with them and killed them in the form of Varāha, Narasimha, Roma, and Krsna.
quotes: Everything in the Vaikuntha is spiritual and personal. So there is no envy there.,  There is no envy or unhealthy competitive spirit in Vaikuntha. On the contrary, the residents of Vaikuntha encourage and appreciate each other in their service to Lord Vishnu. Therefore, one who wishes to go to Vaikuntha should develop such qualities of non-envy.,  The mistake of a follower leads people to blame the leader. So, one must act carefully not to cause a bad reputation to the leaders. The Lord loves His devotees even if they commit mistakes, just as a father loves the child even if the child is naughty and mischievous., Nothing can happen without God's sanction.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? GOD'S FIGHTING DESIRE: The lord is the source of everything. Anger and fighting spirit also exist in Him. But in Vaikuntha, the Lord has no enemies to fight with because everyone serves Him there with love. So, the Lord sometimes sends His devotees (like Jaya and Vijaya) to the material world and makes them temporarily act as His enemies. Only the devotees can satisfy the Lord in every respect, including giving Him the pleasure of fighting. So, the Lord comes as an incarnation, fights with them, and fulfills His desires. While doing this, He also gives several lessons to all of us.
activity: Share your understanding of the responsibilities of a good leader and a good follower.
lesson: A LESSON ON LEADERSHIP: A leader gives protection, encouragement, and reassurance to his followers when they need it. A leader is not one who just orders his followers and accepts their services. An ideal leader also takes responsibility for the mistakes of one's dependents. Lord Vishnu took responsibility for His doorkeepers' offense towards the Kumaras. A good follower shouldn't do anything that brings a black mark on the fame of the leader.

title: Even God Likes To Fight!
story: Diti was one of the many wives of sage Kaśyapa. Seeing that her co-wives had children, she became distressed. She desired the fortune of having sons also. Thus, with an intense desire to have children and an envious attitude towards her co-wives, she approached Kaśyapa in the evening. At that time, Kaśyapa was sitting in a trance after having offered oblations in the sacrificial fire. Diti told him, All of us thirteen sisters are equally faithful to you. So why should I alone remain without a child? Kaśyapa pacified her and replied, I will satisfy your desire. But please wait for one muhūrta because this is the inauspicious time when ghosts move about. But impatient Diti didn't listen to his advice, and Kaśyapa also gave in to her demand. Afterward, Kaśyapa told Diti, You will give birth to two ferocious demons, who will torment the whole world. Lord Visnu will personally kill them. Diti repented for her impatience at an inauspicious time. Then, seeing her regret, Kaśyapa said,Although your sons will be cruel, your grandson will be a great devotee of Lord Visnu. His name will be Prahlada. He will have all noble qualities. He will bring happiness to everyone. Hearing this, Diti was somewhat pacified. In due course of time, Diti became pregnant. However, knowing that her sons will torment the universe and will be killed by the Lord, Diti didn't wish to deliver them. So she held her pregnancy for a hundred years. As a result, great darkness spread in all directions in the universe. All the devatās in the upper planets were confused. They approached Lord Brahma and asked him, Nothing is unknown to you. You know the intentions of everyone. Please tell us what is the cause of this darkness? Lord Brahma then narrated, Once the Kumāras went to Vaikuntha, but were stopped at the gate by the doorkeepers Jaya and Vijaya. The Kumāras became angry and cursed them to go to the material world Thus, Java and Vijaya have now entered the womb of Diti as demons. It is the prowess of these twin demons that have disturbed all of you. There is no remedy for this within my power. Only Lord Visnu can do something to counteract this. Let us wait for Him to take the necessary action. He is most merciful to all His devotees. Hearing this, the devatās gave up fear and returned to their respective places. Eventually, Diti gave birth to two powerful demons. Kaśyapa gave them names Hiranyākṣa and Hiranyakaśipu. At that time, many fearful disturbances occurred on the earth and in outer space. Harsh winds blew with dust and storms and uprooted gigantic trees. Dense clouds covered all the luminaries in the sky, spreading darkness. The ocean, along with the aquatics, wailed loudly. She-jackals vomiting fire yelled inauspiciously along with the cries of jackals and owls. Dogs cried, and asses ran in herds, striking the earth with their hooves and wildly braying. Frightened by the braying of the asses, birds flew from their nests. Seeing these evil omens, everyone was afraid. The two demon brothers began to grow like mountains with bodies as strong as steel. With their gigantic forms, they seemed to kiss the sky with their crowns. Their steps shook the earth. Hiranyākṣa received a boon from Lord Brahmā and traveled all over the universe with a fighting spirit. Once, he went to heaven. Seeing his uncontrollable temper, gigantic form, huge mace, and bodily strength, all the devatās got frightened and fled away. After returning from heaven, Hiranyākṣa dove into the ocean to sport. The aquatics fled in fear. He moved into the ocean, striking the waves with his mace. He thus reached Vibhāvarī, the capital of Varuna, the god of the ocean. There Hiranyāksa fell at Varuna's feet, and to make fun of him, and he said, Give me battle, O Lord! You are a great ruler and a great warrior. Although provoked, Varuna controlled his anger and replied, We have now desisted from fighting, having grown too old. Only Lord Vişnu can satisfy your desire to fight. He appears in various incarnations to punish wicked fellows like you and to show His grace to the virtuous. Proud Hiranyāksa then went to search for Lord Visnu to fight with Him. He learned from Narada Muni the whereabouts of the Lord and quickly entered the Garbhodaka ocean. There he saw the all-powerful Lord Visnu in the form of Varaha, bearing the earth on His tusks. He was Nīla Varāha or Rakta Varāha.Hiranyāksa laughed and said, Oh, amphibious beast! This earth is entrusted to us. You cannot take it. Rascal! You have killed many demons by remaining invisible. O fool, today I shall kill You. When You die smashed by my mace, all the devatās and sages will also die, like trees without roots. Lord Varāha was pained by the shaft like abusive words of the demon. Seeing that the earth on His tusks was frightened, Lord Varāha rose out of the water and placed the earth on the surface of the water. He gave her the ability to float. The devatās rained flowers on Him. The Lord then replied to Hiranyāksa, Indeed, We are jungle creatures searching for dogs like you. I have no fear from your loose talk. Give up all your foolish talk and fight Me if you can. Being thus challenged, Hiranyaksa became angry like a cobra. He quickly sprang upon the Lord with his powerful mace. They struck each other with their huge maces. Lord Brahmā, accompanied by the sages, came to see the terrible fight. Brahmā then addressed Lord Varāha, O Lord, this demon is an offender of devatās, devotees, brāhmaņas, cows and sinless living beings. Having attained a boon from me, he wanders all over the universe, searching for a proper combatant. There is no need to play with him. Please kill him as soon as possible and establish the world in peace. Lord Varāha accepted Brahmā's prayer. Varāhadeva sprang and aimed His mace at the chin of Hiranyāksa. But the demon struck back with his mace, and the Lord's mace slipped from His hand. This was miraculous! Though Hiranyākṣa had the opportunity, he did not strike the unarmed Lord, respecting the law of single combat. Instead, the Lord acknowledged the demon's dharma and invoked His Sudarśana cakra. The people who witnessed this great fight cried, May victory attend You, O Lord! Please kill the demon. Seeing the Lord with His cakra, Hiranyāksa began to hiss like a serpent and bit his lip. Then, he sprang into the air and aimed his mace at the Lord, exclaiming, You are dead! The Lord effortlessly knocked down the mace with His left foot and said, Take up your weapon and try again. Hiranyāksa again attacked the Lord by his mace, and the Lord playfully caught hold of that mace. His valor thus frustrated, Hiranyāksa then invoked a deadly trident and threw it at the Lord. The Lord cut that trident with His cakra. Hiranyāksa struck the Lord's chest with his hard fist and disappeared created many illusions against the Lord. Fierce winds Hiranyākṣa then created blew; stones fell as if shot by machine guns. Clouds, accompanied by lightning and thunder, started raining pus, hair, blood, stool, urine, and bones. Mountains discharged various weapons. Lord Varaha then invoked cakra that destroyed all those illusions. Frustrated, Hiranyākṣa started to strike the Lord's chest with his hard fists, but the Lord then slapped him in the root of the ear. Though struck indifferently, Hiranyākṣa's eyeballs bulged out, his arms and legs broken, hair scattered, and he fell down dead like an uprooted tree. Seeing the dead body of Hiranyāksa, Brahmā and others admiringly said: Oh, who could meet such a blessed death? He was struck by a forefoot of the Lord and died while seeing the Lord's beautiful face. The devatās then praised Lord Varāha. After that, Varāhadeva, having enjoyed his fight with the demon, went back to His eternal abode.
quotes: The birth of demoniac people on the earth causes many disturbances., God is as sentient as we are. He is satisfied if someone offers a nice prayer, and similarly, He is pained if someone calls Him ill names., Though the Lord could instantly kill the demons, He fights with them just to experience the pleasure of fighting., Whenever there is an emergency or acute rise of adharma in this world, the Lord appears in a suitable form to rectify the situation.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? GOD'S BEAUTY: Boar is a wild animal, probably not known for its beauty or great work. But when God appears in the form of a boar, He looks extremely beautiful and performs the most wonderful deeds. So the Lord appears in the human society as Rāma and Krsna, in the animal society as Varāha (Boar), amongst the birds as Hamsa (Swan), amongst the aquatics as Matsya (Fish) and so on. In all forms, He is so beautiful, and His purpose is to establish dharma, eradicate adharma and protect His devotees.
activity: Make a list of at least ten Incarnations of the Supreme Lord and the prominent qualities that they exhibit.
lesson: A LESSON ON PROTECTION: The Supreme Lord appears in multiple forms according to time, place, and circumstances. He plays multiple roles in the maintenance of this universe. He protects virtuous people from various calamities and punishes demoniac people as they deserve. His devotees always desire to serve and worship Him with dedication. We should be grateful to the Lord for protecting us from all evil forces.

title: A Marriage Arranged By God
story: After Varāhadeva rescued the earth planet, Svāyambhuva Manu started residing on earth along with his queen Satarūpa. He stayed at a place called Brahmāvarta and made a city called Barhismati his capital Barhismati was named so because Lord Varaha's hair dropped there and got transformed into sacred kuśa grass. In this place, Manu spread a seat of kuśa grass and worshipped the Lord. Although he was involved in managing a vast kingdom, he never lost focus on his bhakti. He used to hear about Lord Krsna daily in the morning. He was absorbed in hearing, contemplating, writing, and chanting about the Lord's pastimes. He thus passed his long time, which lasted 71 divya-yugas. He never experienced any miseries. Asked by the sages, Manu taught the diverse duties of different sections of human society. His book is called Manu-samhita. Svāyambhuva Manu had five children three daughters namely Devahūti, Ākūti and Prasūti, and two sons namely Priyavrata and Uttānapāda. Äkūti married sage Ruci, Prasūti married Daksa, and Devahūti married Kardama Muni. Kardama Muni was one of the sons of Lord Brahmā. Brahmā ordered him to marry and get good children and populate the universe. Before entering married life, Kardama worshiped Lord Visnu near a lake called Bindu-sarovara, encircled by River Sarasvati. The shore of the lake was filled with pious trees and creepers, rich in flowers and fruits of all seasons. The surroundings resounded with the sweet singing of overjoyed birds like peacocks, cuckoos, ducks, swans, ospreys, cranes, cakoras, and bees. In such a pleasant ambiance, Kardama worshiped Lord Visnu for ten thousand years. Pleased with his devotion, Lord Visnu appeared in front of Kardama Muni. The Lord was as effulgent as the sun, garlanded with white lotuses, and dressed in yellow silk garments. Dark locks of hair surrounded his lotus face. Adorned with a dazzling crown and shining earrings, He was holding śankha, cakra, gadā, and padma in His four hands. He was endowed with Śrīvatsa mark on His chest and a Kaustubha jewel hanging from His neck. He stood on the shoulders of Garuda, His mighty eagle carrier. Kardama became joyful, and with folded hands, he offered prayers, Ο Lord, my eyes have become successful by seeing You. My father Brahmā instructed me to marry and create good progeny. Therefore, I worshipped You desiring to marry a girl of a like disposition. Brahmā also works under Your instruction. Therefore, my desire to marry is, in turn, Your desire to populate the universe. Hearing the sincere request of Kardama, Lord Visnu smiled affectionately and spoke, I know your desire and have already arranged for it. The desires of those who serve Me in devotion are never frustrated. The day after tomorrow, Svāyambhuva Manu and his queen, Śatarūpā, will come here to see you. They have a marriageable, beautiful, and qualified daughter named Devahūti. She is suitable to be your wife, and her parents will conduct your marriage. Thus, you both will have nine wonderful daughters who will get married to nine great sages. They will increase the population of the universe. Impressed with his bhakti, the Lord gave Kardama an additional boon, I shall appear as your son (Kapila). I shall instruct Devahūti in spiritual knowledge. At the end of your life, you will attain Me in My eternal abode. Having said this, the Lord departed from Bindu sarovara to Vaikuntha. The Lord, who was overwhelmed by mercy for Kardama, shed tears that mixed with the lake's water. Therefore, that holy lake was called Bindu-sarovara. Kardama stayed at Bindu-sarovara, waiting for the arrival of Svayambhuva Manu. Finally, on the day predicted by Lord Vişnu, Manu came to Kardama's hermitage, with his wife Satarūpā and daughter Devahūti. Manu saw Kardama's body shining, healthy, tall, with lotus eyes, matted hair, and tattered cloth. Kardama Muni received him respectfully and said, Dear Manu, saintly kings like you embody the protecting energy of Lord Sri Hari. As a perfect representative of the Lord, you are always busy protecting righteous people and punishing the unrighteous. So tell me, why have you come here? Whatever it may be, I shall carry it out. Svāyambhuva Manu felt embarrassed to hear Kardama's praise and said, O great sage, the Lord has created you brāhmaņas to propagate the Vedas. He has created the kṣatriyas to protect the brahmanas. The brāhmanas are said to be the Lord's heart and the ksatriyas His arms. They protect each other, and the Lord protects them through each other. By my fortune, I heard from you the duties of a king. Manu then requested Kardama, Please accept my daughter Devahūti as your wife. She is seeking a suitable husband in terms of age, character and qualities. When she heard from Narada Muni about you, she fixed her mind upon you. She will be a suitable wife for you in every way. I know that you also have a desire to marry. Kardama replied, Certainly, I desire to marry, and your daughter is a perfect match for me. She is endowed with all good qualities. Who would reject her? Her beauty excels the beauty of her ornaments. She is the very ornament of womanhood. Therefore, our marriage can take place according to the Vedic system. But I have a condition. I will stay with her only till she gives birth to children. After that, I shall dedicate my life to bhakti and worship Lord Visnu. Manu, Śatarūpā and Devahūti all became happy with this. Manu conducted the marriage of Devahūti and Kardama at that very place. Empress Śatarūpā lovingly gave the most valuable presents, such as jewelry, clothes, and household articles. Manu affectionately embraced his daughter with tears in his eyes, unable to bear separation from her. After that, Manu and Satarūpā returned to their capital Brahmāvarta.
quotes: No misery can affect a devotee who has taken full shelter of God without distractions., Sages used to meditate and worship in peaceful places away from passion., Seeing the all-auspicious form of God completely satisfies the eyes and heart., Before commencing an important activity, a devotee seeks blessings and empowerment from the Lord., The Lord always knows the pure desire of a devotee and is ready to fulfill it., Maturity of dealings lies in the ability to see the good qualities in others and appreciate them., Brahmanas and kshatriyas mutually respect and cooperate with each other., Devotees prioritize spiritual life, although they responsibly attend to social and family duties.
activity: What is good in seeing the good qualities of others and appreciating them? Discuss with your parents and share your understanding in three points.
lesson: A LESSON ON COOPERATION: Brahmanas and kings are the natural leaders of society. Brahmanas give guidance as per scriptural principles, and the administer kings the kingdom accordingly. Mutual respect and cooperation between the leaders inspire all sections of society. God has created in such a way that no one can live independently without help from others. Thus, by cooperating, we can please the Lord.

title: The Princess Who Became God's Mother
story: After her parents departed, chaste Devahūti served her husband Kardama Muni with great love, respect and intimacy. Thus, serving for a long time, she grew weak and emaciated. Seeing her condition, Kardama became kind and said, I am very pleased with you. You have served me without caring for your own body. I shall offer you all the blessings that I have attained from the Lord through my meditation and worship. Upon hearing her husband, Devahūti was very happy and satisfied. Then, feeling shy, she innocently spoke to Kardama, You have attained many blessings by your devotional service. However, I desire to have children first, since it is praiseworthy quality for a chaste woman. Desiring to please his devoted wife, Kardama Muni created with his mystic power a gigantic aerial mansion that could travel at his will. That airplane has seven stories and was bedecked with jewels. Its pillars were adorned with precious stones, doors bedecked with diamonds, and contained all necessary paraphernalia for enjoyment. There were live swans and pigeons, and artificial swans and pigeons too. The real birds thought of the artificial ones as live like them, and the palace vibrated with the sounds of these birds. Even after seeing this beautiful airplane, Devahūti was not happy because her body was still emaciated. Understanding this, Kardama told her, Please take a bath in Bindu-sarovara, created by Lord Visnu Himself, and then mount the airplane. Devahūti entered that lake with her matted hair and dirty clothes. Inside the lake was a house with thousand young girls fragrant like lotuses. They said to Devahūti with folded hands, We are your servants. The girls then bathed Devahūti with valuable oils and ointments and gave her new clothes, excellent jewels, good food, and sweet drink. In a mirror, Devahūti saw herself clean, well dressed, garlanded, and decorated with necklaces, bangles, golden anklets, and tilaka. Her face shone with beautiful teeth, charming eyes, eyebrows, and locks of hair. Thus she regained her beauty as a princess. Devahūti then remembered her husband. She was immediately transported, along with all the maidservants, to the place where he was. Devahūti was amazed to see Kardama's yogic power. Kardama then took her into the airplane. Surrounded by his wife and many girls, he looked like the moon amidst many stars. In that aerial mansion, Devahūti and Kardama visited many beautiful spots in the universe. They saw the pleasure valleys of Mount Meru and other celestial gardens like Vaiśrambhaka, Surasana, Nandana, and Puspa-bhadraka. Kardama surpassed even devatās in enjoyment. After showing to Devahūti the whole world and its variegated features and many wonders, Kardama returned to his hermitage. In due course of time, Devahūti gave birth to nine beautiful daughters namely Kala Anasūyā, śraddhā, Havirbhū, Gati, Kriyā, Khyāti, Arundhati, and Sänti. After that, Devahūti worshiped Lord Visnu under her husband's directions. Finally, after some years, the Supreme Lord appeared as her son Kapila. Celebrating His appearance, all the devatās played musical instruments and danced in joy. Celestial beings showered flowers. Lord Brahmā arrived there along with many sages. Brahmā said to Kardama, My dear son, you have honored me by following my instructions without duplicity. Your nine daughters are chaste and will increase the population of the universe in various ways. Get them married to the sages, according to their likings. Lord Kapila, with golden hair, has now appeared as your son. Brahmā said to Devahūti, O fortunate Devahūti, the Lord who appeared in your womb, will give you spiritual knowledge. He will increase your fame and travel all over the world. Brahma then departed for Satyaloka on his swan carrier along with Nārada and Kumāras. Kardama Muni got his nine daughters married to nine powerful sages. Kalā married sage Marīci, Anasūyā married Atri, Śraddhā married Angirā, Havirbhū married Pulastya, Gati married Pulaha, Kriyā married Kratu, Khyāti married Bhrgu, Arundhati married Vasistha, and Śānti married Atharvā. Kardama took care of the daughters and sons-in-law for some time, and then they departed to their homes. After that, Kardama approached his son Kapila in a secluded place, offered obeisances, and spoke, O Lord, You have mercifully appeared in my house. You appear in innumerable forms to please Your devotees. I surrender unto You. Now I wish to retire from household life and become a sannyāsī to dedicate my life to bhakti completely. Please give me Your permission. Although the Lord was in his home, still Kardama Muni wanted to leave home to meditate on the Lord. Because he always worshiped the Lord in the mood of a servant (dāsya-rasa). So it wouldn't be natural for him to see the Lord as his son (vātsalya-rasa) staying at home. Lord Kapila replied, Now, you may go as you desire. You will always see Me within your heart and will soon attain Me. I have incarnated as your son to revive spiritual knowledge which was lost. I shall describe this knowledge to My mother so that she will also attain perfection. Kardama Muni circumambulated Lord Kapila and left for the forest. He took complete shelter of the Lord in devotion. He thus became liberated by bhakti and went to the spiritual realm. Lord Kapila later taught His mother Devahūti about sānkhya-yogo (analytical knowledge of matter and spirit), astānga-yoga (meditation on the Lord), and ultimately bhakti-yoga (devotional service unto the Lord), Lord Kapila then took permission from His mother and left for a place called Ganga-sāgara. Even now, Lord Kapila is staying there in a trance for the welfare of the three worlds. Saintly Devahūti performed bhakti, as instructed by her glorious son. She was sorry that her son was separated from her. Yet meditating upon Him, she attained the Lord. The material elements of her body melted into the water of the flowing river. Anyone who bathes there also attains perfection.
quotes: By serving an exalted devotee, one can attain all blessings of God Kind devotees liberally share their good fortune with others., Nothing is impossible for devotees, who have taken shelter of Lord Hari., A devotee worships and remembers the Lord wherever he is, whether at home or in the forest.
activity: What makes your family a good and happy family?
lesson: A LESSON ON FAMILY: One has to treat one's family members with care, love, and respect. Seeing them as God's children, one should be affectionate and responsible towards them. Ideal family life is centered on God-consciousness and culminates in spiritual perfection. Whether one stays at home or in the forest or a temple, if one sincerely worships God while responsibly doing one's duties, one can get the mercy of God.

title: Three Sons Instead Of One
story: Anasüyä, one of the nine daughters of Devahūti, married sage Atri. Atri Muni had a desire to have a son exactly like the Lord of the universe, Jagadīśvara. To please Him, Atri and Anasüya went to Rksa mountain where the river Nirvindhyā flows. Atri performed severe austerities, controlled his mind and breath, and stood on one leg for a hundred years, eating nothing but air. By his tapasya, a blazing fire came out of Atri's head, burning the three worlds. Lord Vişnu is the ultimate Lord of the universe, Jagadiśvara. He perceived Atri's penance fire and directed the other two Lords Śiva and Brahmä, to come before Atri Muni along with Him. Thus, the three principal deities of the universe, Brahmā, Vişnu, and Śiva, went to Atri's hermitage, along with several devatās like Gandharvas, Siddhas, Vidyādharas and Nāgas. Atri, who was standing on one leg, saw the three deities and was astonished. Lord Śiva was sitting on a bull holding a drum. Brahmä sat on a swan with kuśa grass in his hands. Lord Visnu sat on Garuda holding His Sudarśana cakra. Finally, Atri Muni offered them respect by falling flat on the ground. He eagerly approached them but closed his eyes for a moment due to their dazzling effulgence. Gathering his senses, with folded palms, he offered prayers in sweet words, I called for one Lord, desiring a son like Him. But now I see three divine personalities. I offer respect to all of you. But please be merciful upon me and tell me whom did I call among you three. I am bewildered. Hearing his words, the three Lords smiled and replied, Dear Atri, whatever you wished will be fulfilled. We Brahmā, Vişnu, and Śiva oversee the activities of creation, maintenance, and destruction of this universe. So, anyone of us may be considered the Lord of the universe, Jagadīśvara. You didn't specifically mention whom you wanted, so all three of us came before you. Atri called for Jagad-īśvara, but he was not sure who that Jagad-īśvara was. He didn't know who among the three deities was the Supreme. Still, he wanted a son like Jagad-īśvara. So, the three Lords granted his desires. They spoke to him, All three of us will appear as your sons and manifest our potencies partially. By those three sons, your reputation will increase. Then the three Lords disappeared. Later the three Lords Visnu, Brahmā, and Śiva appeared as Atri's three sons, namely Dattātreya, Soma, and Durvāsā respectively.
activity: What would you pray If Lord Krishna offered you one boon?
lesson: A LESSON ON PRAYER: Prayer is one of the most effective ways of connecting with God. Prayers are our private conversations with the Lord. The common elements of prayers are praising God, thanking Him for His mercy, requesting Him for something, or seeking forgiveness. A prayer could be in the form of a song or some simple statement with sublime devotion. Even our chanting of God's names is a prayer. We can learn how to pray from great devotees like Prahlada and Dhruva. By offering heartfelt prayers to the Lord, we receive His grace. We should try our best to offer prayers wholeheartedly and not mechanically.

title: When A Leader Is Arrogant & Angry
story: Prasūti was one of the three daughters of Svāyambhuva Manu. Manu got her married to Prajapati Daksa. Prasūti and Daksa had sixteen beautiful daughters. One of the daughters, Satī, married Lord Siva. The first fifteen daughters gave birth to many sons, but the youngest daughter Satī didn't have children. Daksa was very affectionate to his youngest daughter Sati. On the other hand, Lord Siva was gentle, non-envious, peaceful, and self-satisfied. He was a teacher of the whole world and the greatest of the devatās. But Daksa always envied Lord Śiva because of his exalted position. Thus, there was a bitter quarrel between the son-in-law and father-in-law that ultimately led to the death of Satī. Once several sages, demigods, and other leaders of the universe assembled to perform a thousand-year sacrifice. Daksa entered that sacrificial arena, shining like the sun. The entire assembly was illuminated. Everyone there, except Brahmā and Śiva, stood up respectfully to welcome Daksa. Daksa went to his father Brahma and offered respects. At that time, Lord Śiva was meditating on the Supreme Lord. Seeing Śiva not standing up to honor him, Daksa became enraged and gazed with eyes to burn Śiva. But humble people do not expect respect. On the pretext of speaking about good manners and a culture of respect, Daksa criticized Lord Śiva. He said, O sages and devatās, I am not speaking out of ignorance or envy. This Śiva is unclean, shameless, impure, proud, and has no manners. Like a madman, sometimes laughs and sometimes cries. He smears crematorium ashes, wears a garland of skulls and bones. He is dear to ghosts and crazy beings who are in ignorance. Pretending to be an honest person, this monkey-eyed man has married my fawn-eyed daughter Sati. He thus accepted himself as my subordinate, but now he has failed to respect me even with words. Therefore, though not desiring, I gave my daughter to this unqualified man, at the request of Brahmā. Dakşa thus criticized and insulted Lord Śiva, but Śiva remained tolerant and didn't speak a single word in retaliation. On the contrary, to the astonishment of everyone, Daksa even cursed Śiva saying, Let this Śiva, the lowest of all the devatās, not have a share in the sacrificial oblations. Daksa then angrily left the assembly, although the assembly leaders opposed it. Nandīśvara, the devout servant of Lord Śiva, became very angry. He thus counter-cursed Daksa and his followers, Let Daksa have a goat head very soon. Anyone who has supported Daksa and neglected Lord Siva are foolish. They will be bereft of spiritual knowledge and will be attached to superficial rituals. They will become beggars and will have no discrimination in eating. Seeing Nandi cursing the brahmaņas, sage Bhrgu counter-cursed Lord Šiva's followers, Let the followers of Lord Siva become atheists. Since they criticized brahmaņas and Vedas, let them be diverted from scriptural injunctions and become addicted to wine and flesh. When such cursing and counter-cursing were going on, Lord Siva became morose. To find no means of stopping it, he just got up and left the place. Despite the absence of Lord Śiva and Daksa, the other members performed the thousand-year sacrifice. After completing the yajña, they took their bath at the confluence of Ganga and Yamuna and went to their respective abodes.
quotes: Proud people expect respect from others and even become angry when they don't get it., A victim of undue anger unnecessarily points out others as culprits, and doesn't accept any good advice.
activity: 1. Why does one become envious? Mention two reasons and two ways to overcome envy. 2. Discuss the dangers of undue anger with your friends, and write your understanding of the need to control anger. 3. Are you envious of anyone? If yes, think why.
lesson: A LESSON ON ARROGANCE: High post, position, skill, fame, influence, and so on can make a person proud and arrogant. Such a person considers oneself superior to others. Superiority complex makes one expect respect from others and becomes angry upon not receiving it. One even tends to find faults in others and criticize them unnecessarily. Such people do not realize that they are bringing about their own ruination by their arrogance. Daksa was an example of this. In contrast, Lord Siva was humble and tolerant. Learning from Śiva, we should cultivate humility and stay far away from arrogance.

title: A Decision In Confusion
story: Once Daksa performed a sacrifice called võjapeya. He followed it up with a greater sacrifice called brhaspati-sava. He invited many great sages, devatās, and their wives for the sacrifice, but he didn't invite Lord Šiva or his followers. Being so arrogant, he continued to be hateful towards Siva. Sati, the beloved wife of Lord Siva, heard the heavenly denizens conversing about Daksa's sacrifice. She also saw the wives of many devatās going there well dressed and ornamented. Being the youngest daughter of Dakşa, she also desired to go for her father's sacrifice. Innocent Sati approached Śiva and said, It is your father-in-law's sacrifice conducted by great sages. My sisters must have gone there with their husbands. I see that several devatās are also going. I also want to decorate myself and go there with you. I wish to see my mother, sisters, aunts, and other relatives. I desire to see my birth place. Please be kind to me. How can a daughter be undisturbed hearing of a festive event at her father's house? Thinking that Śiva might say that Daksa had not invited them, Sati said, There's no harm in going to the house of a friend or father even without an invitation. You have accepted me as your better half, and please oblige me. Lord Śiva replied smilingly, It is true that one could go to a friend's house uninvited. But if the host finds fault with the guest and looks at the guest with angry eyes, one shouldn't go to such a person's house. Sati: But my father will not find faults in us because he has wisdom. Šiva: Noble people have six great qualities namely austerity, wealth, knowledge, beauty, youth and heritage. But if one is proud, these qualities become faults in them, and they can't see any good in others. Sati: But even the low-minded people have affection for their children. I am the favorite daughter of my father. Therefore, even if he speaks some unkind words, I shall tolerate. Siva: Harsh words of one's relatives are more painful than the harsh words of enemies. They continue to pain one's heart day and night. Sati: I will go alone. You need not come. Śiva: I understand that you are the beloved daughter of Daksa, but because of your connection with me, he will dishonor you. Sati: You are speaking like this due to your anger towards my father. Śiva: I have no anger on your father. But he hates me. An egoistic person cannot tolerate the greatness of others. Being unable to rise to their standard, such people envy others. Sati: I believe that you do not hate my father. However, he is your father-in-law, so you should have risen from your seat to respect him when he entered the sacrificial arena. Śiva: In pure consciousness, I am always offering obeisances to Lord Vāsudeva, who is within everyone's heart. Because I was absorbed in thinking of Vasudeva, I was respecting Daksa too. Sati was silent and couldn't say anything. Šiva finally said, Please do not go to your father's sacrifice. Because of envy, he has insulted me with cruel words, and he will mistreat you also. If you neglect my words and go, your future will not be good. Disrespect from a relative is as good as dead. In this way, Lord Śiva, being a genuine well-wisher of his beloved wife, advised her. But Sati was anxious to see her relatives and was also afraid of Śiva's caution. In confusion, she moved in and out of the home. Upset at being forbidden, she cried out of affection for her relatives. Her body was shaking as she glanced at Śiva in great anger as if to burn him. Tormented by the extreme emotions, her intelligence was bewildered, and Satī left Śiva, who had given her half of his body. Because of this, later Satī was insulted by Daksa and had to give up her body voluntarily.
activity: Recall an incident where you were stubborn about fulfilling your desire, despite the good advice of a well-wisher. What had been the consequences, and what did you learn from that?
lesson: A LESSON ON DECISION-MAKING: A decision taken in confusion and intense emotion can lead to unpleasant results. So, one should think carefully before making a decision. Desires that seem innocent could be harmful at times. If we are too attached to such desires, we cannot accept good advice from mature people. It's a great fortune to have expert guidance in our decision-making. If we are open to experienced well-wishers' advice and seek their help in decision-making, we can avoid a lot of turmoil.

title: The Father Who Ignored His Daughter
story: Sati decided to go to Daksa's sacrifice, neglecting Lord Siva's advice. Šiva didn't further try to stop her. He understood that Sati was overwhelmed by her emotions for relatives. But he wanted to protect her. So he gave indications to his followers Nandi, Manimän, and others to safely take Sati to Daksa's sacrifice. The associates of Siva then followed Sati, who was going to her father's house. She was made to sit on the bull Nandi and was given her pet bird särikā, a ball, lotus, mirror, white umbrella, fan, and a garland. A singing party accompanied her, and the whole procession was as pompous as a royal parade. Sati thus reached Dakşa's sacrificial arena, which was splendid with the chanting of Vedic hymns, and the presence of great sages and devatās. But no one came forward to received Sati out of fear of Daksa. Only her mother, sisters, and aunts came and hugged her with affection and gladdened faces. They offered her a seat and many gifts, but she didn't accept any of them. She did not even reply to their words of reception because her father did not welcome her due to his hatred for her husband. She could now understand why Śiva told her not to come there. Sati also noticed that in that sacrifice, there were no oblations in the name of Lord Siva. Although she had neglected Siva's advice due to her desire, she had a great love for him. Therefore, she couldn't tolerate Dakşa's offenses towards Lord Siva. She became furious and looked at Dakşa as if to burn him. Seeing her anger, Lord Siva's followers became ready to kill Daksa, but she stopped them. Being sorrowful, she condemned Daksa, Who except you would hate Lord Siva? There is no rival for Siva in this universe. He is the most beloved of all. Although you criticized him as inauspicious, everyone, including Brahmā, considers him auspicious. Sādhus, like him, find no faults in others but magnify even meager good qualities in others. But a proud man like you finds faults even in great souls. Therefore, offense to exalted personalities will ruin you. Pointing out Daksa's offensive mentality, Satī said, You have blasphemed a great Vaisnava. One must cut the tongue or kill an offender like you. If that is not possible, one must block one's ears and leave the place, or give up one's own life as an atonement for hearing the criticism. Because you happen to be my father, I do not wish to kill you. So, I shall give up my body. My body is a source of embarrassment since it comes from a person who has offended Śiva. Sati had the potency to vanquish many universes, including many Daksas. But to save her husband from the charge that he killed Daksa through his wife, Satī did not kill Daksa but decided to give up her own life. Satī thus sat down facing north. Dressed in saffron garments, she sat in meditation and invoked fire within her body. Then, thinking about the holy feet of her husband, she gave up her body in that fire. Seeing Satī's voluntary death, people in the universe said, Daksa was so disrespectful to his honorable daughter, that she had to give up her body. Hard-hearted Dakşa is unworthy to be a brāhmaņa. He was so envious and hateful of Lord Śiva that he didn't even attempt to stop his daughter from committing suicide. While people were thus talking, Lord Siva's attendants prepared to kill Daksa. Seeing them swiftly approaching to attack Daksa, Bhrgu Muni offered oblations into the fire with hymns from the Yajur Veda to kill them. As a result, many thousands of powerful men called Rbhus appeared and chased all the followers of Śiva in all directions. Nārada Muni informed Lord Śiva about Satī's death. Śiva became furious. He tolerated Daksa's offense towards himself earlier, but now he couldn't tolerate Daksa's mistreatment of Sati. Śiva plucked a hair from his head and threw it on the ground in great anger. From that hair, a fearsome black demon named Virabhadra appeared. Vīrabhadra was as high as the sky and as bright as three suns, with hair like blazing fire, fearsome teeth, a garland of skulls, and thousands of arms equipped with weapons. Virabhadra asked Lord Śiva with folded hands, What shall I do? Śiva ordered, Kill Daksa and his soldiers. Virabhadra then circumambulated Śiva and departed for Daksa's sacrificial arena. Virabhadra carried a fearful trident and was accompanied by the associates of Śiva. They all made a thundering sound and created a great dust storm causing darkness. Everybody in Dakşa's sacrificial arena wondered, Where is this dust coming from? This cannot be because of wind or thieves. Prasūti and other women said. This danger is the result of Daksa's sin. He insulted innocent Sati and caused her death. He neglected the honor of Lord Siva. How can anyone have fortune after angering Siva? He can scatter the planets by the movements of his eyebrows. While people were thus speaking, Daksa saw dangerous omens from all sides, from the earth and the sky. Virabhadra and his army, holding various weapons, ran all around Daksa's sacrificial arena and began to create great disturbances. They destroyed pillars, halls, kitchens, homes, and sacrificial paraphernalia. Finally, they extinguished the sacrificial fire, blocked the fleeing priests' way, and arrested the devatās. of Lord Siva. Maniman arrested Bhrgu Muni, and Virabhadra arrested Daksa. Candeśa arrested Pūṣā and Nandīśvara arrested Bhaga. Vīrabhadra tore off the mustache of Bhrgu, who had smiled showing his mustache when Daksa insulted Śiva. Next, Vīrabhadra plucked out the eyes of Bhaga, who had encouraged Daksa by the movement of his eyebrows. Next, he knocked out the teeth of Pusa, who had shown his teeth by smiling. Vīrabhadra then sat on the chest of Daksa and beheaded him. Seeing this, the followers of Lord Śiva expressed great joy, while others expressed grief. Vīrabhadra then offered Daksa's head in the sacrificial fire as an oblation, and departed for Kailāsa, the abode of Lord Śiva.
quotes: Due to ignorance, we ignore good advice at times, only to later realize that our decision was faulty., It is better to follow one's own duties, without unnecessarily criticizing others., Egoistic people can even give up their love for family members, out of their hatred for others., One's offenses may be tolerated for some time, but not forever. One has to face the consequences of one's faulty actions and attitudes.
activity: Sometimes there is a competition within one's mind between ego and love. Who wins between the two depends on one's mentality. Analyze the effects of giving Importance to love (1) ego and (il) love
lesson: A LESSON ON ENVY: Envy is one of the most prominent frailties in this world. An envious person cannot see others being more successful or greater and tries to pull them down by criticism or even physical attack. Envy makes one hard-hearted and insensitive. Envy is like a boomerang that sooner or later comes back to us only to cause damage. Instead of being envious of others' success and greatness, good people honestly appreciate them and seek inspiration from them. Devotees are non-envious; they are genuine well-wishers of others and even help others attain success.
