title: Man With A Goat Head
story: After Virabhadra had destroyed Daksa's sacrifice, all the injured devatās, priests and guests approached Lord Brahma. They informed him of what had happened and asked for his help. Lord Brahma spoke to them, How can you expect any happiness if you offend a great personality like Lord Siva? He is especially sorry because of losing his wife and the harsh words spoken by Daksa. Therefore, you should fall at his feet and beg his pardon. But, nevertheless, he is pleased easily and therefore he is called Āśutosa. Brahma then took all of them and went to Kailasa, the abode of Lord Šiva. The Kailasa Hill was resounding with Vedic hymns. Its scenic ambiance is filled with varieties of flower-bearing and fruit-bearing trees, caves, minerals, jewels, lakes filled with lotuses, waterfalls, animals, and sweet vibrations of various birds like peacocks and cuckoos. It was surrounded by River Alakanandā (Ganga). Passing through the beautiful Kailasa region, the devatās approached Lord Siva. He was sitting under a 100 yojanas wide banyan tree (one yojana 8 miles). He seemed peaceful. He was sitting in virāsana, with his left leg on his right thigh and his left hand on his left thigh. In his right hand, he held rudrākṣa beads. He sat on a kuśa mat and was speaking about bhakti to Narada Muni and other sages. The devatās and sages offered respects to Lord Śiva. Despite his exalted position, Šiva stood up and bowed down in front of Brahmā. Lord Brahmā was smiling to conceal his fear as he was afraid that Lord Śiva might be in an angry mood. Brahmā spoke to Śiva, Please spare sinful Daksa. Great devotees of Vişnu like yourself do not become angry with other beings. You are very exalted. You need not kill sinful people, as they are already killed by providence because of their mean-mindedness, envy, and harsh speech. People like you are very kind to even offenders like Daksa. Please be merciful upon them. Let Dakşa get back his life, Bhaga his eyes, Bhrgu his mustache, Pūṣā his teeth. May the injured devatās recover. Please take your share of the sacrifice, and let your grace complete the sacrifice. Being thus requested by Brahmā, Lord Śiva smilingly spoke, I do not mind the offenses of the devatās, as they are childish and less intelligent. Therefore, I have punished them only to correct them. Lord Śiva then fulfilled the requests of Lord Brahmā, Let Daksa have a goat's head because he had the words and intelligence of a goat. Let Bhaga see with Mitra's eyes. Let Pūsā chew through the teeth of his disciples or Daksa, or eat chickpea dough if he is alone. He has shown his teeth while laughing at the devotees. Let the devatās have their limbs restored as they did not side with Daksa when he criticized me. Let Bhrgu have the mustache of a goat as he was the chief advisor of Daksa. The assembled people approved Śiva's words. Then all of them, including Śiva and Brahmā, proceeded to the sacrificial arena. Daksa's body was joined to the head of a goat. Then, Daksa awoke as if from sleep and saw Lord Śiva. Daksa's heart had been contaminated by hatred for Śiva, but it was cleansed now. He remembered the ill-fated death of his daughter and shed tears. Gaining composure, Daksa began to praise Śiva, I am an offender. Your punishment to me is your mercy upon me. You always protect the brāhmaņas. Not knowing the truth about you, I insulted you. But you were tolerant. Please be satisfied by your own mercy, for I cannot satisfy you with my words. Being pardoned by Lord Siva and with the permission of Brahma, Daksa again began the sacrifice. He offered ghee in the sacrificial fire with Yajur Veda mantras, Then Lord Visnu appeared on His Garuda bird carrier, illuminating all the directions. He was blackish, dressed in yellow, and wore a crown as dazzling as the sun. In His eight hands (like eight petals of a lotus), He held conch, disc, club, lotus, arrow, bow, shield, and sword. His body appeared like a blue lotus flower. His face was decorated with a beautiful smile and captivating glance. He had a white canopy overhead like the moon. The devatās offered their respectful prayers to Lord Visnu according to their capacities. Lord Visnu then instructed Daksa, If a devotee worships Me, but disrespects Śiva and Brahmā, I am not pleased. Therefore, never commit such offenses again. Daksa then worshipped Lord Visnu, and also Lord Siva, Lord Brahmā, and the other devatās and concluded his sacrifice. Then all the assembled people blessed Dakşa and departed. Sati was reborn as Pārvatī in the womb of Menaka, the wife of Himāla Pārvatī married Lord Śiva again and lived happily with him.
activity: Write did you learn from the activities of Daksha. How does his story inspire you to stay away from pride, envy, anger, and disrespect?
lesson: A LESSON ON RESPECT: Even if one worships Lord Visnu, if one disrespects and offends Lord Siva or other exalted personalities, Vişnu is not satisfied with them. What to speak of Siva and Brahma, one shouldn't disrespect any living being. Every living entity is a child of God and is spiritual in nature, although caught up in a material body. Acknowledging everyone's eternal relationship with God, we must duly respect all living beings according to their positions. Disrespecting others out of pride and envy leads to one's own fall down.

title: The Decision of A Disappointed Boy
story: King Uttanapada had two queens - Sunīti and Suruci. The younger queen Suruci was very dear to Uttanapada, while Sunīti was not his favorite. Sunīti had a son named Dhruva , and Suruci's son was Uttama. Once, Uttanapada sat on his throne with Uttama on his lap. As he was patting Uttama affectionately, little Dhruva arrived there. Five-year-old Dhruva also desired to sit on his father's lap like his step-brother. So he tried to get on Uttanapāda's lap, but the King did not welcome him. Uttānapāda was affectionate towards both of his sons, but despite his favoritism towards Suruci, he could not welcome Dhruva, despite his feelings. Seeing Dhruva's innocent desire and attempt, Suruci became very envious. She started speaking with great pride while Uttānapāda listened. Suruci said to Dhruva, O child, although you are also the son of the King, you don't deserve to sit on his lap or the throne because you are not born of me! Being a mere child, you are unaware of the difference between your mother and me. Therefore, your desire is impossible to fulfill. If you still wish to sit on the King's lap, then worship Lord Visnu, and by His mercy, take birth as my son in your next life. Suruci indirectly told Dhruva first to die and then take his next birth in her womb. She wasn't a great devotee of Lord Visnu, but she recommended Dhruva to worship the Lord, just to impress Uttānapāda that she was a devotee. Pierced by Suruci's harsh words, Dhruva breathed heavily in anger, like a snake struck by a stick. Uttānapāda's silence made him even more disappointed. Being a king and a father, Uttānapāda could have been responsible for forbidding Suruci when she was so harsh to Dhruva unnecessarily. But Uttānapāda didn't do anything to comfort Dhruva. Disheartened, Dhruva immediately went to his mother weeping. By the time Dhruva reached Sunīti, the palace residents had informed her about the incident. Hearing this, Sunīti became aggrieved. When she saw Dhruva crying in distress, Sunīti lifted him onto her lap. Losing her patience, she lamented, remembering the harsh words of her co-wife. She burned in grief like a creeper burned by a forest fire and shed tears. Not knowing any remedy for the painful situation, Sunīti tried to console Dhruva. She said, My dear child, please do not wish ill fortune for others. One suffers pain as a result of one's own past mistakes. You have taken birth from an unfortunate woman. Your father feels ashamed to accept me as his wife or even as a maidservant. What Suruci has said is true. If you desire to sit on the same throne as your stepbrother, follow Suruci's advice of worshipping Lord Vasudeva without being envious of her. Recommending bhakti, Sunīti told Dhruva, Only by worshipping Lord Vasudeva, your great-grandfather Brahmā could create the universe, and your grandfather Manu achieved happiness and liberation. So, you also take shelter of the Lord. He is very kind to His devotees. So, keep Him in your heart, and perform bhakti without deviation. His affection for His devotees is more than the affection of millions of mothers put together. No one else is capable of extinguishing your distress except the lotus-eyed Lord. Even Laksmi, who is worshiped by several devatās, serves Lord Vasudeva. Although Sunīti advised Dhruva not to be envious of Suruci, Dhruva still held anger towards Suruci. This was due to his nature as a ksatriya prince. But he took Sunīti's advice of worshiping Lord Visnu very seriously. Because he was not allowed to sit on his father's lap or throne, he desired to sit in a much superior position. He thought, I must attain a position which is superior to even Brahma's position. So Dhruva decided to leave home and enter the forest to worship the Lord with this determined desire.
quotes: Sometimes we may have to act against our own good desires due to unreasonable obligations., Insensitive and harsh speech breaks the hearts of others. Therefore, one must learn to speak politely., The behavior of elders in front of children impacts their minds. So, elders need be careful in their dealings with the younger ones., We shouldn't desire harm for others even if they harm us., Mature elders give affection, encouragement, and guidance to the younger ones when they are aggrieved.
activity: Recall instances where you were consoled by your mother when you were demotivated, How do you express your gratitude to her?
lesson: A LESSON ON CONSCIOUSNESS: Proud people like Suruci are insensitive towards others and speak harshly. Weak-hearted people like Uttanapada fail to act responsibly at the right time. But noble-hearted people like Sunīti do not hold any negative feelings towards even those who hurt them. Their tolerance and mature consciousness can gradually bring transformation in others too. Such great persons humbly take shelter of God and direct others also towards God's shelter. With their devotional consciousness, they can convert adversity into an advantage for themselves and others.

title: Dhruva's Determination Tested
story: With an ambitious desire to attain a position greater than Lord Brahmā, little Dhruva left home and entered the forest. He wanted to worship Lord Väsudeva to attain his goal. The Lord understood the child's desire and inspired His dear devotee Narada to go and guide him. Närada Muni met Dhruva in the forest. He touched the boy's head with his all-virtuous hand and thought to himself, How wonderful are the kṣatriyas who cannot tolerate even a slight infringement upon their prestige. Though he is just a child, he has taken the harsh words of his stepmother so seriously that he left home! Narada then spoke to Dhruva, My dear boy, you are just a child, and you should not be so affected by honor or dishonor. Generally, children are attached to playing. But if you are so developed to understand honor and insult, you should also understand that we receive honor or dishonor due to our karma or past activities. So, an intelligent person is not disappointed by such temporary experiences. Närada Muni tested Dhruva's determination. He said, Dear Dhruva, you have come to the forest to worship Lord Väsudeva, but it is very difficult to satisfy Him. So many great yogis failed to understand and please Him even in many lifetimes. So, please go back home for you will not be successful. Then, when you are grown up, you can attempt to worship the Lord. Nārada Muni didn't mean to discourage Dhruva from worshiping the Lord, but he just tested his determination. Dhruva firmly replied, O great sage, I can't accept your advice. Although your instructions are very good for peace of mind, I am not submissive due to my kṣatriya temperament. Suruci's harsh words have pierced my heart. She didn't allow me to sit on my father's lap or throne Now, I desire the most exalted position in the universe which my forefathers or even Brahmā has not attained. Please advise an honest path to achieve my goal. Nārada was impressed with the honesty and determination of Dhruva. He wanted to help him in attaining his goal. So he mercifully instructed Dhruva, Dear child, I recommend that you perform bhakti to Lord Vasudeva, as described by your mother. Worshiping Him is the only method to achieve any human goal. Go to Madhuvan on the bank of the Yamuna, where He resides eternally. Take bath three times a day in the Yamuna River. Meditate on Lord Vasudeva with a peaceful mind. Nārada then described the form and qualities of Lord Vasudeva on whom Dhruva was advised to meditate, Lord Vasudeva has a joyful face and glance, a beautiful nose, eyebrows, and forehead. He is always youthful and is more beautiful than all the devatās. He is most merciful to all His devotees. He is an ocean of mercy. In His four-handed form, He holds a conch, disc, club, and lotus. He wears a jeweled crown, earrings, necklace, bracelets, and the Kaustubha jewel around his neck. He wears yellow silk clothes and shining golden anklets. His lotus-like feet have jewel-like nails glittering, and He stands on the whorl of the lotus of the hearts of those who worship Him in devotion. Therefore, please meditate on Him regularly with great attention. Thus, you will attain great spiritual joy. Along with the process of meditation, Narada Muni also gave a twelve-syllable mantra (dvādaśākṣara-mantra) to Dhruva. Nārada mercifully spoke in Dhruva's right ear, om namo bhagavate vasudevāya - please chant this mantra. Please make a physical form of the Lord with earth and water, and worship Him with this mantra and water, fruits, flowers, vegetables, and other paraphernalia you can easily obtain in the forest. The Lord, like tulasī, leaves very much, so please offer them to Him without fail. Please be peaceful and be satisfied with eating whatever is available in the forest. Also, meditate on the Lord's divine pastimes in His various incarnations. Thus you will attain all blessings of the Lord, and all your desires will be fulfilled. Thus Nārada Muni tested Dhruva's determination and finally gave him good instructions to attain his goal. Dhruva became very grateful to Nārada Muni for his kind guidance. He then circumambulated Nārada, offered obeisances and went to Madhuvan, which is imprinted with the lotus footprints of Krsna.
quotes: When the Lord sees us eager to perform bhakti, He sends His representative to help us., Meditation on the Lord's charming form pleases the eyes and heart completely.
activity: Recall an Incident, where your teacher guided you in achieving your goals. Share your thoughts on the Importance having a good teacher.
lesson: A LESSON ON DETERMINATION: Doing anything good requires determination. The guru accepts a student after testing how determined is he to pursue his goal. He understands the inclination of the students and gives them appropriate guidance to attain success. And a student needs to be determined in following the advice with faith to be successful.

title: Success In Six Months
story: After guiding Dhruva on worshiping Lord Väsudeva, Nārada Muni went to meet King Uttānapāda. The king welcomed Närada respectfully. Nārada asked him, O King, you look morose. Your face is withered. Why are you so sad? King Uttānapāda replied with regret, O great sage, I am henpecked. I was too attached to my wife Suruci and was merciless towards Sunīti and Dhruva. I have practically banished both of them. My son has now left the palace. He is unprotected in the forest. He might be tired and hungry. Wolves and other wild animals might have attacked him. See my cruelty! Most vile, I did not welcome my son when he tried to climb on my lap. Uttānapāda was very repentant for his mistake. Nārada Muni consoled Uttānapāda, Dear King, don't be aggrieved about your son. He is very competent. He is well protected by Lord Vāsudeva. Though his greatness is not yet known to this world, he will soon become very famous. His fame will spread throughout the universe. He is going to perform the most difficult task of satisfying the Supreme Lord. He will soon return home. Uttānapāda felt pacified after hearing Narada Muni's encouraging words. He began treating Sunīti with love and affection and did not show much favoritism towards Suruci. Instead, he eagerly looked forward to the arrival of his son. Meanwhile, at Madhuvan, Dhruva took his bath in River Yamuna and fasted that night. Then he worshipped Lord Krsna as instructed by Narada Muni. Although a child, he performed severe austerities to please the Lord. In the first month, he he sustained himself by eating Kapittha fruits and berries once in three days. In the second month, he ate dry grass and leaves once in six days. In the third month, he just drank water once in nine days. In the fourth month, he just breathed air once in twelve days. Dhruva had controlled his breath and mind by the fifth month and stood motionless on one foot like a pillar. He thus meditated on Lord Vasudeva's beautiful form without distraction. He completely captured the Lord within His mind. By carrying Lord Visnu within his heart with full concentration, Dhruva practically became as heavy as the Lord. As he steadily stood on one leg, the pressure of his toe pushed the earth down. The deratas and residents of all the planets felt suffocated. The three worlds began to tremble. All the devatās approached Lord Visnu and spoke, Dear Lord, we have never experienced such suffocation. You are the shelter of all living beings. Therefore, we have approached you. Kindly save us from this danger. Lord Visnu reassured the devatās, Do not be perturbed. This situation in the universe is due to the severe tapasya of Dhruva, who is now fully absorbed in meditation on Me. I shall stop him and save you. Being thus reassured by the Lord, the demigods were relieved of fear and returned to their homes. After that, Lord Visnu went on the back of His bird carrier Garuda to Madhuvan to see His young devotee Dhruva. Dhruva was fully absorbed in meditation and could see the Lord's form within his mind. But suddenly, he lost the vision of the Lord. Being perturbed, he opened his eyes. To his surprise, he saw the Lord personally standing in front of him. When the Lord whom he had seen in his heart appeared before his eyes, Dhruva was overwhelmed. Dhruva offered prostrated obeisances to the Lord by falling like a stick in front of Him. In ecstasy, he seemed to drink the Lord's sweetness with his eyes. He seemed to kiss His lotus feet with his mouth and embrace Him with his arms. Dhruva was spontaneously inspired to offer prayers to the Lord. But he didn't have the necessary knowledge, experience, and vocabulary to praise the Lord. Understanding Dhruva's desire to pray and his inability to do so, the Lord mercifully touched His conch to Dhruva's forehead. By the touch of Visnu's conch, the child became perfectly aware of the conclusions of all the Vedas. Thus, he became equipped with the knowledge of the Lord and the ability to praise Him. Dhruva then offered his heartfelt prayers, O Lord. You are all-powerful. With your spiritual potency, You have awakened my power of speech and made me capable of praising You. You are the creator of the universe and the Supersoul of all living beings. The happiness of devotional service unto You is superior to the happiness of heaven or liberation. Therefore, I desire the association of Your pure-hearted devotees and perform bhakti constantly. I wish to hear Your nectarean pastimes in their company. Thus, I can overcome all miseries of this world. A cow gives milk to an ignorant calf and protects it from wild animals even though the calf does not serve her. Similarly, You mercifully give bhakti to Your devotees even though they worship You with material desires. Dhruva worshiped the Lord with a material ambition to attain a position greater than that of Brahmā. But after performing bhakti for six months and personally seeing the Lord, Dhruva has forgotten all his previous material desires. Now he didn't ask the Lord for what he wanted earlier. He gave up all revengeful feelings towards his stepmother and stepbrother. He just desired to perform bhakti and attain pure love (prema) for the Lord. Satisfied by Dhruva's prayers, the Lord mercifully spoke to Dhruva, O prince, all good fortune unto you. I know your heart's desire. You can rule this earth for 36,000 years after your father's retirement. Your senses will always remain strong. Your brother, Uttama, will die in the future while hunting, and his mother, Suruci, will be burnt in a forest fire while searching for him. After ruling this world, you will remember Me and come to My planet, Dhruvaloka. Dhruvaloka, the polestar, continues to exist even after the universe is destroyed. All the luminaries circumambulate it, and the planets inhabited by the great sages. Having said this, Lord Visnu returned to His abode, on the back of Garuda, as Dhruva looked on. The Lord thus awarded Dhruva the polestar, Dhruvaloka, which is the abode of Lord Visnu within this material world. Upon it, there is a milk ocean, within which is an island called Śvetadvīpa. Thus, at the time of the destruction of this universe, Dhruvaloka continues to exist, like other Vaikunthas beyond this universe.
quotes: An honest person admits one's mistakes and repents for them without justifying them., The Lord's kindness fills the hearts of His devotees with satisfaction, joy, and gratitude., When a devotee 'desires' to serve the Lord somehow, the Lord bestows the 'ability to do that service. Thus, even the devotee's ability to offer prayers to the Lord comes from Him., Sincere practice of bhakti will relieve one from envy, greed, and all material thoughts and ambitions.
activity: What are the main obstacles you need to overcome when you have a great goal to achieve?
lesson: A LESSON ON REGRET: Formerly, Dhruva had a revengeful attitude towards Suruci and Uttama. But after practicing bhakti, his heart was transformed, and he regretted his former negative feelings. Such honest regret is good and natural for a genuine person. Mistakes are common, but an honest person realizes his mistake, sincerely regrets it, and genuinely tries not to repeat it. So Dhruva didn't hold grudges towards Suruci and Uttama anymore and treated them with love and respect. All this transformation happened in him due to his sincere performance of bhakti.

title: Good Attracts Good Will
story: Just within six months, Dhruva saw Lord Visnu by his determined practice of bhakti. Although his desires were fulfilled, he was not very pleased. Instead, he felt ashamed, guilty, and regretful, remembering his past material ambitions. He felt unqualified for the association of the Lord in His abode. In deep humility and disgust, Dhruva spoke to himself, Alas, I am so unfortunate and foolish! I could not accept the genuine advice of Närada Muni. I desired perishable material things. I maintained a revengeful attitude towards my stepmother. I saw my brother as my enemy. I hankered for material prosperity, name, and fame, but the kind Lord offered me His personal service. I was like a foolish, poor man who asks for only a few grains of broken rice from an emperor. Thus, feeling morose, Dhruva departed from Madhuvan to meet his family. As he was nearing his father's palace, a messenger informed King Uttanapada that Dhruva had returned. The king couldn't believe his good fortune. He remembered Närada's words became elated. In great joy, he presented a valuable necklace to the messenger. King Uttānapāda eagerly came out of the city on a chariot, with his ministers and friends, with the sounding of conches, drums, flutes, and the chanting of Vedic mantras. Sunīti also eagerly came out riding in a palanquin to receive her dearest son. Being a virtuous lady endowed with the best attitude and behavior, Sunīti had Suruci and Uttama ride in her palanquin. Seeing Dhruva from a distance, Uttānapāda hastily got down from his chariot and, with great affection, embraced the boy. Dhruva is now a great devotee who had been purified by the touch of Lord Visnu. His long-cherished desire fulfilled, the King embraced his son and bathed him with tears. Dhruva respectfully bowed down to the feet of his father and mother. He also touched his head to the feet of Suruci, treating her like his own mother. Having seen the Lord, Dhruva was completely freed from all negative feelings towards Suruci. Seeing Dhruva fall at her feet, Suruci picked him up, embraced him, and with tears in her eyes, she blessed him, May you live long, my child! Although Suruci hated Dhruva earlier and indirectly asked him to die, now she affectionately blessed him to live long. This transformation in Suruci was due to the kindheartedness of Sunīti and the exalted devotional status attained by Dhruva. Uttama and Dhruva embraced each other, overwhelmed by affection, and shed torrents of tears. Now no more bitter feelings in anyone's heart. Sunīti embraced Dhruva, who was dearer to her than her own life. She thus forgot all her grief and was fully satisfied. Sunīti was now the mother of a great hero. Her tears, along with her milk, made Dhruva's body wet. This was auspicious. This represents an abhişeka ceremony performed by his mother, indicating that Dhruva would soon be installed on the throne of his father. People praised Sunīti, By good fortune, your son has come back after being lost for a long time. You must have worshipped the Lord, who saves His devotees from dangers. When everyone was thus praising Dhruva, King Uttānapāda was delighted. He placed Dhruva and Uttama on an elephant and returned to his city. The city of Uttanapāda was decorated beautifully to receive Dhruva. Every house was draped with mango leaves and strings of pearls and was decorated with water pots and lamps. The city's gates and walls were all decorated with golden ornaments. All the lanes, streets, and watchtowers had been cleansed and sprinkled with sandalwood water. Chaste women offered blessings upon Dhruva as he passed on the road, showering him with flowers. While hearing their pleasing songs, Dhruva entered the palace. Dhruva lived in the palace, being cared for by his affectionate father. The soft bedding in the palace was as white as the foam of milk. The bedsteads were made of ivory with embellishments of gold. The chairs and other furniture were made of gold. Walls were made of marble with many engravings made of valuable jewels, which depicted beautiful women with jewel lamps in their hands. Pleasant gardens were filled with trees with pairs of sweet singing birds and buzzing bumblebees. Lakes with emerald staircases were filled with lotuses, swans, and ducks. As Dhruva grew older, he became very intelligent, mature, and influential among the citizens. Finally, King Uttānapāda saw the citizens' love for Dhruva, and the ministers' approval, and enthroned Dhruva as emperor of the planet. Uttānapāda then retired to the forest to fully devote his remaining life for the worship of Lord Visnu. At that time, Dhruva wasn't married.
quotes: If we maintain negative feelings towards others, we will have to regret like Dhruva. Mature people hold no grudges even towards the envious., Everyone naturally loves a gentle devotee, just as water naturally flows downwards.
activity: By performing bhakti, Dhruva gave up his grudge towards Suruct and Uttama? What Inspiration did you derive from this story?
lesson: A LESSON ON DETACHMENT: Great kings in the past did not hold on to their thrones till the fag end of their lives. As soon as they would find a capable successor, they would give him the responsibility of the kingdom and take full shelter of the Lord. Because they have a higher spiritual goal in life, they remain detached in material activities. It the name of detachment, they don't become irresponsible towards their duties. And in the name of responsibility, they don't become unduly attached. Such saintly kings teach us a balance between responsibility and detachment.

attributes.story_setting: Ancient Kingdom / Royal Palace / Sacred Forest

title: Consoling The Angry Grandson
story: King Dhruva married Bhrami, the daughter of Prajapati Šišumāra. They had two sons, namely Kalpa and Vatsara. Dhruva also had a second wife named lla, the daughter of Vayu. She gave birth to a son named Utkala and a beautiful daughter too. Dhruva's brother Uttama once went to the forest for hunting. In the forest, he was killed by a Yaksa. Searching for him, Suruci entered the forest but was burnt in a forest fire. These events were predicted by Lord Visnu earlier. Hearing the news of his brother's death, Dhruva was overwhelmed with anger and lamentation. He took up his bow and arrows to punish the offenders. On a great chariot, he headed northwards to Alakāpuri, the city of the Yakşas. Dhruva blew his conch, and the sky echoed with that sound. Hearing it, the wives of the Yaksas became frightened. Unable to tolerate that sound, 130,000 Yaksas came out to attack Dhruva. Dhruva's twanging of his bow created dismay for the Yaksas. He began killing the Yaksas by shooting three arrows at a time. The Yaksas, being shot in their foreheads, anticipated defeat. But still, in a kṣatriya spirit, they praised Dhruva's feat in their minds. Intolerant, like snakes being trampled, the Yaksas shot six arrows each at Dhruva in retaliation. Finally, they attacked him, his chariot, and his charioteer with various types of weapons. Dhruva was covered by the weapons just as torrents of rain covered a mountain. But with rain, all dirt is washed from a mountain, and it shines. Similarly, Dhruva's vigor was renewed by the arrows of Yaksas. Dhruva appeared to merge among the Yaksas, just as the sun sets in the ocean. But although the sun seems to drown in the ocean, the sun is not harmed. Similarly, Dhruva had no difficulty with the Yaksas. As the Yaksas proclaimed victory, Dhruva re-emerged just as the sun appeared from the foggy mist. Unfortunately, insignificant fog cannot cover the sun. Dhruva scattered the Yaksas' weapons with his arrows, just as the wind scatters clouds in the sky. Dhruva's sharp arrows pierced Yaksas' bodies, just as thunderbolts pierce mountains. The battlefield was filled with the limbs and the ornaments of the Yaksas. The injured Yaksas fearfully fled from the battlefield. Seeing no Yaksas on the battlefield, Dhruva desired to see Alakāpuri. But thinking that the Yaksas could come back at any time, he did not enter the city. Instead, he expressed his doubts to his charioteer. Suddenly, Dhruva heard sounds as if an ocean were there. Then a dust storm appeared. Within a moment, the sky was overcast with clouds, lightning, and thunder. It rained blood, mucus, pus, stool, urine, and so on. Even human trunks began to fall. Dhruva then saw a mountain in the sky. Hailstones fell from all directions along with swords, clubs, and showers of stones. Deadly snakes, mad elephants, tigers, and lions approached to devour him. All these were the dangerous illusions created by the cruel-natured Yaksas with their demoniac powers. As Dhruva stood there being overpowered by the illusory tricks of the Yaksas, some great sages arrived there to encourage him. They prayed for Dhruva's protection, May Lord Nārāyana kill your enemies. Simply by chanting or hearing His holy name, one can easily be protected from death. By offering this prayer, the sages reminded Dhruva about the nārāyaņāstra or the weapon of Lord Nārāyana, which is capable of destroying all illusions. Hearing the encouraging words of the sages, Dhruva fixed the nārāyaņāstra on his bow. Then the illusions immediately vanished. The nārāyaņāstra fired arrows with shafts of gold and feathers of swans, that started destroying the Yaksas. The Yaksas were agitated and angrily rushed at Dhruva with raised weapons. Dhruva then cut off the limbs of the Yaksas with his arrows. Finally, in excessive anger, he started killing so many Yaksas, almost destroying their entire race. Seeing many innocent Yaksas being killed, Dhruva's grandfather Svāyambhuva Manu appeared there along with many sages. He affectionately spoke to Dhruva, Enough dear grandson, excessive anger is sinful. It has been proven that you are affectionate to your brother and aggrieved about his death. But for the fault of one Yakşa, you have killed unnecessarily many offenceless Yaksas. This act is not befitting our dynasty and cannot be appreciated by the virtuous. Manu continued, Dear Dhruva, you are so fortunate that you are already destined to achieve Vaikuntha. I am surprised by your act because you are a great devotee and are recognized by other devotees like Nārada. You are supposed to be an example for others to follow. By being tolerant and merciful to all beings, one can please the Supreme Lord and achieve His abode. The Yaksas are not the killers of your brother because nothing happens unless the Supreme Lord sanctions it. So please give up anger and take shelter from the Lord. By killing so many Yaksas, you disrespected Kuvera, who is their leader. Therefore, you must immediately pacify Kuvera with your prayers. The wrath of great people will affect our family. After thus instructing Dhruva, Manu returned to his abode. Dhruva humbly followed the instructions of Manu and restrained them from fighting. Learning that Dhruva's anger had subsided, Kuvera appeared there. Kuvera spoke, O sinless one, I am very pleased to know that you have given up your enmity, which is very difficult to avoid. Actually, you have not killed the Yaksas, nor did they kill your brother. The Supreme Lord sanctioned all these events. He is the supreme controller and the cause of all causes. So, please worship Him. Please ask a boon without hesitation. We have heard that you are constantly engaged in the loving service of Lord Vasudeva. Dhruva then asked Kuvera, My, I have unflinching faith in and remembrance of Lord Krsna. Although Kuvera was the treasurer of the devatās and could have offered immense riches to Dhruva, Dhruva did not ask him for temporary material wealth. He just desired constant remembrance of the Lord's lotus feet. Dhruva was apprehensive that Kuvera's displeasure might act as an obstacle for his remembrance of Krsna. However, Kuvera gladly offered the boon, and Dhruva returned back to his kingdom.
quotes: One shouldn't underestimate a powerful enemy., The body of every living being is a residence (or a temple) of the Lord. So unnecessary killing of others' bodies is not permitted., Anger is a great enemy on the path of spiritual life., Sometimes even devotees commit mistakes, but when other devotees correct them, they humbly rectify their mistakes.
activity: 1. Is anger always bad? Explain. 2. Recall an incident where your father guided you when you were excessively angry over someone?
lesson: A LESSON ON ANGER: With great power comes great responsibility to utilize it properly. Emotion and discrimination sometimes compete with each other. We shouldn't be carried away by temporary emotions and lose discrimination. Sometimes we give in to negative emotions like anger. Anger, when unchecked, keeps increasing uncontrollably. Thus, one harms others and oneself too. In such situations, well-wishers help us by giving good counsel. We should be open to their good advice to save ourselves from the harmful effects of excessive anger.

attributes.theme: harma (Duty & Righteousness) / Karma (Action & Consequences) / Divine Justice
attributes.time_era: Satya Yuga (Dhruva's story belongs to the earliest Yuga)

title: How Can I Go Without My Mother?
story: Emperor Dhruva ruled his kingdom with full responsibility. He worshipped the Supreme Lord Vişnu by great sacrifices and profuse charities. As a king, Dhruva was endowed with all godly qualities, respectful to the brāhmaņas, kind to the poor, protected dharma, and treated his citizens as his own children. Dhruva thus ruled the earth for 36,000 years as foretold by Lord Visnu. He then handed over the kingdom to his son and retired to Badarikāśrama. There he meditated on the Lord and entered into trance (samādhi). By his constant bhakti, he experienced continuous bliss. One day, Dhruva saw a beautiful airplane coming down from the sky, illuminating all directions like a full moon. In that plane, he saw two chief associates of Lord Visnu - blackish, youthful, four-armed, with reddish lotus eyes, holding clubs, dressed attractively, wearing helmets, necklaces, bracelets, and earrings. Seeing them, Dhruva stood up, but he forgot how to receive them properly, being astonished. He simply offered respect by folding his hands and chanting the holy names. He bowed down humbly, absorbed in thinking of Krsna's lotus feet. Those two divine personalities Nanda and Sunanda, spoke to Dhruva, Dear Dhruva, let there be good fortune unto you. When you were five years old, you pleased the Lord with your worship. We are associates of Lord Visnu, the creator of all universes. Therefore, we have come to take you to His abode. Please come and reside in Vişnu-loka, which is very rare to achieve. That highest planet is circumambulated by all planets and luminaries and is worshipable by the inhabitants of all other planets. Therefore, you are worthy to board this unique airplane sent by the Lord. Hearing these sweet words, Dhruva accepted blessings from the sages, worshipped and circumambulated the airplane, and offered his respects to Nanda and Sunanda. Then, he became as effulgent as gold and prepared to board the airplane. Drums resounded in the sky, Gandharvas sang, and devatās showered flowers. As the plane was ascending, Dhruva remembered his mother, who first instructed him in the worship of Lord Visnu. He thought, How can I go to Vaikuntha, leaving behind my poor mother? Dhruva was about to jump off the airplane. Understanding his mind, Nanda and Sunanda showed him another airplane in which Sunīti was also going to Vaikuntha. Dhruva saw many planets on his way to Dhruvaloka. Thus passing through the Bhur, Bhuvar, and Svarlokas, the airplane finally arrived at Dhruvaloka, the residence of Lord Visnu, beyond the planets of the seven sages. Thus Dhruva, who was fully Krsna conscious, attained the crest jewel of the three worlds. The entire zodiac belt circumambulates Dhruvaloka with great speed. Great devotees very much like to hear about Dhruva. By hearing the story of Dhruva, one attains great wealth, fame, longevity, heaven, Dhruvaloka, pure bhakti, good qualities, power, and respect. All sins and miseries will be diminished. Both the reciter and audience will become perfect.
quotes: What was possible for Dhruva is possible for everyone by proper training in Krishna consciousness from childhood.,  As Lord Vishnu is worshipable, so are His associates, paraphernalia, airplane, and abode., Taking inspiration from Suniti, every mother can train her child to become a devotee of the Supreme Lord., Vaikuntha is easily reached by those who are merciful, peaceful, equipoised, pure, able to please everyone and keeping friendships only with the Lord's devotees.
activity: Write three names of people to whom you are grateful. What made you so grateful to them?
lesson: A LESSON ON GRATITUDE: We can't live life on our own. We are dependent on the kindness of many people and, ultimately, God. Our parents, teachers, and many others help up in different ways in different capacities, directly or indirectly. We must remember their significant contributions to our progressive lives, be grateful to them, and try to serve them to the best of our abilities. Although one cannot completely repay the debt one owes to many great souls, a grateful person humbly attempts to do some service. Such grateful service nourishes our souls and pleases God.

title: A Boon of Misfortune
story: In the glorious dynasty of Dhruva, there was a great king named Anga. Out of his good character, he always protected his citizens like a loving father. He was always respectful to the elders and brāhmanas. His queen Sunitha was the daughter of Mrtyu, death personified. Once King Anga performed a yajña (fire sacrifice) where expert priests chanted mantras to invite the devatās to accept offerings. Although the priests properly chanted the hymns using pure paraphernalia, the devatās didn't arrive. Anga was surprised and confused. DID YOU KNOW? WHAT IS A YAJNA? Yajña genera fire sacrifice, but it is intereat. Yajña is any activity pada pure intent, to please ke His blessings. Traditionally, fire sacrifice involves making various offerings to Lord Vişnu and the devatās, whose pleasure brings peace and prosperity to the people and piety to the performer. Devotees do not appreciate sacrifices conducted for material benefits. Anga asked the sages, O brāhmaņas, kindly tell me if I have committed any offenses because of which the devātas are not accepting my offerings. The head priests replied, O King, you have been sinless in this life. But due to some sin in your previous life, you do not have a son now. That is why the devatas are not accepting your oblations. If you desire a son, you may conduct a sacrifice to please Lord Visnu. He fulfills the desires of one who worships Him sincerely. When you invite Visnu in your sacrifice, then the devatas will follow and accept your offerings. After that, the priests conducted a great sacrifice to enable King Anga to get a son. When they offered oblations to Lord Visnu, an effulgent person appeared from the sacrificial fire, carrying a golden pot of pāyasam. King Anga accepted the pāyasam, and with the permission of the priests, he offered it to his wife, Sunīthā. She drank it and became pregnant.In due course of time, Sunīthā gave birth to a son named Vena. Unfortunately, the boy grew up to be very cruel. He attained the qualities of his maternal grandfather, Mrtyu. Even as a child, he would kill his playmates mercilessly. He would unnecessarily kill innocent animals. All the citizens were frightened by his mere presence. King Anga became worried about his son Vena and tried to reform him by punishing him several times. However, Anga failed in his attempts and thus became greatly aggrieved. Disgusted with his son's character, Anga thought, Being sonless is better than having such a cruel son. A sinful son destroys one's reputation and causes endless anxiety. Anga then saw his situation from a different perspective and concluded, In fact, having a bad son is also beneficial. Because a bad son makes one realize the miserable nature of this world and helps one develop detachment. Also, ultimately one has to focus on one's eternal relationship with God. With these thoughts, King Anga decided to leave home. He entered the forest in the dead of night, giving up all attraction for kingdom and opulence. Instead, he dedicated his life to meditation and service of the Lord without any deviation and finally reached God's abode. What do you think happened next? Did cruel Vena take over, or was the kingdom rendered kingless? Read on to find out!
quotes: To discipline a mischievous child, sometimes parents need to chastise them. This is an expression of their love for the child's welfare., That which brings one close to God is a real blessing, and that which takes one away from God is a curse.
trivia: What is a YAJNA? Yajña generally means a fire sacrifice, but it is not limited to that. Yajña is any activity performed with a pure intent, to please God and invoke His blessings. Traditionally, fire sacrifice involves making various offerings to Lord Visnu and the devtas, whose pleasure brings peace and prosperity to the people and peity to the performer. Devotees do not appreciate sacrifices conducted for material benefits.
activity: 1. Do you think Anga was a good king? Why? 2. What qualities do you think make a good king? Note them down. 3. Recollect an incident in life where your positive perspective helped you become peaceful.
lesson: A Lessson On Perspective: Imagine looking around through a pair of blue glasses. Won't everything appear to be blue? That vision is called perspective. For example, we saw how king Anga earlier felt that having a bad son was a misfortune but later considered it a fortune. This is due to his change of perspective. We can see the same situation - positively or negatively, materially or spiritually. Life becomes a refreshing journey simply by molding our perspective. To respond to various situations effectively, we need to equip ourselves with a mature perspective. It is possible by associating with the wise, reading wisdom texts, and worshiping God. The power to turn a situation into a blessing or a curse now rests in your hands!

title: The Cruel Comes to Power
story: The news of King Anga's sudden departure spread throughout the kingdom. The citizens, priests, and ministers became greatly aggrieved. They searched for Anga everywhere, but no one could find him. Disappointed, they all returned to the city and informed the assembled sages. The sages, headed by Bhrgu Muni, were always concerned about the welfare of people in general. However, they could see that without a king, people would be unregulated and stoop to the level of animals. Thus, they decided to make Anga's son Vena the King. Although the ministers disagreed, the sages took permission from Queen Sunīthā and coronated Vena as the King. Vena's cruelty was well-known all over the kingdom. When the thieves heard that Vena became the King, they became afraid and hid. Naturally, Vena was ruthless, and he became even more arrogant on ascending to the throne. He considered himself the greatest and started insulting exalted personalities. Being blind and intoxicated with power and position, The traveled everywhere, causing the Earth and sky to tremble. He prohibited the brāhmaņas from performing sacrifices and forbade all spiritual activities in the kingdom. Seeing Vena's atrocities, the sages became concerned about the citizens' welfare. Being compassionate at heart, they discussed, Fearing a political crisis in the absence of a king, we crowned Vena as the King. Naturally, he is cruel, and by becoming the king, he turned out to be an enemy of the citizens. The people are in danger from both sides due to an irresponsible king and the thieves. It is like a log with fire blazing at both ends. We should try to counsel Vena. If he does not accept our advice, we shall burn that sinner to ashes with our powers. Supporting this wicked King is like maintaining a poisonous snake with milk. Having thus decided, the sages approached Vena. Concealing their anger, they tried to pacify him with sweet words. They said, Dear King, please hear us attentively, for our good advice will surely benefit you. By acting according to dharma, you will be freed from all miseries and attain liberation. By obstructing the worship of Lord Visnu and the devatas, you will spoil the spiritual lives of your citizens and will surely fall from your position. A pious king is supposed to protect the citizens from enemies and facilitate the worship of Lord Visnu. When the Lord and the devatās are satisfied, you will attain all success and prosperity. Although the sages spoke appropriate words with good intentions, Verna replied very arrogantly, I am the King and the real God and master of all the citizens. Since you all are unchaste, you desire to worship Visnu and the devatās instead of me. You can't be happy in this life or the next. The King is the reservoir of all the devatās. Vişnu, Brahmā, Śiva and all the devatās reside in king's body. So, you better worship me with all your offerings and sacrifices. Only I can enjoy all the sacrificial offerings. In this way, Vena foolishly spoke some false philosophy considering himself God and disregarded Lord Visnu. Being so sinful, he deviated from the right path. He thought himself very learned and insulted the merciful sages who had made him king. Hearing Vena's disrespectful words and considering his sinful mentality, the sages became enraged and shouted, Kill him! Kill him! He is the most heinous and impudent person who disregards Lord Visnu. If he lives, he will turn the whole world to ashes. Therefore, he does not deserve to sit on the throne. Then the sages killed shameless Vena simply by their angry words, without any weapons. After the sages left, Vena's mother, Sunīthā, being aggrieved, preserved Vena's dead body with special ingredients and mantras. But what happened to the kingless state? After so much chaos, there isn't any answer to the search for a suitable king. Will thieves rule the general public? Will the sages help in some way, or will they neglect the situation? Read on to find out!
quotes: Being proud of one's power and position causes one's downfall., Absorption in spiritual life doesn't make one indifferent to others' suffering but makes one compassionate., A king's responsibility is not just to protect the citizens physically but also to ensure that spiritual culture is followed in the kingdom., An arrogant person not only disrespects God but also considers himself God. Such fools will sooner or later reap the results of their attitudes and activities., False pride makes one disrespectful to great personalities., While humility attracts the grace of great souls, pride attracts their curses.
activity: 1. Do you remember a situation when you became excessively proud? What were you proud of? 2. Share the stories of two people from the Bhagavatam who disrespected great personalities and ended up in trouble. 3. How do you think a culture of respect would benefit everyone? 4. Was pride the cause of the ten-headed Ravaea's downfall too? Try recollecting.
lesson: A Lessson On Concern: Think of how much your mother is concerned about your wellbeing! In this story, the brahmaeas, although uninterested in political matters, out of great concern for people in general, advised Vena on how a king should rule. Sometimes when leaders become corrupt and trouble their subjects, the sages responsibly step in to rectify the situation. It is they who impart wisdom and educate people in morality and spirituality. Although kindhearted, they may chastise the wrongdoers to protect the innocent. Exactly what a loving mother would do out of concern! We can also show genuine concern for our family, friends and society to the best of our capacity, without being indifferent towards them.

title: The Mystical Birth of a King
story: The sages killed cruel Vena for the benefit of the citizens. However, after Vena's death, thieves in the kingdom flourished. They took advantage of a kingless state and tormented innocent people who thus suffered greatly. One day, the sages assembled at the banks of River Sarasvatī to discuss spiritual subjects. Considering the country's worsening situation, they thought to themselves, Although we brāhmaņas are supposed to be peaceful and equipoised, we shouldn't be neglectful to people in general. Such neglect will diminish our spiritual power just as the water kept in a cracked pot leaks out. Although the powerful sages could subdue the thieves, they considered it improper. They felt that the solution to the problem is not just punishing the thieves but appointing an able king who punishes them and protects the people. Thus, the sages desired to restore the pure dynasty of King Anga, who was a descendant of bruva. Although vena was born in such a glorious dynasty, he turned wicked by acquiring the qualities of his maternal grandfather Mrtyu, death personified. Therefore, the sages decided to produce another body from the carefully preserved dead body of Vena by using their powers. The sages then approached Vena's mother, Sunīthā, and brought out the dead body of Vena. They churned the thighs of Vena's body in a specific method, and from that a devilish dwarf-like person appeared. He was blackish and short with large jaws, a flat nose, reddish eyes, and copper-colored hair. His name was Bāhuka, a product of the impure portion of Vena's body. Taking over the terrible sins of Vena on being born, Bāhuka later fathered an uncivilized tribal race called the Naisādas. His descendants always reside in hills and forests, engaging in sinful activities. Vena's body was produced from both Anga and Sunīthā. The sages separated the impure portion of Vena's body resulting from Sunīthā in the form of degraded Bahuka. The pure portion of Vena's body, resulting from saintly Anga, would give birth to a noble king. The sages then churned the two arms of Vena's body from which a celestial male and female appeared. The sages were pleased and said, This divine couple have appeared as incarnations of Lakṣmī and Närāyana. The effulgent man is Prthu, an expansion of Lord Visnu. He will be the foremost among kings because he has the power to maintain the whole world. That beautiful queen's name is Arci, an expansion of Goddess Laksmi. The brahmaņas praised King Prthu, the Gandharvas sang His glories, the Siddhas showered flowers, and the Apsaras danced in ecstasy. Conches, bugles, drums, and kettledrums were played joyfully in the  outer space. Lord Brahmā also arrived there along with the devatās. Seeing the special and auspicious marks on the body of King Prthu, Brahmā concluded that Prthu was an incarnation of the Lord. The brahmaņas then arranged for King Prthu's coronation as the King. People collected different paraphernalia for the ceremony. King Prthu was exquisitely dressed and sat on the throne with his well-ornamented wife, Arci. They appeared as bright as rare golden pearls. Various personalities generously offered precious gifts to King Prthu. Kuvera, the treasurer of the devatās, presented a gleaming royal throne made of pure gold. Varuna, the God of oceans, offered a gigantic umbrella as effulgent as the moon. Vayu, the wind-god gif two enormous camara fans. Indra, the King of heaven, prese a magnificent crown. Yama, the Lord of death, presented a sters punishing rod to discipline the miscreants. Brahmä gave him an armor Sarasvati offered a divine necklace studded with gemstones. Lond Hari gifted a potent Sudarśana cakra. Laksmi bestowed imperishab opulence. Lord Śiva presented an exquisite sword marked with ten moons. Durga gifted a shield marked with hundred moons. Soma the moon god, gave powerful horses. Viśvakarma offered a beautiful chariot. Agni, the fire god, gave a special bow. Sürya, the sun god, offered him arrows as brilliant as sunshine. Bhūmi presented magical flying shoes. The sages offered profuse blessings. All the devatas constantly showered fragrant flowers. Professional singers and bards offered prayers and praises to King Prthu. Prthu smiled and spoke, You are praising me extraordinarily for having many good qualities. But I haven't yet portrayed these qualities. If I don't display these qualities in the future, your words will be as good as a lie. So, it is better to praise someone who has already displayed these good qualities. In such great assemblies, the Supreme Lord Vişnu must be glorified, not a low human like me. The bards were very pleased with the humility of King Prthu. They continued to praise his qualities of compassion, courage, righteousness ability to protect citizens, truthfulness, respect, detachment, devotion, etc. Humble Prthu then offered gifts to the bards, who then departed happily. Prthu then began ruling the kingdom. How did Prthu restore the prosperity of the kingdom? Was everything peaceful and harmonious forever? Read on to know!
quotes: We need to understand and address the root cause of the problem instead of just dealing with the symptoms of the problem., An incarnation of God has some striking features; His advent is mentioned in the scriptures. Therefore, one shouldn't blindly accept anyone as an incarnation., Offering gifts is an expression of love and respect that sweetens relationships., Unless a king is endowed with good character, he cannot effectively rule and protect his citizens.
activity: 1. What gifts gave you the greatest happiness so far? Who gave it to you? What gift would you like to offer that person(s) in return? 2. Isn't it difficult to refuse praise? Share your thoughts. 3. Go and praise someone in your family who you find humble. Note their response. 4. Recall two incidents where you humbly denied praise despite doing something good and accepted praise without doing much.
lesson: A Lesson On Humility: Don't you like being praised? Enjoying praise is easy, but refusing is difficult, isn't it? We feel encouraged when someone appreciates us, yet it's possible that we can become proud of undue praise. The weapon that helps us counteract the ill effects of pride is humility. Despite being qualified, a humble person denies praise. Accepting glorification without any qualification is inappropriate. While proud leaders like Vena demand respect like Prthu deny respect despite being qualified. Humble people know that all they have attained is due to the mercy of the Lord. So they are not falsely proud of their achievements but acknowledge the grace of God and remain His humble servants.

title: Chasing Goddess Earth
story: One day the citizens of King Prthu approached him with sad faces and said, Dear King, we are starving and suffering from great hunger due to insufficient food grains. Please help us! King Prthu thought on their complaint for a long time and finally came to the conclusion that mother Earth was not providing sufficient food grains. Annoyed with this, King Prthu took up his bow and aimed an arrow at the goddess of Earth. Trembling with fear, she took the form of a cow and ran away like a deer pursued by a hunter. Powerful Prthu started chasing the cow-shaped Earth wherever she fled, even in outer space. Finally, the Earth turned to Prthu in helplessness and said, O King, being the knower of dharma, you are meant to offer shelter and protection to all living beings. I have not committed any offenses. How can a merciful person like you attempt to kill a sinless woman like me? King Prthu said, O Earth, you claim to be sinless, but your mistake is that you have not produced sufficient food grains for my citizens. Therefore, punishing such an offender is appropriate. You have hidden all the seeds of plants within you. A king is supposed to kill such a merciless person. The Earth could understand that Prthu Mahārāja was an empowered incarnation of Lord Visnu. She spoke with folded hands to pacify him, Please control your anger and hear me patiently. Yes, I had hidden the seeds and grains, because materialistic people use all my seeds, herbs, and grains for their selfish purposes. The King before you (Vena) didn't properly protect me. He disrespected me by stopping all the sacrifices and spreading adharma everywhere. After his death, the kingdom was filled with thieves. Therefore, I withheld all the resources within me so that I can provide them back when righteous kings like you start ruling. The Earth continued, Now because a righteous person like you has become the king, I am ready to provide all the grains, seeds, and all other natural resources for your kingdom. After hearing the words of the Earth, King Prthu became very pleased. As promised, the Earth generously provided all her resources to everyone. Therefore, King Prthu was very satisfied with the Earth and developed a fatherly affection towards her. After this, Prthu flattened the Earth by breaking up the hills with his bow. He created suitable houses for them and founded many villages, towns, cities, forts, mines, etc. Earlier people lived in an unorganized manner, but Prthu made town and city planning in an organized way. Prthu was as like a good father to all the citizens. He conducted many sacrifices for their welfare and prosperity. But the nature of this world is that although one tries to do good to everyone, some envious people try to create problems. What problem did Prthu encounter? Read the next chapter to know.
quotes: A good leader must be a good listener and thinker. Only then can he address problems effectively., Children, women, cows, brahmanas, and old people should always be protected. Therefore, one should not harm them in any way., Just as the Lord reserves the right not to reveal Himself to unqualified people, the Earth reserves the right not to provide her resources to sinful people.
activity: 1. Pick up your photo album. Look at the scenic places you have visited and thank mother Earth for providing them for you. 2. Get some juicy fruits, and appreciate the love of mother Earth as you see, touch and savor them. 3. Can you resolve to use less plastic and more public transport to save mother Earth?
lesson: A Lesson On Harmony: The planet Earth is the mother of all living beings. She happily provides food, shelter, and all-natural resources needed by all life forms. Isn't it our duty to take care of such a loving mother? What is painful to her is when human beings take to sinful attitudes and activities. Instead of exploiting the resources of Earth and distributing other living beings, we need to live in harmony with her, and utilize her resources for our sustenance and service to the Lord. If we do so, Mother Earth will give us all prosperity. It is completely up to her to make available or withhold her resources, depending on how pure or sinful we are. All in all, let us pledge to live in harmony with mother Earth today!

title: One Short of A Century!
story: Once, King Prthu intended to perform one hundred sacrifices at a place called Brahmāvarta, where the holy River Sarasvati flowed. Lord Vişnu, Brahmā, Śiva, the devatās, and many sages were present in those sacrifices. Prthu thus successfully completed ninety-nine sacrifices and was about to begin hundredth one. Indra, the King of heaven, could not tolerate Prthu's success. Indra was called śata-kratu because he had performed a hundred sacrifices to attain his post. Seeing Prthu breaking his record now, Indra became very envious. He felt insecure that Prthu would outdo him. So, he planned to impede Prthu's sacrifice, although he was aware that a sacrifice is the worship of Lord Visnu, and should not be disrupted. When Prthu was performing the hundredth sacrifice, Indra appeared there dressed up like a noble sādhu. He cunningly stole the sacrificial horse which was an essential part of the sacrifice. Sage Atri noticed this and hurriedly informed Prthu's son to catch and the thief. Indra fled with the horse through the sky in great haste. Seeing Indra in the dress of a sannyāsī, with matted locks and a body smeared in ashes, Prthu's son did not release his arrows. But Atri Muni encouraged Prthu's son to kill Indra. Indra then gave up his fake dress and the horse and disappeared from that spot. Prthu's son then brought the horseback to the sacrificial arena. Seeing this great act, the sages named him Vijitāśva, he who has won the horse. Indra again came in the form of another sannyāsi. Using his mystical powers, he created dense darkness in the sacrificial arena and again shamelessly stole the horse. Vijitāśva chased Indra again, but seeing Indra in the dress of a sannyāsī, carrying a staff with a skull on top, Vijitāśva did not kill him. Again, ordered by Atri, Vijitāśva angrily aimed an arrow to kill Indra. Indra gave up that horse and his false dress upon seeing this and became invisible. Vijitāśva brought back the horse once again. Whatever different forms Indra accepted for stealing the horse misguided common people. Some foolish people who saw this started adopting the dresses of sannyāsīs like Indra. They thought that the sannyāsa dress was an excellent way to escape punishment for theft or other such crimes. Thus, Indra irresponsibly misled the people. Seeing Indra repeatedly disrupting his sacrifice, Prthu angrily took up his bow to kill Indra. The priests then requested Prthu, O great soul, please don't kill Indra. We will offer him into the sacrificial fire by the power of our mantras. Then the priests prepared to offer oblations into the fire to kill Indra. At that moment, Lord Brahmā appeared there and forbade them to do so. Lord priests, Brahmā told You should the not kill stubborn Indra. He has already disrupted dharma by attempting to hinder the sacrifice. If you oppose him more, he will further misuse his power and introduce many other false religious systems. Brahma then turned to Prthu and said, Being a sensible king, it is better that you stop your hundredth sacrifice to prevent the spread of adharma by Indra. Instead of stopping stubborn Indra, who wouldn't listen to good advice, elderly Brahmā suggested Prthu stop the sacrifice. Because Prthu was more mature, responsible, flexible, and submissive, he immediately stopped his hundredth sacrifice. He understood Brahmā's concern for people in general. By Brahmā's blessings, Prthu's fame exceeded that of Indra, although he performed only ninety-nine sacrifices. Also, we see that Brahmā desired a transformation in Indra and not his death. After that, Lord Visnu appeared in the sacrificial arena, along with Indra. Prthu became very happy to see his beloved Lord. The Lord said, My dear Prthu, I am very pleased with you. Here is Indra, who has come here seeking forgiveness from you. Please forgive him. Ashamed of his sin, Indra fell at Prthu's feet with a regretful heart. Prthu embraced Indra and wholeheartedly forgave him. Lord Visnu was satisfied with Prthu. Seeing the Lord's graceful form, Prthu's eyes were filled with tears and his voice choked up in ecstasy. The Lord could not depart, being captivated by Prthu's devotion. His feet generally do not touch the Earth. But out of affection for Prthu, He touched the Earth and placed His hand on Garuda as if to prevent Himself from losing his balance. Wiping his tears, Prthu offered his prayers, O Lord, You are the best giver of boons. But I don't ask You for heaven or liberation. Instead, please give me a million ears to hear Your wonderful pastimes from Your devotees. I only desire to serve You like Mother Lakṣmī. I don't exactly know what to ask for. Therefore, please give me whatever You think is best for me, just like a father acts for the benefit of his child. Then Lord Visnu told Prthu, May you have bhakti unto Me for nothing is more beneficial than that. Having thus blessed Prthu, the Lord departed. All in all, Prthu scored 99, while Indra scored 100. Prthu's flexibility submissiveness, detachment, responsibility, forgiveness, and the blessings he received from Brahma and Lord Visnu - all together are hundreds of times greater than a hundred sacrifices. On another occasion, Prthu conducted another sacrifice attended by great sages and devatās. In that great assembly, Prthu spoke about God's unlimited mercy and how we should perform bhakti to please Him. In this manner, King Prthu thus ruled his kingdom in an exemplary manner. Although he was amidst great opulence and comforts, he was fixed up in his bhakti. As a result, his reputation was widespread throughout the universe. Eventually, Prthu handed over the kingdom to his sons and retired to the forest to worship the Supreme Lord Krsna. With his uninterrupted and determined efforts he finally reached the spiritual world. What happened to King Prthu's kingdom after he left? Did it perish!? Flip forward to find out!
quotes: Unwanted qualities like envy and pride exist even in devatas, who thus sometimes commit sins knowingly., A stubborn person doesn't restrain from committing a mistake despite repeated failures. On the contrary, if such determination is employed in good activities, one is benefitted a lot., Leaders must behave responsibly, knowing that their activities impact innocent people., A mature leader tries to resolve conflicts without rejecting the wrongdoer but reforming him. Hate the sin, not the sinner., Forgiveness is a quality of those who are advanced in spiritual wisdom., One's glory depends not on the size of one's accomplishments but on the quality of one's character.
activity: 1. Sacrifice is a means of worshiping Lord Vishnu. Indra performed 100 sacrifices, and Prthu performed only 99. So who do you think won the heart of Vishnu, and why? 2. How does this story inspire you to appreciate other's success and not envy them? 3. Enlist two ways how you can increase your flexibility.
lesson: A LESSON ON FLEXIBILITY: In this story, King Prthu was flexible and prioritized higher principles and the welfare of people over a completing hundred sacrifices. But King Indra was too rigid in fulfilling his selfish purposes, despite repeated failures and harm to others. Flexible people win more trust from their seniors than those who are stubborn. Although sometimes they are seen as weak for giving up their ambitions, it is they who are truly strong. Defeat lies in being rigid to serve one's selfish purpose, while victory lies in compromising for a higher purpose!, A LESSON ON COMPETITION: Do you enjoy competing with your friends? Or do you just feel it is necessary to prove yourself or outsmart someone? A healthy competitive spirit that results in improving our performance is good. But an unhealthy competition inspired by envy is harmful to oneself and others. Påthu never intended to compete with Indra, but Indra felt insecure seeing Prthu's success. One shouldn't unnecessarily compete with others in a spirit of passion and intolerance towards their success. An insecure person like Indra cannot digest others' success and causes impediments in their efforts. On the contrary, one who has good character inspires, encourages, and helps others attain success and wholeheartedly appreciates their success.

title: Worship Underwater
story: After Prthu's retirement, his eldest son Vijitāśva became the King. He gave his younger brothers different parts of the kingdom out of love. Vijitāśva considered his kingly duties, like collecting taxes and punishing people, very painful. So, he gave up his kingly position on the pretext of performing a long sacrifice. He thus worshipped the Supreme Lord Visnu in His form called Hamsävatara (the Swan incarnation) and attained the Lord's abode. Vijitāśva's son named Havirdhāna then became the King. He had six sons. The eldest son was Prācīnabarhi, an expert in performing sacrifices and yoga. He was very much attached to conducting several sacrifices and so covered the entire earth with kuśa grass. On the order of Brahmā, Prācīnabarhi married Śatadruti, the beautiful daughter of the ocean god. They gave birth to ten virtuous sons together called the Pracetās. Prācīnabarhi ordered his sons to enter married life, beget children and rule the kingdom. As a preparation to take up the serious responsibilities as husbands, fathers, and rulers, he had sent them to the forest to perform devotional austerities to please Lord Vasudeva (Krsna). Accepting their father's instructions submissively, the Pracetas travelling towards the west, reached a dense forest, where they saw a huge, beautiful lake with blooming lotuses. The atmosphere around the lake was so festive with the chirping of sweet-sounding birds, accompanied by gentle cool breezes. There were also trees, creepers and humming bees. The Pracetās also heard attractive celestial songs and became amazed. To their surprise, the Pracetās saw magnificent Lord Śiva emerging from that lake along with his wonderful associates. The ten princes immediately offered obeisances to Lord Śiva out of great respect. Lord Śiva then mercifully blessed the Pracetās and said, O princes, let there be good fortune unto you. I am very pleased with your excellent etiquette and knowledge. I am granting you special mercy for you to worship Lord Vāsudeva. Anyone who worships Vāsudeva with devotion is very dear to me. I love devotees like you as much as I love the Lord Himself. The devotees also consider me as dear to them as the Lord Himself. Let me teach you an auspicious and divine prayer called the Rudra-gīta. By chanting this song, you will receive the mercy of Lord Vasudeva. With a joyful heart, Lord Śiva then sang the Rudra-gīta. The Pracetas heard him very attentively with folded hands. In the beautiful Rudra-gīta, there were prayers offered to various divine forms of Lord Krsna. Rudra-gīta include praises of the Lord's powers, expressions of pure devotion, and requests for protection. It also describes the most enchanting form of Lord Krsna, who is the collection of all beauties. Lord Śiva declared that the most favorable method for everyone to easily attain the kingdom of God is the all-auspicious path of bhakti unto Lord Krsna. Having thus taught the Rudra-gita to the Pracetās, Lord Siva instructed them, Please chant this Rudra-gita prayer wholeheartedly regularly. Meditate on Lord Visnu and worship Him with devotion. Lord Brahmā had said that this prayer destroys ignorance and enables one to become a devotee of the Lord quickly. Hearing Rudra-gita early in the morning and letting others hear it frees one from all miseries Recite these prayers, and thus you will surely attain Lord Visnu's mercy. Lord Siva then departed. The Pracetās submissively and sincerely followed the instructions of their guru, Lord Śiva. Exhibiting complete dedication, they entered the sea and meditated on Lord Visnu while chanting the Rudra-gīta for ten thousand long years in the water. Thus, they eventually attained the darśana of Lord Visnu, who offered them profuse blessings and benedictions. Hold on... are we missing someone? Yes! Prācīnibarhi, the father of the Pracetās. Was he worried that his sons hadn't returned? What was he doing in the absence of his sons? Read on to find out!
quotes: Austerity means to accept some inconvenience upon oneself for a higher purpose voluntarily. Austerities ensure the holistic development of one's personality with internal maturity and external tolerance., A compassionate devotee guides new devotees in bhakti even without being asked., A sincere recipient of true knowledge passes it on to others without any adulteration., By sincerely following the guru's instructions with dedication, one can attain the mercy of the Lord.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? WHOM DOES LORD SIVA FAVOR? Lord Siva is sometimes seen giving boons to materialistic people or demons like Rävaņa, Bāņāsura, Vrkāsura, and so on. But Śiva is not impressed with them, nor does he intend to favor them. So how can a demoniac person please a noble personality like Śiva? Śiva offers boons to demons only as a formality in response to their austerities. However, those boons ultimately lead to the destruction of the demons in the hands of Vişņu, Krsna, or Rama. Thus, the benedictions of Lord Siva generally end up glorifying Lord Vişnu as the ultimate protector. Śiva, therefore, takes pleasure in praising his beloved Lord Vişņu. One who worships Lord Vişnu or Krsna is called a Vaisnava. Śrīmad Bhagavatam says that Lord Śiva is the foremost among all the Vaisnavas (vaişņavānām yathā śambhu). Thus, Śiva is very favorable to all the devotees of Lord Visņu and voluntarily guides them in vişnu-bhakti, just as he did in the case of the Pracetās.
activity: 1. What did you learn from the qualities of Lord Siva, who guided the Pracetas voluntarily?, 2. Were the Pracetas obedient sons? Why do you think so?, 3. What is your favorite bhajan? Why? Can you explain its meaning to your friend?, 4. Try recollecting an instance when you obeyed the instructions of your parents or teachers. Did it help?
lesson: A LESSON ON SINCERITY: A genuine teacher desires the success of the students. Isn't it? Reciprocally, a sincere student is submissive to such a teacher's instructions and grateful for the guidance received. Good students show submissiveness in front of the teacher and follow the teacher's advice even in their absence. Such qualities in teachers and students are crucial in spiritual life. The secret of success in spiritual life is in sincerely following the instructions of a guru and thus attaining the Lord's mercy. This is what has happened in the life of the Pracetas.

title: Movie In The Sky
story: While the Pracetãs were in the forest worshiping the Lord, their father, Prācīnibarhi, was engrossed in performing various fire sacrifices. Unfortunately, in those sacrifices, many animals were being killed. The great sage Narada became compassionate on the animals and the ignorant King as well. He felt that a descendant of Dhruva's glorious dynasty shouldn't be involved in such material activities. So he decided to meet Prācīnabarhi and educate him. Nārada Muni went to Prācīnibarhi and asked, What do you desire to achieve by these sacrifices? You can't attain enduring happiness or avoid miseries by these sacrifices! Prācīnibarhi was shaken and said submissively, O great sage, my intelligence is very poor. Please enlighten me with the right knowledge. Nārada Muni then created a mystic vision in the sky for Prācīnibarhi and said, O King, please see those animals you have mercilessly sacrificed. They all are awaiting your death, to pierce your body with deadly iron horns. Prācīnibarhi was surprised. Nārada Muni then narrated a symbolic story of a mythical character called Purañjana: King Purañjana lived in a city of nine gates. He represents a living being who dwells within a body with nine holes (mouth, ears, eyes and so on). He would kill innocent animals in the forest by hunting. He was too engrossed with materialistic affairs and didn't take interest in spiritual life. Eventually he died while thinking of his wife. Then the soldiers of Yamarāja, the lord of death, dragged him to hell. After undergoing hellish suffering, he was born as a woman. In this manner, if a person is too absorbed in materialistic activities due to material desires, one has to take birth again and again in various species. The only way to stop this cycle of birth and death is to clean the mind from all material desires. The best way to purify the mind is to perform bhakti unto Lord Krsna under the guidance of a guru. Bhakti is very joyful and takes us to the eternal world of God. Narada Muni then narrated another story, Once a deer was grazing on grass and enjoying with his wife in a serene garden filled with fragrant flowers. The deer relished the songs of the bumblebees swarming around in the garden. But, in his great joy, the deer didn't notice a hungry tiger coming in front of him. Also, a hunter was hiding behind a tree to shoot the deer with his arrows. But the deer didn't notice these two dangers, absorbed in his enjoyment. Similarly, a materialistic person becomes absorbed in temporary enjoyment and doesn't notice the passage of time (tiger) and the Lord of death (hunter) standing behind. In short, Narada Muni indicated to Pracinabarhi that he was neglecting his spiritual by being too absorbed in material activities, Narada for saving him from hellish life. Inspired Prancinabarhi was determined to leave the kingdom and exclusively worship the Lord. At that time, his sons, the Pracetās, were still in the forest, but he didn't wait for their return. He ordered his ministers to inform his sons to protect the citizens. He wanted to take shelter of Lord Krsna without any further delay. So, he departed for a place called Kapilāśrama and constantly worshiped Lord Krsna and eventually reached the spiritual world. Well, Prancīnabarhi attained a spiritual destination, but what happened to his sons, the Pracetās, performing austerities in the forest? Jump ahead to discover!
