quotes: By killing innocent animals, one has to suffer serious reactions in the future, although one may seem unaffected in the present., Bhakti-yoga is the way to end our miseries in this world and reach the Lord for an eternal life., One must use one's precious time very carefully. Even a single moment that has passed won't come back.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? ANIMAL SACRIFICES In the previous yugas, old animals like a horse or a cow were sacrificed as a part of a yajña, so that the sacrificial animal would be elevated to human life by the power of mantras chanted by pure brāhmaņas. Such scarifies conducted benefit the performer, the common people, and even the animal. However, if there is a slight discrepancy in the yajña, the animal wouldn't get a human life, and the performer would incur immense sin instead of piety. In in the present age of Kali-yuga, due to the lack of such powerful brāhmaņas, animal sacrifices are completely prohibited. The recommended sacrifice for this age is hari-nāma-sańkīrtana, or the process of chanting the holy names of Lord Hari.
activity: 1. Do you think Narada Muni gave good advice to Prancinabarhi? Why?, 2. Why should one abstain from non-vegetarian food? What are your thoughts?, 3. How does spiritual life make one sensitive towards other living beings?
lesson: A LESSON ON NON-VIOLENCE: Violence is not just to kill or harm the physical bodies of other people. To unnecessarily cause distress to others' minds by one's words or actions is also violence. Scriptures and saints prohibit violence, and teach us to be kind towards all living beings. One should be non-violent not only towards human beings, but towards animals too. Just as we are pained by others' violence towards us, others also feel pain when we are violent. Knowing this, noble people treat all living beings with empathy and kindness. However, sometimes violence is necessary to punish vicious people and to establish dharma. Especially kñatriyas use violence as a tool to teach a lesson to the miscreants and protect the innocent.

title: The Power of Unity
story: Being pleased with the ten-thousand years long worship of the Pracetas, Lord Visnu mercifully appeared before them. He manifested His graceful eight-handed form on the back of Garuda, His eternal eagle carrier. With His soothing beauty, He enchanted their eyes and completely satisfied their hearts. He wore dazzling yellow garments, a fragrant garland, a dazzling crown, and the Kaustubha-mani necklace. He held various magnificent weapons in His eight hands. With a compassionate glance, Lord Visnu blessed the Pracetas and said, My dear princes, I bestow all good fortune upon you. I am very pleased with Your friendly dealings and sincerity in bhakti. Your cooperation and unity in devotion unto Me has completely captivated My heart. You may ask any benediction from Me. Lord Visnu generously gave the Pracetas some boons even without asking. He said, Those who remember you every evening will also develop close friendships with their brothers and all living beings. Those who glorify Me with the Rudra-gīta prayers will receive My benedictions. Then the Lord instructed them to marry a beautiful girl called Marisa, who was like the daughter of the trees. He said, All of you, Pracetās, please marry her because your natures are very similar to hers. She is very obedient, just as you all are obedient to your father. Therefore, she should be the wife of all of you. By my blessings you will have a famous son whose progeny will fill the three worlds. Although it's quite unusual for a girl marry multiple husbands, the Lord's direct blessings made it possible. Only in some exceptional cases can a girl marry multiple husbands, provided she can treat all her husbands equally. One such example was Draupadi, who married the five Pandavas. Lord Visnu continued, Dear Pracetās, you can enjoy all facilities of this world and heaven with full bodily strength for one million celestial years. Then you will develop pure devotion unto Me and surely attain Me after leaving this world. Overwhelmed by the Lord's mercy, the Pracetas offered their heartfelt prayers unto Him in a faltering voice. They said, O Lord, You relieve all the distresses of Your devotees. We just want to chant Your all-auspicious name and hear Your unlimited pastimes life after life. We only desire Your satisfaction. What further benediction may we ask? We don't even want liberation. A bee approaching a pārijāta tree cannot leave it because it finds an abundance of honey there. Similarly, we cannot leave Your shelter, for it provides endless spiritual bliss. The Pracetas recollected that it was only by Lord Śiva's mercy that they were able to get Lord Vişnu's grace. With their hearts filled with gratitude for Siva, they spoke to Visnu, O Lord, even a moment's association of a pure devotee cannot be compared to heavenly happiness or even liberation. We can see You now having been empowered by a brief association with Lord Śiva, who taught us the Rudra-gīta. Your devotees always discuss Your topics, and in their discussions, You are personally present with them. All we want is their association. The Lord granted the desires of the Pracetās and departed from there, although their eyes were not yet completely satiated seeing Him. The Pracetas then came out of the sea and discovered something very astonishing. The next chapter reveals that! So, delve in right away!
quotes: Real unity can be achieved by keeping the service and satisfaction of God in the center.,  Loving relationships and cooperation amongst devotees greatly please the Lord.,  When we glorify the good qualities of the Lord and His devotees, we also develop those qualities., A devotee is not interested in wealth. But the Lord sometimes gives wealth if He is confident that it doesn't distract His devotees from bhakti., A devotee derives great satisfaction in hearing about the Lord and serving Him., The association of pure-hearted devotees is the greatest blessing one can have in this universe.
activity: 1. Do all your friends behave similarly? If not, do you still like being with them?, 2. If you had the opportunity of asking for a boon from the Lord, what would it be?, 3. Try eating with only one finger. Now eat using all five fingers. Experience the strength in unity.
lesson: A LESSON ON UNITY: Have you seen how a team of footballers works as ane unit despite being different individuals to win match? This spirit of oneness that binds diverse people for a noble cause is called unity. No two human beings are alike in all aspects. We differ in forms, desires, tastes, working styles, etc. This diversity in human society makes it beautiful. We need to respect and love each other despite our differences. When siblings are friendly and stay united, the parents become pleased. Similarly, when all the living beings cooperatively co-exist, the Lord, their Supreme Father, becomes happy. This unity in diversity and loving relationships attract God's blessings.

attributes.story_setting: Celestial Realm (Vaikuntha) & Sacred Forest (where the Pracetas meditated)

title: When Devotees Become Angry
story: After Lord Visnu departed, the Pracetas came out of the sea. To their surprise, they saw tall trees everywhere. When they were worshiping the Lord in the water, their father, Prācīnabarhi, had retired from the kingdom. Because there was no king to see to the management of the kingdom, the Earth became overgrown with trees. When too many trees grow everywhere, there won't be sufficient land for agriculture. The Pracetās became outraged. They wanted to clear the Earth of unnecessary trees to produce food grains. So they generated fire and wind from their mouths and started burning all the trees. Soma, the moon god, felt sympathy for the trees and immediately appeared there and spoke to the Pracetas, Control your intense anger! Please do not kill these poor trees. They are needed to maintain your citizens because they provide fruits and other eatables to everyone Let the remaining trees be happy. As the Lord had instructed you, accept this girl Mārisā as your wife. Lord Brahmā also appeared there to pacify the Pracetās and advised them to marry Mārisā. The Pracetās then married Mārisā and ruled the kingdom righteously. Daksa was born as their son. This was the same Daksa who had offended Lord Śiva in his previous life. After ruling the kingdom for thousands of years, the Pracetas left their wife Mārisā in the care of their son Daksa and retired. After that, they all went to the seashore, worshiped the Lord, and constantly meditated upon Him. Once, Narada Muni came came to see the Pracetās. They respectfully offered a seat to Nārada Muni and inquired from him, O great sage, it is our great fortune to see you. Your movements are like that of the sun which drives away all fear and the darkness of night. But, unfortunately, because of ruling the kingdom for a long time, we almost forgot the spiritual teachings of Lord Śiva and Lord Visnu. Therefore, kindly enlighten us in spiritual knowledge. Nārada Muni replied, Dear Pracetās, one's birth, activities, life-span, mind, and words are perfected by bhakti unto Lord Krsna. For example, watering the root of a tree, its trunk, branches, twigs, and everything else gets energized. But just by sprinkling water on the branches and leaves, the plant wouldn't survive without watering the root. Likewise, all the senses and bodily limbs are nourished by supplying food to the stomach. Similarly, by worshiping the Supreme Lord Krsna, all the devatās are satisfied. The Lord is one, yet He mercifully becomes the Supersoul of all living beings. Therefore, perform unalloyed bhakti unto Him. Having thus enlightened the Pracetās, Narada Muni departed. Hearing from Narada the glories of the Lord, the Pracetās continued to worship Him with intense devotion, and finally attained His abode. What happened to the Pracetās' kingdom after their departure? Did their son Daksa rule it? Or did it decay and disappear? Unfold the mystery on the next page!
quotes: Sometimes, even devotees become angry. But they humbly rectify themselves and restrain their anger upon good advice.
activity: 1. Can you share the favorite advice you received from your parents?, 2. Recollect an instance when you popped in some candies despite the doctor's advice! Share what happened next., 3. Try recollecting a yatra or a popular tourist spot you visited. Did you have a tour guide show you around?
lesson: A LESSON ON GUIDANCE: Guidance from wise people is required in every walk of life. Especially in spiritual life, one needs guidance from mature devotees at all stages. The Pracetas were guided by Lord Shiva when they just began to perform bhakti. They were guided by Lord Brahma and the moon god when they became outraged. Narada Muni guided them after their retirement. This guidance from great people is beneficial and essential in life. One shouldn't be overconfident and think that one can lead life independently. Instead, one should seek advice from the wise by humbly serving them and asking relevant questions.

attributes.main_character_type: Royal Family Member (Pracetas, sons of King Prācīnabarhi)

title: The Second Sun
story: Svāyambhuva Manu, the son of Brahma, had two sons namely Uttānapāda and Priyavrata. In the dynasty of Uttānapāda there were several great kings like Dhruva, Anga, Prthu, and the Pracetas. The son of the Pracetas was Daksa. After the Pracetās retired, Daksa didn't take charge of the kingdom but went to perform austerities to please Lord Visnu. So, Svāyambhuva Manu became concerned about the kingdom. Seeing no alternative, Manu wanted his other son Priyavrata to take charge of the kingdom. But at that time, Priyavrata was in the forest. He had no desire to marry or become a king. So he remained as a brahmacāri and accepted Nārada Muni as his guru. Under the guidance of Nārada Muni, he attained spiritual knowledge and worshiped Lord Krsna. He was absorbed in discussing the topics of the Lord and was uninterested in anything else. Hoping to crown Priyavrata, Svāyambhuva Manu went to the forest to meet him. He reached Gandhamādana Hill, where he saw Priyavrata and Nārada Muni. Manu spoke to Priyavrata, My dear son, your brother's dynasty has ruled the earth so far. Now there is no one amongst his descendants to protect the citizens. So I request you to take charge of the kingdom, because you possess all the good qualities required by a king. Although the father's order cannot be refused, Priyavrata did not welcome it. He feared that being a king would distract him from bis bhakti. Moreover, he didn't want any diversion in his exclusive devotional service to the Lord. Understanding the situation, Lord Brahmā, the father of Svāyambhuva Manu, appeared there from Brahmaloka on his mighty swan carrier. He was accompanied by his associates and many devatās who praised him. Svāyambhuva Manu and Narada Muni saw their father Brahma and immediately stood up in great respect and praised Brahma eloquently. Then Lord Brahmā looked at Priyavrata with love. He smiled, thinking that he would change his grandson's decision. He thought to himself, Dear grandson, to refuse the kingdom is your stubbornness. To make you rule the kingdom is my stubbornness. Let us see whose stubbornness will prevail. Such joking competitions are common between a grandson and a grandfather. Brahma then compassionately spoke to Priyavrata, The Supreme Lord desires that you take charge of the kingdom. Nobody can defy the Lord's order. All of us, including Siva, Manu, and Närada, must carry out His instructions. He is our supreme well-wisher, and whatever He offers to us must be accepted with faith. Addressing Priyavrata's concern about his spiritual life, Brahma said, Please don't think managing a great kingdom will distract you from bhakti. For those who are disciplined and self-controlled, household life and a kingdom are not harmful. If you always seek the shelter of Lord Krsna with devotion, you will never deviate from bhakti. Thus being advised, Priyavrata bowed to Brahmā and agreed to rule the earth. Svayambhuva Manu felt relieved and happy. Nārada Muni had no objections. Having thus convinced his grandson and being pleased with his obedience and selflessness, Brahmā departed. With the permission and blessings of Narada Muni, Svāyambhuva Manu established Priyavrata as the king. King Priyavrata ruled the kingdom with great commitment. He married two queens and had thirteen sons and one daughter. Although he had no interest in the kingdom, he ruled the world just to honor the orders of his elders. He promptly attended to his various responsibilities, yet he never forgot to worship Lord Krsna. Once Priyavrata had become dissatisfied with the movements of the sun. The sun lit up half the earth's surface while the other half remained dark. Priyavrata wanted to give light to the other half by becoming a second sun in the universe. So, by the power of his yoga, he expanded himself into two forms, one as the king and one as the sun. He then followed the orbit of the sun-god on a brilliant chariot and thus turned night into day. By dissipating the darkness of night, Priyavrata wanted to give happiness to his citizens. But he never wanted to compete with the sun. Priyavrata was cooler than the moon in hot months like Jyestha. And in cold months like Mārgaśīrṣa, he was warmer than the other sun at dawn and dusk. As Priyavrata was moving on his chariot following the sun's orbit, the impressions of his chariot wheels created seven ring-shaped ditches. They became the seven great oceans. Naturally, seven great islands were formed between the seven oceans on the Bhū-mandala (the earthly plane). After successfully ruling the earth for thousands of years, Priyavrata desired to retire. So he made seven of his thirteen sons the rulers of the seven islands he had created. Three of the remaining sons became brahmacārīs, and the other three sons became Manus in the future. Priyavrata spent the rest of his life worshiping Lord Krsna as taught to him by his guru Nārada Muni. He thus finally attained the kingdom of God. What happened to the kingdom then? Read the next story to discover.
quotes: One who extends oneself to fulfill the desires of great people shall receive great blessings., When we are sincere, the Lord will help us balance our social duties and spiritual life nicely., Wise people intend to help others but not compete with others or outsmart them., Just as the Lord performs astonishing pastimes, His devotees also perform wonderful activities by His empowerment.
activity: 1. Write any two qualities of Priyavrata that inspire you., 2. What do you think would happen if the whole planet experienced only daytime? 3. Do you think we should always compromise on our plans to fulfill other desires? Elaborate.
lesson: A LESSON ON EMPOWERMENT: Not a blade of grass moves without the Lord's sanction. The Lord possesses all powers, and He empowers different people to act in different ways. When we have an earnest desire to attain success, sincerely endeavor for it, and humbly offer prayer to the Lord, the Lord empowers us to accomplish the unimaginable. The Lord significantly empowers His devotees to succeed in their endeavors because the devotees eagerly participate in His mission. Lord Krishna empowered Arjuna and Bhima to become the heroes of the Kurukshetra battle. Lord Rama empowered Hanuman to find Sitadevi, burn Lanka, and terrorize the hearts of all the demons headed by Ravana.

title: Desiring a God-like Son
story: Priyavrata's first son was named Āgnīdhra. He ruled the Jambūdvīpa, the middlemost island in the Bhūmandala. He protected the citizens like his own children. Desiring to get a perfect son Agnīdhra worshipped Lord Brahmā in the valley of Mandara Hill. Understanding Āgnīdhra's desire, Brahmā sent a beautiful damsel named Pūrvacitti to him. Agnīdhra married her, and they begot nine great sons who became the rulers of the nine parts of Jambūdvīpa. Nābhi, the eldest son of Āgnīdhra, ruled Bhārata-varsa, a prominent part of the Jambūdvīpa. His queen was called Merudevī. Desiring to have children, Nābhi and Merudevī requested some pure brāhmaņa priests to conduct a great sacrifice for the mercy of Lord Visnu. Nābhi prayed to the Lord with great faith and devotion. Being very affectionate to His sincere devotees, Lord Visnu appeared on the back of Garuda in the sacrifice of King Nābhi. He wore a yellow silk garment, fragrant garlands, a Kaustubha gem, a dazzling crown, a pearl necklace, and various ornaments. He held conch, lotus, disc, and club in His four hands. Seeing the Lord, King Nābhi, his priests, and others felt like poor people who had obtained great riches. The Lord's unparalleled beauty captivated everyone's eyes and satisfied their hearts. The priests prayed to Lord Visnu, O Lord, please accept our respects, for we are Your servants. Your name, form, and qualities are all divine. Chanting Your glories is auspicious and wipes out the sins of all mankind. You are certainly very satisfied when Your devotees offer You prayers, Tulasi leaves, and water. Nabhi's priests then expressed the purpose of their sacrifice, O Lord, although we are foolish, ignorant and have not worshipped You properly, You have mercifully appeared in this sacrifice. Your appearance itself is the greatest benediction for us. Seeing You is extremely rare. We called You here because king Nābhi desired a son like You. Lord Visnu was pleased. He spoke with compassion, You are all qualified brāhmanas. Your words should not prove untrue. You have prayed for King Nābhi to have a son like Me. But I am the Supreme Person, and there is no one like Me. Therefore, I will personally appear as the son of Nabhi. Speaking thus, the Lord disappeared from the sacrifice. Lord Visnu appeared as the son of Nabhi and Merudevī. He manifested the symptoms of God when He was born. Nābhi named Him Rsabhadeva, the best of human beings. Nābhi was always blissful, having attained his desire for a perfect son, the Lord Himself. He affectionately raised the Lord, who acted like a human being. To train his son in protecting the citizens, Nābhi entrusted Him to learned brāhmaņas. Rsabhadeva completed his education first in a Gurukul (school) and gave guru-daksiņā (donation of gratitude) to His gurus. Rsabhadeva became popular amongst the citizens and ministers. Everyone became happy seeing His good qualities, powers, strength, beauty, name, fame, and influence. Eventually Nabhi enthroned Rsabhadeva. Thereafter Nabhi and Merudevi went to Badarikāśrama, where they worshipped Nara-Nārāyana in deep devotion. In due course of time, they went to Vaikuntha. Once Indra became envious of Lord Rsabhadeva. What did he do out of his envy? And how did Rsabhadeva respond? Turn the page to find out!
quotes: The Lord is extremely reciprocal. He eagerly satisfies the desires of His dear devotees., Although the Lord doesn't need our offerings, He accepts them in reciprocation with our love only to benefit us.
activity: 1. What aspects of the Lord's beauty do you appreciate the most?, 2. How would you like to reciprocate your parents' love?, 3. Write or sing a small prayer offering it to the Lord. Express your love for Him.
lesson: A LESSON ON LOVE: The Lord is not dependent on anyone. Neither is He obliged to anyone. Yet, He becomes pleased when we sincerely worship Him and thus mercifully fulfills our desires. His mercy is our hope, and by love, only can we attain His mercy. Although He is far beyond the reach of a materialistic person, He is easily approachable to those who love Him and eagerly serve Him. It's love that makes the inconceivable Lord accessible to all. So let us love the Lord selflessly with all our hearts, and the fulfillment of desires will follow.

title: A Divine Downpour
story: Indra, the lord of rains, had once stopped the rains in Bhārata-varsa. This was due to his envy of the exalted Lord Rsabha. Rsabhadeva then profusely poured rain into Bhārata-varsa by His spiritual power. This humbled Indra. He then offered a woman named Jayanti as the wife of Lord Rsabhadeva. Rsabhadeva had a hundred sons who are similar to Himself in good qualities. Bharata, the eldest of all, was an exalted devotee. In his honor, this planet became known as Bhārata-varsa. All the hundred sons of Rsabhadeva were ksatriyas by birth. But only ten of them, headed by Bharata, became ksatriyas with courage and power. Eighty-one sons were expert brāhmanas, perfect in Vedic knowledge and rituals. And the remaining nine sons became very advanced devotees together called the nava-yogendras. They became authorized teachers of Śrīmad-Bhagavatam and were glorified for their strong devotion to Lord Vasudeva. Lord Rsabhadeva was well-versed with Vedas and merciful to all. To set a right example as a king, He conducted several sacrifices according to Vedic injunctions, followed the advice of brahmaņas, and strictly observed dharma. In His rule, the citizens were fully satisfied. Once Lord Rsabhadeva toured the world and reached a place called Brahmāvarta. In an assembly of many brāhmanas, sages, and common people, He gave wonderful teachings to His good sons. He told them, My dear sons, all living beings need some enjoyment, but temporary material enjoyment is not the only goal of human life. In comparison to animals, human beings have higher intelligence by which they can cultivate spiritual knowledge and come closer to God. This is possible in the company of devotees who are dedicated to bhakti. Rsabhadeva continued, One has to develop love for Lord Vasudeva by hearing about Him and chanting His names. Then one can easily be liberated from material miseries and reach the spiritual world. The leaders of society must mercifully educate innocent people in devotion. Following your eldest brother, Bharata, protect your citizens effectively and never disrespect pure brāhmaņas as they are very dear to the Lord. In this way, Lord Rsabhadeva instructed His sons, although they were perfectly educated and cultured. He was instructing everyone through His sons. Enthroning Bharata as the king of Bhārata-varsa, Rṣabhadeva took a vow of silence and left home to tour the world. He acted like an avadhūta who externally appears like a madman but is internally absorbed in spiritual consciousness. Foolish people threatened and threw stones and dust at Him, but He remained indifferent like an elephant surrounded by flies. He was situated in His spiritual glory, and didn't care for these material insults. Even as an avadhūta, He appeared beautiful in His divine spiritual body. Although Rṣabhadeva had all mystic powers, He never displayed them to attract the public's attention. He neglected all yogic powers and was absorbed in spiritual consciousness. He exhibited deep detachment in the final stages of His pastimes, just to teach everyone that this material world is not a worthy place for living. He wandered all over the earth and reached Karnataka state in South India. There He concluded His earthly pastimes by entering a forest fire created by the rubbing of bamboo due to the force of the wind. All the animals and trees in that forest attained liberation due to the presence of Rsabhadeva. How did Bharata rule the kingdom after Rsabhadeva's departure?
quotes: Envious people cannot tolerate the glory of others. Envy is an indirect appreciation of others. Better to appreciate them directly and be relieved from the burden of envy., In the Vedic culture, people are accepted as brahmanas or kshatriyas not by their birth, but by their qualities & activities., One needs to avoid the company of bad people and associate with good people., When God descends as an incarnation, He performs enchanting activities & gives enlightening teachings to humanity.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? Bhārata-varşa was formerly known as Ajanābha-varsa because it was ruled by King Nābhi and his son, Lord Rṣabhadeva. After King Bharata's rule, it became celebrated as Bhārata-varsa.
activity: 1. Do you know even Krishna performs duties to set a right example for common masses? Try finding a shloka in the Bhagavad Gita that suggests this., 2. Do you have a younger sibling? How can you inspire him or her by your behavior? 3. Who is your role model? What would you like to emulate from him or her? 4. How many incarnations of the Lord do you know? Who is your favorite?
lesson: A LESSON ON EXAMPLE: Whatever great people do, common people follow. The leaders of society have the responsibility to set the right example for everyone. Their attitudes and actions influence people in general. Even when the Lord descends as an incarnation. He gives us divine teachings and acts in a way that people learn from His activities. By following the instructions and example of the Lord, we attain all success. And taking inspiration from Him, we should also be a good example for the youngsters to follow.

title: Can Compassion Become A Distraction?
story: King Bharata, the first son of Lord Rsabhadeva, protected the earth following his father's footsteps. Being a learned king, he perfectly performed his duties and inspired his citizens to execute their duties. He was free from qualities like envy, greed, or attachments. Bharata performed various sacrifices without any material desires, just to worship Lord Krsna with love. He performed bhakti by hearing Krsna's pastimes, chanting His names, and meditating upon His qualities and forms. After ruling the Earth for 10,000,000 years, he divided his wealth among his five sons and retired as a king. Then, he went to a peaceful place called Pulahāśrama, where the Gandaki River flows, and śālagrāma-śilās are obtainable. At Pulahāśrama, Lord Hari is visible even now in the form desired by the devotees, out of His affection for them. Bharata lived there alone. He would bathe in the Gandaki River and worship Lord Hari with various flowers, tulasī leaves, and water from the river. His heart was completely satisfied with such selfless worship of the Lord. His love for the Lord increased day by day, and he showed symptoms of spiritual joy and tears of affection for Him. Once, after finishing his morning duties, Bharata sat on the bank of River Gandaki and chanted some prayers. At that time, a thirsty Pregnant doe came there. As she started drinking water from the river peacefully, she suddenly heard the roar of a lion. She became very frightened and quickly leaped across the river though she had not yet quenched her thirst. When she thus jumped in fear, her baby fell from her womb into the flowing waters. Being thus distressed and separated from its flock, the doe died on the spot. Seeing the newborn fawn floating down the river, Bharata felt great compassion and immediately lifted it from the water. Then, knowing the fawn to be motherless, he brought it to his āśrama. Bharata began to raise the helpless deer as his child. However, by being so absorbed in maintaining the deer, he gradually neglected to worship the Lord. Finally, he thought, The deer has taken my shelter with full faith. Hence I should selflessly raise and protect it, even at the cost of neglecting my spiritual practices. Due to excessive affection for the deer, Bharata lay down, walked about, bathed, and even ate with it. Fearing that ferocious animals might kill the deer, Bharata took it with him wherever he went in the forest. He would carry the deer on his shoulders, sometimes keep it on his lap or, when sleeping, on his chest. Thus, he felt great bliss in petting it. While he was worshipping the Lord, he would get up and see where the deer was. Seeing it, he would be satisfied and bless it, saying, My dear calf, may you be happy in all ways. Having compassion for the deer wasn't wrong on the part of Bharata, but being overly attached to it and neglecting his sādhana was his mistake. Once, the deer wandered into the forest, leaving Bharata. Not seeing the deer, Bharata became anxious, like a miser who has lost his wealth. Did the deer get lost? Did Bharata find it again? Read on to find out.
quotes: Spiritual practices done with absorption, without any distraction offer great joy to the heart., Life is unpredictable. Dangers can come from anywhere at any moment., Great people are naturally compassionate toward suffering living beings., Sometimes our innocent attachments could make us neglect what is beneficial to us.
activity: 1. Do you think King Bharata made a mistake If yes, what was it? 2. What would you do if you saw a motherless deer on your way? 3. Follow a 'No Distraction Day' by keeping away from phones, laptops, and similar gadgets. Instead, observe how you find more time to spend on important things. 4. Try to remember a goal you want to achieve. Then, identify what distracts you from the goal, and share how you would like to overcome them.
lesson: A LESSON ON ATTENTION: Attentiveness is one of the important qualities needed to achieve anything. So many unexpected distractions come on our way to attain our goals. We fail if we divert our attention from what is beneficial to what is not. So we need to be constantly alert to deal with distractions. How is that possible? The most effective way of saving oneself from distraction is a good association. However knowledgeable and determined one may be, one can lose focus on goals due to distractions, as we see in the case of the Bharata. But if we keep the company of well-wishing like-minded friends, they will remind us of our goals whenever we are distracted.

title: A Deer's Past Life Memories
story: King Bharata, who was once immersed in the thoughts of Lord Krsna, became immersed in the thoughts of the lost deer. Unable to understand his emotions and attachment, Bharata became very sorrowful. He thought, Oh, I am so negligent and cruel like a hunter. Perhaps the deer lost faith in me and left me. Oh, shall I see it again? Will the Lord protect the deer? When will I see him wandering again in the garden eating soft grass? Bharata desired the deer's safety and remembered its cute activities. He said to himself, Perhaps the deer has been eaten by a wild animal. Seeing my fake meditation, it would move around me and touch me with its soft horns, which felt like drops of water. Then, when I chastise him by pushing it away for disturbing my worship, it would sit down motionlessly. Although Bharata was in worship or mediation, his mind was thinking of the deer. After thus speaking like a madman, Bharata went outside and saw the deer's footprints fortunate to have the deer's beautiful and auspicious footprints. He on the ground. He thought the Earth was thus lamented till the sunset. Seeing the dark marks on the rising moon that resembled a deer, he said, Has the compassionate moon given shelter to the deer? Is Seeing the dark marks on the rising moon that resembled a deer, he protecting it from the fearful attacks of a lion? Unfortunately, Bharata was overwhelmed by an uncontrollable desire to see the deer and forget his spiritual goals. Bharata was free from all bad qualities and had many good qualities like compassion. However, his compassion for the deer became a distraction in his spiritual life due to his inattentiveness. Bharata's thoughts about the deer increased with time, and his life span decreased. Finally, the time of death, which is like a venomous snake entering a mouse hole, approached him. Bharata imagined the deer by his side like his own son. Absorbed in thinking of the deer while leaving his body, Bharata died. Because he was immersed in the thoughts of the deer, he was born as a deer in his next life, in the Kālañjara Mountain area. Although king Bharata became deer Bharata, he could understand the cause of his deer birth. He thus lamented, Oh, what misfortune! I gave up my kingdom and opulence to worship and remember Lord Krsna. But out of foolishness, I became attached to the young deer and became an animal now. I should have been more careful and not neglected my spiritual duties. To increase Bharata's devotion, the Lord punished him with a deer body for a short time. However, the Lord was merciful to him and gave him the remembrance of his past life, even in an animal body. Deer Bharata became anxious to get out of his deer body. He intensified his bhakti. Thus, this punishment was a blessing for Bharata. Thus, deer Bharata constantly repented for his mistake. He left his mother deer at Kālañjara Mountain and again went to Pulahāśrama. Now deer Bharata was cautious not to fall victim to any distractions to spiritual life. Deer Bharata ate dry leaves, grass, and bushes. He bathed in that holy place and always meditated on the Lord. Taking Paramātmā as his companion, he awaited his natural death. In this way, he spent his life in the body of a deer but the mind of a devotee. Finally, he gave up that deer body one day. What happened next? Did he take rebirth or attain the spiritual world? Read on to find out!
quotes: Even kindness can create complications in life if it's reposed in the wrong way., A mere show of worship while thinking of something else is not truly beneficial., Whatever is one thinks of at the time of death, one attains that. If one remembers God at the time of death, one reaches God., Behind the strictness of God is His soft heart, due to which He cannot disown His devotees even if they make mistakes.
activity: 1. Recollect an incident where you felt that due to God's mercy, you made an accomplishment? 2. Did you experience something that you felt as a rebuke but later realized it as a blessing? 3. Do you remember anyone else in the Bhagavatam who was punished for a mistake but took it positively?
lesson: A LESSON ON MERCY: God loves all living beings unconditionally. Especially when they worship Him with devotion, His attention towards them increases. Even if the devotees commit some mistakes, or get distracted from bhakti, the Lord's mercy on them doesn't diminish. On the contrary, just to bring them back on track, He mercifully punishes them so that they can reconnect with rejuvenated devotion. The Lord's mercy comes in multiple forms. Although it may not be palatable sometimes, it's always beneficial. After all, He is our supreme well-wisher. We can access His mercy by attentively practicing our spiritual life.

title: Foolish Yet Wise
story: Once in the dynasty of sage Angira, there was a gentle and learned brāhmana who had two wives. His first wife gave birth to nine sons while the second wife gave birth to twins a girl and a boy. That boy was Bharata who took birth as the son of this brāhmana, after giving up the body of a deer. By the Lord's grace, Bharata remembered his past two lives as a king and as a deer. Learning from his past mistakes, he always thought about Krsna in his present birth. Although the new family members of Bharata were good in their habits and culture, they were not so elevated in spiritual life. Moreover, they were somewhat materialistic in their attitude. So, Bharata was very cautious in associating with them because he didn't want to get distracted this time. Externally, Bharata behaved like a dumb man to avoid bad association, but internally he always thought of his dear Lord Krsna. Considering him foolish, people called him Jada Bharata, jada meaning 'dull.' Jada Bharata's father was always affectionate to him. He tried to educate him in various ways, teach him cleanliness, Vedic mantras, and other etiquettes of brāhmaņas. Bharata acted like a fool before his father and did the opposite of what his father taught, just to stop him teaching any further. Although instructed to wash his hands after father tried to teach him the Gayatri mantra along with oṁkāra, but excreting, Bharata would wash his hands before. Nonetheless, his even after four months of attempt, he was unsuccessful. It wasn't necessary for Jada Bharata to learn these basic principles because he was already advanced in spiritual life. Moreover, he didn't want any emotional bondage with people. His father finally realized that Bharata was unfit for marriage and household life. Without fulfilling his desire to make Jada Bharata a scholar, the brāhmana died. After his departure, the nine stepbrothers of Jada Bharata stopped his education. Although learned in the Vedas, they were not spiritually inclined or kind. They considered Bharata brainless, and couldn't understand his exalted position. Insensitive people made Bharata do physical work as a slave and addressed him as mad, dull, and dumb. Yet Bharata neither protested nor tried to prove himself great. He would eat whatever food came of its own accord without any desire to satisfy his tongue. He was wise and a liberated person, fully satisfied in his meditation on the Lord. Jada Bharata looked as strong as a bull. He did not cover his body fully with proper cloth despite too much cold, heat, or rain. He wore only a dirty loincloth, and his sacred thread was blackish. He would lay on the ground without a bath. His spiritual knowledge was covered, like a gem covered by dirt. Ignorant people called him brahma-bandhu, an unqualified brāhmana. Being thus insulted and neglected by materialistic people, Jada Bharata wandered here and there. Jada Bharata would work only for food. Taking advantage of this, his stepbrothers engaged him in agricultural work. They would give him broken rice and worm-eaten grains that were stuck to the cooking pot. But ada Bharata gladly accepted all this as if it were nectar. Bharata was determined to finish his business in this material world, not caring for any insults or attachments. He just wanted to meditate on Krsna internally and reach Him. While thus living his life, suddenly one day, a band of dacoits arrested him, intending to kill him. Did the dacoits kill him? Or did Bharata escape? Read on to find out!
quotes: One who looks foolish externally need not be a fool. So, we shouldn't judge people by their outward demeanor., Great people are unaffected by undue praise or unnecessary criticism; they focus on their priorities.
activity: 1. Share your thoughts on the behavior of Jada Bharata's stepbrothers. 2. Do you think tolerating makes you weak? 3. You see some bullies overpowering a child. Should you tolerate it? 4. Do you feel more comfortable dealing with a person who has tolerance? Why? 5. Recollect an incident when you judged someone outwardly but later regretted it.
lesson: A LESSON ON TOLERANCE: Sometimes people may taunt us or comment on us unnecessarily. We may have to respond to them appropriately. In the name of tolerance, we need not allow ourselves to get exploited. When others consider us foolish, we may try to prove our talent. If they consider us cheaters, we may prove our innocence. However, sometimes tolerating can be a better choice. When a regal elephant passes on the road carrying the Lord's deity on his back, some street dogs may bark at him, but the elephant focuses on his service to the Lord. If proving ourselves in front of others is unworthy of our time and energy, we may prefer not to respond to them and focus on our good work. But in doing so, we shouldn't be proud or arrogant. If others' feedback or comments help us improve ourselves, we should accept them positively.

title: The Headless Dacoits
story: Once, the leader of some dacoits desiring to have a son worshiped goddess Kāli. To please her, he wanted to offer in sacrifice a dull man who was no better than an animal (puruṣa-paśu). His followers forcefully caught a foolish man; however, he escaped at the last moment. So, the leader ordered the dacoits to find him immediately. Wandering here and there in the middle of the night, the dacoits found Jada Bharata, who was guarding a paddy field. After observing him closely, they felt that he was foolish like an animal and thus a perfect choice for their human sacrifice. Being overjoyed with their find, they immediately arrested Bharata and brought him to the temple of goddess Kālī. But Bharata didn't even protest. The leader of the cruel dacoits became pleased and began performing their imaginary ritual. There was no mention in the scriptures of sacrificing a human being however dull he may be. Moreover, Bharata was a brāhmaṇa and a great devotee. But the dacoits were bent upon performing the sacrifice. According to their concocted procedure, the dacoits first bathed Bharata, dressed him in new clothes, and then decorated him with ornaments, sandalwood pulp, garlands, and tilaka. Then, they fed him sumptuously and made him sit in front of the huge deity of Bhadra Kāli. Finally, they offered her arati, prayers, and their so-called devotion for a selfish purpose. The chief priest then picked up a fearsome sword and chanted a mantra of Bhadra Kālī. Desiring to offer her the blood of Jada Bharata so that she may drink it as liquor, he raised his sword to behead him. The low-minded and envious dacoits, whose business was just to plunder people, didn't realize the gravity of their offense to Jada Bharata. How can Kāli be pleased with the blood of a pure devotee of Lord Visnu? After all, she is also a devotee of Visnu. Kālī couldn't tolerate the sinful dacoits offending Jada Bharata. Her deity burst open and she emerged from it in a form burning with an intolerable effulgence. The angry goddess displayed her fierce, curved teeth, frowning brows and glowing reddish eyes. She manifested a fierce mood, as if to destroy the entire creation for the offence being performed towards an innocent devotee. Leaping violently from the altar, she immediately beheaded all those rogues with the very sword with which they tried to kill Jada Bharata. She then drank the hot blood that flowed from their necks as if it were liquor. Despite all these events, Jada Bharata was calm. He didn't desire harm for them even in his mind. He is no one's enemy. As Jada Bharata continued to live in this way, he encountered a king who insulted him. This time Jada Bharata didn't keep silent. He responded to the king strongly. Who was that king? And what was the dispute? To know the details, read the next story.
quotes: An envious person who tries to commit violence towards a great personality, is punished severely., The Lord always protects His devotees, because they are non-envious and have completely taken His shelter.
activity: 1. Share any other story where a selfish person is punished for trying to exploit the innocent. 2. Do you recall any story in this book where a devata became vicious and tried to harm the virtuous? 3. Do you know any other devatas who didn't protect their worshipers who tried to harm the devotees of Vishnu or Krishna?
lesson: A LESSON ON DESIRE: Who wouldn't desire to have a beautiful house, car, wealth, and luxuries? It is natural for all living beings to have desires. But some desires are reasonable and some are not. One may endeavor to fulfill one's reasonable desires by honest means. However, if one pursues one's selfish desires even at the cost of troubling innocent people, one ends up in trouble like the dacoits. We can regulate our desires by scriptural study and good association. Positive desires are beneficial to oneself and others. Especially desires to serve the Lord elevate us to His company.

title: The Enlightened Madman
story: King Rahūgana, the ruler of Sindhu and Sauvīra provinces, was once on his way to Kapilāśrama. His servants carried him on a beautiful palanquin. However, as they reached the riverbank, they needed another person who could carry the palanquin. So they began searching for someone. By chance, they saw young and strong Jada Bharata who was fit enough for the job. So, they forcefully brought him and made him carry the king's palanquin. While carrying the palanquin Jada Bharata saw some ants on the road. He didn't want to step on them due to his sense of compassion. So, he walked erratically, because of which the palanquin shook constantly. King Rahūgana was disturbed so he asked the palanquin carriers the reason. They became afraid of punishment and said, O King, we are not negligent in our service. This new man does not walk swiftly, and therefore we cannot carry the palanquin with him. Although Rahūgana was knowledgeable and had served great sages earlier, he became angry due to his innate nature as a king. Thus, he spoke to Jada Bharata sarcastically, Oh! You must be fatigued from carrying the palanquin alone for so long, because you are old, weak, and unhealthy. Are your fellow carriers not cooperating with you? By these words, Rahūgana indicated to Jada Bharata that he was young, strong, was not fatigued, and therefore had no reason to perform poorly. Being unaffected by the king's sarcastic remarks, Bharata didn't respond and continued walking. After a while, King Rahūgana noticed that his palanquin was still shaking. He then severely chastised Jada Bharata, Are you dead despite the life in your body? Are you mad? You are disregarding the orders of your master. For this disobedience, I shall punish you. Jada Bharata smiled and replied to the king, O King, as you rightly said, I am not fatigued because fatigue belongs only to the body. I a spirit soul detached from the body. My body may be strong and am a young, but these qualities don't apply to the soul. You said that you are the king, and I am your servant. But these positions are temporary and may change later. You said you would punish me, but that is useless, for I am a self-realized soul wandering like a madman. There is no use punishing a self-realized man or a mad man. Saying this, Jada Bharata continued to carry the palanquin as before. Hearing Bharata's profound reply, Rahūgana immediately gave up his pride as a king, and fell flat at Bharata's feet. Then, humbly begging for forgiveness, he inquired, Who are you? Are you a learned brāhmaṇa or a liberated saint like Dattatreya? Are you Lord Kapila or Lord Nārāyana? Why are you wandering around like a madman? Please mercifully reveal your identity. With a repentant heart, Rahūgana further spoke, I am not afraid of Indra's thunderbolt, Lord Śiva's trident, Yamarāja's punishment, or the weapons of great devatās. But I am afraid of offending the brāhmanas, sages, and devotees like yourself. So please forgive my offense committed without knowing your great position. Jada Bharata replied, I was the famous emperor Bharata in my past life. I was fully absorbed in the Lord's service but became distracted due to undue affection for a deer. Thus, I become a deer in the next life. But I could remember my previous life and meditated on Krsna even in a deer body. Thus, I have now attained this brāhmaņa birth. To avoid material association, I am wandering about unnoticed. King Rahūgana being astonished at understanding Bharata's elevated position inquired about various philosophical and spiritual subject matters from him. Bharata said, When the mind is absorbed in material enjoyment, it causes suffering. But when the same mind is attached to Krsna, it leads to liberation. The uncontrolled mind is the greatest enemy of the living entity. One can conquer the mind with the weapon of service to the devotees, guru, and Krsna. Rahūgana expressed his gratitude to Bharata for his teachings while Bharata continued his wanderings and eventually attained the kingdom of God.
quotes: Kind people do not wish to harm even an ant., We are not temporary material bodies but eternal spirit souls. Those who realize this are unaffected by bodily pains & pleasures., In ignorance, one may commit a mistake, but in knowledge, one regrets the mistake and tries to rectify it instead of justifying it., It is wise to apologize when we realize that we have offended someone. A delay would aggravate the reaction; just as delaying treatment can aggravate a disease.,  In the association of wise people, one is enlightened about the true purpose of life.
activity: 1. How would you respond when you realize that you have offended someone by your words or actions? 2. Do you think we need to be kind towards non-human beings? Why? 3. Compare the characters of King Vena and King Rahugana, and write down your observations. 4. Does sincere repentance authorize us to keep repeating the same mistake? Explain.
lesson: A LESSON ON REGRET: Remember when you broke a window glass accidentally while playing? Making mistakes is common for any human being. But honest people do not commit mistakes or offend anyone purposefully. If they happen to commit an offense incidentally, they genuinely repent and try to rectify their mistakes. Such sincere regret is perfect atonement for their mistakes. King Rahugana would have been held up for his offense towards Jaòa Bharata, but his regret saved him, and made him a recipient of spiritual knowledge. Sincere repentance attracts forgiveness.

title: The Four Syllables of God's Name
story: In a place called Kānyakubja, lived a gentle and learned brāhm named Ajamila. He was respectful and kind towards everyone and completely free from bad qualities. One day, Ajāmila's father told him to collect some fruits and flowers from the forest for worship. On his way back home, he saw an unusual vulgar scene of a shameless man hugging a maidservant publicly. Both the man and the woman were drunk; their eyes were rolling in intoxication, and their dresses were loose. Seeing their inappropriate behavior, Ajāmila was disturbed mentally. He tried to remember the scriptural instructions, but his mind went out of control. He left the spot, but the scene was haunting him. Ironically, he desired to marry that woman, although he already had a beautiful young wife coming from a respectable family. Ajāmila's mind was covered with the thoughts of that bad lady. He lost all his good sense and became determined to be with her. Within a short time, he brought her as a servant into his house. Captivated by her so-called beauty, he started spending his inherited money to buy her various presentations so that she would remain pleased with him. Gradually losing all brahminical principles, he abandoned his chaste wife and parents. A brāhmana is meant to please Lord Krsna, but Ajāmila strove to fulfill the desires of a woman. Ajāmila married that sinful lady and ate food cooked by her. By eating her remnants, he became impure and addicted to sinful activities. He would plunder people or cheat them in gambling in order to earn nis livelihood and maintain his children. As a result, he became a fraud, burglar, and drunkard. He led an irresponsible life, and thus eighty-eight years of his life passed. Ajāmila had ten sons. Fortunately, by the mercy of some devotee, he named his youngest son 'Nārāyana.' Nārāyana was naturally very dear to his parents. Ajāmila took great pleasure in his broken language and childish activities. With deep attachment and affection, Ajāmila would often call out 'Nārāyana, Nārāyana' repeatedly. When he would eat, he would call the child, Nārāyana, come and sit, eat this food. When he would drink, he would call, Nārāyana, come and drink this juice. Thus, always taking care of the child, he didn't notice the passage of time. Eventually, old Ajamila became diseased and was neglected by his wife. Finally, when he was on his deathbed, he saw three terrifying personalities with twisted faces and erect hairs. They were the Yamadūtas, the soldiers of lord Yama, who would award suitable punishments to sinful people in hell. Ajāmila had committed many sins with his body, mind, and words. Therefore, three Yamadūtas came to him with ropes to drag him to hell. Frightened, with tears in his eyes, Ajāmila loudly called his son, Nārāyana, Nārāyana, who was playing nearby. Unfortunately, the boy didn't havethematurity to understand his father's situation and anxiety. Although the child 'Nārāyana' didn't respond to Ajāmila's cries, Lord Nārāyana did. Ajamila had neglected to worship the Lord all these days, but the Lord's heart melted hearing him calling out His name helplessly. The Lord mercifully sent His servants, the Visnudūtas, to rescue him. Because dying Ajāmila chanted four syllables of God's name Nā-rā-ya-na, four Visnudūtas came to help him. How did the Yamadūtas respond when the Visnudutas suddenly intervened? Did the Visnudūtas save Ajāmila from the Yamadūtas? Was there a fight between both parties? Read on to discover.
quotes: When eyes glance at obscene visuals, the mind can be distracted drastically., Absorption in any activity, whether good or bad, doesn't allow one to keep track of the passing time., The Lord and His name are nondifferent. Therefore, we can invoke the Lord's protection by fervently chanting His name.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? NAMING CHILDREN: Traditionally people used to name their children with the names of God or His associates - like Hari, Rāma, Sītā, Govinda, Rādhā, Krsna, Lalitā, Keśava, Lakṣmī and so on so that they would be purified by repeatedly calling those names with affection. Because the name of the Lord is not different from the Lord, one develops love for Him by repeatedly calling out His names.
activity: 1. Whom do you remember when you find yourself helpless? 2. How can one avoid the ghastly Yamadutas and attract loving Vishnudutas? 3. Try to recall the names of some devotees who remembered the Lord in distress, and the Lord reciprocated. 4. Find and note down the meaning of each of the following names of the Lord -Krishna, Damodara, Acyuta, Hrishikesh, Shyamasundara.
lesson: A LESSON ON GRACE: Of the unlimited qualities of the Lord. His grace on His devotees is the foremost. He is always merciful to His devotees, even if they commit mistakes sometimes. He finds some reason, direct or indirect, to shower His grace upon them. Although Ajamila was calling his son Näräyana, the Lord considered that Ajämilä was chanting His name Näräyana and showered His grace. Just imagine how much would He be kind to someone who lovingly chants His name? Although Ajamila accidentally became sinful, the Lord didn't give up His love for him. In ignorance, we ignore people who love us, and love those who have no intent or ability to reciprocate our love. But the Lord is ever willing to shower His grace upon us. We can access it by chanting His names with devotion.

attributes.narrative_style: Balanced (Mix of rich description and philosophical elements.)

title: One Million Sins Destroyed
story: As the Yamadūtas were snatching the soul from the core of Ajamila's heart, the Visnudūtas stopped them. They threatened the Yamadūtas with resounding voices, If you want to live, do not take away this devotee Ajamila! The Yamadūtas were astonished to see and hear the Visnudūtas. The Visnudūtas looked very fresh and beautiful in yellow silk garments. Their faces were glowing with lotus-like eyes and dazzling crowns. Their four long arms held maces, bows, quivers of arrows, swords, clubs, conches, cakras and lotus flowers. They were also decorated with lotus garlands and jewelry. Their effulgence dissipated all darkness. The Yamadūtas had jurisdiction over all sinful people, but the Visnudūtas were capable of punishing anyone, including the Yamadūtas and even Yama, if they wrong a devotee of Visnu. The Yamadūtas were never obstructed by anyone before. They asked the Visnudūtas, Who are you? Are you some devatās? Why are you forbidding us of our duty? We are soldiers of Yama, the lord of death. The Visnudūtas smiled and replied gravely, You claim to be the servants of Yama, but you seem to be mere ghosts. If you are the servants of Yama, then explain what is dharma and what is adharma? What is the process of punishing sinful people? The Yamadūtas replied, The Vedas are given to humanity directly by Lord Nārāyana. Therefore, what is prescribed in the Vedas is dharma, and the opposite is adharma. The sun, fire, sky, air, devatās, moon, evening, day, night, water, the Supersoul, and Yama himself witness the activities of all living beings. Therefore, the candidates for punishment are those who are confirmed by these witnesses to have performed adharma. Ajāmila performed many sinful acts without undergoing any atonement, so we must take him to hell, where he will be punished. The Visnudūtas replied, Ajāmila has atoned for millions of lifetimes of sins just by uttering the name of 'Nārāyana' helplessly when he saw you. Even previously, whenever he called his son, he uttered the holy name of Nārāyana affectionately. By such chanting, although done unintentionally, he is purified of all his sinful reactions. That's the power of chanting the Lord's holy name. Simply by chanting the name of Lord Visnu, even sinful persons attract the attention of the Lord, who enthusiastically gives him all protection. Therefore, do not take Ajāmila to hell. By chanting the name of 'Nārāyana,' he is free of all sinful reactions. The Visnudūtas continued, A person who chants the name of the Lord while falling, slipping, traveling, in pain, or being injured, will not suffer hellish punishment. As a fire burns dry grass to ashes, the Lord's holy name burns all sinful reactions, whether chanted knowingly or unknowingly. Just as powerful medicine acts even when taken without the knowledge of its powers, the Lord's holy name is effective even when the chanter utters it unknowingly. Having thus established the fact that Ajamila was purified of all sins, the Yamadūtas released Ajamila from imminent death. Thus defeated, the Yamadūtas left there to inform their master Yama about the incident. Although almost unconscious, Ajamila still heard the long coaxeration between the Yamadūtas and the Visnudūtas. While the Yamadūtas spoke ordinary principles of punishing a sinful person, the Visnudūtas spoke extraordinary principles of forgiveness and mercy upon a person who chanted the Lord's holy name. Ajāmila bowed his head at the feet of the Visnudūtas. Then, as he was about to say something, the Vişnudūtas suddenly disappeared. Ajāmila began to repent for his sinful life and spoke in self-reproach, Alas, I acted so sinfully and degraded my family tradition. I should be thrown into hell for my sins. But those effulgent men saved me from the fearsome men who came with ropes to arrest me. Was it a dream or a reality? Where have they gone? I must have seen them due to some previous spiritual activities. Ajāmila's heart became overwhelmed with gratitude for the Vişnudūtas. Then, he resolved,Having gotten this second chance, I will give up my degraded habits, perform devotional service unto Lord Nārāyana, and chant His holy names with love and affection. Ajāmila then went to a holy place called Hardwar, where he performed bhakti unto Visnu with full dedication. After thus living a purely spiritual life for twelve years, Ajāmila gave up his material body on the bank of the River Ganges and attained a spiritual body appropriate to that of an associate of Lord Visnu. Then, accompanied by Visnudūtas, he boarded the golden airplane and went to Vaikuntha. But what happened to the Yamadutas? After they went back to hell, being defeated by the Visnudūtas, what did they tell Yama? Read ahead to find out!
quotes: Even unintentional and unconscious chanting of the Lord's name purifies one from all sins. Just imagine what will happen if one chants with love.,  While ordinary dharma proposes punishment, divine dharma suggests reformation and forgiveness., Repentance for mistakes, gratitude for those who help, and determination to come on the right path will soon bring one to perfection.
activity: 1. Why do you think did the Lord Ajamila another chance? 2. Why didn't the Vishnudutas immediately take Ajamila to Vaikuntha? 3. What can you learn from Ajamila's guilt? 4. Is guilt good for a person?
lesson: A LESSON ON DEVOTION: Ajamila's story is an exceptional example of the Lord's mercy. However, its message is not to encourage a sinful life and still save oneself from the reactions just by saying Nārāyaņa at the end of life! God is merciful, but one shouldn't take undue advantage of God's forgiveness and purposely commit sins. The story is meant to help us appreciate the Lord's mercy and thus approach Him with devotion. Ajamila chanted 'Nārāyana' without faith what will happen if one chants with faith? Ajamila chanted 'Näräyana' while dying what will happen if one chants while living? Ajämila chanted 'Nārāyaņa' to indicate his son what will happen if one chants to indicate the Lord? Ajämila was very sinful what will happen if a sinless person chants 'Nārāyana'? If Ajamila had attained Vaikuntha, what to speak of one who chants the Lord's holy name with devotion?

title: The Ticket to Hell
story: Being defeated by the Visnudutas, the Yamadūtas approached Yamaraja in frustration. Because lord Yama didn't protect them while executing his orders to arrest Ajamila, they felt that there was no need to serve such a master. They even doubted whether he had the power to punish the sinful or if there were some authorities superior to him. They spoke to Yama, How many managers are there to punish sinful people? If multiple judges have multiple opinions on how to punish or reward people, there will be a lot of chaos and confusion! We thought you were the only punisher of all sinful human beings. But your order has been transgressed by four wonderful persons. They had cut our ropes when we were bringing sinful Ajāmila to hell. When Ajamila chanted Nārāyana, these four men quickly came and saved him. Can you tell us who they are? Instead of being angry with his soldiers who spoke in a challenging spirit, Yamarāja was pleased to hear the holy name of Lord Nārāyana from them. Then, remembering his beloved Lord, he said My dear soldiers, Lord Visnu is the supreme. He is superior to me and all the devatās, including Brahmā. He is the creator of everyone and everything in this universe. The four people you saw were His servants, the Visnudūtas. They are almost like the Lord, worshiped even by the devatās. Common people ver rarely see them. They protect the Lord's devotees from enencies and all difficulties. Yamarāja had explicitly described the good qualities of the Visnudūtas to convince his servants not to be envious of them. The Yamadūtas asked, If they protect the devotees, why are they favoring adharma by saving a sinful man like Ajamila? Yamarāja answered, No one can perfectly understand dharma except the mahajanas or pure devotees. The ultimate dharma of a living being is to perform devotional service unto the Lord. Bhakti begins by chanting the holy name of the Lord. There is no need to search for proof. Ajamila is a direct example. Although sinful, Ajamila was liberated from the ropes of death just by chanting the name of Nārāyana. Yamarāja continued, Those who perform bhakti unto Lord Visnu or Krsna or Rāma or any other form of God are beyond my jurisdiction for punishment. Even if they sin, they are protected by chanting the Lord's holy name. So please never try to arrest devotees. They are constantly protected by the Lord's club called Kaumodaki. Therefore, Lord Brahmā, I, and even the time factor cannot punish them. After thus cautioning the Yamadūtas, Yamarāja instructed them whom to bring to hell. He said, Bring to me for punishment, those who never worshiped Lord Krsna, never chanted His names or qualities, never remembered Him or bowed down to Him. Considering himself and his servants to be offenders, Yamarāja begged forgiveness from the Lord: O Lord Nārāyana, please forgive us. Because of our ignorance, we mistreated Your devotee Ajamila Since then, as soon as the Yamadūtas saw devotees of Lord Visnu or Krsna, they became fearful and didn't look at them again.
quotes: All sins are completely eradicated by sincerely chanting the Lord's holy name., One who constantly hears and chants Lord Hari's wonderful activities can easily counteract sin.
activity: 1. Do you think Yamadutas were right in challenging their master Yama? Explain. 2. What is the first step of empathy? 3. After reading the three stories about Ajamila, what do you think people should do to avoid entering hell? 4. The chanting of God's names shall burn all sinful reactions. Does this entitle us to sin freely?
lesson: A LESSON ON EMPATHY: Imagine you approach your elder brother when you are in some tension, and he scolds you further! Would you be comfortable? Empathy is an important aspect of relationships. Empathy means putting ourselves into another person's shoes and trying to recognize their feelings, and help them suitably. For example, when the Yamadūtas spoke to Yamaraja in a challenging tone, he first heard them patiently. He didn't chastise them or get offended. Instead, he explained things to them in loving manner. Similarly, when people approach us in frustration or disappointment, we should try to empathize with them, console them and help them as much as possible.

title: Eleven Thousand Sons
story: After Daksa was reborn as the son of the Pracetas, he went to the Vindhya mountains to worship Lord Visnu. With a desire to increase the population of the universe, he performed austerities (tapasya) for millions of years. Then Lord Visnu appeared before him on the back of His eternal carrier Garuda. Visnu looked very pleasing in His eight-handed form while holding His magnificent śankha, cakra, gada and padma. Also, His charming smile on His divine face completely vanquished all miseries in one's heart. Daksa bowed down to Lord Visnu in respect. The Lord spoke, Dear Daksa, I know your desire. By My mercy, you will beget hundreds of children who will further increase the world's population with various types of species. Saying this, the Lord disappeared. Soon, Daksa married a woman named Asiknī, and begot ten-thousand sons called the Haryaśvas. They were well-behaved and noble-hearted. Following the tradition, Daksa ordered them to go to the forest and perform austerities for purification, before taking on serious responsibilities as kings. The Haryaśvas then travelling towards the west, reached a beautiful lake called Nārāyana-saras. Great sages resided there, and in their association, they constantly worshipped Lord Visnu. Once, Narada Muni saw the Haryaśvas at Nārāyana-saras and felt, I should enlighten these young princes with spiritual knowledge, for they are pure-hearted and are qualified for liberation. So he approached them and spoke about the importance of spiritual life and the temporary nature of material life shortly and sweetly. Carefully thinking about Nārada's words, the Haryaśvas collectively decided to dedicate their lives to the service of the Lord, rather than entering family life and politics. After offering their respects to Nārada Muni for his teachings, they all turned into sannyāsīs. By sincere and dedicated worship of Lord Visnu, they eventually attained Vaikuntha. Daksa became upset when he heard how his ten-thousand sons became sannyāsīs. Lord Brahmā came to him and consoled him. Later Daksa begot another thousand sons named the Savalāśvas. As a dutiful father, he sent them also to Nārāyana-saras to perform austerities before getting married. The Savalāśvas went to Nārāyana-saras, and became purified by bathing in the holy waters and chanting the holy names of God. Once, Nārada Muni approached them and spoke, You are all affectiona to your elder brothers. So, you should follow their path. Nārack desired that the Savalaśvas will join the Haryaśvas in Vaikuntha After showering his merciful glances upon the young princes, Narada departed. The Savalāśvas decided to dedicate their life to the servic of Lord Visnu and thus became sannyāsīs just like the Haryaśvas. Daksa heard this and almost fainted. Nārada Muni then thought, In the dynasty of Svayambhuva Manu – Priyavrata, Uttānapāda, Dhruva, Prācīnabarhi, the Pracetās, Haryaśvas and Savalāśvas – all attained the Lord by my humble efforts. Why should only Daksa remain? I will help him also. Now that his sons have become sannyāsīs, Daksa must have developed detachment. So, this is a suitable time to give him mercy. If he does not come to me, I will go to his house. Thinking thus, Narada went to see Daksa. Although Narada Muni came with all good intentions, Dakşa became furious. He strongly criticized him, saying, I am an honest householder, but you are a cheater in the dress of a sadhu. You have spoiled the minds of my young sons and made them sannyāsis. You are heartless and sinful. You are surely not a devotee of Visnu. Nārada remained silent. But Daksa continued, You may be forgiven once for influencing my first group of sons! But you have done the same thing to my second group of sons also. I cannot tolerate this. So, I curse you to keep traveling all over universe, without any fixed residence. Daksa thought that having no home was a punishment! But for a devotee like Nārada, it is a boon, because he can travel everywhere and inspire many people in devotion to God. Though capable of cursing Daksa in return, Nārada patiently tolerated and accepted the curse, thinking, Let him rebuke me. Then, when his anger subsides, he will regret for his misbehavior, and realize that I am tolerant. Then I can teach him about bhakti. But seeing Daksa reluctant, Nārada Muni silently departed. Since Daksa had been offensive to Lord Śiva in his past life, he offended Nārada now. Nārada Muni continued to travel all over the universe to spread bhakti. But what did Daksa do? Did he beget any more children? How did he fulfill his desire to populate the universe? Read on to find the answers.
quotes: Any creation in this world takes place only with the blessings and sanction of the Lord., By the blessings and inspiration of a devotee, one can easily attain God., A compassionate devotee always looks forward to bringing people closer to God., Offense to one devotee can lead to offenses to multiple devotees.
activity: 1. Do you think Narada is appropriate in making all of Dakña's sons into devotees? Elaborate. 2. Was the response of Dakňa unreasonable? Explain. 3. Daksha did tapasya for thousands of years and even saw Lord Vishnu. Still, he was offensive to Narada Muni. Can you explain why is it so? 4. Who is your source of inspiration? Why? What would you like to emulate from them?
lesson: A LESSON ON INSPIRATION: The driving force that impels one into doing something is known as Inspiration. Don't you sometimes feel inspired to become a singer, a writer, a painter, or a dancer? Generally, that happens by seeing or hearing someone. Wise and kind persons like Närada Muni try to utilize every opportunity to bring even offensive people to come closer to God. However, they only inspire people but not force them. Unless people are respectful and receptive, they cannot take benefit of a saint's mercy. Fortunate are those who take inspiration from wise devotees and advance in spiritual life (Dakşa's sons), but foolish are those who misunderstand and criticize them (Dakşa).

title: The Price of Pride
story: After Daksa's eleven thousand sons became sannyāsīs, he begot sixty beautiful daughters. They gave birth to various types of species in the universe: birds, serpents, aquatics, animals, demons, etc. Twenty-seven of the daughters of Daksa married the moon god. One of them, named Rohini, became the favorite wife of the moon, who started neglecting the remaining wives. This made Daksa angry, and he cursed the moon. Thus, the moon lost his shine and could not beget children also. Thereafter, he pacified Daksa and regained the light he had lost. Because of this curse, the moon loses his shining during the dark fortnight, and it manifests again during the bright fortnight. Among the remaining daughters of Daksa, ten daughters married lord Yama, seventeen married sage Kaśyapa and so on. Diti and Aditi were the prominent wives of Kaśyapa. Diti was the mother of the demons who are evil in their activities and attitude. Aditi was the mother of the devatās who are generally noble in their character. The devatās and demons often fight with each other due to their opposite natures. Once Indra was sitting on his great throne, surrounded by various categories of devatās in heaven. May singers and musicians praised him, as the heavenly damsels danced in joy. Over him was a white umbrella as effulgent as the full moon. He was served royalls while being fanned by yak-tail whisks. He became very puffed up by his opulence and position. At that time, Brhaspati, the guru of the devatās, came to that assembly. Indra did not rise from his seat to offer him respect or welcome him despite seeing him. Understanding that Indra was puffed up by his opulence, Brhaspati silently left the assembly. He didn't curse Indra, although capable of doing so. Indra immediately realized that he had offended his guru. Regretting his grave mistake, he spoke, Alas, I am so foolish to have committed such a great offense due to my pride! I failed to respect my guru. Now I will go and bow down at his feet. Although Indra searched for Bṛhaspati everywhere with the assistance of the devatās, he couldn't find him. To teach a lesson to Indra, Bṛhaspati had disappeared by his great power. Indra lost his peace. Hearing of Indra's pitiable condition, the demons declared war against the devatās. Their guru Śukrācārya guided them to attack the devatās. Soon the demons heavily injured the devatās and chased them away from heaven. Then, they occupied the heaven and enjoyed all its comforts. The distressed devatās approached Lord Brahma with bowed heads, seeking shelter and guidance. Brahma scolded them for their misbehavior. He admonished them saying, Due to the madness of your wealth and position, you failed to receive your guru Brhaspati properly. He is a virtuous brāhmana with great spiritual knowledge. Due to your offenses, you who are so strong have been defeated by the weak demons, who have been defeated by you several times before. The demons gained great strength by worshipping their guru. If you respect brahmanas, cows and Lord Govinda, there will be no misfortune; but if you disrespect them, there will be great misfortune. Brahma then instructed the devatās, Now you all should accept Viśvarūpa as your guru. His father Tvastā is a powerful brāhmaṇa while his mother Racanā is the daughter of demons. So, Viśvarūpa will help you regain your kingdom. But because he is related to the demons through his mother, he can show some affection for them too. So you have to tolerate that. Thus, Lord Brahmā guided Indra and the other devatās in their difficulty. Did Brahmā's solution work? How did Viśvarūpa respond to the request of the devatās? Turn over to the next story to find out.
quotes: False pride makes one disrespect great personalities., When we humbly approach wise people for help, they will show some way out.
activity: 1. Do you think wealth makes everyone proud? 2. How do you greet your teacher? 3. How would you feel when you are ignored at a get-together of friends? Explain. 4. Treat the people the way you want to be treated by them. Explain this statement.
lesson: A LESSON ON ETTIQUETTE: When your teacher comes to your home, wouldn't you receive him or her with warmth and respect? Any sane person observes the general etiquette of honoring elders, parents and teachers. As soon as a student sees the teacher, the student must acknowledge the teacher's presence by standing up, greeting and bowing down. With such a culture of respect, one receives blessings. The satisfaction of guru is the source of great strength in life. Conversely, dissatisfaction of guru makes one weak. By disrespecting their guru, the strong devatās became weaker than the demons. And by respecting their guru, the weak demons become stronger than the devatās. So let's cultivate the right etiquette towards all elders.

attributes.main_character_type: Celestial Being (Indra, Brihaspati, and other Devas)
