title: The Invincible Shiled
story: After hearing the advice of Brahmā, the devatās were somewhat relieved of their anxiety. They all went to Viśvarūpa, the powerful brāhmana with three heads. Embracing him they said, Dear Viśvarūpa, may there be all good fortune for you. Although you are younger than us, we offer our obeisances to you, because you are advanced in mantras. We accept you as our guru because you are a perfect brāhmaņa, and by your power we will easily defeat our enemies. Please mercifully relieve our distress. The demons took away our positions. Viśvarūpa was pleased and replied, Dear devatās, I agree to be your priest. I can't refuse even a small request from you because you are the commanders of the universe. After making this promise, liberal Viśvarūpa taught Indra a secret protective prayer called Nārāyaṇa-kavaca as follows. Protection by chanting mantras: Chant the eight-syllable mantra - 'om namo nārāyaṇāya' - chant one syllable of this mantra on the following limbs in order: feet, knees, thighs, belly, heart, chest, mouth, and head. Then chant the twelve-syllable mantra - om namo bhagavate vāsudevāya - place the syllables of this mantra on the tips of the fingers, from right index finger to left index finger, place the remaining four syllables on the joints of the two thumbs. Then chant the six-syllable mantra - om vişnave namah - place the syllable om on the heart; vi on the top of the head; sa between the eyebrows; na on the śikhā; ve between the eyes; na on all the joints of the body and meditate on the syllable ma as being a weapon. Thus, the mantras will become protective armors in all directions. Protection by different avataras: May Lord Visnu on the back of Garuda, whose eight hands hold the conch, disk, sword, shield, club, arrow, bow and noose, protect me on all sides. May Matsya avatara (the Fish incarnation) protect me in water from fierce animals. May Lord Vamana (the dwarf-brāhmana incarnation) protect me on the land. May Lord Nrsimhadeva (the half-man half-lion incarnation) protect me in difficult places like the forests and battlefield. May Lord Varaha (the Boar incarnation) save me on the streets. May Lord Kurma (the Tortoise incarnation) save me from falling to hell. May Lord Ramacandra protect me in the foreign countries. May Lord Dhanvantari protect me from unhealthy eatables and physical illness. May Lord Rṣabhadeva save me from all fears. May Lord Balarama protect me from injuries caused by others. May Lord Sesa from envious serpents. May Vyāsadeva protect me from ignorance. May Lord Buddha save me from activities opposed to the Vedas and laziness. May Lord Kalki protect me from the dirt of Kaliyuga. Protection by the Lord's weapons: May the Lord's disc (Sudarśana cakra) burn all our enemies to ashes. May His Club (Gadā) help me pound to pieces all the evil beings like the ghosts and demons. May Lord Krsna's conch (Pāñcajanya) filled with His air creates fearful sound vibrations and cause trembling in the hearts of enemies. May the Lord's sword cut the soldiers of my enemies to pieces. May His shield marked with a hundred brilliant moonlike circles cover the eyes of the sinful enemies and pluck out their sinful eyes. Holy name: May the Lord's name protect us from the influence of bad planets, meteors, envious people, serpents, scorpions, ferocious animals, ghosts and sins. May Garuda protect us from all dangers. Viśvarūpa concluded, Dear Indra, by employing this Nārāyana-kavaca prayer, you will be able to conquer the demons easily and will be saved from all dangers. By the power of Nārāyaṇa-kavaca, Indra conquered the demons, and again became the ruler of heaven. Did Indra live happily ever after? Or did the demons make a stronger comeback? Read ahead to find out!
quotes: The names of God are not different from God. Therefore, by chanting His names, we invoke His protection., All the avataras of the Lord are eternal, although they come and go at different times., All the weapons of the Lord are personalities who hear and respond to our prayers.
activity: 1. Do you think the Lord will personally listen to our prayers? Explain. 2. What is your favorite form of the Lord? Which prayer do you love to offer Him daily? 3. Try to memorize a scriptural prayer, and understand its meaning. 4. Lord Krishna protected cows & is known as Gopala. Would you like to protect cows too? If so, how? 5. Try finding out which form the Lord took to protect Bhumi devi from the threat of a tyrant.
lesson: A LESSON ON PROTECTION: Lord Krsna in the Bhagavad-gita said that He incarnates in every yuga to protect the virtuous and punish the vicious. Thus, He has unlimited forms in which He reciprocates with the devotees as per their mood. All the incarnations of the Lord are eternal, and they continuously protect the devotees. For instance, Lord Narasimha protected Prahlada and killed the demon Hiranyakasipu. But that doesn't mean He wouldn't protect His devotees now. He eternally protects all His devotees and punishes the demons who torment them. We can invoke the Lord's protection by sincere worship and devotion. The Lord is so merciful that He protects His selfless devotees even without asking for it.

title: The Birth of a Brahmana Demon
story: One day, Indra saw Viśvarūpa performing a sacrifice in which he was visibly offering oblations to the devatās, and secretly to the demons as well. It was because his mother came from the family of demons Indra noticed this and thought that Viśvarūpa was cheating him. Feeling very insecure that the demons would become strong again, Indra angrily cut off Viśvarūpa's three heads. Those heads became three types of birds. Indra had committed a grave sin by killing a brāhmaṇa who had acted as his guru and helped him regain his position. Thus Indra suffered the sinful reaction for one year, and repented for his misdeed. Viśvarūpa's father Tvastā became very upset with Indra for killing his son. To take revenge on Indra, he performed a sacrifice to get a son who could kill Indra. However, because of improper pronunciation of mantras, he got a son who would be killed by Indra. From Tvastā's sacrificial fire appeared a fearful demon who looked like the destroyer of the entire creation. He was tall, blackish, gigantic, and lustrous, with a coppery hair, beard, and moustache. His eyes were burning red, and he held a blazing trident. He shouted in a loud voice, and made the earth tremble as if from an earthquake. As he yawned, he seemed to swallow the sky with his cave-like mouth. He seemed to be licking up the stars with his tongue and eating the entire universe with his long, sharp teeth. Seeing this gigantic demon everyone ran in all directions in great fear. Because he covered all the planets, he was named Vrtrāsura (one who covers everything). Although a demon, Vrträsura was considered a brahmana because he was the son of Tvasta who did sacrifice to beget him. And Tvasta's son Viśvarūpa was Vrträsura's brother. Now Vrträsura's mission was to attack Indra who had killed his brother Viśvarūpa impulsively. Vrträsura immediately left the sacrificial arena to fight with the devatās. The devatās attacked Vrtrāsura, striking him with heavenly bows and arrows and other weapons, but Vrtrāsura swallowed all their weapons. Struck with wonder and disappointment, the devatās ran away for the shelter of Lord Visnu. They prayed, O Lord, You have protected us earlier in many incarnations (avatāras). You appeared among the devatās as Lord Vāmana, among the sages as Lord Paraśurāma, among the animals as Varaha, among the aquatics as Matsya and Kürma, and among men as Rāma and Krsna. Now please appear in some form and save us from this fearful demon Vrtrāsura. In response to their appeal, Lord Visnu appeared in front of them. Seeing Him, the devatās fell at His feet like rods, and said, O supremely merciful Lord! You are the sole proprietor of the entire universe. You have always appeared in various incarnations to punish the demons. Please appear today as another incarnation to kill Vrtrāsura. He has swallowed all our weapons, and strength. Hearing the prayers of the devatās, Lord Visnu replied, Dear devatās, pure devotees only aspire to serve Me selflessly, without any material desires. But since you have approached Me for protection from a demon, I shall suggest you a way to come out of this danger. What was the advice of Visnu to the devatās? Did his solution help them kill Vrtrāsura? Read the next story to know!
quotes: Anger makes one commit serious sins without considering the consequences., In sacrifices for material purposes, even if there is a slight discrepancy, the results would be opposite., The Lord has solutions for all problems. So, in any situation it's best to seek His shelter.
activity: 1. Recall an incident where you hurt someone out of momentary anger? 2. Tvashta decided to take revenge against Indra. Do you think it was reasonable? Explain. 3. What would you do when your friend confesses his mistakes and miseries? (i) passively listen, (ii) scold him, (iii) gossip about it, (iv) help him with a solution.
lesson: A LESSON ON SUPPORT: How would you feel when you have someone to support you in times of difficulty? As long as one is in this world, whether on earth or in heaven, one commits mistakes and faces troubles. Even the devatās are not an exception. Although they sometimes manifest poor attitudes and behaviors, they are obedient servants of Lord Vişņu. So, the Lord always supports them in difficulties, and shows them how to come out of dangers. Similarly, when we see youngsters commit some small mistakes sometimes, we shouldn't ignore the persons, but try to extend our support and help them overcome their shortcomings.

title: Unbelievable Generosity
story: Seeing the devatās fearful of Vrtrasura and seeking some solution, Lord Visnu advised them, You all should immediately approach sage Dadhici, who is My great devotee. His body is very powerful because of his great spiritual knowledge and activities. Earlier, he taught spiritual science to the Aśvinī-kumāras, the heavenly doctors. Once, the Aśvini-kumāras approached Dadhici Muni and begged him to teach spiritual science. Dadhīci replied, Now I am busy with some sacrifices. Please come after some time. The Aśvinī-kumāras then left. Thereafter, Indra approached Dadhici and said,My dear Muni, the Aśvinī-kumāras are just doctors. Please do not instruct them in spiritual science. If you do so, I shall cut off your head. After warning Dadhīci in this way, Indra returned to heaven. The Aśvinī-kumāras knew Indra's mind, yet they again approached Dadhīci for spiritual knowledge. When Dadhīci informed them of Indra's threat, they said, Dear sage, first we will cut off your head and replace it with a horse's head, through which you can teach us. When Indra comes and cuts off that head, we shall restore your original head. Dadhīci considered that he had already promised the Aśvinī-kumāras, so he agreed to their proposal, and gave them divine spiritual teachings through the mouth of a horse. Such was his selfless nature. Continuing to praise Dadhici in front of the devatās, Lord Vişnu said, It was Dadhici who taught the Narayana-kavaca to Tvastā, who then taught it to Viśvarūpa. Later Viśvarūpa taught it to Indra, who thus conquered the demons and regained heaven. Now you all ask Dadhici for his bones. He will give them to you if the Asvini-kumaras request him. Then, the heavenly architect Viśvakarma will prepare a thunderbolt (vajra) weapon from his bones. This thunderbolt will certainly kill Vrträsura. Vrtrāsura is also My devotee and will not harm you. Do not worry. Having thus instructed the devatās, Lord Vişnu disappeared. Following the advice of Lord Visnu, all the devatās approached Dadhici and begged for his bones. Dadhīci smiled and jokingly said, Don't you know about the unbearable pain of death? The body is very dear to every living being. One has to protect it by all means. How can one give it up, even if demanded by Lord Visnu? The devatās replied, O great sage, you can understand others' difficulties, because you are compassionate. Selfish people don't understand the pain of others. If the rich knew the beggar's pain, they would not refuse to give charity. So, what is difficult to give up for merciful people like you? Dadhīci Muni replied, Dear devatās, I refused to offer my body, just to hear from you about dharma. Otherwise, I have no objection. I shall happily give it for your service as advised by Lord Visnu. Anyways, I will have to leave this temporary body one day. It may die at any moment. Using it for the welfare of others is the right utility of this body. One who has no compassion for suffering people, and does not use one's body for others' welfare, is pitiable. Dadhīci then gave up his body while meditating on his beloved Lord Visnu. In a deep trance, he did not even realize that he was dying The devatās took away the bones from his body, and gave them to Viśvakarmā, to make a thunderbolt (vajra) weapon from them. When Viśvakarmā made the invincible thunderbolt, charged with Dadhici's power, Indra took it up. Riding on his elephant carrier Airāvata, surrounded by thousands of devatās, Indra went to attack Vrtrāsura. Vrtrāsura was accompanied by powerful demon warriors. A fierce battle took place between the devatās and the demons on the bank of the Narmadā River. Who won in the battle? Was Indra able to kill Vrtrāsura with the vajra? Read on to discover.
quotes: Merciful people always extend themselves to help others. Because seeing others in distress causes them distress., Noble people lament the distress of others and rejoice at their joy.
activity: 1. Name two persons who did selfless service even at the risk of their lives. 2. What stops us from being selfless in serving others? 3. Does selflessly serving others means compromising on your own basic needs and desires? Explain.
lesson: A LESSON ON SELFLESS SERVICE: What do you think is the best use of our bodies? Eating, sleeping, working, earning money. enjoyment and so on! Yes, the body may be utilized for all these activities. Yet there is a better use of it - for the service of other living beings, who are God's children. Wise people know that the body is temporary and can collapse at any moment. So, they utilize every opportunity to use it for the welfare of others, without expecting anything in return. Such selfless service - (i) pleases the Lord, (ii) satisfies ourselves, and (iii) helps develop loving relationships. Compassionate people serve others even at the cost of personal inconvenience. The greatest type of service one can render others is to bring people closer to God. Let us cultivate such a spirit of selfless service by taking Inspiration from examples like Dadhici Muni.

title: Motivation on The Battlefield
story: The demons attacked the devatās with mountain peaks, tridents, axes, swords and other deadly weapons. The devatās were covered by arrows like the stars are covered by dense clouds, but they quickly slashed those lethal weapons to pieces before they even reached them. The demons became afraid when they saw that the soldiers of King Indra were not at all injured by their weapons. Scared for their lives, they left their leader Vrtrāsura even at the beginning of the fight, and ran away from the battlefield. Vrtrāsura spoke some wise words to motivate the fleeing demons, O Vipracitti! O Namuci! O Pulomā! O Maya and Śambara! Please hear me. If one dies on the battlefield by fighting the enemies without showing one's one's back, one will be promoted to higher planets. So don't run away. Fight! However, the demons were too fearful. They didn't pay heed to their commander's words, and started running away from the devatās. Taking advantage of their fear, the devatās chased them and attacked them from rear. Vrtrāsura then chastised the devatās, Attacking the demons is useless. What is the benefit of killing enemies from behind if they are fleeing in fear? It is a shame on you. If you are courageous, stand before me for a moment on the battlefield. Angry Vrträsura terrified the devatās. When he roared with an enormous voice, resembling a lion, the devatās fainted as if struck by thunderbolts. As the devatas closed their eyes in fear, Vrträsura, taking up his trident and making the earth tremble, trampled the devatās like a mad elephant tramples hollow bamboos. Seeing Vrtrāsura, Indra became intolerant and threw a great club at him, but Vrtrāsura easily caught it with his left hand. Then, Vrträsura angrily struck Airāvata's head with the same club and roared loudly. For this heroic deed, the soldiers on both sides glorified him. Spitting blood from its broken mouth, Airāvata was pushed back fourteen yards along with Indra. Seeing the condition of Airavata and despondent Indra, Vrtrāsura didn't further strike Indra. Indra relieved Airavata with his nectar-producing hand and gained composure. Remembering Indra's sinful acts, Vrtrāsura spoke, O abominable one! You acted like a butcher by mercilessly severing the three heads of my brother Viśvarūpa. He was a sinless brāhmaņa and your guru. You have no shame and mercy. I will clear my debt to my brother by piercing your stone-like heart with my trident. When I kill you, only vultures will eat your body. If the other devatās attack me, I shall sever their heads too. Indra became ashamed of hearing these words. Vrtrāsura instructed Indra, But if you kill me in this fight, I will go to Vaikuntha. Why don't you hurl your thunderbolt weapon at me? Indra thought, Vrtrāsura is cheating me. Just as he made my club useless, he will make the thunderbolt useless by his powers, and again attack me. To reassure him, Vrtrāsura said, Your victory is assured. The thunderbolt has been empowered by Lord Visnu's blessings and Dadhici's austerities. You can kill me with it. When Visnu favors a person, victory, opulence, and good qualities are assured. By that thunderbolt, I will be freed from this world and attain Lord Sankarşana in Vaikuntha. Material heaven is of no use for the Lord's devotees. Seeing that Indra did not throw the thunderbolt, Vrtrāsura thought, What is the use of speaking to this rascal Indra who sees everything materially? I better pray to my Lord. What were the prayers offered by Vrtrāsura? After the prayers, did the fight continue or not? Turn the page to discover!
quotes: Death is unavoidable, and there is no means to escape it.
activity: 1. Can those born as demons can be devotees of the Lord? Give some examples. 2. How do you think one can build steady faith in the Lord? 3. Does having faith In the Lord mean, ceasing to make any effort ourselves? Explain with some examples.
lesson: A LESSON ON TRUST: Who is the most trustworthy person? One who always keeps one's promise, and whose words shall never go wrong! Isn't it? - God is most trustworthy. Lord Krşņa spoke many principles and gave many promises in the Bhagavad-gita, that can never be wrong. Because He is all-powerful and always compassionate, one can completely depend on Him and trust Him. Trusting the abilities and intentions of the Lord is a vital aspect of bhakti. In this story, we see that Vrträsura's faith in Lord Vişnu's words is more than that of Indra. That faith makes demon Vrträsura a better devotee than devatā Indra.

title: The Devotion of A Demon
story: Seeing Indra not ready to fight, Vrtrāsura meditated on Lord Visnu. He prayed, O Lord, may my mind always think of You. May my words always praise Your divine qualities. May my body always engage in Your loving service. I do not desire heavenly enjoyment, mystic powers or liberation. All I need is Your service. May I become a servant of Your wonderful servants. Expressing his longing to reach the Lord, Vrtrāsura implored, Just as baby birds are dependent on the mother bird to feed them, just as hungry calves wait to drink the milk of their mother cows, and just as a wife lovingly waits for her husband to return home, I always yearn for the opportunity to serve You directly! Please give me the friendship of Your wonderful devotees. Let my mind not be attached to anything in this temporary world. Vrtrāsura then thought, Indra would become agitated and fight again, if I show my prowess. So, Vrtrāsura whirled his trident and threw it at Indra exclaiming loudly, O evil one, now I shall finish you off! Indra cut that blazing trident to pieces with his thunderbolt and also cut off the right arm of Vrtrāsura ruthlessly. Vrträsura then angrily struck Indra on the jaw with an iron mace. He also struck Airāvata. Then the thunderbolt weapon slipped from Indra's hand and fell to the ground. The devatās praised Vrtrāsura's deed, but seeing Indra in danger, and they lamented, Alas! Alas! Having been practically defeated, Indra felt ashamed to pick up his thunderbolt again. Vrtrāsura encouraged Indra, Take up your thunderbolt and kill your enemy. This is not the time for lamentation. Only Lord Visnu is always victorious. All others are sometimes victorious and sometimes defeated. Time is the cause of victory or defeat. Therefore, one should be equipoised in all the disturbing circumstances in life. Look at me! Even my arm is cut, I am still trying my best to fight, without being discouraged. Hearing Vrtrāsura's insightful words, Indra was surprised and thought, How can a demon possess such devotion, wisdom and detachment? Then he recollected how Prahlada, Bali and others who were born as demons but were very wise and devotional. So he felt that Vrtrāsura was like them. Indra took up his thunderbolt again, and praised Vrtrāsura: You are a perfect devotee. I can see your composure, wisdom and devotion despite your dangerous position. Thus, Vrtrāsura and Indra, both powerful fighters, spoke about bhakti even on the battlefield, and again began fighting dutifully. Vrträsura then threw his iron club at Indra with his left hand. Indra smashed it with his thunderbolt, and cut Vrtrāsura's left hand too. With his both hands lost, Vrtrāsura was bleeding profusely. Even in his weak state, he seemed to devour the entire universe. His gigantic form seemed that his lower jaw was on the ground, and his upper jaw in the sky. His mouth was deep like the sky, and his tongue was like a large serpent. He shook the mountains, crushing the earth's surface, as if he were the Himalayas walking about. Gaining his composure, Vrtrāsura came before Indra and swallowed him along with Airāvata, just as a gigantic python might swallow an elephant. Seeing this, the devatās and sages became surprised. Then Vrtrāsura reflected, Now I have killed Indra. There is no need to fight any more. Let me meditate on the Lord. He thus went into a trance. The living spark (soul) then came out of Vrtrāsura's body and joyfully entered Vaikuntha. Thus, he became an associate of Lord Sankarsana, a divine form of Lord Visnu in the spiritual world. Although swallowed by Vrtrāsura, Indra didn't die within his belly, because he was protected by the Nārāyaņa-kavaca. Instead, Indra came out of Vrtrāsura's abdomen by piercing it with his thunderbolt. Then he cut off Vrtrāsura's head with the thunderbolt. It took one year for him to do so. All the devatās celebrated Indra's victory, and showered flowers upon him in joy. But Indra wasn't happy. He was extremely sad despite being victorious. Read the next story to find out the reason.
quotes: A devotee desires to serve God without any selfish motives., The deep longing of devotees to serve God takes them closed to Him., We can responsibly perform our duties, but the results are not in our hands., Whether one is a devata or a demon, a child or an elder, a man or a woman anyone can have devotion for the Lord., When one's mind is fully absorbed in devotion to God, one doesn't even realize physical pain including death.
activity: 1. Whom did Lord Vishnu really favor in this story -Vrtrasura or Indra? 2. What are the examples of longing' that Vrtrasura mentioned? Whose longing is deeper? Explain.
lesson: A LESSON ON STEADINESS: Isn't it difficult to remain steady in challenging circumstances? It could be an exam, or an accident or some misunderstanding with a relative we tend to get confused and overwhelmed. But great people maintain steadiness in all situations. In this story, the demons on the side of Vrträsura left him. But instead of being discouraged, he fought alone. He even motivated Indra to perform his duty. He didn't misunderstand Lord Visnu, who arranged for his death through the thunderbolt. Thus, he showed great steadiness in his duty and devotion. Such steadiness in difficult situations comes from the blessings of devotees and deep faith in the Lord. Let's cultivate it and pray for it.

title: Victorious Yet Defeated!
story: When Vrtrāsura was killed, all the devatās felt relieved and returned to their homes peacefully. While departing, no one spoke anything to Indra. Indra was very dejected. He was mentally disturbed after killing Vrtrāsura, who was a brāhmaņa and a devotee of Lord Visnu. During the war, Indra was hesitant to kill Vrtrāsura, whom he found very exalted. But the devatās and the sages encouraged him to do so. Then Indra asked them, Previously, I foolishly killed Viśvarūpa and received a terrible sinful reaction, but somehow I was relieved from it. But now, if I kill Vrtrāsura, another noble brāhmaņa, how shall I free myself from the sin? The sages told Indra, We shall perform an aśvamedha yajña to release you from any sin you may accrue by killing the brāhmaņa. Do not fear. Thus, encouraged by the sages, Indra had killed Vrtrāsura, hoping that the yajña would relieve him from sins. Soon, the sinful reaction to killing a brahmana approached Indra. It took the form of a witch afflicted with tuberculosis. Her body was covered with filthy blood. Her head was covered with scattered grey hair. Her unbearable foul breath polluted the surroundings. She called Indra, Wait! Wait! and followed him wherever he went - in the sky and in all directions. At last, Indra went to the northeast and entered a lake called Manasa-sarovara. Indra lived invisibly in that lake for a thousand years always thinking of how he could be relieved from his sinful reaction. Finally, he stayed in the subtle fibers of a lotus stem, practically starving. In the absence of Indra, the devatās needed a king for the heaven. So, they approached a powerful king on the earth named Nahusa to rule the heaven. Nahusa had great knowledge and mystic powers. He agreed to take up the position, but became very proud of it. Once, Nahusa asked Indra's wife, Now I am in the position of Indra. Therefore, you should serve me. Surprised at this unreasonable proposal, Indra's wife reported this to Brhaspati, the guru of the devatās. Then Brhaspati advised her, Tell Nahusa that you will serve him if he comes in a palanquin carried by brāhmanas. She then informed Nahusa of the same. Thereafter, Nahusa ordered the sages including Agastya Muni to carry his palanquin. While the sages were carrying him, Nahusa arrogantly said, sarpa, sarpa, meaning Go quickly, go quickly. He even haughtily touched Agastya Muni with his foot. Agastya became angry and cursed Nahusa, O impudent king, you are so proud and disrespectful to the brāhmanas. May you become a sarpa (snake)! Thus, handsome and powerful Nahusa fell from his position and became an ugly python. Meanwhile, Indra, who was living in the Manasa-sarovara, repented for his sins by sitting in the lotus stem for a long time. Further, by the influence of Lord Śiva, Indra became further purified. And Mother Laksmi, who resides in the lotus, also gave protection to him. By meditating on Lord Visnu, Indra was ultimately relieved of all sins. Then he was called back to heaven by the brāhmaņas. Later Indra performed an aśvamedha-yajña and became relieved of all his sins. Thus, he was honored by everyone again. While reading the story, did you wonder how the king of devatās could get such a grave sinful reaction by killing a demon? Also, how could Vrtrāsura develop such great devotion to Lord Visnu? Turn on to the next story to find your answers.
quotes: Purposely committing sin on the strength of a spiritual activity is a great offense., Pride makes one fall from any great position.
activity: 1. How are purposely committed sins different from accidentally committed sins? Explain. 2. Recall a few names from the Bhagavatam who were cursed due to false pride. 3. Pride is like a thief who sneaks into our hearts unknowingly. Suggest some ways of guarding yourself against it. 4. Can we really love the Lord if we are proud?
lesson: A LESSON ON PRIDE: Would you be comfortable dealing with a person who is too proud? May be not, isn't it? Of all the bad qualities that a person can have, pride is one of the most degrading one. Nahusa, a human king on the earth, became the king of heaven because of his good qualities, but his pride made him a python! One may be very beautiful, educated, wealthy, popular and successful, but pride nullifies them. Proud people cannot accept others' greatness or understand others' pain. They tend to disrespect, mistreat and look down upon others. So, let us be extremely careful not to be proud. The opposite quality of pride is humility. We can save ourselves from pride by humbly transferring the credit for our success to all those who have helped us in life, and by respecting everyone appropriately.

title: When Happiness Meets Sorrow
story: In his previous life, Vrtrāsura was a great king named Citraketu, who ruled the Śūrasena province. He was handsome, educated, wealthy and kind. During his reign, the earth was prosperous in all ways. He married a beautiful queen named Krtadyuti, but he had no children. Then he married another wife, but still he didn't get a child. He desired a good successor who could take charge of the kingdom after his retirement. But he remained childless even after marrying ten million wives, due to his destiny. This filled his mind with anxiety. His wealth, beautiful queens and control over all lands didn't give him any happiness. Once, a powerful sage named Angirā, travelling all over the world, came to the palace of King Citraketu. Citraketu received him with great respect and bowed down to his feet. Being pleased with the hospitality, Angirā spoke, Dear Citraketu, is everything well? Are your wives, citizens, ministers, and servants cooperating with you? I see that your mind is not pleased. Your pale face reflects your anxiety. Citraketu bent his head and replied, What is unknown to perfect yogīs like yourself! Yet, because you asked me, let me disclose to you the cause for my anxiety. My prosperous kingdom doesn't please me, because I do not have a child. Please help me get a son. Merciful Angirā wanted to help Citraketu. He performed a sacrifice for him to get a son. He gave the prasādam (divine food) offered in the yajña to Krtadyuti, the first and most perfect among Citraketu's millions of queens. Then Angira departed after warning Citraketu, You will have a son, who will cause you both happiness and sorrow. Citraketu understood Angira's words in this way: My son's birth will certainly cause happiness. But, because he will be my only son, he will probably be proud of his great wealth and empire, and may not be very obedient. Thus, he might cause distress. But that is alright. Eventually, Krtadyuti gave birth to a beautiful son. Hearing this news, all the citizens were extremely pleased. Citraketu's happiness knew no bounds. First, he requested expert brāhmaņas to perform the birth ceremony for the new born baby. Then, like a cloud pours rain, he generously gave charity of gold, silver, garments, ornaments, villages, cows, and so on to receive blessings for his son. Citraketu's affection for his son increased daily. However, he spent most of his time with the boy and Krtadyuti, and neglected his other queens. This made them extremely unhappy. Feeling ignored by their husband, they desired to have children like the first queen. They all thought, If only we had children, we wouldn't be neglected by our husband. Even maidservants get respect from the husband, but childless wives are most unfortunate. The co-wives of Krtadyuti became envious of her fortune. They lost their intelligence, became hard-hearted and very intolerant. Considering the child to be the cause of their current situation, they gave him poison and killed him. Envy makes one hard-hearted, lose all common sense and take to destructive action. Unaware of the sinful act of her co-wives, Krtadyuti thought that her son had been sleeping for a long time. Later, she sent her maid to wake him up, only to realize that the child was dead. Shocked at seeing the lifeless boy, she cried profusely and fell to the ground unconscious. All the palace residents gathered there and began to cry. The queens who had given the poison also cried pretentiously. How did Citraketu react to his son's untimely death? What happened to his wives who poisoned the child? Read the next story to discover.
quotes: Just endeavoring to fulfill one's desires is not sufficient; one needs the sanction of God., Great persons can read the minds of people just by seeing their faces., Envy makes one hard-hearted, lose all common sense and take to destructive action.
activity: 1. Do you think Citraketu was also sesponsible for the actions of his wives who poisoned the child? Why? 2. King Citraketu's childless wives acted out of envy. How do you think you can tackle envy? 3. Mention some ill effects of envy. 4. Recollect some persons in the Bhagavatam who tried to harm others out of envy.
lesson: A LESSON ON ACCEPTANCE: Did you ever fail to achieve something despite trying so hard? Yes, it happens! Everything in our life is not in our control. We cannot decide the place of our birth, color of our bodies, gender, etc. But we do have the independence to make some choices in life. So, we need to focus on what is within our control, and accept things that are beyond our control the way they happen. God is watching all of us and shall certainly bestow what we deserve. But this shouldn't make us lazy. We should responsibly work towards our realistic goals, leaving the results in God's hands. We should know our practical limitations and shouldn't hanker for things that are too difficult or impossible to attain. That only wastes our time, which could have been productively used in self-improvement and God's service.

title: The Dead Comes to Life!
story: This news of the child's death reached King Citraketu, who came to the spot in great haste. His sorrow grew like a blazing fire. He became almost blind. Slipping and falling, he approached the dead child and fell unconscious at his feet, with his hair and dress scattered. Regaining consciousness, his eyes were tearful, and he could not speak. Seeing her husband's lamentation and the dead child, Krtadyuti blamed God, Alas, O Supreme knower, You are so foolish, for You have caused the death of his son while the father is still living. You have created strong bonds of affection and have broken them abruptly. What is the need for such a God? Krtadyuti then turning to her child's dead body, spoke, My dear son, please get up and drink my milk. Just look at your sad father. We are completely dejected by your absence. Please get up from your long sleep, your playmates are calling you. I am very unfortunate, for I can no longer see your charming smile, joyful eyes, lotus face and hear your pleasing voice. You have closed your eyes forever. As she piteously cried, the entire palace and kingdom of Citraketu were immersed in sadness. When Citraketu lay like a dead body next to his son's dead body, Nārada Muni and Angirā Muni spoke to him, Dear Citraketu, what relationship does this dead body have with you? Did this relationship exist before? Does it truly exist now? Will it continue in the future? Citraketu was confused to hear such questions. In deep grief he couldn't reply. Narada Muni said, As sand particles on a seashore come together and get separated by the force of waves, the living beings also sometimes come together and are separated by the force of time. We were not together before birth and will not be together after death. God brings people together and disperses them as they deserve. King Citraketu understood the philosophy verbally, but couldn't digest it heartily. The sages explained further, As from one seed another seed is generated, so from the parents' bodies, a child's body is generated. But the soul is not created by the parents. The body of the child is right in front of you! And you have never seen the eternal soul within the body. Whom are you lamenting for? Citraketu became enlightened by these timely teachings of the sages. Wiping his face with his hand, he said, O wise brāhmaņas, you travel on earth just to educate ignorant people like me. So, please enlighten me with your spiritual teachings. Then sage Angirā spoke, Dear king, we have come to relieve you from your sadness. Learned devotees never lament for material loss or gain. Earlier when I met you, you were overwhelmed with the desire to have a son. So I fulfilled your desire. Now that you have understood the temporary nature of material relationships, you are ready for spiritual knowledge. Narada Muni then spoke to Citraketu, I shall give you a very auspicious mantra. By receiving it, you will be able to see Lord Sankarşaņa face to face just in seven nights. Even Lord Siva and other great devatās took shelter of Lord Sankarsana with this mantra. Nārada Muni then brought the dead son alive with his mystic power and said, Dear child, just see your father and mother. Everyone is sad because of your passing away. Re-enter your body and enjoy life with your relatives. Accept your father's royal throne and wealth. The boy spoke, O great sage, in which birth were these persons my parents? I have been wandering in the bodies of devatās, animals, and human beings. In many lifetimes, I had many parents from different species. In different births people become our friends, relatives, enemies, well-wishers and so on. All these relationships are valid only when one is within a body. But no one is permanently related. Saying this, the boy again left, and people saw only his dead body. Citraketu and all others were astonished on hearing the bitter facts of life taught by the child. Giving up their sadness, they dutifully arranged for the funeral ceremony of the dead boy, as a matter of custom. Krtadyuti's co-wives were ashamed of their sinful act. They atoned for the killing of the child on the bank of the Yamuna River as directed by brāhmaņas. There after, Citraketu chanted the mantra given by Narada Muni continuously for one week His mind thus became increasingly attached to Lord Sankarsana, who was pleased to appear in front of him. The Lord's complexion was whitish. He was dressed in bluish garments, and was adorned with a dazzling crown and other ornaments. Seeing the Lord, Citraketu offered Him prayers. The Lord blessed him and said, By the instructions of Narada and Angira, you have gained spiritual knowledge and are able to see Me. Human Birth is very rare, and must be utilized properly. Its ultimate goal is to perform bhakti-yoga and understand Me. O King, you will achieve Me at the end of life. Saying this, the Lord departed as Citraketu looked on. By the mercy of the Lord, Citraketu became the ruler of the Vidyadhara planet. The story doesn't end here! There was an unexpected difficulty in Citraketu's life when he encountered Lord Śiva. He became a demon! To know how, turn on to the next chapter!
quotes: Unaware of the laws of nature, people blame and criticize God for their miseries.
activity: 1. Do you think Krtadyuti's blaming of the Lord was right? Expalin. 2. Material relationships are temporary as we read in this story. Does that mean that we have to be indifferent to them? 3. Recall an instance where you received timely advice from someone unexpectedly?
lesson: A LESSON ON ENLIGHTENMENT: Do you remember a situation where you became emotional and confused, and your mother comforted you? When unexpected things happen, me tends to get puzzled and demotivated. In such circumstances, we need timely enlightenment from a mature well-wisher. Kind devotees give us the right perspective in life's situations and clear our confusions. Opportunity to associate with such people is a great fortune. When King Citraketu was overwhelmed due to his son's death, Närada Muni and Angirä Muni enlightened him with the right knowledge and helped him attain the Lord. That's the power of wise association. Let us humbly seek enlightenment from such great people to solve life's puzzling problems, instead of getting depressed or discouraged.

title: The Miraculous Curse
story: Once King Citraketu was traveling in outer space on a celestial airplane given to him by the Lord Himself. He was surrounded by many women who are singing about Lord Visnu with devotion. While thus traveling, he saw Lord Śiva in an assembly of many sages, with Pārvatī sitting on his lap. Seeing this, Citraketu laughed loudly and spoke in front of everyone, Lord Śiva is everyone's guru and a great speaker of dharma. Yet, he is publicly sitting with his wife on his lap, as if he were a shameless man! Even ordinary people embrace their wives in solitary places. How surprising it is that he is doing so in an assembly of saints! Citraketu didn't mean to insult Lord Śiva like Daksa did. He certainly had great respect for Śiva. But he was concerned that when common people see Lord Śiva sitting with Parvati on his lap, they might misunderstand and criticize him. He didn't want exalted Śiva to have such infamy. Knowing Citraketu's mind, Lord Śiva smiled and mained silent. The sages and brāhmaņas sitting there also did not Speak. Although Citraketu had a genuine concern, he was somewhat proud of his attaining the mercy of Lord Sankarsana. Hence, he fearlessly commented on Lord Śiva, which Mother Pārvati didn't appreciate. She was very upset with his bold behavior. Mother Parvati angrily spoke, Has this upstart been appointed as the punisher of shameless persons like us? It seems Brahmā, Nārada, Manu and Kapila have all forgotten dharma, as they did not stop Lord Śiva's so called improper behavior! This person who proudly insulted Śiva doesn't deserve the shelter of Lord Visnu. He is puffed up, thinking himself a great devotee. O arrogant Citraketu, may you become a demon so that you will not commit such an offence again towards great personalities. Citraketu then came down from his airplane, bowed down before Pärvatī with great humility, and pleasingly spoke, O mother, I accept your curse. I don't blame anyone for this incident, because happiness and distress are results one's own deeds. In this material world, what is a curse and what is a blessing? What is heaven and what is hell? None of these have a permanent effect. Please forgive me for my improper speech. Saying this, Citraketu left in his airplane as everyone looked on in astonishment. Then Śiva spoke to Pārvatī, O Pārvatī! You angrily cursed Citraketu, but he didn't become angry or curse you in return. Instead, he was composed, and respectfully addressed you as a mother. That means your curse didn't have any effect on him. Such devotees never fear any condition of life. For them heaven, hell or liberation are all the same. They are interested only in the service of Lord Nārāyana. Both Citraketu and I are very dear to the Lord Sankarsana. Sometimes he jokes with me, and sometimes I joke with him. Hearing Lord Śiva's words, Pārvati felt ashamed for cursing Citraketu. Because of Parvati's curse, Citraketu became Vrtrāsura, the great demon who terrorized all the devatās, and was finally killed by Indra's thunderbolt. In fact, Pārvatī's curse was a boon for Citraketu. Because, after taking birth as the demon Vṛtrāsura and dutifully fighting with Indra, he immediately went to Vaikuntha. Being born as Vrtrāsura increased his love for the Lord. Lord Visnu wanted Citraketu to come to Vaikuntha as soon possible. So, out of affection, He inspired Mother Parvati to curse Citraketu. In this way, he showed us that a devotee is unaffected by curses and blessings.
quotes: Even if there is some apparent fault in the activities of an exalted person, one shouldn't correct them., A mother's punishment for a misbehaving son is out of her natural affection., Tolerance is one of the primary qualities of a devotee., Whether a devotee is born in the body of a devata or a demon or an animal, it doesn't matter.
activity: 1. Do you think Citraketu's remark was inappropriate? Why? 2. What should we do when elders chastise us without understanding our intentions? 3. What would you do when someone comments on you publicly?
lesson: A LESSON ON RESPECT: Would you feel comfortable when someone criticizes you publicly? Public disrespect is painful, especially when a younger person does it. Just as we expect others to deal with us respectfully, we ought to treat them respectfully. Especially when we are dealing with elders, Including parents and teachers, we need to be very respectful. Even if we happen to see some faults in them, we shouldn't criticize them arrogantly, considering their age and experience. If we disagree with their decisions or actions, we may express it respectfully and privately without demeaning them. Such a culture of respecting elders shall please the Lord.

title: Turning Revenge into Love
story: Once Diti, the mother of the demons, became very upset with Indra. She thought, To favor Indra, Lord Visnu had killed my two sons Hiranyāksa and Hiranyakaśipu, in the forms of Lord Varāha and Lord Narasimha respectively. Hardhearted Indra is the cause of my sons' death. Only when sinful Indra is killed, I can rest in peace. I wish to have a son who can kill him. Hiranyāksa and Hiranyakaśipu were cruel demons, who had tormented the devatās, sages and innocent people. So, the punishment they received was appropriate. Still, Diti envied Indra and desired his death. To fulfil her wicked desire, Diti constantly served her husband Kaśyapa Muni with her sweet and charming words, and tried to impress him. Though learned, Kaśyapa was pleased by her artificial behavior and assured her, My dear Diti, I am very happy with your service. You can ask for any boon from me. Hearing her husband's promise, Diti became joyful and expressed her desire, My only desire is to get an immortal son who can kill cruel Indra, who was the cause of my sons' death. Hearing such an unusual request, Kaśyapa thought, If I fulfill my wife's desire, I will fall down to hell. I ignorantly promised her not knowing her cruel intentions. I cannot give up my promise, but Indra should not be killed also. I need to find a suitable solution. Thinking thus, Kaśyapa spoke to Diti, I will teach you a method of worship called pumsavana vrata, that you need to perform for one year. If you follow it strictly, you will get a son who can kill Indra. Otherwise, your son will become a friend of Indra. Diti enthusiastically said, I will follow the vrata strictly. Please tell me all its rules and regulations. Kaśyapa Muni instructed Diti, While doing this pumsavana vrata, you should not harm or curse anyone, speak lies, touch impure things, or associate with sinful people. You should worship cows, brāhmaņas, Goddess Lakṣmī and Lord Nārāyana. Diti eagerly started the vrata. Understanding Diti's purpose, Indra came in disguise and started serving Diti. He carefully observed her routine just to find a fault in her vrata. He daily brought flowers, fruits, roots, wood, kuśa grass, leaves, sprouts and water at the proper time for her worship of Lakṣmī Nārāyāņa. Just as a hunter covers himself with a deerskin and becomes like a deer to kill a deer. Unable to find any faults in her practice, he became worried. One day, Diti unfortunately neglected to wash her mouth, hands and feet after eating, and went to sleep during the evening time. Finding this fault, Indra entered her womb with his mystic powers, while she was fast asleep. With his thunderbolt, he cut her embryo into seven pieces. But they became seven children. He then cut each of them in to seven pieces again. These forty-nine pieces became forty-nine children, and Indra was surprised. Being aggrieved, the children pleaded to Indra with folded hands, Dear Indra, we are your brothers, the Maruts. Why are you trying to kill us? When Indra heard their appeal, he said, You were supposed to be the cause of my death, but since you are all my brothers, you have nothing to fear. I shall not kill you. Meanwhile Diti got up from her sleep and saw her forty-nine sons, as brilliant as fire, and in friendship with Indra. Diti saw Indra and asked him, I performed this vrata just to get a son to kill you. I prayed for only one son, but now there are forty-nine. How has this happened? Please tell me the truth. Indra replied, My dear mother! Being selfish, I came to find fault in your vrata and cut your embryo. When I cut the child into seven pieces, seven children appeared. When I cut each of them into seven pieces, forty-nine children appeared. None of them died. Seeing this great wonder, I understood that this is a result of your sincere worship of Lakṣmī Nārāyana. I am a fool. Kindly excuse me for my sinful acts. Diti was pleased by Indra's truthfulness and humility, Diti gave up her anger. Because she worshipped Lord Visnu wholeheartedly for a long time, her sons became equal to the devatās. Then, Indra offered respects to her, and with her permission went to heaven with his brothers, the forty-nine Maruts. Kaśyapa was delighted with the transformation in Diti. Wise people expertly engage common people in the worship of Lord Visnu to purify their bad intentions.
activity: 1. Recall any other personality form the Bhagavatam who worshiped the Lord with material desires, but was purified later. 2. Do you believe that Diti's desire to have a son to kill Indra is justified? Explain.
lesson: A LESSON ON TRANSFORMATION: Ideally one should worship God selflessly. But what if someone performs bhakti with evil desires? Will the Lord show mercy on such people? - The answer to this question is so beautifully depicted in this story. Diti had a malicious desire to kill Indra, but Kaśyapa tactfully engaged her in worshiping the Lord, by which she was purified of her evil intentions. Sincere practice of bhakti transforms the hearts of even selfish people. Therefore, whatever may be our mood or desire, we can perform bhakti of Lord Vişnu or Krşņa, and that bhakti shall purify us of all unwanted qualities. If someone with selfish motives is purified by bhakti, what to speak of performing bhakti with pure intentions to serve the Lord.

title: The Philosophical Demon
story: Hiranyākşa and Hiranyakaśipu were two powerful asuras born of Diti and Kaśyapa. Hiranyākṣa performed severe austerities and received great boons from Lord Bramhā. As a result, he became very proud and tormented the entire universe. To end his atrocities and rescue the world, Lord Vişnu appeared as a divine boar, Varahadeva, and heroically killed him. Hearing the news of his brother's death, Hiranyakaśipu became enraged and began biting his lips. He gazed at the sky with fierce glances and frowning eyebrows. He summoned his demoniac companions ragingly and said, O Śambara, Namuci, Vipracitti and other Rākṣasas, please hear me. Although Lord Vişnu is equal to everyone, just like a restless child, He sided with the insignificant devatās who were His devotees. In the form of a boar, He mercilessly slayed my well-wishing brother Hiranyakşa! I will soon behead that diplomatic Vişnu with my trident! With His blood, I shall please my brother, who is very fond of drinking blood. When a tree's root is cut, the branches and twigs automatically shrivel up. Similarly, when Vişnu is killed, the devatās will automatically become powerless. Therefore, Hiranyakaśipu continued, while I execute my plan of killing Vişnu, you asuras should destroy everyone engaged in sacrifices, Vedic study, and dharma. The earth is flourishing because of the pious brāhmaņas and their austerities. If we stop all their spiritual activities, we can easily destroy the devatās and Vişnu. By nature, the demons love creating chaos. Having received the orders of Hiranyakasipu, they became even more enthusiastic. They set cities, villages, gardens, fields, forests, hermitages, and cowsheds ablaze. They didn't even spare the trees. Being disturbed by their malicious activities, innocent people were forced to give up the Vedic culture. As a result of the yajñas stopping, the devatās didn't receive their share of oblations and were thus dissatisfied. Havoc and misery rampaged in all directions. Meanwhile, Hiranyakaśipu performed the last rites of Hiranyakşa. Seeing his mother, Diti, sister-in-law, nephews, and family members heartbroken, Hiranyakaśipu began consoling them. Being an expert diplomat, he was well-versed in the art of speaking according to the situation. He said, Dear relatives, please don't mourn the death of my brother. He was a great hero who died gloriously while battling his enemy. We cannot control birth and death. We come together as members of the same family only until our karma keeps us together. Once that karma is exhausted, we head to different destinations. Like travelers who meet at a restaurant for some time and then depart after enjoying the meals, we, too, come together for a while and then part ways. Also, unlike the body, the soul is eternal. Therefore, we shouldn't feel depressed at the loss of a person because death is unavoidable. Hiranyakaśipu then narrated the tale of a great king as follows: Once there lived a king named Suyajña who ruled the province of Uşīnara. One day, in a deadly battle, he was killed by his sly enemies. His solid armor lay smashed, ornaments scattered, hair disarrayed, and eyes lifeless. His body was smeared entirely with blood while his heart was pierced with razor-sharp arrows. He thus fell on the battlefield. Upon hearing this, all his queens came running to his dead body. Being dismayed, they wept profusely. Thinking about their dear husband, their hair scattered about their faces while their ornaments fell to the ground. Their condition evoked sympathy from others. Recollecting their loving exchanges with the king, they continued wailing. Even at sunset, they obstructed their husband's body from being burnt. Their loud cries reached the ears of Yamarāja, the lord of death. Yamarāja then personally came from Yamaloka. He appeared before the queens as a little boy and said, Alas, it is amazing that these people older than me, who have seen hundreds of births and deaths, are still bewildered. No one can avoid death! Why can't they understand this? The Lord who has protected us in our mother's womb will surely protect us everywhere. By His will, people will live, and when He sanctions, people will die. Hence, one shouldn't become confused and dysfunctional with the death of relatives. Then, the boy (Yamarāja) narrated a small story: Once, there lived a hunter in a forest who sustained himself by killing birds. One day, he saw a pair of birds and cunningly captured the female bird in his net. She then began crying profusely. Seeing his wife in danger, the male bird lamented and said, Alas, destiny is so merciless. My wife has been put in this awkward situation. Let me also have the same fate. My wife is half of my body. What is the use of my living without her? Our children are completely helpless. How can I maintain them without my wife? In this way, the male bird lamented. Meanwhile, the hunter killed the male bird, too, with an arrow. After narrating the story of the birds, Yamarāja spoke to the queens of Suyajña, O foolish women, even if you lament for hundreds of years, your husband will not become alive. And in the meantime, your lives will also be finished. Hearing these words of wisdom, everyone was struck with wonder. Then Yamarāja disappeared. And the funeral ceremony of Suyajña was conducted. Thus, speaking many philosophical stories, Hiranyakaśipu consoled his relatives, who then felt a sense of peace. What do you think Hiranyakaśipu did after this? Did he philosophically console himself too? Or, did he act on his evil plan by attacking Lord Visnu, avenging his brother's death? That only the next chapter can tell! So, why wait?
quotes: Wicked people are those who like to trouble innocent people unnecessarily., The soul, which is different from the body, never dies. At some point or the other, the body is sure to perish. Those who know this do not lament unnecessarily.
activity: 1. 'Actions speak louder than words' is a popular idiom. How do you think this applies to this story? 2. Did you promise something but failed to keep it? Think why! 3. What is the difference between someone who consciously commits sins, and someone who sincerely tries to follow a noble principle but fails sometimes? How does the Lord treat them?
lesson: A LESSON ON INTEGRITY: Integrity is the quality of honestly sticking to moral values in all circumstances. Such a person's thoughts, words, and actions are perfectly aligned. But asuras like Hiranyakaśipu lack such integrity, mainly because they are attached to the so-called happiness they attain from immoral actions. Sometimes they speak great wisdom, but their behavior indicates the opposite. Even if they might know what's right and wrong, they choose to tread the wrong way. So learning from their mistakes, let's not simply memorize some philosophy but also try to apply it with integrity!

title: Austerities For Immortality
story: Although Hiranyakaśipu pacified his relatives by speaking lofty philosophy, he preferred not to practice it. He maintained revengeful feelings toward Lord Visnu and wanted to kill Him. He desired to become immortal and unconquerable, and rule the entire universe. Intending to gain special powers from lord Bramhā, Hiranyakaśipu set off for the great Mandara Mountain. He performed severe austerities (tapasya), standing on his toes, pointing his huge arms upwards, and glancing at the sky. Even the devatās were surprised seeing his intense tapasya. Fire emanated from his head and spread everywhere while burning all the planets. The rivers and oceans were agitated while the mountains and islands started crumbling. The stars and planets were set ablaze as they fell in different directions.The scared devatās approached lord Brahmā and pleaded, O lord! We cannot stay on our planets because of the rising heat levels. Please stop these disturbances caused by Hiranyakaśipu's austerities. He wants to occupy your auspicious post. If it happens, everything will be lost. Kindly help us in this situation. Upon hearing the complaints of the devatas, Lord Brahma decided to go to Hiranyakasipu. Accompanied by great sages like Bhrgu, he then reached Mandara Mountain. On arriving there, Brahma was initially unable to see Hiranyakasipu, for his body was covered by an anthill, tall grasses, and thorny bamboos. The ants had eaten up the skin of Hiranyakasıpu without sparing his flesh and blood! Half of his body was totally eaten up! Still, Hiranyakasipu continued his severe austerities with great determination. Finally, Brahmā spotted Hiranyakasipu, went close to him, and said, Dear Hiranyakasipu, your austerities are astonishing. Despite being eaten by all kinds of insects, your life is still circulating within your bones! Even great sages haven't performed such austerities in the past, and neither will anyone be able to do so in the future. You sustained your life even without water for 100 celestial years! I'm impressed with your austerity. You can ask for whatever boon you desire. Then, lord Brahmā revived Hiranyakaśipu by sprinkling over him divine water from his kamandalu (water pot). Thus enlivened, Hiranyakasipu arose like a young man, with his body as strong as a mountain. He was delighted to see Brahmā, and fell flat on the ground in respect. He rose, and with tears in his eyes, he prayed, O lord, please fulfill my wish. Let me not meet death by way of any of the living beings created by you; within or outside any home; during the daytime or at night; on the ground or in the sky; by any weapon, human being or animal, by any living or non-living entity, by any devatā or asura or snakes. Let me not have any rivals. Please give me sole lordship over all the living beings and devatās. Please bless me with all the mystic powers. Lord Brahmā was obliged to give all the boons Hiranyakaśipu asked for. He said, Dear Hiranyakaśipu, although these boons are very difficult to obtain, I shall grant them to you. Brahma then departed. Having received such boons, Hiranyakaśipu became formidably powerful. He was nearly immortal. What do you think he did next? Equipped with the rarest of all boons, was he able to conquer Lord Vişnu? Flip forward to finding out!
quotes: Determination is a great virtue, but if it is coupled with evil intensions, it only leads to destruction., The devatas are not always happy to grant boons to asuras, but sometimes they are obliged.
activity: 1. Name a few asuras who performed austerities for evil purposes. 2. Name a few devotees who performed austerities for noble purposes. 3. Name an austerity that devotees perform to attain the Lord's mercy. 4. What is the mood in which you perform an austerity on a festival day? 5. Why did Brahma give a boon to a demon like Hiranyakashipu?
lesson: A LESSON ON AUSTERITY: Austerity or tapasya means voluntarily taking up some inconvenience on oneself for a higher purpose. Austerity performed for selfish and evil purposes disturbs the world. But when austerity is performed to worship the Lord, it creates peace and prosperity for one and all. Hiranyakasipu performed austerities to become immortal. But death is unavoidable. Despite one's intelligent plans to be immortal, one cannot escape the laws of nature that work under God's control. Instead of performing austerities to escape death in this temporary world, if one performs devotional service to the Lord, one can attain the 'death-free' spiritual kingdom.

title: Demonizing Divine Boons
story: After being awarded the rarest boons from lord Brahmā, Hiranyakasipu's body turned a shining gold. He was brimming with immeasurable strength. Thus, he became extremely proud. Recalling the death of his dear brother Hiranyāksa, he continued being envious of Lord Visnu. Traveling throughout the universe, he conquered the three worlds of the devatās, humans, and serpents. The leaders of various planets of the universe bowed down to him. Hiranyakaśipu occupied Indra's heavenly palace built by the celestial architect Viśvakarma, and began using it as his residence. Filled with all kinds of enjoyment, the palace was also ornamented with celestial gardens that boast colorful canopies and ruby-studded seats. The steps leading to the door of the celestial mansion were made of coral, while its floors were bedecked with emeralds. The walls were made of clear crystal, and the tall columns were made of rare gems. The rooms consisted of beddings covered with foam-like silken cloth with precious pearls stitched onto it. While residing in such a luxuriant palace, Hiranyakaśipu oppressed the devatās. He causelessly troubled them. Always intoxicated, with rolling eyes, he enjoyed all facilities. Except for Brahmā, Vişnu, and Śiva, he oppressed all the principle leaders of all the planets. Additionally, he controlled mother nature. Mother earth would provide abundant food grains without being plowed, while the cows supplied milk profusely. The seven great oceans (of saltwater, ghee, sugar cane juice, milk, yogurt, sweet water, and wine) and the rivers supplied him with various gems and jewels. The outer space was adorned with wonderful phenomena for his happiness. Lush mountains and valleys served as fields of pleasure for Hiranyakasipu. Trees and plants produced fruits and flowers perennially. He singlehandedly carried out all the functions of all the devatās. Thus, he passed a long time while being proud of His opulence and disobeying all scriptural principles. Yet, Hiranyakaśipu's uncontrolled senses made him dissatisfied. Troubled by the unjust punishments of Hiranyakaśipu, the devatās took shelter in Lord Visnu. They prayed, O Lord, please protect us from this tyrant. Then, Lord Vişnu spoke to the devatās in a grave voice while remaining invisible to their eyes. The Lord's voice resounded in all directions while reassuring the devatās of their safety. Lord Vişnu spoke thus, Do not fear devatās! I wish all good fortune to you. I know the evil acts of Hiranyakaśipu and will stop them soon. Please wait patiently until I appear. When one is envious of the devatās, the Vedas, cows, brāhmaņas, Vaisnavas, and dharma, one will soon be vanquished by Me. When Hiranyakaśipu harasses his godly son Prahlāda, I shall kill him despite the boons he has received from Brahmā. Thus assured by the Lord, the devatās offered Him obeisances and considered Hiranyakaśipu dead already. Hiranyakaśipu had four wonderful sons, out of which the best was Prahlada. He was an embodiment of all good qualities. He was kind to the poor, unlike a father. He was affectionate to his friends like a brother and respectful to his gurus like a servant. He was endowed with good education, wealth, and beauty, and was free form pride and envy. He was undisturbed by all dangers. Although born in the family of asuras, Prahlada inherited none of the demoniac qualities. Prahlada was naturally an unalloyed devotee of Lord Krsna. He was aninterested in childish play, and his mind was fully captivated by the Shoughts of the Lord. He saw his beloved Lord Govinda everywhere Feeling the loving embrace of his Lord while sitting, walking, eating, drinking, and talking, he experienced boundless spiritual bliss. How the son of a cruel Hiranyakaśipu became such a gentle devotee like Prahlada? Well then, find out how in the next chapter.
quotes: Demons control their senses with great determination to receive boons, but by the power of those very boons, they become victims of their uncontrolled senses., Demons control their senses with great determination to receive boons, but by the power of those very boons, they become victims of their uncontrolled senses., All the boons one has received would be made null and void as soon as one offends devotees., A person does not qualify or disqualify for bhakti based on birth., A devotee is naturally endowed with knowledge and good qualities.
activity: 1. Mention the names of some people who attained great boons by austerities. 2. If you receive a boon of great wealth, what will you do with it? 3. What do you think is the best boon to attain? 4. Cite a few examples of those who misused their boons to trouble the innocent. 5. Can a curse be a boon? Cite a few examples from the Bhagavatam of when a curse turned into a boon.
lesson: A LESSON ON MISUSING POWER: Just like a bully may misuse one's power to oppress the weak, Hiranyakasipu, having gained great boons from Brahmä used his power to torture, innocent people. With power comes great responsibility. Power used to fulfill evil intentions is harmful to oneself and others. Although demons like Hiranyakasipu may receive the greatest of powers and best of facilities, they remain unsatisfied at heart. If we misuse the power we have, power will not come to our rescue when we need it the most. Such was the case with Hiranyakasipu.

title: Virtuous Son of a Vicious Father
story: When Hiranyakaśipu was performing austerities to receive boons from lord Brahma, the devatās attacked his kingdom. The devatās, headed by Indra, thought to themselves, Hiranyakaśipu will now be defeated, just as small ants eat a snake. Intending to destroy the leaders of the asuras, the devatās invaded Hiranyakasipu's kingdom unannounced. Seeing them, the asuras fled in different directions. The devatās then entered Hiranyakaśipu's palace and saw his chaste wife, Kayādhu, who was then pregnant. Indra approached Kayādhu and arrested her. She then began crying helplessly, just like a small bird captured by a big vulture. But Indra and the other devatās continued to drag her mercilessly. At that time, the great sage Närada Muni appeared there. Stopping the devatās from doing so, he said, What are you doing? This woman is a sinless and chaste wife of another man. How can you drag her off mercilessly in this way? You must release her immediately! Nārada Muni was a great saint and a pure devotee of Lord Visnu. The devatās were very respectful and obedient to him. Revealing his plan to Nārada, Indra spoke, O sage, we don't want to kill this woman. She is currently carrying the child of Hiranyakaśipu in her womb. Just as Hiranyakaśipu is a cruel demon, his son will also become a great demon and unnecessarily torment innocent people, like his father. So, we wish to kill him as soon as he is born. After that, we will release this woman. Nārada Muni understood the fear and concern of the devatās. He then clarified to them, Dear devatās, you expect Hiranyakaśipu's child to be another tyrant like him. But the child in the womb of this sinless woman will become a powerful devotee of Lord Visnu. He will grow into a mahā bhāgavata (a great devotee). Therefore, killing him would be a great offense. Hearing this, the devatās headed by Indra immediately released Kayādhu. They deeply trusted the words of Narada Muni. They even circumambulated Kayādhu and bowed down to her and the devotee within her womb. The devatās were obedient to Nārada Muni because whatever a pure devotee says would be very authoritative. Kayādhu was very much worried and frightened. Seeing her pitiable condition, Narada Muni compassionately brought her to his own āśrama. He told her, You can stay here until your husband returns. You will be safe here. There is no need for you to fear. Kayādhu continued to stay under the care of Narada Muni. She desired to give birth to Prahlada after the arrival of her husband. Meanwhile, she respectfully rendered various services at Närada Muni's āśrama. One day, Narada Muni sat in front of Kayādhu and started enlightening her with a spiritual discourse. He was merciful towards the mother and the child in her womb. He wanted to enlighten both of them by speaking about Lord Vişnu and the process of bhakti yoga. Närada Muni explained that the nature of a living being is to serve the Supreme Lord Vişnu eternally lovingly. Kayādhu heard Nārada's instructions but not very attentively. She was very much concerned about the safety of the child in her womb. Also, she earnestly waited for her husband's return. As a result, she could not grasp the divine instructions and teachings of Narada Muni. Thus, she forgot whatever she heard.But, the child within Kayādhu's womb was very attentive to the teachings of Narada Muni. Free of any worry and anxiety, he focussed on the great sage's wisdom words. He understood that the goal of life is to perform bhakti unto Vişnu. In due course of time, that child came to be known as Prahlada, the most celebrated devotee in the history of the universe. Thus, Prahlāda became a pure devotee even before his birth. After Prahlada was born, he exhibited great devotion to Lord Vişnu while constantly chanting 'Hari Hari.' How do you think Hiranyakaśipu treated Prahlada? Would the Lord's enemy, Hiranyakasipu, be comfortable seeing his son becoming a devotee of Krsna? What action would Hiranyakaśipu take? Flip forward to finding out!
quotes: Devotees are naturally compassionate, and thus they want to help common people understand the truths of life.
activity: 1. Who is the greatest inspiration in your spiritual life? Recall how they inspire you. 2. Narada Muni taught bhakti to both Kayadhu and Prahlada, but only Prahlada got benefitted. What can you learn from this?
lesson: A LESSON ON INSPIRATION: Prahlada was an unborn child in his mother's womb when he received. spiritual inspiration from Närada Muni. Although he belonged to the asura clan, this did not prevent the flow of inspiration to perform bhakti. Thus, inspiration in bhakti doesn't depend on external conditions like age, caste, dynasty, etc. Bhakti is completely independent. The stream of devotional inspiration flows smoothly when the teacher is potent, and the student is sincere. So let's pace up our devotion with the fountain of inspiration within our hearts!
