title: Unwavering Devotion
story: Sukrācārya was the guru of the asuras. He was a learned brahmana. A real brāhmana guides people in spiritual life, but Sukrācārya accepted the priesthood of asuras just for material benefits. He had two sons, namely Sanda and Amarka. They lived near Hiranyakaśipu's palace. When Prahalāda turned five, he was sent to the school of Sanda and Amarka along with the other asura children. Prahlada was already knowledgeable because he had received spiritual education from the best teacher, Narada Muni. Despite this, he was sent to school for material education. Sanda and Amarka started teaching him politics, diplomacy, and differentiating between people as enemies and friends. But Prahlada didn't like those teachings. One day Hiranyakaśipu called little Prahlāda and made him sit on his lap. He then affectionately asked, My dear son, how are you studying at school? Please tell me about your favorite subject? Prahlāda replied, Dear father, I think the best activity for all living beings is to give up their selfish nature and the thoughts of 'I and mine. Therefore, everyone should give up their materialistic household life, go to the forest of Vrindavan, and take complete shelter of Lord Hari. Hiranyakaśipu expected Prahlada to speak something sweet but not anything practical. Certainly, he didn't expect such a profound philosophical reply from his young son. He was surprised to hear Prahlada's words and started laughing. He then spoke gravely, It looks like some enemies are secretly entering the school and polluting children's minds. I must protect Prahlada from the devotees going to the Gurukul in the disguise of brahmaņas. Sanda and Amarka, were surprised to see that a child could speak such great words of devotion. However, they were also very afraid. They thought that Prahlada's devotion unto Lord Hari would cause Hiranyakaśipu to kill them. Thus Sanda and Amarka lovingly spoke to Prahlada, Dear child, all good fortune unto you. Please tell us the truth. Who has polluted your intelligence? Other boys don't speak like you! Where did you learn all this bhakti philosophy from? We never taught this to you. Hari and His devotees are our enemies. So how can you praise Him? Prahlada politely replied, My dear teachers, no one is our enemy. Everyone is a child of God. I offer my respects to Lord Hari, by whose grace one's bad intelligence is destroyed. My intelligence is different from yours because of Lord Hari, your so-called enemy. My consciousness is naturally attracted to Lord Vişnu just as iron is naturally attracted to a magnet. Hearing this, Sanda and Amarka scolded Prahlāda, Bring a stick! This boy deserves punishment. By his bad intelligence, he is defaming our dynasty. He's like a thorn tree in the sandalwood forest of the Rākṣasa dynasty. If Visnu is like the axe to cut the Rakshasa forest, then Prahlada is the handle of that axe. Later, Sanda and Amarka forcefully taught Prahlāda many materialistic subjects like politics and diplomacy. But Prahlāda had no bitter feelings towards Sanda and Amarka or even Hiranyakashipu, who troubled him in many ways. After a few days, they presented Prahlada before Hiranyakaśipu, thinking that the boy was sufficiently educated. That day Prahlada was nicely dressed and decorated by his mother, Kayādhu. Prahlāda respectfully bowed down to his father, Hiranyakasipu. He was pleased with his son's behavior, so Hiranyakaśipu happily embraced him and showered his blessings. Then, with tears of affection in his eyes, he placed Prahlada on his lap and asked, My dear son, please repeat whatever you liked the most from what your teachers taught you. This time Hiranyakaśipu asked a specific question. Instead of asking Prahlada to speak whatever he liked, he asked him to speak what his teachers taught. But Prahlāda had two types of teachers, a spiritual teacher (Narada) and materialistic teachers (Sanda and Amarka). Remembering the teachings of Narada Muni, Prahlāda wittily replied, My dear father, there are nine ways of performing bhakti unto Lord Visnu. One who follows one or more or all of these nine limbs of bhakti unto Lord Visnu or Krsna is the most knowledgeable person. Hiranyakasipu became furious and chastised the teachers, You unqualified brahmanas! You have disobeyed my orders and taught this poor boy nonsensical philosophy about Visnu, our sworn enemy. You are my enemies in the disguise of friends. Śanda and Amarka replied, O King! We did not teach anything that your son spoke. Please don't accuse us unnecessarily. Prahlāda's devotion to Vişnu is natural in Him. Hiranyakaśipu then asked Prahlada, You are the most degraded one in our family! If your gurus haven't taught this, how did you develop this devotional mentality? Prahlāda replied, Dear father, bhakti unto Krsna is not developed by those people who are not self-controlled. Because of their uncontrolled senses, they enter hellish life and repeatedly chew the chewed, i.e., desire same temporary pleasures. They don't understand that Lord Vişnu is their real shelter and goal. They become ambitious to enjoy in this world. They become blind to spiritual life, following other blind people. Thus, they are strongly bound by the ropes of material miseries. On the other hand, those who take shelter of pure devotees and serve Lord Visnu with love are freed from the cycle of repeated birth and death and ultimately enter Vaikuntha, the Lord's eternal abode. As Prahlada was speaking such words, Hiranyakaśipu was bursting with fury, Blinded by anger and pride, he threw the child off his lap onto the ground. His eyes became reddish like burning copper. How did he act next? Did he punish Prahlada or forgive him, considering him a child? That only the next chapter can reveal. So why wait?
quotes: Mature devotees don't differentiate between people as friends and enemies instead, they treat everyone as a child of God. They see the spiritual oneness amongst living beings beyond their bodily differences., A devotee is ajata-shatru: he is never hateful of anyone, even those who hate him., We may disagree with others' philosophies, but we need not disrespect them.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW?9 WAYS OF BHAKTI 1. Śravaņam - Hearing about Lord Hari 2. Kirtanam - Chanting Hari's names & pastimes 3. Smaraņam - Remembering the Lord 4. Pāda-sevanam - Serving His lotus feet 5. Arcanam - Worshipping His Deity 6. Vandanam - Offering prayers unto Him 7. Dāsyam - Becoming His servant 8. Sakhyam - Considering Him to as best friend 9. Ätma-nivedanam - Completely surrender
activity: 1. Can we disagree with someone without disrespecting them? Share your thoughts. 2. What will you do if someone opposes your devotion to your beloved Lord?
lesson: A LESSON ON FEARLESSNESS: Can a tender child face a ferocious demon? Generally, a child fears being scolded and chastised by a strict elder, but little Prahlada fearlessly opposed the mentality of his aesthetic father and teachers. He was polite and humble, yet he never compromised his devotion to Lord Visnu. Such fearlessness and humility are the natural symptoms of devotion to God. When one becomes fully dependent on the Lord, one is devoid of all material fears. However, when we turn our face away from God, we are naturally situated amidst fears and anxieties. Fixing our hearts on the lord will 'frighten' the fear in us!

title: The Shield of Devotion
story: Prahlada thus openly expressed his devotion to Visnu in front of Hiranyakasipu. He even advised his father to become a devotee. Hiranyakaśipu became enraged at this. Although he could overrule everyone in his vast kingdom, including the powerful devatās, he was agitated when a five-year-old boy didn't obey him. He gave up his love for his little son, unable to tolerate the boy's love for Lord Visnu. Being unable to tolerate his son glorifying his enemy, Hiranyakaśipu ordered his servants, O demons, this boy deserves to be killed. He is untrustworthy and has become devoted to our enemy while forsaking his parent's affection. This foolish boy is like an unwanted black spot on our spotless dynasty. Prahlāda remained silent while all the palace residents were surprised to hear their king's order to kill his son! Hard-hearted Hiranyakaśipu continued, A rare medicinal herb in the forest must be protected if it helps cure a disease. But if a bodily limb is diseased, it must be amputated so that the rest of the body remains unaffected. Similarly, even if an outsider is favorable, he must be protected just like a son. And even one's son must be rejected if he acts against the family. Therefore, killing this boy is perfectly justified. Kill him immediately! All the demoniac soldiers rushed forward to kill Prahlada, who peacefully meditated on Lord Visnu. However, by Lord Hari's mercy, none of the deadly tridents and clubs hurled at Prahlada could touch him. Astonished, Hiranyakaśipu irritably ordered his servants to kill Prahlāda using other means. Then the asura soldiers took Prahlada away and threw him under the feet of mad elephants to get trampled upon. But Prahlāda didn't die. Then they locked him in a dark room filled with huge venomous snakes. Still, he didn't die. Next, they pushed him down the peak of a big mountain. They imprisoned and starved him in a black cell. They poisoned him They exposed Prahlada to severe cold, winds, fire, and water. Finally, they released boulders to crush his tender body. Still, by all these means, they could not kill Prahlada. When all the attempts to kill Prahlada failed, Hiranyakasipu became greatly perplexed. He thought, I tried to the boy in all possible ways, yet, he remains unhurt. Despite being a small child, he's completely fearless. He never forgets his beloved Lord. He's just like a stubborn dog's tail that never straightens. His strength appears to be unlimited, and he seems to be immortal. What if I die because of my enmity towards him? Wondering in this way, Hiranyakaśipu disappointedly sat down on his throne. At that time, Śanda and Amarka approached Hiranyakaśipu and secretly murmured, O King, why are you so sad? There is no reason for you to be so disappointed. You have conquered all three worlds. All the devatās are afraid simply of the movement of your eyebrows. It's better not to take Prahlāda seriously. He is a mere child and will surely give up his devotion when he grows up. We will train him. Hiranyakaśipu accepted the suggestions of Śanda and Amarka and sent Prahlāda again with them to the Gurukul. What did Prahlada do in school? Did his teachers become successful in destroying his devotion? Read the next chapter to find out.
quotes: For proud people, envy towards enemies is more important than love for their children. One may have the best possible boons and powers, yet in the corner of the heart, one always fears death. This fear can be overcome only by devotion to God.
activity: 1. Do you think the Lord is not merciful when you don't score well in your exams? Explain. 2. Taking lessons from this story, what will you do when you face difficulties? 3. Recollect some instances when you felt the Lord's protection. 4. What do you think made Prahlada's faith unshakeable?
lesson: A LESSON ON FAITH: If the Lord decides to save a person, nobody can harm him, and if the Lord decides to punish a person, nobody can save him. The Lord personally takes the responsibility of protecting His faithful devotees from all dangers. Faith in God's protection is very rare. It's easier to think of one's happiness and success as God-sent, but when one faces difficulties and failures, one doubts the Lord's mercy. But the stories of great devotees like Prahlada, who remained undisturbed and faithful even amidst difficulties, can inculcate faith in the Lord's protection.

title: Spirituality In An Atheistic School
story: Prahlada, as usual, was very submissive and humble to his elders. Sanda and Amarka eagerly taught him all kinds of materialistic topics. But Prahlāda remained attached to the divine teachings of bhakti given by Närada Muni. During the absence of his teachers, Prahlada's young classmates would call him to play with them. All the children were attracted to Prahlada's gentle and loving nature. Prahlāda would speak to his friends very politely and sweetly. He would also teach them bhakti. The innocent children, not yet contaminated by the materialistic teachings, eagerly listened to the words of Prahlada. They all surrounded him and heard him with fixed attention. Prahlāda kindly began to teach them about bhakti: My dear friends, intelligent people should worship Lord Hari right from one's childhood. Human life is very rare. Although it is also temporary, it is very effective to perform bhakti. It is very natural for everyone to love Visnu because He is our dearest well-wisher. One should not waste human life to attain some material pleasures and facilities. Rather one should utilize one's life to worship the Lord Visnu. Prahlada continued, Human life is about a hundred years. Out of those hundred years, most of the time is spent sleeping, sporting activities, old age, etc. The rest of the time is spent making unnecessary attachments and fulfilling material desires. Instead of being so absorbed in just external duties in this material world, one should better try to please Lord Nārāyana, who is the Father of all beings. He is very merciful to everyone. By surrendering unto Him, one can attain Him in His eternal abode. I received this knowledge of bhakti from Narada Muni while in my mother's womb. At the time, my mother was under the care of Narada Muni. The children of the asuras were surprised to see the devotion of their dear friend Prahlada. Prahlada continued, Bhakti is the best spiritual path by which one becomes liberated from this material world. One should perform bhakti under the guidance of a bona fide guru. And one must faithfully worship the Lord in the company of other devotees. According to the scriptures, one should hear about the Lord and meditate upon Him. One must also be very respectful and loving towards all living beings. Thus, one will be freed from all bad qualities and attain the love of the Lord. So, I request all of you to take to perform bhakti. In this way, Prahlada lovingly educated his friends. All the children found Prahlada's teachings more interesting than the discourses of their teachers. Because Prahlāda was a great devotee, he could easily gift devotion to his friends. Inspired by Prahlada, the children began to chant the holy names of Lord Hari. Then, they joyfully started singing and dancing along with Prahlada while chanting. While they were thus absorbed in bhakti, Śanda and Amarka suddenly saw them and were shocked. What action did the teachers take then? Did they chastise Prahlada or the other students? Or did they also get transformed into devotees? Flip forward to find out.
quotes: One who had devotion can only inspire devotion in others.
activity: 1. Would you like to share with your friends what you learned from the Bhagavatam? Try with a friend today. 2. How will you inspire your friend to the bhakti path? List some practical ways.
lesson: A LESSON ON KNOWLEDGE TRANSMISSION: Närada Muni inspired Prahlada to take to devotion while he was still in his mother's womb. Later, Prahlada passed on those teachings to his classmates thus inspiring them. The effectiveness of one's teachings depends on how sincerely one has heard and followed the guru's teachings, and how transparently one transmits them to others. Because Prahlada sincerely followed Närada Muni's teachings, he could pass on that knowledge to his friends. Thus, authentic devotional knowledge is always passed down by a succession of genuine teachers and students called as the paramparā.

title: God In The Pillar
story: Seeing all the Gurukul boys becoming Lord Hari's devotees, Sanda and Amarka became worried. So they immediately went to Hiranyakaśipu and informed him about these events. Hearing the brahmanas, Hiranyakaśipu became enraged. Hissing like a trampled snake, he called for Prahlada. Undisturbed by his father's anger, Prahlada stood with a peaceful mind and folded hands. Hiranyakaśipu spoke like thunder, O impudent boy! Your unintelligent acts have defamed our family. You are the lowest among men. How dare you violate my orders! Today, I shall send you to hell. When I become angry, the planets begin trembling, then by whose power are you so fearless? Prahlāda gently replied, Dear father, please understand that the source of my strength is the source of your strength as well. Lord Hari is the source of everybody's strength in this world. The Supreme Lord is the creator, maintainer, and destroyer of all the universes. Prahlada continued, My dear father, please give up your demonic mentality of discriminating between friends and enemies. The only enemy of a person in this world is one's uncontrolled mind. All other kinds of enemies are mere imaginations. Therefore, one will have no enemies if one conquers the mind and senses, gives up one's bad qualities like anger, envy, and greed, and treats everyone equally. Hearing this profound reply from Prahlada, Hiranyakaśipu shouted, Your foolish words are only increasing my desire to kill you with my own hands. You rascal are boasting as if you are more self-controlled than me! Where is your beloved God? You always describe Him as the all-pervading! If He's everywhere, is He present in this pillar too? Hiranyakaśipu pointed to a huge pillar in the royal palace and challenged Prahlada, I shall now slash your head off. Let me see if your Lord comes from this pillar to protect you. Hiranyakasipu then took out his sharp sword. Obsessed with anger, he struck his fist against the pillar. Thud! From the pillar came a fearful sound that appeared to destroy the entire universe. Hiranyakaśipu stood astonished. He had never heard such a massive sound earlier. Fright took over the faces of the other demons in the palace.To save His dear devotee, the omniscient Lord Visnu appeared in the most wonderful form that had never been witnessed. That form was a fusion of a robust man and a ferocious lion. Puzzled, Hiranyakaśipu wondered, What is this weird being breaking out from this pillar? This was the manifestation of the fearsome Supreme Lord, Narasimha (the half man half lion incarnation). Curious, Hiranyakaśipu began detailing the form of the Lord within his mind. The Lord had angry eyes resembling molten gold. His mane shone while his deadly teeth covered the movements of his sword-like tongue. His gaping mouth was an invitation for all demons to be burnt. His nostrils appeared like dark mountain caves. His broad chest seemed thrust into the sky, while his bodily hairs resembled the moon's splendor. Hiranyakaśipu had never seen such a being, so he never asked a boon from Brahmā to be protected from such ghastly creatures. But lo and behold! This was the omnipotence of Lord Visnu. Mustering some courage, Hiranyakaśipu attacked the Lord with his small club, thinking he would be safe owing to the boons that Brahmā he received. However, the Lord effortlessly tossed away the club and captured him. The Lord's radiating bright effulgence made Hiranyakaśipu invisible. To enjoy the spirit of fighting, the Lord left Hiranyakasipu gave him another chance to fight. However, and gav Hiranyakaśipu foolishly thought that the Lord was afraid of his powers and backed off. And the devatās witnessing the fight from the upper planets became anxious to see the Lord leaving Hiranyakaśipu. Again, Hiranyakasipu attacked the Lord with a sharp sword and shield. Laughing loudly, the Lord captured him with speed faster than that of a gliding hawk. Then the Lord dragged the demon to the doorway and effortlessly tore him apart. Lord Narshima could have easily killed Hiranyakaśipu with a simple snap of His fingers. But He wanted to respect the boons that Brahmā gave the demon. That's why Lord Narasimha killed Hiranyakaśipu by piercing him at the door, which was neither inside nor outside his house. He placed Hiranyakaśipu on His lap, which was neither a part of the sky nor land. He pierced him with His nails, which were neither living nor dead weapons. He killed him during twilight, which was neither a part of day nor night. Thus, the Lord wittingly annihilated Hiranyaśipu only to save His devotee, Prahlāda. Lord Narasimha's mouth and mane were drenched in shiny red blood. It was impossible for anyone to even glance at His ferocious eyes. Decorated with a garland of the demon's intestines, the Lord resembled a ferocious lion that had just slayed an elephant. Then the Lord uprooted Hiranyakaśipu's heart and examined it thoroughly. He thought, This place is where I should reside. Why did this person let demoniac qualities like anger, greed, and envy take My place? Thus, the Lord killed Hiranyakasipu and his demoniac associates. Seeing no one to fight Him, the Lord went towards his throne and majestically seated Himself on it. Having thus stationed Himself on the throne, what would the Lord do? Would He stay there a little longer? Would He occupy the kingdom of Hiranyakaśipu? Read the last chapter of this section to know.
quotes: A devotee is firmly convinced that the Lord is the source of eveything, and everyone ultimately depends on Him., Atheists keep challenging the existence of God, but a devotee continues to worship God., Material boons of so-called immortality are very difficult to attain and maintain. Some demons may sometimes attain it, but don't ensure deathlessness.
activity: 1. Mention some things or situations in which you can feel the presence of the Lord. 2. Find out in which chapters of the Bhagavad-gita did Lord Krsna say that He is present everywhere and In everything. State some examples. Take help from your parents, teachers, or friends. 3. constantly Hiranyakaśipu threatened Prahlada. But he was calm and composed. What do you think helped him to be so calm?
lesson: A LESSON ON FAITH: Our unmoving and firm belief in something is called conviction. Devotees who deeply love God are convinced about His presence everywhere. But an atheistic person devoid of love of God doesn't even believe in His existence. Although having no qualification to see God, such a person challenges the devotees to show God. Of course, the Lord is not obliged to reveal Himself to such people. But when they trouble the devotees, the Lord indeed comes to protect His devotees. One must first understand from the scriptures that the Lord is everywhere, and then we must worship Him with devotion. Then, gradually, by the Lord's mercy, one will see His presence everywhere.

title: The Love of Lord Narasimha
story: In his previous life, Hiranyakaśipu was a great devotee. He was Jaya, the gatekeeper in Vaikuntha. Owing to the curse of the four Kumāras, he became a demon, along with Vijaya, his co-gatekeeper. Lord Narasimha sat on Hiranyakaśipu's throne only to indicate that His devotees are always fortunate in all circumstances. After Hiranyakasipu's death, the wives of the devatās showered flowers on Lord Narasimha out of great joy. The sky was crowded with airplanes of the devatās, who began to beat drums and play other melodious musical instruments. The heavenly women danced, and the Gandharvas sang sweetly. Then, all the devatās and sages offered their prayers to Lord Narasimha. They expressed gratitude to the Lord for killing Hiranyakaśipu and 5 restoring their powers and positions. Despite receiving great praises and prayers from many devatās and sages, Lord Narasimha was still angry. Even lord Śiva and Brahmā were afraid of approaching Him. Mother Lakṣmī also couldn't gather the courage to go near her husband. When no one could calm the Lord, Brahmā finally asked little Prahlāda, My dear boy, please go and satisfy the Lord with your prayers. Only you can bring a smile across His fierce face. Prahlada agreed and joyfully proceeded towards the Lord. The Lord didn't get pacified by anyone only because He wanted His young devotee to console Him. He wanted to exhibit His affection for Prahlāda. As soon as Prahlāda bowed down, Lord Narasimha was overwhelmed with affection for His young devotee. The Lord lovingly placed His lotus hand on the head of Prahlada, who then developed ecstatic symptoms. With tears in his eyes, Prahlāda said, O Lord, great devatās and sages couldn't satisfy You with their excellent praises. Then how is it possible for me, a member of a demoniac dynasty, to appease You? Although Prahlada was chosen to pacify the Lord when all the great devatās and sages failed, he didn't feel superior to them. Prahlada continued, My dear Lord, wealth, scholarship, beauty, intelligence, fame, and so on are not necessary to please You. You e satisfied only by loving devotion. One who doesn't possess bhakti unto You cannot please You, even if he is a well-qualified brāhmaņa. But, on the other hand, even a person born in a family of dog-eaters can easily satisfy You with bhakti. Having thus declared that only love can please the Lord, Prahlada lovingly requested, Dear Lord, please give up Your anger, for you have already killed the demon Hiranyakaśipu. Everyone is rejoicing in his death. Your ferocious form as Narasimha doesn't cause fear in my heart. I am only fearful of this material world filled with distractions and miseries. And the so-called solutions to those problems are more painful than the problems. Therefore, the only way to be freed from all world's difficulties is to take Your shelter and chant Your glories. With a grateful heart, Prahlāda said, Today I have become fortunate by the touch of Your lotus hand. I received this mercy from You only because of the mercy of my guru Nārada Muni. I wish to serve him. Satisfied by Prahlada's lovely prayers, Lord Narasimha gave up his anger and posed a cheerful smile on His lotus-like face. He spoke, My dear Prahlada! All good fortune unto you! Very few people are fortunate to have My darśana, but by your sublime bhakti, you Shave forced Me to come to you. I'm very pleased with your faith and devotion. Please ask for any boon from Me. Prahlada said, O Lord! Due to my demoniac birth, I'm already attached to many material desires. Now, please do not allure me with boons. I am not a stingy merchant who demands some material benefits in exchange for devotion. I am Your eternal servant and You are My eternal master. I do not want any material gifts from You. If You want to give me any boon, please destroy all my material desires. Impressed with Prahlada's pure devotion, Lord Narasimha said, Dear Prahlāda, I know that you don't desire any material benefits from Me. Still, I order you to enjoy as the king of asuras until the end of this manvantara. Even though you're in this world, you can always remain in My company by constantly hearing My pastimes and thinking of Me. And you shall finally attain Me. Your pure glory will be sung even in the heavens. Anyone who remembers your activities and chants your prayers will become free from all karma. Prahlāda replied, My dear Lord, You are very merciful to the fallen souls. I have one request. Out of ignorance, my father Hiranyakaśipu envied You and tormented me. Please excuse his sins. The Lord replied, Dear Prahlada, because of your birth, your father and your entire demoniac dynasty have been purified. Even great sinful dynasties are sanctified if great devotees like you take birth. Your farther has already been purified by My touch at his death. Lord Brahma spoke to Lord Narasimha, O Lord of the Lords! This demon received the boon of not being killed by anyone within my creation. But You appeared in This divine form, killed him, and saved Your dear devotee. Anyone who meditates upon You will be protected from all dangers. Lord Narasimha told Brahmā, Giving such boons to demons is as dangerous as feeding milk to a poisonous snake. I warn you, never give such boons to any demon again. Saying this, the Lord disappeared. After that. Prahlada was enthroned as the king of asuras in a grand ceremony by learned brāhmaņas. One who hears the wonderful story of Prahlada and Narasimha shall develop pure devotion to the Lord.
quotes: An obeisance unto the Lord causes fearlessness in the minds of those fearful of death., Although fully qualified to serve the Lord, a devotee is always very humble., Only by the guru's grace can one attain the Lord's mercy., A devotee's service to the Lord is completely selfless without any expectations.
activity: 1. Can you pray for the wellbeing of someone who tried to harm you? If so, what would you pray for? 2. Think of some devotees around you whose devotion is intense. What makes you think so? 3. The world is filled with difficulties. Does it mean we have to hate it? Share your opinion. 4. Make a small skit with your friends or family members on the story of Prahlada.
lesson: A LESSON ON INTENSITY: Both a candle and a 2000-watt bulb can light up a dark room. While the dim candle flame illuminates only a corner of the room, the bulb brightens up the entire room. Similarly, if one's practice of bhakti is weak and wavering like the flame of a candle, one cannot derive the full mercy of the Lord. Progress in bhakti depends on the intent and intensity of one's practice. One who performs bhakti selfishly and irregularly cannot experience the real pleasure bhakti offers. Drawing inspiration from the character of little Prahlada, let's take baby steps to intensify our absorption in the practice of bhakti!

title: Trouble at Trikūța
story: Located on the higher planets was the serene mountain range called Trikūta. Comprised of three main peaks made of iron, precious silver, and fine gold, they beautified the directions and the sky. An aromatic milk ocean surrounded this mountain range. The other smaller peaks in this range housed abundant pearls, minerals, lush greenery, and abundant waterfalls. The waves of the milk ocean always washed the soft soil at the foothills and thus produced rare emeralds. The caves were populated with celestial beings. The valleys of the region were filled with wild animals, fragrant gardens, sweet chirping birds, and gems embedded in the crystalline lakes and rivers. In such a beautiful Trikūța region, there was also a beautiful garden called Rtumat, which belonged to the ocean God, Varuna. In it blossomed various flowers and juicy fruit-laden trees. Splendid lotus-filled lakes surrounded by a swarm of buzzing bees added to the charm. The chirping of the birds created an extremely pleasing atmosphere. Sweet-scented Kadamba trees abundantly covered these water bodies. Gajendra, the leader of the elephants, used to live in this heavenly forest. Seeing him or even smelling his bodily odor, even ferocious animals of the forest would scatter away in fear. Surrounded by numerous elephants, Gajendra made the entire Trikūța region tremble. Once, while wandering in the forest with female elephants, Gajendra felt fatigued and thirsty. Walking to a nearby lake, he started drinking its sweet waters mixed with lotus pollen. He happily bathed and played in the cool waters. With his enormous trunk, Gajendra drew out water from the lake and sprinkled it over his family in a playful mood. Suddenly, a strong crocodile angrily swam toward Gajendra and caught his leg in the water. Powerful Gajendra tried his best to free himself from the crocodile's jaws, but he couldn't. Gajendra became helpless, Anxiety took over his wives, and they started crying. Even the other elephants wanted to help Gajendra but, couldn't do anything. Gajendra and the crocodile began fighting, pulling each other in and out of the water. Gajendra thought that the crocodile would leave him in some time. But the fight went on and on for one thousand years! Seeing their fight, even the devatās in heaven were surprised. After all, Gajendra was a land animal, while the crocodile was a water animal. Gajendra would have destroyed the crocodile easily if he had attacked him while on land. But within the waters, Gajendra became weak. His mental and physical strength was depleted in water, while the crocodile's enthusiasm and strength increased. Thus, Gajendra became helpless. What do you think Gajendra did next? Would he succumb and perish, or would he somehow rise and defeat the crocodile? Well, turning the page may be a good call!
quotes: The stunning beauty in this world is only a spark of God's splendor. So, while appreciating the spark of God's creations, let's not forget to appreciate Him, the creator.
activity: 1. Because the Lord is the ultimate protector, does it mean that we don't have to put in our efforts to escape dangers? 2. Name a few devotees who did everything humanly possible to escape dangers yet ultimately depended on the Lord.
lesson: A LESSON ON DANGERS: This world is full of dangers. There is danger at every step. Everyone is caught by the crocodile of 'time. But sometimes, being lost in fun and enjoyment, we may overlook a danger. And the situation can be such that no one can help us People may want to help, but they may not lave the ability. Sometimes, people may be able to help, but they may not be willing to do so. So, despite being careful to save ourselves with our abilities, we may still be in trouble. Taking shelter in the Lord is the ultimate solution.

title: The Ultimate Rescuer
story: In a helpless state, Gajendra started thinking, All my relatives and friends cannot rescue me from this crocodile. My weeping wives are unable to save me in any way. Now I must take refuge in God, the supreme shelter. Only He has the power to save everyone from the greatest dangers, including death. Let me pray for His help. By the Lord's mercy, Gajendra could recollect a prayer he had learned in his previous life. He prayed, O Lord! You are the root cause of everything in the entire universe. You are its creator, maintainer, and destroyer. The entire universe is dependent on You. You are the shelter of all the great sages and devatās. I bow down to You. By Your divine energy, you can see everything. It's impossible to even for the great devatās and sages to understand You fully. Then how can an unintelligent animal like me understand You? Only selfless devotees who flawlessly practice bhakti can truly know You and attain You. In his prayers, Gajendra praised the general characteristics of the Supreme Lord but didn't call out to the name of any specific form ike Krsna, Rāma, Varāha or Narasimha. He didn't know the identity of God. Yet, he described the qualities of the Supreme Person, whom he thought couid protect him. The elephant continued, O Lord, You appear in various incarnations in different jugas to protect Your devotees. Being extremely merciful, You liberate anyone who performs bhakti unto You. You stay within the hearts of all living beings and observe all their activities. My dear Lord! I do not wish to live anymore after being released from the jaws of this crocodile. What is the use of an elephant body covered with ignorance? I desire liberation. I only desire to attain You! Thus, Gajendra described various attributes of Lord Hari. The devatās like Brahmā and Indra also saw Gajendra's terrible situation, heard his prayers, and were capable of protecting him. But they didn't intend to do so because they thought, The elephant didn't call out our names, nor did he praise us. Instead, he glorified Lord Visnu's qualities. However, Vişnu doesn't come so easily. Thinking thus, they became indifferent to him. But Lord Hari is never indifferent toward the suffering of a devotee. Although Gajendra didn't call out a specific name of the Lord, all the qualities he described in his prayers were present in Lord Hari. So, the supremely compassionate Lord Hari hastily arrived on His mighty bird carrier, Garuda, to protect Gajendra. Noti ing this, the devatās thought, Oh, Lord Hari is going to save the elep ant. How unwittingly we thought that He wouldn't go to rescue Gajendra! Thinking thus, the devatās also went behind Lord Hari to the ikuta Mountain region. Seeing the all-attractive Lord Hari in the sky approaching him swiftly, Gajendra felt hopeful. Though he was reeling in severe pain, he picked up a lotus from the lake with his trunk and offered it to the Lord, praying, O Nārāyana! O, Supreme Master! I offer my heartfelt obeisances unto you. Pleased with Gajendra's devotion and concerned about his condition Lord Hari immediately sent His Sudarśana cakra and severed the head of the crocodile. After that, all the devatās headed by Brahma and Siva praised Lord Hari while showering flowers. Then, the Gandharvas began dancing, singing, and playing various musical instruments. Interestingly, the crocodile turned into a handsome Gandharva. And Gajendra attained a form similar to the Lord - a bluish body with four hands and a charming face. Gajendra had been a great devotee of Lord Vişnu in his past life. Keen to know more about the crocodile and the elephant? Flip forward to rewind their lives.
quotes: The Lord mercifully gives us the intuition to seek His help in difficulties., Prayers purify our minds and protect us from dangers even in the next life., Love for His devotees is the topmost quality of the Lord.
activity: 1. Names some devotees who offered prayers to the Lord in difficulties, seeking His help. 2. Which prayer do you regularly chant? How do you feel while praying? 3. Would you like to share a prayer that you know with your friend? Try today.
lesson: A LESSON ON CARE: The Lord finds some reason, direct or indirect, to bestow His mercy upon us. Although Gajendra didn't call out to the Lord with a specibe name, the Lord considered that he prales qualities. The Lord Himself inspired mendra to chant a prayer he had learned in his previous life. And in response to Gajendra's prayers, the Lord at once arrived to rescue him. Only the Lord is complete aware of our problems, is ever-intending to help us, and is fully able to protect us. Therefore, he is our ultimate rescuer and caretaker.

title: The Two Curses
story: When the Sudarśana cakra of Lord Hari beheaded the crocodile, the crocodile became freed of all sins and assumed a beautiful form of a Gandharva. He bowed before the Lord, circumambulated Him, and went to Gandharvaloka. In his previous life, the crocodile was a Gandharva king called Hühū. Once, he was bathing in a lake along with his wives. At that time, a great sage named sage Devala came to that lake to offer his prayers to the sun god. Hūhū saw sage Devala and wanted to have some fun at his cost. He then swam towards the sage and dragged his leg within the water. The sage was disturbed in his prayers. He opened his eyes and saw Hūhū doing the mischievous act. Devala became furious and said, O foolish Gandharva, you are behaving like a crocodile. May you become a crocodile. Having thus been cursed by the sage, Hühū said, O sage, please forgive me for my impudent act. Please relieve me of this curse. Seeing the king's repentance, Devala said, I cannot reverse the curse. But I can give you a blessing. When you become a crocodile, you will be slayed by Lord Visnu and thus be liberated. Due to this curse, Hühū became a crocodile and now was liberated by Lord Visnu. By the touch of Lord Hari, Gajendra was relieved from the crocodile's jaws, and was also liberated from ignorance. Gajendra then attained a similar spiritual form to that of the Lord, with dazzling yellow garments and four hands. This is called sārūpya mukti. In his previous birth, Gajendra was a great king named Indradyumna, who ruled the glorious Pandya dynasty in South India. He was a great devotee of Lord Krsna. He exceptionally ruled his kingdom like the loving father of his citizens. When he grew older, he responsibly retired from family life and left for a sacred hermitage in the Malaya hills. With matted locks of hair, he performed severe austerities and lovingly worshiped Lord Hari. Once, Indradyumna accepted a vow of silence and started worshiping the Lord in full absorption. Suddenly a sage named Agastya arrived there along with his disciples. Seeing Indradyumna silently worshiping the Lord and not offering him a reception, Agatsya became angry and said, This king is not gentle. He is degraded and uneducated. He does not even know how guests must be welcomed. He has insulted a brāhmana. May he become a dull and dumb elephant in his next life! Cursing Indradyumna in this way, Agastya left the place. Because of Agastya's curse, Indradyumna became Gajendra in his next life. Agastya's curse to Indradyumna was indirectly a boon that the Lord arraged. By the Lord's mercy, simply in one life as an elephant, Ind dyumna destroyed all his sinful reactions and was promoted to Vaikuntha. Although he got an elephant body that destroys memory due to his previous performance of bhakti, he still remembered His beloved Lord and the prayers he had learned. Thus, he offered prayers Lord Hari. who then arrived and took him to Vaikuntha. Lord Hari said, One who hears the story of Gajendra, early in the morning will become a great devotee and will be freed of all kinds of sinful reactions. After getting out of bed in the morning, one who chants this narration can counteract all the troubles of bad dreams. Anyone who offers Gajendra's prayers to Lord Hari early in the morning shall surely attain the spiritual world at the end of their life.
quotes: One should learn to respect great souls and not insult them. Insulting great souls is equal to inviting great troubles., Even when the devotees are cursed, they remain recipients of the Lord's mercy. The Lord is so grateful for even the slightest amount of bhakti rendered by His devotees and protects them in the most dangerous circumstances.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? 4 TYPES OF MUKTI (LIBERATION) 1. Sārūpya mukti: Attaining the same form like the Lord 2. Salokya mukti: Attaining the same planet as the Lord 3. Samipya mukti: Staying very close to the Lord in His abode 4. Särşți mukti: Attaining same opulence like that of the Lord
activity: 1. Recollect the names of some devotees from the Bhagavatam, who have been cursed heavily for their small mistakes but accepted them in a positive spirit, and finally attained the Lord. 2. Write down a few ways to improve your dealings with others and thus attract their blessings.
lesson: A LESSON ON CURSES: Even curses of saintly persons indirectly act as blessings, enabling one to receive God's grace. That was the case with both the kings, Hühü and Indrdyumna, who were cursed by sages but finally got the Lord's mercy. Whether something is a curse or a blessing depends on how one perceives it. Sometimes in the Bhagavatam, we see that even devotees are cursed heavily for their small mistakes. But those devotees accepted those curses as reactions to their own mistakes and didn't blame or hate anyone. Knowing nothing would happen without the Lord's sanction, they remained humble and content. They sincerely repented for their mistakes, avoided repeating them, and took the Lord's shelter heartily. Thus, they were ultimately liberated.

title: The Peace-making Strategy
story: Once in the celestial skies, Durvāsa Muni saw Indra elegantly seated on the back of his heavenly elephant, Airāvata. Being pleased to see the king of heaven, Durvāsa respectfully offered him a garland that hung around his neck. A sage's gift is considered a blessing, but proud Indra didn't value it. So he took that garland and disrespectfully placed it on the elephant's trunk. Being an animal, Airāvata couldn't understand its value and ignorantly smashed it under his feet. Durvāsa Muni burst out furiously and said, Indra, you are so proud of your wealth. I curse you to become poverty-stricken. Soon after this incident, the asuras attacked the devatās and defeated them. All the devatās lost their positions. The wicked asuras took over the heavens and started tormenting innocent people. All this began with Indra's offense towards Durvāsa Muni. The devatās couldn't find a solution to this problem. Hence they all went to the Sumeru mountain to meet Lord Brahmā. They bowed down before Brahmā and informed him of their precarious situation. Seeing the distressful faces of the devatās, Bramhā spoke, We all must take shelter of Lord Visnu, for He is the source of everyone's strength. Being the all-merciful Lord, He will surely help us. Brahmā, accompanied by the devatās, soon reached Sveta-dvīpa, the spiritual abode of Lord Vişnu, which is situated in an ocean of milk. However, the Lord was not visible to the devatās. Brahmä then offered prayers from the Vedas to please Lord Vişnu. He prayed, O Lord, although I am the creator of this universe, it's difficult for me to understand Your greatness. Please reveal unto us Your smiling face, We are in great difficulty. Please help us! Being pleased with the prayers of Brahmā, Lord Vişnu appeared in front of the devatās. He was as brilliant as thousands of suns rising together. Blinded by His effulgence, the devatās couldn't even see Him. Then the Lord mercifully uncovered His effulgence and revealed His beautiful form. He had a beautiful blackish body that resembled a marakata gem. His eyes were reddish, like freshly blossomed red lotuses. His yellow silken garments resembled shining gold. His entire body was attractively decorated. A glance at His smiling face and eyebrows would destroy all of one's distresses. He was adorned with beautiful gem-studded necklaces and a Kaustubha Mani. An exquisite lotus garland adored His neck while He gracefully held the sharp Sudarśana cakra and Kaumodaki Gada in His other hands. Seeing the beautiful form of Lord Vişnu, Brahmā spoke, O Lord, by seeing You, the long-desired goal of our life is finally achieved. You know everything that takes place in every corner of the universe. You are also aware of the troubles we are facing. Please show us how the devatās can regain their original positions. Lord Visnu could solve the devatās' problems at once, but He didn't do so. He desired to perform some enchanting pastimes. Therefore, He suggested to the devatās, It would be best if you make a truce with the asuras. Try to produce amrta (nectar). Cast all vegetables, grasses, creepers, and herbs into the milk ocean, and churn the ocean using Mandara Mountain as the churning rod and Väsuki serpent as the churning rope. Shake hands with the demons, and with combined efforts, try to extract amrta. Anticipating the doubts in the minds of the devatās, Lord Vişnu said, Many products will emerge from the churning of the milk ocean. The asuras might demand them. Allow them to take those products without becoming greedy. Focus on your goal of obtaining amrta. It's difficult to deal with the demons, but with patience and peace, everything is possible. If you become distracted and frustrated, you won't be able to achieve your goal. Having thus advised the devatās, Lord Visnu disappeared. What will the devatās do now? Will they go to the asuras, their enemies, to make a truce? Will the asurās agree with their proposals? Flip the page to find out.
quotes: Too much wealth and fame can sometimes make one proud and disrespectful towards great personalities.
activity: 1. Have you ever worked In a team? Did you ever have clashes with your team members? Share your experience. 2. While cooperating with others, does it mean we need to compromise and let others' opinions overrule us?
lesson: A LESSON ON COOPERATION: Is it possible for a team to win a match if the teammates refuse to cooperate? No, right? Similarly, churning out amrta from the milk ocean was no cakewalk and was impossible without cooperation among those who were churning. Therefore, the Lord instructed the devatās to cooperate with the asuras, although their natures were opposite. Sometimes, we too may have to cooperate with someone whose opinion and working style differ from ours. But when we keep the higher goal in mind, keep aside our ego and envy, and adjust with tolerance, it becomes easy to work cooperatively with others.

title: An Unusual Tug of War
story: After receiving Lord Visnu's advice, the devatās approached Bali, the king of asuras. Bali was a great personality who could tactfully use peace-making and war. So when the devatās approached the asuras, some of the commanders of the asuras came forward to kill the devatās. But Bali stopped them, seeing the devatās not coming to fight but to discuss. The devatās approached Bali and spoke politely, Dear Bali Mahārāja, we have a humble proposal. Both our camps can team up to churn the milk ocean and produce amrta (nectar). Then, both of us can share it among ourselves and become immortal. After contemplating Indra's proposal for some time, the asuras finally decided to befriend the devatās to obtain amṛta. Internally, the asuras had decided to churn the milk ocean with the devatās and later grab all the amrta only for themselves. But, of course, even the devatās had similar intentions. Thus, the two enemy parties now shook hands for churning the milk ocean. First, they went to the huge Mandara mountain, which was to be used as the churning rod. Then, with all their strength, they lifted the mountain and began carrying it towards the milk ocean. But because o its weight, they became very fatigued while on the way. Unable to Cry it any further, they suddenly dropped the mountain. As soon as the heavy golden mountain fell, the limbs of many devatās and asuras Vere crushed under its weight and thus broke. At that time, Lord Visnu appeared there on the back of Garuda. He revived the unconscious devatās and asuras just by His kind glance. Then He lifted the mountain and placed it on the back of Garuda. He also took all the devatās and all the asuras on Garuda! Elegantly seated, the Lord reached the milk ocean, and immediately told Garuda to leave the spot, after unloading the mountain. Then, the devatās and asurās summoned the great snake Vāsuki. Vāsuki coiled the Mandara Mountain like a rope, and the devatās and the asuras are supposed to hold the snake's front and rear portions to do the churning. Lord Vişnu then grasped the head of Vasuki, followed by the devatās. Then the asuras protested, The snake's front part is considered auspicious while the tail is inauspicious. We are very educated and qualified, so we musthold the front part, and you devatās hold the tail. Lord Visnu smiled at their demand and directed the devatās to hold on to Vāsuki's tail. The devatās obediently followed. Finally, the two 'teams' began churning the milk ocean. But as soon as the churning began, the Mandara mountain started sinking into the ocean, because of lack of a supporting base! The devatās and asuras became anxious. Seeing this hindrance, Lord Visnu immediately expanded Himself into a mammoth tortoise, the magnificent Kürma avatara. Then Lord Kürma entered into the milk ocean. He effortlessly lifted and held the Mandara mountain on His gigantic back, 800,000 miles wide like a huge island. Encouraged by this, the devatās and asuras restarted their 'tug of war.' Lord Kürma experienced a nice, pleasing sensation with the mountain rolling on His back. Now, mustering all their strength, the two parties vigorously rolled the mountain and churned the ocean. After a while, they were all fatigued. Vāsuki was almost dying due to the pain from his skin rubbing against the mountain vigorously. Seeing their condition, Lord Visnu desired to rejuvenate them. So ne re-energized the devatās with sattva-guna (mode of goodness), the asuras with rajo-guna (mode of passion), and Vasuki with tamo-guna (mode of ignorance). These three qualities of material nature enable different people with different mentalities to work differently. Thus, the Lord increased everyone's strength. Lord Kūrma gave the stability to the mountain from bottom To also balance the mountain from the top and give it further steadiness, Lord Vişnu appeared in a humongous thousand handed-form, Sahasra-bāhu, and held the top of the mountain with one hand. All the devatās offered Him eloquent prayers. Encouraged by the Lord's empowerment, everyone continued their hard work to obtain the amrta. They all vigorously churned for a long time. But soon, their energy was drained. Due to constant friction with the mountain, Vasuki's thousand mouths spat smoke and fire. The demons who were on the side of Vasuki's head appeared to be powerless. Even the luster of the devatās diminished. Once more, Lord Visnu helped the hard workers by arranging for cool breezes and cold showers falling from rain clouds above, which relieved them of all fatigue. When the amrta, didn't appear despite everyone's intense efforts, the Id decided to join in personally. The Lord looked extremely extra dinary while He partook in the churning. The ocean became turbunt, and all the aquatics, including fishes, sharks and whales, becare agitated. Finally, the first product of Samudra-manthana appeared. That was an extremely dangerous poison called hālāhala. This toxic substance began spreading in all directions in the universe. Feeling unsheltered, everyone grew fearful! What would they do now? Who would come to their rescue? Will Visnu save them now as well, or someone else?
quotes: In this material world, there is a cheating mentality everywhere, even in heaven., Demoniac people naturally want to enter unnecessary competitions and prove themselves greater than others.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? Why did Lord Vişnu ask Garuda to leave? Garuda being a mighty eagle, had the capacity to eat big snakes. But it was the snake Vāsuki who would come there to play the part of the churning rope, and Vāsuki would be the natural food for Garuda. DID YOU KNOW? Why do the waves of the ocean come out? Lord Kürma, who had entered the ocean, started breathing within the ocean. When He exhaled, the waves of the ocean came out of the ocean. And when He inhaled, the waves went inside the ocean. Since then, the ocean waves have continued to come out and go in.
activity: 1. List all ways Lord Vişnu helped the devatās and the asuras in the churning of the milk ocean. 2. When the people whom you are working with are quarrelsome and always want to compete with you and dominate you, how will you deal with them?
lesson: A LESSON ON SUPPORT: Without the Lord's inspiration, sanction, and support, none of our plans can take shape. As a gigantic tortoise Kürma, the Lord supported the huge Mandara Mountain from the bottom, and as the thousand-handed Sahasra-bähu, He balanced it from the top. From conceiving the plan to churn the milk ocean up to its execution, it's the Lord's support that made this massive effort successful. Thus, even the devatäs in heaven always depend on the Lord for guidance and support. Understanding this, let's remind ourselves to humbly thank the Lord for His support and blessings in our endeavors.

title: Drinking A Deadly Beverage
story: The Hālāhala poison kept spreading in all directions. With no help in sight, the devatās decided to approach Lord Śiva for shelter. Although Lord Vişnu was undoubtedly competent to save the universe from the poison, He wished to give credit to His greatest devotee, Lord Śiva, and therefore abstained from doing so. Soon, all the devatās reached the pristine mountain Kailāśa where Lord Śiva was seated with his wife, Bhavani, only for the prosperity of the universe. The devatās then requested Lord Śiva, O Lord, please save us from this fiery poison. O Mahādeva! We have come to you for your shelter because we know that you can easily destroy this poison. You are very powerful and benevolent. Glorifying his qualities, the devatās continued, At the time of destruction, you turn the entire universe into ashes just by the sparks of fire emanating from your eye. On the other hand, your presence brings flourishing happiness to everyone. Even Brahmā cannot estimate your greatness. Mature people worship you and appreciate your great character. But shameless fools criticize you and your wa lerings in the crematorium. Seeing the universe aggrieving due to the poison, Lord Siva became ve compassionate. He spoke to his wife, O Bhavani! Just see how the people have been placed into great danger due to this poison. It is my duty to protect them. Lord Vişnu will be very pleased when someone extends themselves for others' welfare. Therefore, let me drink this poison for the sake of all living beings. Fully aware of Lord Siva's powers, Bhavāni immediately agreed with his proposal. Then, powerful Śiva took every drop of the widespread poison into his palm and effortlessly drank it. That deadly beverage created a blue line on his neck, which he accepted as his ornament. This extraordinary act of selflessness by Lord Siva won the hearts of all great personalities, including all the devatās and even Lord Visnu. After Lord Śiva drank the poison, the devatās and the asuras resumed churning the milk ocean with renewed enthusiasm. Soon a majestic Surabhi cow appeared from the churning. This cow produced delicious milk, butter, and ghee and would be extremely helpful for Vedic sacrifices. Hence, the great sages accepted the cow as theirs. After further churning, a moon-white horse named Ucchaisrava appeared and was taken by King Bali. Then, a white elephant named Airavata appeared and was given to Indra. Further, precious jewels like the Kaustabha-mani and Padmarāga-mani appeared and decorated the chest of Lord Vişnu. Finally, after many such products, goddess Lakṣmī magnificently appeared from the churning. Her extraordinary beautiful features, youth, and complexion delighted everyone's minds. Who would have Goddess Lakṣmī as their possession? Read the next chapter to find out.
quotes: Giving credit to His devotees is one of the most endearing qualities of the Lord., Selfless devotees can't bear the sufferings of others but take up hardships to relieve others from difficulties.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? Why Snakes are Poisonous? When Lord Śiva drank the poison, some drops rolled down his hands. The scorpions and snakes immediately took the opportunity to drink those drops, and thus, they also became poisonous.
activity: 1. Remember some people who helped you when you needed it the most. Share how they helped you. 2. Try helping a few people without expecting anything form them. Share your experience. 3. We may not be able to help everyone, but everyone can help someone. Reflect and share your understanding on this statement.
lesson: A LESSON ON SELFLESSNESS: Noble people work not only for their benefit but for others' welfare too. As genuine well-wishers of all, they selflessly extend themselves to serve others. They even sacrifice their comforts for others' welfare. Such people are endearing to the Supreme Lord and can easily attain the spiritual world. The best example of such a person is Lord Çiva. We may not be able to mirror his selflessness at once, but by drawing inspiration from him, we can surely begin cultivating selflessness in the soil of our hearts.

title: The Divine Wedding
story: When the divine goddess of fortune, Laksmi Devi, appeared from the Samudra Manthana, various personalities offered her several gifts, desiring her wealth in return. Indra, the heavenly king, offered her a gem-studded throne. The lovely cows offered her Pancha-gavya (a combination of five products: milk, curd, ghee, urine, and cow dung). Great learned sages performed an exquisite abhişeka for Mother Laksmi. The Gandharvas sang melodiously while the apsaras danced in joy. Sarasvati Devī, the goddess of learning, offered a majestic necklace, while Lord Brahmā presented her a pink lotus flower. Adorned with lotus garlands and fine necklaces, Laksmi Devi walked about to find a suitable match for her. Then, smiling bashfully, she walked on while her cheeks were covered with long, shining earrings. Her golden form looked as beautiful as a creeper of gold. Accepting the ocean-god as her father, Mother Laksmī, scrutinizingly examined the Gandharvas, Asuras, Siddhas and all the notable personalities present. Durvāsa Muni was endowed with great austerity but occasionally lost his temper. Bṛhaspati, the guru of the devatās, was like a treasure of knowledge, but he had many material attachments. Brahmā was very exalted, but he had many ambitious desire Indra had a great position, but sometimes that would become the case of his pride. In the way, Mother Lakṣmī examined different personalities but found that one of them was a flawless match. So, finally, she came to Lord Visnu the Supreme personality present there. After deep scrutiny, goddess Laksmī concluded that Lord Visnu was an ocean of flawless qualities. Completely self-satisfied, He didn't even want beautiful Lakṣmī as His wife. But being attracted by His qualities, Laksmi wanted to have Him as her husband. So, she placed her garland on His neck and shyly waited for His response. Pleased by Mother Laksmi's devotion for Him, Lord Visnu accepted her at once. The devatās and their wives then made wonderful pompous arrangements for the divine marriage of Lakṣmī and Narayana in the presence of great personalities of the universe. Everyone was present, sang, and danced in ecstasy. Flowers flooded the Divine Couple while everyone praised Them eloquently. Thus, Lakṣmī and Nārāyana came to be known as the Supreme Parents of everyone. Lord Visnu is the father of the three worlds, and Mother Laksmi, who resides on His chest, is an ocean of unending mercy who increases the glories of all planets. After the marriage of Laksmi and Narayana, the devatās and the asuras continued the churning of the milk ocean. Then a lotus-eved goddess named Vāruni, who induces drunkards to get intoxicated, appeared to from the churning. Out of greed, the asuras immediately took possession of Varuni. After the appearance of Varuni, finally, as the churning continued, a divine young personality appeared from the milk ocean. He was exquisitely garlanded, heavily ornamented, and beautifully dressed in yellow clothes. He had a blackish complexion, long arms, and a broad chest. Carrying a jug of amrta in His hands, He looked extraordinary. He was none other than Dhanvantari, an incarnation of Lord Visnu. Lord Dhanvantari was the master of Ayurveda, or traditional medical science. As soon as the asuras saw Dhanvantari and the pot of nectar, they immediately snatched the pot from His hands, and ran away! The devatās helplessly watched this with disappointed faces. Would the asuras drink the nectar, not leaving a drop for the devatās? What would the devatās do now? Would they be bereft of their share of nectar, or would they snatch the amrta back? Find out in the next page.
activity: 1. Is possessing wealth good or bad? Explain. 2. Recollect some marriage ceremonies of the Leed and His eternal consort in different yugas.
lesson: A LESSON ON WEALTH: Wealth is something that almost everyone in this world wants. While sinful people try to acquire wealth illegally, pious people worship the goddess Lakşmi to attain wealth. Even great devatās worship her for prosperity. However, if one worships only Lakşmi for material wealth and ignores her beloved husband Närāyaņa, she wouldn't be pleased with such worship, and she doesn't favor the worshiper. Demoniac Rāvana desired to possess Sītā Devi but envied Lord Rama. Proud Sisupäla wanted to marry Rukmiņi Devi and envied Lord Krşņa. But both Ravana and Sisupāla met with misfortune due to their hatred for the Lord. Lakşmi and Nārāyaņa are a divine couple, our supreme parents. So, if we worship them together, we become recipients of Their profuse blessings.

title: Mohini Fools the Asuras!
story: The asuras successfully snatched the amrta pot away from Dhanvantari's hand. But they were not successful in drinking the amrta. Soon they broke into a quarrel. Being selfish, each one wished to drink the nectar first before everyone else. Seeing the stronger demons entering disputes, the weaker demons proclaimed, Dear friends, even the devatās have helped produce this amrta. They should, too be given their rightful share. But, of course, the weaker asuras weren't so selfless to share the nectar with the devatās, but, seeing no other means to get their share, they wielded morality as a weapon. Seeing the asuras grab the nectar pot, the devatās plunged into disappointment. Finally, however, Lord Visņu reassured them. He then assumed the form of an exquisitely beautiful woman called Mohini-Mūrti. Mohini-mūrti was beautifully ornamented with jewels and garlands. Divine aroma emanated from Her body. She moved from here and there as if searching for someone with Her restless eyes. Then, slowly, She reached the demons. As beary personified, She instantly mesmerized all the demons with Her ill ory potency. After all, She was Visnu, the master of maya. All the suras came under her magic and desired to befriend Her. Captivated by Her charm, they spoke thus, O lotus-eyed girl! Who are You? Your beauty and behavior have completely won our trust. Can you please bring an end to our fight and rightfully distribute the amrta amongst us? Smilingly, Mohini replied, O sons of Kaśyapa! I am not trustworthy, Please don't entrust Me with a task of such great responsibility. Hearing such words from Her, the mesmerized demons thought she was joking with them. So they repeated their request with complete confidence in Her. Again, Mohini-mürti replied, If you accept whatever I do, whether right or wrong, only then will I take charge of this nectar distribution. The demons foolishly agreed to Her proposal, trusting Her completely. Each one of the demons thought that She loved him more than the others. Eventually, Mohini-mūrti agreed to distribute the nectar. Thereafter, dressing in beautiful clothes and ornaments, the devatās and the asuras assembled, eager to partake of the nectar. Mohini-mūrti came before them dressed in a beautiful sari, golden anklets, and earrings. She carried the pot of amrta in Her hands and walked gracefully with a smile on Her face. Mohini-mürti then started her nectar distribution. The demons eagerly awaited Her merciful glances. However, She refrained from giving the nectar to the asuras. All of them were like crooked snakes; giving nectar to them would be as dangerous as feeding milk to a poisonous snake. Mohini gave the nectar to the devatās and freed them from old age. Looking at this, the asuras thought to themselves, Maybe Mohini-mūrti giving amṛta to the devatās before us to pacify them. After giving them a little, She will give us more nectar. Let the restless devat drink the amrta first; meanwhile, we will fill our minds with the grater nectar of Mohini Murti's charm. We don't want to quarrel with a woman. We want to please Her. Honoring their promise to Mohini-mūrti earlier, the asuras kept silent. They had developed love, affection, and respect for Her and she didn't want to disturb that relationship. Seeing the asuras, Mohini-mürti indirectly indicated, The devatās are excessively anxious to take the nectar first. Let them have it now. Since you are noble and great, please be patient and wait a little longer. All the asuras came under the magical spell of Mohini-mürti and kept quiet. But one asura named Rahu became greedy to drink the amrta. Disguising himself as a devatā, he entered their assembly. Mistaking him to be a devatā, Mohini-mürti offered Rāhu some amṛta as well. Just as Rāhu was about to gulp it, the Sun god and the moon god realized he was an asura. Hurriedly, they informed Mohini-mūrti about this. Mohini-mürti, at once cut off Rahu's head with the Sudarśana-cakra, even before the nectar could flow down his gullet! After having thus distributed all the nectar amongst the devatās, Lord Visnu withdrew His woman form as Mohini-mūrti. He then mounted on Garuda and left for His abode Vaikuntha. All the devatās felt joyful, and the asuras were shocked! The asuras understood that Lord Visnu had cheated them. How would the angry asuras avenge this trickery? Would they attack the devatās and kill them? Read on to find out.
quotes: While demons are only bent upon fulfilling selfish desires, the only concern of devotees is to satisfy the Supreme Lord.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? Rāhu & Eclipses Since Rahu's head had come in contact with the nectar, his head survived the onslaught of the Sudarśana-cakra, but not his body. Rāhu's head had become immortal, and Lord Brahmā converted it into a planet like the Sun and the Moon. Out of enmity, Rāhu attacks both the Sun and the Moon in the form of eclipses. Mohini-mürti did identify Rāhu, the asura, but, She allowed him to drink a little nectar only so that people could understand the effects of drinking nectar.
activity: 1. Try reasoning out how the Lord's killing of asuras is His mercy towards them. Give some examples. 2. Compare the dealings of the Lord and a loving mother, and share your understanding.
lesson: A LESSON ON PARTIALITY: Although the efforts of the devatas and the asuras were equal, they got different results. Was it due to the Lord's partiality? It may seem so, but in truth, it isn't. Consider this example: A good teacher appreciates a disciplined student and scolds a mischievous student. This difference in treatment is not due to the teacher's partiality but a natural response toward the students' attitude and behavior. Similarly, although the Lord is equal to all, He is more inclined to His obedient devotees and punishes the miscreants. He is not partial to anyone but reciprocates with peoples' moods and deeds. Ultimately whether the Lord protects or punishes, He remains everyone's Supreme well-wisher.

title: A Deadly War
story: Deprived of their share of ampta and feeling thoroughly cheated by the devatās and Lord Vişnu, the asuras grew very angry and intolerant. Filled with hatred, they picked up their dangerous weapons and marched toward the devatās to fight. The devatās, who were just empowered by the amrta counter, attacked the asuras in a great fighting spirit. A hair-raising battle took place on the serene banks of the milk ocean. Both armies fought ruthlessly with deadly weapons. The battlefield was thudding with the sounds of conch-shells, bugles, and drums. The king of demons, Bali, sat on an invisible airplane equipped with powerful weapons and constantly terrorized the devatās' army. But, on the other hand, King Indra sat on his majestic Airāvata elephant, surrounded by several warriors, fighting fiercely. Within no time, the battlefield was crowded with dead bodies. Due to the trampling of both parties, dust rose violently in all directions, covering outer space with a dust cloud. Later, the dust could no longer float because of the blood that sprinkled down and sprayed up so high. King Bali began shooting arrows at Indra and his Airāvata. However, even before Bali's arrows could touch him, Indra expertly counteracted them with his bhalla weapon. Seeing this, Bali became angry and shot his śakti weapon, but again, even before Bali could leave his weapon, Indra cut it to pieces. In this way, Indra was constantly tormenting the demons. Finally, Bali resorted to demonic illusions. He created a giant mountain from which trees burnt in a blazing fire and sharp chips of stone smashed the heads of the devatās. That mountain also rained scorpions, snakes, lions, tigers, boars, and elephants that seemed to crush everything. Whirlpools, winds, and furious floods appeared on the battlefield. All the devatās became morose due to this mystical atmosphere created by invisible asuras. Unable to counteract the illusions, the devatās meditated on Lord Vişnu. Seeing His devotees in trouble, Lord Vişnu majestically appeared on the back of Garuda. Just by the Lord's presence, all the illusions were immediately vanquished. Seeing this, a cruel demon named Kälanemi, who was riding on a lion, threw his trident on Garuda's large head. But the all-knowing Lord caught hold of the weapon mid-air and killed Kälanemi by shooting back the same weapon he threw. Later, the Lord beheaded some prominent demons like Māli, Sumāli, and Malyavān with His potent Sudarśana cakra and left the battlefield. In this way, the devatās were revived by Lord Visnu. Then they started destroying the very demons who were trying to destroy them. Indra took his powerful thunderbolt to kill Bali. Seeing their leader in trouble, all the demons were worried. While releasing the weapon, Indra rebuked Bali, You rascal! Just as a cheater blindfolds a child and takes away all his belongings, you are trying to defeat us with your mystic powers. But understand that we are the masters of all the childish powers you are demonstrating. Wait for my thunderbolt; today, I will finish you off! In response to Indra's offensive words, Bali said, Indra, don't speak arrogantly. Whatever results one attains are according to one's destiny. But out of ignorance, you consider yourself to be the cause of your victory. Because Bali's rebukes were truthful, Indra couldn't say anything. However, he continued to fight. Indra released his brahmāstra at Bali. Then, at once, Bali fell from his airplane and was severely injured. Seeing Bali fall, Jambhāsura, seated on a lion, came to help him. He attacked Indra and hit Airāvata with his club. The mighty elephant became unconscious. Then Indra's charioteer Mātali brought a chariot drawn by thousand horses and asked his master to sit in it. Impressed by Mātali's timely service, Jambhāsura attacked Mātali with a blazing trident. Countering Jambhāsura's attacks, Indra finally killed him with his Vajra weapon. Then a demon named Namuci came there. Roaring like a lion lion, he released a huge spear at Indra. However, just as one cuts vegetables into tiny pieces, Indra slashed the huge spear into pieces. He then attacked Namuci with his thunderbolt, which couldn't even slightly pierce Namuci's skin. Indra was astonished.  Then suddenly, an unembodied mystical voice spoke to Indra, Namuci cannot be killed by anything dry or moist. Think of another way to kill him. Indra began thinking deeply about the message for some time. Finally, the solution struck him! He decided to use a weapon made of foam, which was neither dry nor moist. At once, this foam weapon killed Namuci. The sages praised Indra for his sharp intelligence. In this way, Indra and the other devatās started killing the asuras just like a lion would kill a deer. Seeing the imminent destruction of all the demons, Lord Brahmā sent Närada Muni to stop the fight. Nārada Muni at once appeared and told the devatās, Dear devatās, all of you are protected by Lord Vişnu. Additionally, you have received the amṛta and thus became powerful. Now please stop fighting. There is no need to kill all the asuras. Hearing the advice of the respectable sage, the devatās stopped fighting and returned to their heavenly planets. What would the asuras do now? Would they keep silent and avoid fighting or raise their arms again? Flip the page to find out.
quotes: Simply by remembering the Lord, all the dangers are vanquished, then what to speak of His personal presence.
activity: 1. Cite an example from the Bhagavatam where a devotee became excessively angry and killed many people unnecessarily. Mention who gave him good advice and controlled his anger.
lesson: A LESSON ON OBEDIENCE: Isn't it very difficult to give up one's anger, especially amidst a fierce war? Although it may be so, the devatäs immediately gave up the battle upon being advised by Närada Muni. They obeyed the sage and trusted his well-wishing words. Sometimes, unknowingly we may be subjected to qualities like anger and greed and even tend to harm or punish others beyond necessity. At that time, a mature well-wisher's advice comes to our rescue. If we humbly listen to their good advice, we will surely be saved from committing great blunders.
