title: Marching on to Victory
story: After the devatās went to the heavens, Narada Muni approached the demons. He urged them to take King Bali for urgent medical treatment. Then the demons immediately took Bali to the Astagiri hill, where their guru Śukrācārya resided. Śukrācārya then used his renowned Sanjīvini mantra and brought Bali back to life. He also revived all the other dead demons to a stable health condition. After King Bali became conscious, he didn't lament the lost amrta or the defeat at the hands of the devatās. Being very mature and experienced in life, he knew that nothing could take place without the sanction of the Supreme Lord. Grateful to his guru Śukrācārya, he started to render faithful service unto him. Šukrācārya and the brahmana descendants of the Bhrgu dynasty became pleased with Bali's service and offered his profuse blessings. They also made a sacrifice called Viśvajit yajña to empower Bali to conquer the devatās. From that yajña, Bali received a celestial chariot, a bow, two quivers, and armor. In addition, Bali's celebrated grandfather Prahlāda gave him special blessings. Equipped with all this military paraphernalia and blessings, Bali decided to attack the city of Indra. He marched toward heaven with thousands of soldiers, weapons, and chariots. It seemed as if he was making the entire planet tremble. The heavenly kingdom was very beautiful, for it was filled with lovely gardens, fine fruit trees, chirping birds, and singing bees. Constructed by Viśvakarma, the city boasted lavish palaces decorated with golden doors and marble carvings. Moreover, the entire kingdom had breezes that carried the fragrance of flowers. Then Bali powerfully blew the conch shell that his guru gave. The thundering sound frightened everyone in heaven. Then Bali attacked Indra's city from all directions with his brave soldiers. Just recently, all the devatās had defeated the demons, but when the devatās saw the demons in such courageous spirits, they were surprised. Indra then went to his guru Brhaspati and asked, Our old enemy Bali has come back with renewed enthusiasm and astonishing power, which we cannot resist. He seems to be devouring us. Please tell me, what is the cause of his strength? Bṛhaspati said, Dear Indra, the cause of Bali's power is the blessings of his guru and the brahmaņas. They were pleased with his devotion and blessed him with great power. It is their power, not Bali's power. Indirectly, Bṛhaspati hinted to Indra that he was also powerful like Śukrācāraya and if the devatās had served and pleased him with devotion, he would also bestow such power upon the devatās. Brhaspati continued, No one can stand before Bali except the Supreme Lord Vişnu. Right now, Bali and all the asuras are very powerful, and you do not have the strength to oppose them. Therefore, you all have only one way out. You should leave heaven and hide somewhere else until the situation of your enemies is reversed. Thus advised by Brhaspati, the devatās had no option but to leave heaven. Then they disguised themselves and slyly departed. Realizing that the devatās had wilfully left heaven, King Bali brought the entire heaven under his control. All the demons now ruled the three worlds. The brahmanas of the Bhrgu dynasty encouraged Bali to perform hundred Aśvamedha sacrifices to keep his position as the king intact. Thus, Bali gained a great reputation and enjoyed his rule due to the brāhmaņas' blessings. Will Bali rule the three worlds forever? What happened to the escaped devatās? Will they continue to wander in disguised forms without any shelter? Or will they regain their kingdom by defeating the demons? Read on to find out.
quotes: By sincerely serving and satisfying spiritually advanced personalities we receive unlimited blessings from God., The blessings of a guru are more powerful than one's power. One can gain extraordinary strength beyond one's imagination by serving and pleasing the guru.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? How long can one stay in Heaven? Although heaven (svarga-loka) is filled with many facilities and enjoyment, no one can stay there permanently. One goes to heaven by performing many pious activities. And as soon as one's pious credits are finished, one has to fall. Hence, devotees of Lord Visņu or Krsna aspire to go to the eternal spiritual world Vaikuntha or Goloka Vrndāvana, instead of the temporary heaven. When the entire universe is destroyed, heaven is also destroyed.
activity: 1. Name some people who served their gurus sincerely and got their blessings. 2. Mention an example of someone who displeased their gurus and lost their blessings.
lesson: A LESSON ON BLESSINGS: King Bali served his guru, the brahmaņas, and thus attained their heartfelt blessings. The asuras could conquer the devatās even without raising arms by the power of those blessings. Although the devatās drank some amṛta and gained power, they lost their heavenly positions. This is the power of the blessings of great souls. However powerful, successful and famous, one derives the greatest strength from the blessings of personalities like one's guru. It is by displeasing them that one loses one's strength. Therefore let us serve our spiritual teachers with love and respect.

title: A Mother's Anxiety Relieved
story: Knowing that the devatās were deprived of their positions in heaven, their mother, Aditi, lamented for them. After a long time, Kasyapa Muni, the husband of Aditi and the father of all the devatās, came out of his samādhi or deep meditation. When he met Aditi, he felt that she was in a dull mood. With great concern, Kaśyapa asked Aditi, My dear wife, why are you looking so sad? Have you not properly received uninvited guests at our home? Homes from which guests go away without being received, even with an offering of little water, are like holes of jackals. Are you in the anxiety of separation from me? Are your sons happy? Your withered face shows that your mind is not peaceful. Aditi replied, Everything is well regarding my household duties and guest reception. Because I always follow your instructions, I cannot neglect dharma. My only concern is for my sons, the devatās. They are deprived of their positions in heaven because the demons have occupied their positions. As a result, my sons are now wandering in disguise. Please help them regain what they have lost. Sympathetic to Aditi's affection for her children, Kaśyapa Muni said, Dear Aditi, you must worship Lord Visnu. Only He is capable of subduing all enemies. If He is pleased by you, then undoubtedly, all your wishes will be fulfilled. Aditi felt hopeful and asked, Please tell me the method of worshiping Lord Vişnu and save my sons from this precarious situation. Kaśyapa Muni replied, I shall explain to you the same process Lord Brahmā had taught me when I desired a son. This is called the Payo-vrata process of worshipping Lord Visnu. In the bright fortnight of the Phālguna month, for the twelve days till Dvādaśi, one should subsist only on milk and worship the lotus-eyed Lord Vişnu with unalloyed devotion. Then, you should perform your daily spiritual duties, offer various prayers to the Lord. Finally, you should chant the dvādaśākṣara mantra - om namo bhagavate vāsudevāya. Aditi listened carefully, and Kaśyapa Muni continued, Offer garlands, incense, and lamps to the Deity, bathe Him with milk, and dress Him nicely. During these twelve days, avoid all material talks, remain free from envy and keep yourself pure. Distribute prasāda to the brahmaņas and poor people. The Lord will soon be pleased with you and fulfill your desires. Thus, advised by Kaśyapa, Aditi strictly followed the Payo-vrata without any laziness. After Aditi successfully completed the Payo-vrata for twelve days, Lord Vişnu appeared in front of her in a four-handed form. Seeing Him, Aditi was overwhelmed with bliss. She stood up to offer prayers, but couldn't, due to her intense emotions. Tears fell from her eyes. Finally she gained composure and started offering prayers to the Lord with great love. She appeared to drink the Lord's beauty with her eyes. She prayed, My dear Lord! You're the master and protector of Your devotees. Your feet are the shelter of all holy places. Being the all-knower, You are already aware of my desires. If You are pleased by my service, please show me Your mercy! Lord Visnu replied, Dear Aditi, I already understood your long-cherished desire for the welfare of your sons, who were deprived of all the opulence by the asuras. Lord Visnu continued, O mother of the devatās! Your sons will surely be back in their lost positions. But at this moment, the asuras are unconquerable because they have been favored by the brahmanas, who are in turn favored by Me. Therefore, trying to fight against them will not be beneficial. Yet, I will surely favor you. I shall take birth as your son and thus protect the devatās. Till then, you may worship your husband Kaśyapa, who is pure by his austerity. Always think of Me, and keep this secret, even if someone inquires. After thus blessing Aditi, Lord Vişnu disappeared, and Aditi became extremely jubilant. Soon the Lord entered Kaśyapa's mind and later into Aditi's womb. Knowing this, Brahmā offered his prayers, O Lord! All glories unto You! Your uncommon activities are very difficult to comprehend. You have appeared in the womb of Prsni previously and now in Aditi's womb. Several times You appear as the son of Your devotees only to please them and perform beautiful pastimes. Lord Vişnu then appeared from the womb of Aditi in a four-handed form. He wore exquisite yellow garments and held śankha, cakra, gada, and padma. His complexion was just like an effulgent black pearl. Just by His divine appearance, He created auspiciousness and happiness in the entire universe. Then to please His parents, the Lord mercifully assumed the form of a small sweet brāhmaņa dwarf named Vamana. Learned sages joyfully performed a sacred thread ceremony for Lord Vāmana. Many celestial beings and devatās made loving offerings to the Lord. Mother Earth offered Him a deerskin, while the moon god gave Him a huge staff called brahma-danda. Lord Brahmā gave Him a water pot, while Mother Sarasvati gifted Him a string of rudrākṣa beads. Thus various prominent personalities like Śiva, Pārvati, Brhaspati, and others offered Him various presentations. After the sacred thread ceremony, Lord Vämana heard that King Bali was performing an aśvamedha sacrifice at Bhrgukaccha on the northern side of River Narmada. Naturally, Vāmana wanted to go there. What would happen when Vämana meets Bali for the first time? Read about the exciting meeting in the next chapter.
quotes: A bona fide guru always directs one's disciples towards to take shelter of the Lord for any purpose., When someone sincerely follows the guru's instructions, one attains the Lord's mercy., In the hearts of His devotees, the Lord is always aware of His devotees needs and is ready to help them in difficulties.
activity: 1. Remember how Diti reacted when the Lord killed Hiranyakşa and Hiranyakasipu. Compare her response with Aditi's in this story.
lesson: A LESSON ON AFFECTION: Do your remember what Suniti told Dhruva? Here are her words for reference: I am one mother whose heart is filled with affection for my child. But Lord Hari has the combined affection of millions of mothers. The Lord is the Supreme mother and father of all living beings. He alone has a complete affection, intention, and ability to understand what is best for His children and help them accordingly. He can very well understand a mother's heart and her anxiety for her children and do the needful to address a situation. Sometimes what He does may not seem pleasant externally, but He knows what is best for everyone, and those who have faith in Him can understand and accept His decisions.

attributes.story_setting: Celestial Realm (Swarga, Vaikuntha) & Ancient Kingdom (Bali’s kingdom)

title: An Unusual Charity
story: Lord Vamana started walking towards the sacrificial arena of the King of asuras, Bali. While walking, the young boy's steps pushed the earth down at every step. When he reached the spot, the priests of Bali saw effulgent Vämana, who appeared like the rising sun, robbing everyone with His splendor. Everyone stood dumbstruck, stood up from their seats, and welcomed the young brahmana boy. King Bali became very happy to see Vämana and instantly developed deep devotion to the Lord. But he restrained his devotional feelings because he acted as the asura king. Nevertheless, it was natural for kṣatriyas to honor the brahmaņas. So, Bali unhesitatingly washed Lord Vāmana's lotus feet and placed the water so collected on his head. Bali praised Vämana, My dear brāhmaņa, I heartily welcome You. What can I do for You? By Your auspicious arrival today, our entire dynasty has been purified. Today my sacrifice has finally been completed. All my sins are destroyed by this water that has washed Your feet. The touch of Your divine feet has sanctified the entire earth. Intending to offer charity to the young brāhmaņa guest, Bali said, It appears that You have come here to ask me for something. You may take whatever You want from me a cow, golden palaces, palatable food, horses, elephants, chariots, or anything else. Please ask me without hesitation. Lord Vamana was very pleased and satisfied by Bali's extraordinary reception and said, Dear King! Your words are truthful and excellent. Your advisors are the exalted brāhmaņas from the Bhrgu dynasty, while your ancestors boast of the greatest Prahlada. I only want three steps of land to the measurement of My steps. I don't ask for anything else from you. Although you're the king of the entire universe and very generous, I don't want anything beyond my necessity. One who accepts charity beyond one's own needs will be entangled in sin. Considering little Vämana not very intelligent, Bali said, Dear brāhmaņa! Being a mere boy with insufficient intelligence, You aren't aware of Your own needs. Although I can gift You an entire island, You're asking only for three steps of land! One who approaches me for something need not ask for anything more from anywhere or anyone Please ask me for whatever You want. Lord Vämana gently replied, Dear king, even all the enjoyment in the entire universe cannot satisfy a person with uncontrolled senses. Therefore, if I am not satisfied with the three steps of land, I will not be satisfied even with the seven islands on the Bhū-mandala. Great kings ruled the entire earth, but they couldn't achieve satisfaction. Therefore, I only ask for three steps of land, for that will satisfy me. Bali Maharaj then smiled and said, All right! Please take whatever You like. Then he prepared himself to offer the charity that Vamana wanted. This alarmed his guru Šukrācārya. Sukrācārya could recognize Vāmana as Lord Visnu Himself. To stop Bali immediately Sukrācārya spoke to him, Dear King, this brāhmaņa boy who has appeared as the son of Aditi and Kaśyapa, is Vişnu Himself. He has appeared to support the devatās. The promise you have made unknowingly is very harmful to the asuras. This boy will take away all your land, wealth, and property and give it to Indra. How will you then live if you give Him everything in charity? While Bali silently heard his guru, Śukrācārya cited more reasons. He said, You will not even be able to fulfill your promise. You will then have to suffer in hell. Now, if you have to go to hell by giving everything, isn't it better to keep everything to yourself and enjoy it? A charity that endangers one's livelihood is not praiseworthy. One should use one's wealth for dharma but also keep aside some wealth for one's family welfare. Śukrācārya concluded, Take back your promise! A promise is truthful only when preceded by the word om. Therefore, don't worry. One may speak lies in certain situations like protecting one's wealth or saving someone's life. After hearing his guru's advice, Bali thought about it for some time. Then he replied, Dear guru, what you have spoken is true. A householder should have a means of livelihood and should not give up his duty of family maintenance. But I am the grandson of Prahlada. How can I withdraw my promise out of greed for money? How can I cheat a brāhmaņa? I have already promised Him that I will give Him three steps of land. There is nothing more sinful than untruthfulness. Mother Earth can bear any heavyweight except the burden of a liar. I do not fear poverty, distress, or even hell, as much as I fear cheating a brāhmana. Śukrācārya didn't seem to agree with Bali. Emphasizing his decision, Bali continued, Wealth is anyway temporary and is separated at the time of death. So why not please a brāhmaṇa with that wealth I'm going to lose at the time of death? Many great men like Dadhīci and Sibi sacrificed their own lives for others' sake. So why should I hesitate to give up this insignificant land to please this great brāhmaņa? Time will destroy everything that we have except our reputation. If I develop a good reputation by offering my property to this brāhmaņa as a charity, that would be more precious than my insignificant wealth. If becoming poverty-stricken by giving charity to the needy is excellent, then what to speak of giving charity to this knowledgeable brāhmana? Over and above that, according to you, if this boy is Lord Visnu, then without a second thought, I vow to give Him whatever He wants. In this way, king Bali rejected the advice of his guru. Śukrācārya became furious with Bali's reply and said, You consider yourself so learned that you disobey my order! Therefore, I curse you to become poverty-stricken soon. Inspired by Lord Vişnu, Šukrācārya thus cursed Bali. Now, what would be Bali's response? Would he fall at his guru's feet and beg forgiveness? Would he withdraw the promise he made to Vamana? Or did he do as he had decided before his guru cursed him? Read the next chapter for an exciting episode.
quotes: A devotee who is determined to serve the Lord can reject anything or anyone that creates an obstacle in one's service.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? Why did Šukrācārya stop Bali? Śukrācārya was a materialistic priest of the demons and didn't follow the principles of devotion unto God. If Bali became poverty-stricken, that would indirectly affect Śukrācārya, as he depended on him for financial maintenance. Therefore he tried to forbid Bali. But Bali was very truthful in his promise and wanted to offer his wealth to Lord Vāmana even at the cost of being poverty-stricken. That's the nature of his pure devotion.
activity: 1. What would you offer the Lord if He asked you for a gift? 2. Was Bali's disobedience to his guru proper? Explain. 3. If you were in Sukrācārya's place, would you allow Bali to offer charity to Vāmanadeva or stop him? Why?
lesson: A LESSON ON PROMISE: A truthful person never takes back his words, come what may. For a kṣatriya like Bali, a promise made to a brāhmaņa should be honored even if that means draining the royal treasury to the last coin. Sukrācārya warned Bali that the brāhmaņa was indeed the Lord, who had come to take away all of Bali's property. He strongly advised Bali to withdraw his promise and tried inducing him to lie. But Bali was a man of his word and would not budge, although he represented the asura lineage. On similar lines, let's try our best to honor the promises we make. Also, let's think twice before making a promise, that is not simply mouth-deep but also heart-deep! A LESSON ON OFFERING: Factually, no one can give anything to the Lord for He is full in all aspects. What we offer the Lord is not charity but a service. Our offerings are not for His benefit, but for our benefit. What we offer to Him doesn't belong to us, nor does it enrich His opulence. But such an offering brings us closer to Him, by purifying our hearts. It's an expression of our devotion which is the very nature of the soul.

attributes.main_character_type: Divine Being (Vamana, an avatar of Vishnu)
attributes.narrative_style: Balanced (mix of dialogues, descriptions, and action)

title: The Greatest Cheater!
story: Bali was prepared to give charity of three steps to Vamanadeva even after being cursed by his guru. He joyfully washed the Lord's lotus feet and then took that water on his head. Seeing this act of Bali, great Gandharvas, Vidyādharas, Siddhas, and Caranas praised him for his honesty and showered flowers upon him. After receiving the three steps from Bali, Lord Vamana manifested His divine pastime. Vāmana, a small brāhmaņa boy, started increasing His size until everything in the entire universe was occupied. Seeing His gigantic form containing all the planets, skies, oceans, etc., everyone was awestruck. They began offering prayers. The devatās offered fragrant flowers while the Gandharvas and Apsaras joyously sang and danced for the Lord's pleasure. Lord Vamana covered the earth's entire surface in His first gigantic step. After that, his body covered the vast skies and His arms covered all directions. With His second step, He covered all the upper planets. Finally, his foot grew larger and larger and covered all the planets, including Satyaloka, Tapaloka, Janaloka, and others. Thus, the Lord didn't find any place for His third step! The effulgence of Lord Vamana's toenails even defeated the effulgence of Brahmaloka. Lord Brahmä, the sages like Marichi, and other great yogis seemed extremely insignificant. Various great personalities came to worship the Lord. The Lord appeared majestic when he occupied the entire universe with just two steps. This gigantic form of Lord Vämana is called Trivikrama, or one who has conquered all three worlds by occupying them with His own body. Brahma then worshipped Lord Vāmana's upraised lotus foot with the water from his pot (kamandalu). That water that washed the Lord's foot became River Gangā. Falling down from the sky, Gangā purifies the three worlds. Lord Vämana, after occupying the entire universe with just two steps, then reduced to His original form. Seeing the Lord's bewildering feat, all the asuras became very angry. They complained, This Vāmana is not a brāhmaņa, but Vişnu. He is the greatest of all cheaters who works only for the interests of the devatās. Our king embodies truthfulness and kindness towards the brāhmaņas, so he will not punish this cheater. But we shouldn't let Vişnu take unnecessary advantage of our leader! It is our duty to kill this Vāmana and thus serve our master! The asuras then took up their weapons and rushed to kill Vämana. Lord Visnu's associates, Nanda, Sananda, Jaya, Vijaya, Garuda, Jayanta, and others, forbade them. Being as powerful as ten thousand elephants, they began trampling the asuras. Seeing Lord Vāmana's associates were killing the asuras, Bali told them, O Vipracitti! O Nemi! Please stop fighting! By human efforts, no one can defeat the all-powerful Supreme Lord. Time is also not in our favor. Previously, fate favored us, and we could defeat the devatās and occupy their heavens. Now, this same fate is in favor of the devatās. Therefore, we must wait till time favors us. By the influence of time, one can lose one's power, position, and everything. Better you all go to the lower planets now. Bali thus controlled the enraged demons. Garuda then came with the ropes of Varuna (varuņa-pāśa) and arrested king Bali. Lord Vämana then spoke to Bali, O king! You had promised me three steps, but I occupied the entire universe with just two steps. Where should I put my third step? Being proud of your wealth, you promised to gift me three steps of land, but you couldn't fulfill your promise. One who doesn't give charity properly should go to hell. How would Bali respond to such allegations? Would he protest and speak against the Lord's cheating? What exactly were the Lord's intentions in treating Bali this way? Flip on to find out.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? King Bali promised Lord Vāmana only the land occupied by his steps, but how can the Lord occupy the sky also? Steps include everything downward and upward. When one stands up, one occupies not only the land below one's feet but also certain portions of the sky. Thus, the Lord rightfully covered the entire skies with His huge steps. DID YOU KNOW? THE THREE GANGĀS 1. The water from Lord Brahmā's pot that washed Lord Vamana's feet became River Gangā. 2. River Gangā arose from the causal ocean, outside the universal shell pierced by Lord Vämana's toenail. 3. River Gangā is directly a liquid form of Lord Nārāyaņa. Thus, it should be understood that River Gangā is a mixture of all three.
activity: 1. If a mother feeds a bitter medicine to her child within a morsel of tasty food, is that cheating? Explain. 2. If a father take away his son's smartphone to save him from mobile vibrations and distractions, is it a mistreatment? Explain. 3. Quote an example of someone who has cheated for a greater cause.
lesson: A LESSON ON CHEATING Great people cheat for a great cause. Although Lord Vamana cheated Bali, He did so for Bali's benefit. If a devotee is proud thinking of oneself as the proprietor of everything, the Lord takes his property away. This is to protect His devotee from illusion and pride and to show special mercy. By taking everything away from Bali, Lord Vamana allowed him to surrender himself fully. Later the Lord gave Himself to Bali, as we will see in the next chapter. Whatever God does is for our good. Thus, externally the Lord might seem partial or biased, but in reality He is our only well-wisher in all circumstances.

title: God At The Gate
story: Lord Vämanadeva seemed to have mistreated king Bali and made him break his promise. But Bali was not at all agitated. On the contrary, he was very patient and tolerant and said, O Lord! If you think my promise is faulty, I shall surely rectify it. So please place your third footstep on my head. I do not fear living in hell or losing my position. I do not fear being arrested or suffering from poverty. But I fear ill reputation. I don't want to be seen as a liar or become infamous for breaking my promise. Bali then expressed his heartfelt devotion and gratitude to Vāmanadeva, My dear Lord! You are our eternal well-wisher. One's body, relatives, and home are all temporary. Only the service rendered unto You is permanent. Prahlada, my grandfather, was harassed by his father in many ways, yet You always protected him. I will also worship You, although You have taken away all my property. I only see this situation as an opportunity to surrender unto You. Your punishment will help me become detached from my temporary positions and possessions. While Bali was thus praying to the Lord, Prahlada appeared on the scene. Bali couldn't bow down to his grandfather because of being bound by ropes. He just offered him respect in his mind. Bali's eyes were filled with tears, and his face was lowered in shame. Bali thought, Because the Lord binds me, my grandfather might think that I have displeased the Lord. Seeing Lord Vamana, Prahlada was overwhelmed with tears of joy aid, My dear Lord! Lord! It is You only who has given heaven to Bali, and it is You only who has taken it away from him. In both situations, You are merciful towards him. While taking away his property and position, You have saved him from material illusion. This is just an act of your unlimited mercy. Then Lord Brahmā was about to say something, but Bali's wife, Vindhyāvalī, arrived at the scene. So Brahmā allowed her to speak, and she said, O Lord! You have created this universe for Your pastimes. Unfortunately, however, foolish people claim proprietorship over it for enjoyment and consider themselves the doers of all their activities. Prahlāda and Vindhyāvalī indirectly approved the Lord's punishment to Bali, who was slightly proud of his wealth and charitable nature. But Lord Brahmā became sympathetic to Bali. Brahma then spoke to Lord Vāmana, O Lord! You are the well-wisher and master of all. Please release Bali. He doesn't deserve to be punished anymore. He offered You everything he had, including his own body! You are supremely pleased when anyone offers you a small flower or little water with love. By Your mercy, they attain Vaikuntha, then what to speak of Bali who has offered You the three worlds, without duplicity. How, then, can he deserve to suffer from arrest? Please release him. Please be merciful upon him. Finally, Lord Vämana spoke, revealing His heart, I favor My devotee who is proud of material wealth by taking away all his wealth. Despite possessing high birth, youth, beauty, education, opulence, and wealth, if one is not proud, such a person is understood to be favored by Me. Then the Lord began praising Bali and expressed His deep affection, I am very much pleased with Bali's tolerance. He has surpassed māya. He is fixed up in his vow despite being bereft of his riches, fallen from his position, defeated and arrested by his enemies, rebuked by his relatives, and cursed by his guru. He remained tolerant and unagitated. Lord Vämana thus glorified Bali, and blessed him, Dear Bali, in the next manvantara, you will become Indra, the king of heaven. Until then, you may live on the Sutala planet, which is not obtainable even by the devatās. I am offering this to you, being impressed with your devotion. And I will personally become your gatekeeper at the Sutala loka. I will stay awake to protect you from any attacks by envious people. I bless you to remain devoted to Me even amidst distracting opulence. Bali was then released from the Varuna-pāśa. He became overwhelmed with the Lord's blessings and kindness. Folding his hands, with tears in his eyes, he spoke, O Lord, I merely offered obeisances to You within my mind when You came to me. Yet I attained results sought by fully dedicated devotees. The rare mercy You have shown me by putting Your foot on my head was not achieved even by the devatās. Saying this, Bali bowed down to the Lord and the other devatās like Brahmā and Śiva and joyfully went to Sutala, along with the asuras. Lord Vämana then spoke to Prahlāda, My dear son! All good fortune unto you! For the time being, please go to Sutala planet and enjoy with your grandson and relatives. You will see Me there with a club in hand. Prahlada obediently followed the Lord's advice. Then, Lord Vamana gave the proprietorship of heaven to Indra and thus fulfilled the desire of mother Aditi. Lord Bramhā, the devatās, the sages, the Manus, and everyone else glorified Vamanadeva as the protector of the universe. The Lord performed such astonishing acts only for the pleasure of Aditi and Kaśyapa and for the welfare of all living entities. The leaders of heaven brought Vamana to the heavens in a celestial airplane and then sang His glories. Everyone named Vāmana as Upendra, the younger brother of Indra. Anyone who hears the activities of Lord Vämana is undoubtedly freed from all sins. No one can count the glories of Lord Trivikrama, just as one cannot count the number of atoms on Earth.
quotes: The Lord gives the necessary intuition to His devotee to come out of a bewildering situation., Knowing the Lord to be one's true well-wisher, devotees always remain grateful to the Lord no matter however He treats them., If one becomes proud, thinking of himself as the proprietor of everything, the Lord takes away all of his wealth, only to protect him from pride and gift him the ultimate wealth of devotion., A pure devotee never deviates from the Lord's service despite all difficulties., The Lord takes great pleasure in serving His devotees., A devotee feels indebted and grateful to the Lord for His mercy. Although a pure devotee may appear to have gone to hell or heaven, he doesn't live in either place. Instead, he always lives in Vaikuetha, engaged in the Lord's service.
activity: 1. Cite some incidents where you offered something to the Lord. 2. Do you think you have received the Lord's mercy in some form? Share your experience. 3. Does the Lord always take His devotees' wealth, or has he ever blessed His devotees with wealth? Cite a few examples to support your answer. 4. While praising Bali, the Lord glorified his qualities like tolerance and truthfulness. Do you think it's necessary to cultivate such qualities along with devotion for the Lord? Explain.
lesson: A LESSON ON SPECIAL MERCY: The Lord's mercy comes in different shapes and sizes. Although Lord Vāmana apparently cheated Bali earlier, He did so to free Bali of his slight pride. In reciprocation to Bali's surrender, the Lord showered upon Bali His affection by becoming his gatekeeper. Bali was not a sadhana siddha or one who becomes perfect by following various bhakti practices. Bali was a kṛpā-siddha or one who becomes perfect by the mercy of devotees and the Lord. Because of the merciful blessings of Prahlada, Bali developed a deep devotion to Lord Vämana as soon as he saw Him and offered Him everything. Thus he attained the Lord's special mercy.

title: The Divine Fish
story: Once upon a time, there lived a great King named Satyavrata. He ruled the Dravidadeśa during the Cakşuşa-manvantara. He was a great devotee of Lord Visnu. One day, King Satyavrata went to river Krtamālā to offer his oblations. He took some water into his hands and found a beautiful golden fish in his palms. He threw it back into the river, and again picked up some water from the river. The fish came back into his palms, and he threw it again into the water. To his surprise, the fish started speaking to the King. The fish said, O King, you're the protector of the poor, then why are you throwing Me in this river? I'm not safe in this river. I'm very much afraid of the big aquatics who can kill Me. Please give Me shelter. King Satyavrata was astonished to see the speaking fish. The king decided to protect the fish by agreeing to the fish's request. He brought the fish to his palace and placed it in a big water jug. Within one night, the fish grew so large that it could not fit in the jug. The fish then spoke to Satyavrata, Dear King, this jug is very congested for Me. Can you please give Me a better shelter? Then, the King kept the fish in a large well. But within a moment, the fish expanded in size and occupied the entire well. Satyavrata was surprised, and left it in a huge lake. But within no time, the fish assumed a form exceeding the extent of the lake and spoke to the Satyavrata, O King, this lake is not sufficient for Me to live in. Please put Me in a water reservoir that is big enough to accommodate Me. Even the largest reservoir of water wasn't sufficient for the fish. So, the King released the fish into the ocean. Then the fish said, O Satyavrata, there are so many dangerous sharks that will eat Me in the ocean. Please don't throw Me here. Bewildered, Satyavrata asked the fish, Who are you, sir? In one day, You expanded Your size so much that You couldn't fit in any of the vessels I provided. I have never seen such a miraculous aquatic before! By the Lord's mercy, King Satyavrata understood the fish's identityand said, You are certainly Lord Nārāyaņa. I offer You millions of obeisances. To show mercy on all living beings, You have now assumed the form of an aquatic. All Your pastimes and incarnations are only for the welfare of all living beings. I wish to know the purpose of Your Matsya incarnation. Why did You appear in the form of a fish? Lord Matsya replied, Dear King, please hear Me attentively. On the seventh day from today, all three worlds (Bhūh, Bhuvah, and Svah) will merge into the waters of devastation. The universe will be annihilated, and the three worlds will be submerged in the flooding ocean waters. During such chaos, I will send you a large boat. You should collect all types of herbs, seeds, and everything valuable and immediately stock them on the ship. Then, accompanied by the seven great sages (sapta rşis) and all kinds of living beings, please board the boat. Afterward, attach the huge vessel to My horn using the Vasuki serpent as a tying rope. Then, in the light of the effulgence of the sages, travel on the dark ocean of inundation without fear. Pulling the boat, I shall travel in the waters of the devastation until Brahma's night slumber is over. Saying this, Lord Matsya disappeared. King Satyavrata was astonished to hear such news from the Lord. But maintaining his cool, the King began meditating on Lord Matsya while sitting on a kuśa mat. After some time, heavy rains poured. The ocean began to overflow and inundated the entire world. Then, as foretold by Lord Matsya, Satyavrata saw a big boat coming towards him. He then collected all the herbs and creepers, and, accompanied by the sages; he boarded the boat. The sages spoke, Dear king, please meditate on the Lord, for only He can save us from this huge danger. Satyavrata then began meditating on the Lord. Suddenly, a large golden fish, eight million miles long, with a horn, appeared in the ocean. Following the Lord's advice, the King anchored the boat to the Lord's horn with the Vāsuki serpent. King Satyavrata then offered his heartfelt prayers to Lord Matsya, Ο Lord, You bestow knowledge upon the ignorant. You are our Supreme guru. Foolish people material activities hoping for happiness, but they only get suffering. Only by serving You can become free from all suffering, and attain eternal happiness. Neither the devatas nor the sages can understand You fully. You are the supreme well-wisher of everyone. Please be merciful upon us. Thus praised by Satyavrata, Lord Matsya explained spiritual knowledge while moving in the ocean. Lord Matsya taught him the Matsya Purāna and Sankhya yoga (analysis of matter and spirit). King Satyavrata and the sages were blessed to hear Lord Matsya's instructions. Anyone who sincerely hears this great divine narration is freed from all sins. Satyavrata, in his next life, became the son of the sun-god Vivasvān. Therefore he was called Vaivasvata Manu. Flip on to the next section to know about his descendants - the great kings of the Sun dynasty.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? PRALAYA OR DEVASTATION: At the beginning of Brahmā's day, all the different planets and species in the universe are created. And at the end of Brahmā's day (during the night), everything that has been created is destroyed. One day of Brahmā is divided into fourteen parts, and each part is called a manvantarā. Also, at the end of some manvantaras, the three worlds can partially be destroyed.
activity: 1. List at least the four incarnations of the Lord in which He saved His devotees from difficulties. 2. Which avatara of the Lord is your favorite? Why? List a few special feats of that avatāra that you would like to narrate to your friends.
lesson: A LESSON ON DIVINITY: In whichever form the Lord appears - as a hog (Varaha), as a tortoise (Kürma), or as a fish (Matsya), or as a child (Vämana), or a half man half lion (Narasimha), or as a human being (Rāma) - He is always divinely beautiful, and protects His devotees from calamities. He also distributes divine knowledge to enlighten His devotees. It is due to His concern and care for all His devotees, that the Lord appears in various forms and performs divine activities. Thus He attracts us to Himself and inspires us to join Him in His eternal world. We should be grateful to the Lord for His mercy upon us, and worship Him with devotion.

title: Sudyumna: The Boy who Became a Girl
story: Initially, Vaivasvata Manu did not have children. To get a son who would rule the kingdom after him, he conducted a sacrifice under Vasistha Muni's guidance. During the sacrifice, his wife, Śraddhā, observed the Payo-vrayā vow, subsisting only on milk. Although Manu desired a son, his wife desired a daughter. So, she approached the priest and requested him for a daughter. The priest then offered oblations into the fire to get a daughter for the Queen. Eventually, Śraddhā gave birth to a beautiful daughter named Ilā. Vaivasvata Manu was happy with her birth, but his desire for a son remained. So, Manu went to Vasistha Muni and asked, Dear sage, you brāhmaņas are sinless, austere and are experts in chanting mantras. So then, how was the result of the sacrifice opposite? Why did I get a daughter instead of a son? Vasistha replied,This discrepancy in the sacrifice was due to your priest. He chanted mantras so that you get a daughter instead of a son. But don't worry, I can give you a son. Sage Vasistha then offered prayers to Lord Visnu to transform Ilā into a boy. Being pleased, Lord Vişnu granted Vasistha's desire, and thus Ilā became a handsome boy named Sudyumna. Sudyumna grew up nicely as a prince. He went to the forest to hunt with his followers one day. While chasing the animals, he entered a forest named Sukumāra, where Lord Śiva stays with his wife, Umā. As soon as Sudyumna entered that forest, he immediately transformed into a female. Even his followers also became females. Everyone was confused. Even Sudyumna's horse became a mare! Sudyumna, having been transformed into a beautiful woman Ilā, began loitering in the forest along with his soldiers, who also became a woman. At that time, Budha, the son of the moon god, saw Ila and became attracted to her. Budha then married llä and got a son named Purūravā. Later, Sudyumna (Ilā) remembered his guru Vasistha. Vasistha came and saw his miserable condition. Earlier, Vasistha transformed Ilă into Sudyumna, and now because of entering into Sukumāra forest, Sudyumna again became Ilā, a female. So Vasistha worshipped Lord Śiva to transform Ilā into Sudyumna again. Pleased with Vasistha, Śiva appeared before him and said, Sudyumna may remain a male for one month and female for the next month. Thus, Sudyumna regained maleness every alternate month and ruled the kingdom, although his citizens were not satisfied. Finally, after thus ruling for some time, Sudyumna retired and gave the entire kingdom to his son Purüravā. Later, Vaivasvata Manu had more sons. Who were they? What were their stories? Flip the page to find out.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? THE STORY OF SUKUMĀRA FOREST: Once, some sages came to see Lord Śiva in the Sukumara forest. At that time, Lord Śiva was his wife, Parvati. Uma felt shy and uncomfortable seeing the sages, and the sages immediately departed. Knowing the embarrassment of Parvati, Lord Śiva said, Dear Parvati, any male who enters this forest shall immediately become a female henceforth. Since then, no male has entered the forest.
lesson: A LESSON ON FATE: Sudyumna's father desired a male child, while his mother desired a female child. Then Sudyumna was first born as a girl, became a boy, and again became a girl. After that, he remained a girl for one month and a boy for one month. The nature of this world is that, despite one's desire, determination, and endeavor, one cannot change one's destiny so easily. But there is a way to escape destiny, too that is the path of bhakti. Only bhakti or devotion unto Lord Krsna or Vişnu can change the course of one's life, as seen in the following story.

attributes.narrative_style: Balanced (Mix of rich descriptions, action, and dialogue)

title: Prşadhra: One who Surpassed a Curse!
story: After Sudyumna retired, his father, Vaivasvata Manu, wanted more sons. He then performed severe austerities on the bank of River Yamuna for 100 years. He worshipped Lord Visnu and thus obtained ten sons. One of them was Prşadhra. Vasistha Muni instructed Prsadhra to take care of the cows. Following his guru's order, Prşadhra would stand all night with a sword to protect the cows from ferocious animals like tigers and lions. One day, a tiger entered the cow shed during the night. At that time, the stars were covered by clouds. Everything was dark. All the cows became scared and started running here and there. The tiger roared and caught one cow, who screamed in distress. Prsadhra took up his sword and carefully followed the sound of the tiger and cow in the darkness. He wanted to cut the head of the tiger, but by mistake, he cut off the cow's head with his sword. The sword also cut off the tiger's ear, and the tiger fled in fear while bleeding. In the morning, Prşadhra realized that he had killed a cow, and felt very depressed and regretful. Although this sin was unintentional, guru Vasistha became very angry and cursed Prşadhra, May you take birth as a low-born śūdra in your next life, for the sin of killing a cow. Vasistha could have suggested a process of atonement for Prsadhra's unintentional sin. But instead, he impulsively cursed Prsadhra. Accepting the curse with folded hands, humble Prşadhra did not protest or defend himself. Taking the vow of celibacy (brahmacharya), he just worshipped Lord Vasudeva with fixed devotion. Saintly Prṣadhra was detached, self-controlled, and satisfied with his knowledge and devotion. Thus, he traveled all over the earth, as if dumb, blind, and deaf, absorbed in devotional meditation to Lord Vasudeva. Once, while traveling, he entered a forest fire and left his body there. He thus attained Lord Krsna in the spiritual world. Although because of his karma (Vasistha's curse), he was supposed to take birth as a sudra in his next life, he avoided it by performing bhakti unto Lord Krsna. He escaped the effects of the curse.
quotes: Sometimes even great sages come under anger and overly punish someone for an innocent mistake.
lesson: A LESSON ON DEVOTION: Prşadhra killed a cow unintentionally, yet he was harshly cursed by Vasistha to become a śūdra in the next life. But instead of becoming disappointed, Prşadhra accepted the curse and sincerely performed bhakti unto Lord Krşņa. Eventually, he attained the Lord's abode instead of taking birth as a śūdra. That is the power of bhakti. One who seeks God's shelter remains unaffected by the reactions, curses, and sufferings of this world.

attributes.main_character_type: Devoted Seeker (Prṣadhra, a sincere devotee despite the curse)
attributes.story_setting: Holy River (Yamuna), Sacred Forest (where he wandered and attained liberation)
attributes.narrative_style: Balanced (mix of action, emotion, and spiritual wisdom)

title: Sukanya: The Young Wife of An Old Sage
story: Vaivasvata Manu had another great-son named Śaryāti. Moreover, King Śaryāti had a beautiful daughter named Sukanyā. One day, Śaryāti and Sukanyā went to the aśrama of sage Cyavana, along with some soldiers. Sukanyā, who was very young then, started collecting fruits in the forest with her friends. Interestingly, she saw two glowing objects within an anthill. Out of curiosity, she went close to the anthill and innocently pierced the two glowing objects with a thorn. Suddenly, lots of blood started oozing from there. Sukanyā grew fearful, and Śaryāti became surprised. After that, all the soldiers of Śaryāti felt constipated and couldn't pass urine. Śaryāti then spoke to his associates, It appears that someone among us did something wrong and polluted Cyavana Muni's āśrama. Frightened, Sukanyā went to Śaryāti and told them what she had done. After that, Saryāti became afraid and tried to appease Cyavana Muni, sitting within the anthill. Finally, Śaryāti said, O great sage, please forgive my foolish daughter. She did it out of innocence. Cyavana Muni asked Śaryāti, Is your daughter married? Śaryāti understood Cyavana Muni's desire just by his question. So then, Saryāti said, No, my dear sage, my daughter is not married. But, if you desire, you can marry her. Cyavana Muni agreed. Sarvāti then got his daughter married to the sage and returned to his kingdom. Cyavana Muni was old and irritable. Sometimes he would unnecessarily get angry. However, Sukanya was endowed with great patience. She served her old husband carefully, understanding his temperament, and slowly conquered his heart. One day, the Aśvinī-kumāras, the doctors in the heavens came to Cyavana Muni's āśrama. Cyavana Muni greeted them and requested, You are great doctors in heaven. Can you please help me regain my youth? In return, I shall give you a pot full of soma-rasa, although you are ineligible to drink it. The Aśvinī-kumāras were experts in Ayurveda, just like Lord Dhanvantari. So, they could make an older man young. So, they happily accepted Cyavana Muni's proposal. They caught hold of the old and emaciated Cyavana Muni and entered a lake. After some time, three handsome men came out of the lake. When Sukanyā saw three young men similar to each other, she was confused. It was clear that two of them were the Aśvini-kumāras and the third one was Cyavana Muni, but she couldn't recognize her husband because they all looked similar. She could have chosen any of them but only wanted her husband. Sukanya then requested the Aśvinī-kumāras, O great devatas, please mercifully show my husband. Pleased with her chastity and honesty, the Aśvinī-kumāras then revealed her husband, and returned to their heavens. Cyavana Muni thus became a young man and started staying happily with Sukanyā. Once King Śaryāti came to Cyavana Muni's home, to perform a sacrifice. There, he found Sukanyā with a young man he had never seen. Meanwhile, Sukanyā came and bowed down to her father respectfully. Then Śaryāti, instead of giving her blessings, spoke to her angrily, You have cheated your respectable husband, a brāhmaņa sage. But, because he was old, did you accept this young man as your husband? Śaryāti misunderstood Sukanyā because he did not find the old sage but found a young man instead. But Sukanya, being very tolerant, smiled and spoke, My dear father, this young man is Cyavana Muni. By the grace of Aśvinī-kumāras, he became young now. Hearing the whole story from Sukanyā, Śaryāti was surprised and happy and embraced his beloved daughter. Cyavana Muni then assisted to perform a soma-yajña and later he offered a pot full of soma-rasa to Aśvinī-kumāras. The devatas in heaven generally drink soma-rasa, a special beverage, but the Aśvinī-kumāras, being just doctors on the heavenly planets, weren't qualified to drink it. But still, Cyavana Muni offered them this soma rasa. Knowing this, Indra came there angrily and took up his thunderbolt to kill Cyavana Muni. But Cyavana Muni, with his powers, paralyzed Indra's arm. After that, all the devatās agreed to allow the Aśvinī-kumāras to drink the divine beverage.
activity: 1. When someone confronts you unfairly, what would be your present response? How does this story help you to refine your response? 2. In the name of being tolerant and patient, should we allow ourselves to get unnecessarily exploited by other people?
lesson: A LESSON ON PATIENCE: Sukanva committed the innocent mistake of piercing Cyavana Muni with a thorn. After marrying Cyavana, she treated him with love, respect, and patience, although he was old and irritable. When her father became angry seeing her with a young man, she patiently clarified to him that he was Cyavana. In this way, Sukanya showed great patience in her dealings instead of being impulsive and angry. Thus, she could win the heart of her husband and her father. If we, too, try to be accommodative to others' moods and deal with them patiently, we can build loving relationships with everyone around us.

title: Revati: The Shortened Bride
story: King Kakudmi was the grandson of Saryāti. He had a beautiful daughter named Revati. Once, he went to Brahmaloka along with Revati to inquire from Brahmā about a suitable husband for her. At that time, lord Brahma was hearing a musical performance by some Gandharvas. So, Kakudmī waited for him. After the musical performance, Brahmā came to see Kakudmi, who submitted his proposal. Brahmā smiled and told Kakudmi, Dear king, twenty-seven catur-yugas as you waited for me. Because the time calculations on the earth and higher planets are different. Presently, it is Dvāpara-yuga on the earth. I suggest you offer your daughter Revati to the most powerful Lord Balarama, who has now descended on the earth along with Lord Krsna. Hearing this, Kakudmī went to Lord Balarama, who agreed to marry Revati. But Revati was tall as she belonged to the Satya yuga. Balarāma then pulled her down with his plow and brought her to the size of people in the Dvāpara-yuga. Then the divine marriage of Lord Balarama and Revatī took place amidst great fervor and pomp. After that, Kakudmi retired and went to Badarikāśrama to worship the Lord.

attributes.main_character_type: Royal Family Member (King Kakudmi, Princess Revati)

title: Nābhāga: An Emblem of Simplicity
story: Vaivasvata Manu had another son named Nabhaga. Nabhaga's son was Nābhāga. Nābhāga went to the school to study under his guru and lived there for a long time as a brahmacārī. Meanwhile, his brothers thought he wouldn't return to marry or rule the kingdom. So, they all divided their father's property amongst themselves. Later, when Nābhāga returned, his brothers didn't give him any wealth. Instead, they slyly told him, Your share is our father. When simple-hearted Nābhāga went to his father, his father said, Don't believe your brothers' cheating words. I am not a property that can be enjoyed. Innocent Nābhāga didn't go back to his brothers again for his share of the property. So, his father felt pity on him and suggested a means of livelihood. Nabhaga advised Nābhāga, The sages of the Angirā dynasty are going to perform a great sacrifice. Although they are learned, on every sixth day, they will make mistakes. Go to them and describe two Vedic mantras. After completing their sacrifice, they will give you the money they received in the sacrifice. Nābhāga acted accordingly, and the sages gave him all their wealth. While Nābhāga accepted the riches, a black person (Śiva) said, All this wealth belongs to me. Please give it. Nābhāga said, The sages have given this to me. This is mine, not yours! Śiva retorted, Let's ask your father to settle our dispute. When Nābhāga inquired from his father, he said, Whatever the great sages offer in yajña belongs to Lord Siva. Therefore, all this wealth is his. Hearing his father's verdict, Nābhāga bowed to Lord Siva and begged for his mercy. Pleased with Nābhāga's detachment, devotion, and simplicity, Lord Śiva gave him all the wealth from the sacrifice and blessed him with spiritual knowledge. Later, Nābhāga became the father of a glorious king and a celebrated devotee named Ambarīşa.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? TWO KINDS OF BRAHMACĀRĪS: 1. Upakurvāņa brahmacārī: After education by a guru, he returns home, marries, and becomes a householder. 2. Brhad-vrata brahmacārī: Doesn't marry whole life.
activity: Should we always tolerate when someone cheats us? What will you do if someone cheats you? Explain.
lesson: A LESSON ON CHARACTER: Simplehearted Nābhāga was initially cheated by his brothers. Bearing no grudge towards anyone, he faced life's situations with humility and tolerance. Later he was blessed by Lord Siva with material wealth and spiritual knowledge. A person with a good character and behavior never encounters misfortune but is ultimately blessed with good fortune sooner or later. Therefore, let's stick to noble virtues despite all odds.

attributes.story_setting: Ancient Kingdom & Sacred Temple (where the yajña took place)

title: Ambarīsa: Conqueror of God's Heart
story: King Ambarīşa was the glorious son of Nabhāga. He ruled the entire earth. An exalted devotee of Krsna, he was not at all proud of his immeasurable wealth. He utilized his body, mind, and words in Krsna's service while responsibly ruling his citizens like a father. He would conduct various sacrifices for the welfare of his citizens. All his citizens were content and satisfied under his rule. They were accustomed to hearing and chanting about Lord Krsna and His glorious activities. Once, Ambarīşa, along with his queen, observed the Ekādaśī vrata at Mathura for one year. After that, in the Kārtīka month, Ambarişa fasted for three nights and bathed in River Yamunā. He also pleased the brahmanas by donating decorated cows and feeding them delicious foods. With their permission, as he was about to break his Ekādaśī fast, Durvāsā Muni appeared on the scene as an uninvited guest. Ambarīşa respectfully welcomed Durväsä Muni and said, Dear sage, please honor meals at my home. Durvāsā gladly replied, I shall surely eat at your home. But before that, let me go to Yamuna to bathe and perform my rituals. Saying this, Durvāsā Muni left for Yamuna. Ambarīşa waited for Durvāsā's return, but in the meantime, the auspicious time during which he had to break his fast was passing by. So, Ambarīşa considered, If I break my fast before feeding Durvāsā Muni, then that would be an offense to the brahmaņa guest. But if I do not break my fast and wait for Durvāsā Muni, then that would be a flaw in my Ekādaśī vrata. So, let me drink a little water which would count as eating and not eating too. Thinking thus, King Ambarīşa drank a little water. After some time, Durvāsā Muni returned from Yamuna, having completed his rituals. Ambarīşa welcomed him with respect. Durvāsā, by his mystic power, understood that Ambarīşa had drunk water. He became furious and criticized Ambarīşa, Alas, see the mentality of this cruel king! Intoxicated with wealth, he thinks of himself to be God. He had invited me as a guest, but before feeding me, he ate first. I shall now punish him for his misbehavior. Durvāsā Muni created a fiery demon by uprooting a bunch of hair from his head. That demon resembling the blazing fire of destruction came before Ambarīsa holding a trident. But Ambarīşa was not at all disturbed. He didn't even move slightly! Completely dependent on Lord Visnu, he thought, I should not counteract the power of a brahmana sage. I should tolerate his rage. While Ambarīşa was thus meditating on Lord, the Lord's Sudarśana cakra suddenly appeared on the scene and burnt the fiery demon at once, just as a forest fire burns a snake. Then the Sudarśana cakra started flying towards Durvāsā at great speed to kill him too. Durvāsā Muni was frightened. To protect himself, Durvāsā ran swiftly and entered a cave in the gigantic mountain named Sumeru. However, the Sudarśana cakra continued to chase him even within the deep caves. Being a mystic yogi, Durvāsā could go anywhere. He fled in all directions - in the sky, earth, caves, oceans, planets, and even the heavens. But wherever Durvāsā went, the Sudarśana cakra hunted him down. Finding shelter nowhere, Durvāsā Muni went to Brahmāloka, seeking Lord Brahma's help. Brahmā told him, Dear sage, I am fully dependent on Lord Vişnu. Myself, Śiva, Bhrgu, all the sages and devatās, surrender unto Him. I have no power to save you because you have offended Lord Visnu's devotee. When thus refused by Brahmā, Durvāsā Muni went to Kailāsa to take Lord Śiva's shelter. Lord Śiva said, Dear Durvāsā, myself, Brahmā, and all the devatās are always under the control of Lord Vişnu. We cannot compete with Him. Even great sages like Nārada and Vyāsa cannot understand His glories. So when He has decided to punish you, who are we to protect you? It's better that you go to Him for protection. Durvāsā Muni then went to Vaikuntha and fell at the feet of Lord Visnu. Scorched by Sudarśana cakra's heat, he spoke, O Lord Vişnu, O Ananta, O Acyuta, O Narayana, You're the well-wisher of the entire universe. Please protect me from this reaction. Lord Visnu said, Dear sage, I'm not independent. I am completely under the control of My devotees. They control My heart because their hearts are pure without any malice. What to speak of My devotee, even the devotees of My devotees are very dear to Me. I cannot enjoy all My opulence and position without My devotees. They give up their homes, riches, relatives, and lives to serve Me. How can I give them up? They are always satisfied in serving Me and are not interested even in liberation. They do not know anything else but Me. And I do not know anyone else but them. They're in the core of My heart, and I always stay within their pure hearts. Durvāsā: O Lord, if I have offended you, I fall at your feet begging forgiveness. Lord Vişnu: Not Me. Please go to Ambarīşa and beg for forgiveness. I will be pleased only when his heart is pleased. Durvāsā: O Lord, but can't You see his fault? He invited me but ate before feeding me. How can You tolerate an offense to a brāhmana? Between respecting a brāhmaņa and following the Ekādaśī vrata, which is more important? Lord Visnu: Durvāsā, you're so ignorant of the conclusions of scriptures. Go and ask Ambarīşa. He will teach you. The scriptures say that drinking water is both eating and not eating also. Thus, just by drinking little water, Ambarīşa has equally respected his brahmaņa guest and the Ekādaśī vrata. By offending Ambarīşa, you have acted with self-envy. Go and immediately fall at his feet for your own protection. Lord Visnu continued, For a brāhmaņa, austerity and learning are certainly auspicious, but if he is not gentle and has bad conduct, his austerity and learning are of no use to him. Therefore, you should go to Ambarīşa and please him. Only then will you attain peace. Hearing Lord Vişnu's words, Durvāsā immediately ran towards Ambarīşa and fell at his feet. Ambarīsa felt ashamed to see a brāhmaņa sage falling at his feet. Durvāsā was about to get up and praise Ambarīşa, but Ambarīşa understood the situation and requested Sudarśana cakra, O Sudarśana, you're very dear to Lord Visņu. Your thousands of spokes can destroy all weapons. You're known to destroy demoniac people, but not the gentle brāhmaņas. This brāhmaņa sage is not your enemy. If our family has given any charity, performed sacrifices, properly carried out our duties, and pleased the all-merciful Lord, please, may this brahmaņa be freed. Because of Ambarīşa's prayers, Sudarśana cakra became peaceful and stopped burning Durvāsā Muni. Being grateful, Durvāsā praised Ambarisa, Today I have witnessed the greatness of Lord Visnu's devotees. O King, although I have offended you and tried to kill you, you have prayed for my life. What is impossible to do for pure devotees like you? I'm indebted to you. Ambarīşa had astonishingly fasted since the time Durvāsā was being chased by Sudarśana cakra. So, he requested Durvāsā, O sage, you had come to eat at my house one year ago. But I couldn't feed you. So please accept the food now. Durvāsā then praised Ambarīşa, I'm very satisfied and pleased by your hospitality. Simply by associating with you, I am feeling very joyful. Durvāsā Muni then happily ate in the house of Ambarişa and requested him also to eat his meals. Later, Durvāsā Muni departed for Brahmāloka while praising Ambarīşa and his bhakti. Ambarīşa didn't take any credit for the protection of Durvāsā. All he knew was that the Lord is all merciful. After responsibly performing his kingly duties for a long period, Ambarīşa divided his property amongst his sons. He then retired to the forest and concentrated his mind fully upon Lord Vasudeva. With sincere and dedicated spiritual practices, he finally attained the spiritual world. Anyone who chants or even thinks about the narration of Ambarīşa Mahārāja becomes a pure devotee of the Lord.
quotes: A devotee balances his social and spiritual duties nicely., The Lord inspires His sincere devotees to take suitable decisions according to time, place and circumstances., Pure devotees are not afraid of danger because they always depend on the Lord., One's prowess employed against a devotee certainly harms the person himself., One who truly loves God naturally loves His devotees too. But one who is rude and offensive to the devotees is not a true lover of God., The Lord experiences pain in His heart when someone tries to harm His devotees., Devotees are willing to sacrifice everything they have to serve or save others., Sometimes tolerance and forgiveness can be more effective than weapons in transforming the heart of a proud and envious person., Devotees do not take credit for their benevolent actions. They transfer all glory to God and His mercy.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? How Ambarīşa used all his senses in Krsna's service? Mind - Meditating on Krsna's lotus feet Words - Glorifying Krsna's qualities Hands - To clean Krsna's temple Ears - Hearing narrations about Krsna Eyes - Seeing the deities of Mukunda Sense of touch - Touching devotees Nose - Smelling the fragrance of Tulasī Tongue - Tasting the Lord's prasāda Legs - Walking to holy places & temples Head - Bowing to the Lord's feet
activity: 1. Recollect the examples of people who tried to harm devotees but ended up in trouble. 2. Did anyone deal with you badly? If so, think of some reasons why you should forgive them. 3. Mention the names of some devotees who forgave those who offended them. 4. If forgiveness is a godly quality, then why does the Lord punish the demons? Can't He forgive them? Explain.
lesson: A LESSON ON FORGIVENESS: Although a devotee doesn't take offenses seriously, the Lord does not tolerate any offense against His devotees. Therefore, offenses against a devotee are very severe. Mature devotees readily forgive any offender, but the offender must give up his false ego and sincerely beg forgiveness from the devotee. Only then will the Lord excuse the offender. Devotees are so forgiving that they are willing to go to any extent to save the offender, and they don't even take credit for their kindness. They attribute all credit to the Lord. They hold no grudges, envy, or negativity towards the offenders. Forgiveness makes one's heart peaceful, brings a transformation in the offender's heart, and ultimately pleases the Lord.

title: Saubhari: Distracted Under Water
story: Vaivasvata Manu's eldest son of was Ikṣvāku, who was born from Manu's nostrils when he sneezed. Out of the several great kings in Ikṣvāku's dynasty, Māndhātā was one. Māndhātā's birth was very interesting. His father, Yuvanāśva, had no sons initially. Therefore, he retired from family life and went to the forest with his hundred wives. In the forest, some sages saw Yuvanāśva and felt compassion for him. Intending to get him a son, the sages performed an Indra-yajña, a sacrifice to please Indra, the king of the devatās. During the night, Yuvanāśva became very thirsty. Finding no water, he entered the sacrificial arena and drank the sanctified water. That water was meant to be drunk by his wife so that she could give birth to a child. But Yuvanāśva drank it. Later, the brahmaņas saw the water pot empty and found that the king had drank that water. Because Yuvanāśva drank the water that was meant for his wife, Yuvanāśva had to give birth to the child. In due course of time, Yuvanāśva gave birth to a powerful son named Māndhātā. The baby cried for his mother's milk, but because he was born to his father, he was bereft of milk. As the brāhmaņas were wondering who would feed the child, Indra appeared there. He put his forefinger in the baby's mouth and fed Māndhātā. Being blessed by the brahmaņas, Yuvanāśva didn't die, despite giving birth to a baby as a male. After this incident, Yuvanāśva dedicated himself to performing various devotional austerities. Finally, by the Lord's mercy, he attained the spiritual world. Yuvanāśva's son Māndhātā became a very great emperor. Indra named him Trasaddasyu (giver of fear to criminals) because he would instill fear even in great demoniac rogues like Rāvana and others. Residing in the city of Mathura, Māndhātā was so powerful that he alone ruled the entire world only from one place. Māndhātā performed many sacrifices for Lord Vişnu's pleasure and gave profuse charity to the brāhmanas. Mandhātā had three sons and fifty daughters. One day, a great sage named Saubhari came to King Māndhātā and said, Dear King, I would like to get married. Could you please hand me one of your daughters in marriage? Earlier, Saubhari Muni performed austerities alone deep inside River Yamuna's pristine waters. Once, he saw a couple of fish enjoying in the water and desired to get married and enter family life. Thus he came out of River Yamuna and met King Mandhātā in Mathurā city. Seeing the old sage's worn-out condition, Māndhātā felt, This old brāhmaņa is not a suitable husband for my beautiful young daughters. But if I deny his request, he might become upset and even curse me. Thinking thus, Mandhātā told Saubhari, Dear brāhmana, my daughters may accept a husband according to their choice. You can see my daughters, and if any one of them chooses to marry you, I have no objection. Saubhari Muni thought, I'm an old and feeble yogi with grey hair and wrinkled skin. Seeing my condition, no woman would like to marry me. And this King almost refused my proposal by giving this reason. But I must somehow marry someone. With my mystic power, I shall reform my body so that even celestial ladies desire to marry me, what to speak of these princesses on the earth. After that, a servant of King Māndhātā took Saubhari Muni to the lavish quarters of Māndhātā's daughters. On the way, Saubhari Muni transformed into a young handsome man. When he came in front of the fifty princesses, each one of them was attracted to him. So, they all gave up their sisterly relationships and started quarrelling amongst themselves, I will marry him, I will marry him. Finally, they all decided to accept Saubhari Muni as their husband. Due to his expertise in chanting mantras that could create wealth and any facility, Saubhari Muni enjoyed with his wives extravagantly. He had built a well-furnished lavish home surrounded by clean lakes and fragrant gardens with chirping birds, and humming bees. With his yogic power, he enjoyed delicious foods, wonderful garments, and gem-studded ornaments. Even Emperor Māndhātā was surprised and defeated when he saw the opulence of Saubhari Muni. Saubhari thus enjoyed his life for some time and had many children through his fifty wives. But he was not happy at heart. Because hefully forgot his spiritual life and bhakti. One day, he sat in a peaceful place and thought about his deviation from spiritual life by seeing the fish in the river. Then, he regretted,Alas, earlier, I was alone doing austerities inside water. But now, I became the husband of fifty wives and begot a hundred sons from each of them. Now, my family contains five thousand people! I gave up my bhakti towards the Lord and was completely caught in temporary enjoyment. Let me develop detachment and devotion and go to the forest again. Thus, Saubhari Muni retired from family life and resumed his spiritual life. Even his devoted wives followed him. Saubhari Muni dedicatedly worshiped Lord Hari in the forest and finally attained the Lord in the spiritual world. By following their husbands footsteps, even the wives of Saubhari Muni were able to attain Lord Hari's abode.
quotes: By yogic power, even sages can enjoy great facilities, but the real utility of one's powers is to serve the Lord.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? Once, Garuda came to river Yamunā and ate fish there. Being an eagle, Garuda naturally eats fish. Saubhari Muni, who was performing austerities at Yamunā, desired to protect the fish, and thus cursed Garuda, You will die if you again attempt to eat the fish here. Although powerful Garuda was not obliged to accept this curse, still, he respected the sage's curse and avoided coming to Yamuna again. Thus, Saubhari Muni committed an offense against a great devotee Garuda. Therefore, he distracted from his spiritual life.
activity: 1. Name a few devotees who were distracted from devotion. How did they come back to bhakti? 2. When do you find yourself most distracted? While preparing for tests, doing homework, or some other time? 3. Having read this story, how can you deal with the distraction you identified in the previous question?
lesson: A LESSON ON DISTRACTION: Anyone can follow the spiritual life, be it a sage or a householder. Great devotee kings like Ambarīşa, Dhruva, Yidhişthira, Manu, and others worshiped the Lord with great devotion, along with their wives and children. But sometimes, persons like Saubhari might get distracted from spiritual life and become attached to temporary enjoyment. This is due to their offenses to great devotees. Therefore, one must be careful not to offend devotees. However, if one realizes one's mistakes through careful introspection and re-establishes one's determination in spiritual life, one can attain the Lord, just like Saubhari Muni.
