title: 60,000 Princes Burnt to Ashes
story: In the dynasty of Mandhätä, there was a king named Bahuka. Despite his heroics, Bahuka's enemies snatched away all his possessions. So, he left his kingdom and entered the forest with his wives. Performing devotional austerities, one day, he left his body. Unable to stay without him, one of his wives wanted to die with him. However, their guru Aurva Muni forbade her because she was pregnant then. But her co-wives became envious of her as she was going to give birth to a child. So they fed her poison to kill the child in her womb. Somehow, the poison did not act, and the child was born with (sa) poison (gara). Therefore he was called Sagara. Sagara later became a great emperor. He performed many sacrifices to please Lord Hari. He had sixty thousand sons. Once, when Sagara performed an Aśvamedha sacrifice, Indra became envious of him and stole his sacrificial horse. Sagara's sixty thousand sons searched for the horse, and dug into the earth extensively. Finally, they found the horse near the hermitage of Kapila Muni. Suspecting that Kapila was the thief, they shouted at Him, He is sinful. Kill him! Kill him! As they tried to attack Kapila Muni with their upraised weapons, Kapila opened His eyes. Kapila Muni was an incarnation of Lord Visnu, and the teacher of Sankhya philosophy by which one can attain liberation. By the influence of Indra, the sons of Sagara had lost their intelligence and suspected Lord Kapila. Due to their disrespectful attitude towards a great person, fire emanated from their bodies, and thus, they were at once burnt to ashes. Some people thought that the fire of Kapila's anger burned Sagara's sons. But actually, Kapila never became angry. They all died only because of their offensive attitude toward Lord Kapila. Knowing that his sons were burnt to ashes, King Sagara became very sad. His sacrifice remained incomplete. After some time, Sagara considered how to retrieve his horse. Sagara had a powerful grandson named Amśumān. Sagara requested Amśumān to retrieve the sacrificial horse to complete the sacrifice. Amšumān followed the path dug by his uncles and finally found the horse near a pile of ashes. There, he also saw Lord Kapila. Amśumān respectfully bowed to Lord Kapila and praised Him with folded hands. Lord Kapila then mercifully explained to him spiritual knowledge and said, Dear Amšumān, please take this sacrificial horse of your grandfather. Your relatives, lying there as a pile of ashes, can be liberated only by the touch of the waters of River Gangā. Amśuman brought the horse back to their kingdom. King Sagara then completed the sacrifice. Following his guru's instructions, Sagara retired from his duties and attained the spiritual world. How would the 60,000 sons lying as piles of ashes be liberated? At that time, River Gangā didn't flow on the earth. Ganga, after having originated from the lotus toes of Lord Vämana, meandered across the higher planets only. Someone would have to bring her to the earth. Who would do that, and how? Flip on to find out.
lesson: A LESSON ON SUSPICION: Sometimes, we may doubt the character of an genuine person. Based on what we see with our eyes, we might jump to unnecessary conclusions. Suspecting, accusing, or harming an innocent person without knowing the facts is a great offense. Although wise people don't take such offenses, but such an offense rather harms the offender. External looks may be deceptive, therefore we should think twice before judging someone.

title: Bhagiratha Brings Gangā to Earth
story: King Amśumān wanted to bring mother Gangā to the earth to revive his uncles. So he performed severe austerities for a long time, but still, he couldn't succeed. In due course of time, Amśumān died. Amśumān's son Dilīpa also tried to bring Gangā to the earth, but he also remained unsuccessful and passed away. Dilīpa's son, Bhagiratha, then performed severe austerities to please Gańgādevī. Finally, Gangā appeared before Bhagiratha and said, Dear King, I'm satisfied with your worship. So I shall grant you the boon you wanted. Bhagiratha said, O, worshipable Goddess, my only desire is to deliver my ancestors. They are lying near Lord Kapila's hermitage as a pile of ashes. They'll regain their forms only when your waters touch them. Mother Ganga said, Dear Bhagiratha, I can come to the earth from the upper planets, but when I fall from the sky, my waters will be so forceful that I could pierce the Earth's surface and go to the lower planets. Who will sustain my force? Bhagiratha replied, Dear mother, Lord Śiva is very powerful. He can sustain your forceful waves on his head. I will request him to help me. Ganga Devi then expressed her second concern, Dear Bhagiratha, on the earth, people will bathe in my waters to be purified of their sinful reactions. How then shall I be freed from the sins that I accumulate? Bhagiratha replied, Dear mother, the devotees of Lord Hari are pure in their character, and can purify the entire world. They carry Lord Hari within their hearts. Because Hari can destroy sin, when His devotees take a bath in your waters, they can remove all the sins you have accumulated because of the bathing of sinful people. Gangā Devi was pleased with Bhagiratha's answers and finally agreed to descend from the upper planets to the planet of Earth. Bhagiratha then performed severe austerities to satisfy Lord Śiva. Lord Śiva has another name called, Āśutoșa, which refers to the one who is pleased very quickly. Eventually, Lord Śiva became pleased and accepted Bhagiratha's request. After that, the mighty river Gangā began to descend from the heavens unto the earth. Lord Siva sustained the water on his head. Thus Gangā flowed through the locks of Lord Śiva's hair. Bhagiratha began to drive on a swift chariot, and river Gangā followed him. She purified many places until she reached the ashes of the sons of Sagara. Then, simply by being sprinkled with the water of Ganga, the sixty thousand sons of Sagara were elevated to the heavenly planets. Although offending Lord Kapila destroyed Sagara's sons, they were still purified by the touch of mother Gangā. Who are the descendants of Bhagiratha? Read the next chapters to learn more exciting stories of other Kings in Bhagiratha's dynasty.
quotes: Holy devotees are holier than holy places and holy rivers. By their purity, they can remove the sinful contamination of all people in all places.
activity: 1. Name a few personalities who showed great determination to attain their goals. 2. What do you do when you lack the determination to do your work?
lesson: A LESSON ON DETERMINATION: What enables you to attain your goals easily? - It's the quality of determination. Achieving anything in life requires determination. Those who are determined are fully focussed on their goals without any distractions. But those who are not determined become diverted towards multiple things. When we are determined, we automatically get support from others and higher powers. Our sincere desire and determined efforts coupled with support from great souls guarantees success. Determined people easily attain success because they accept whatever is favorable to attain their goals and reject whatever is unfavorable. But those who lack such determination cannot easily achieve their goals.

title: Saudāsa: Cursed to be a Cannibal
story: In the dynasty of Bhagiratha, there was a great King named Saudāsa. He had a beautiful queen named Damayanti. Once, Saudāsa went to the forest to hunt. In the forest, he saw a Rākṣasa, a fierce demon accustomed to troubling innocent people. So Saudāsa fought with the Rākṣasa and killed him. The Raksasa had a brother who wanted to take revenge on Saudāsa. Later, when Saudāsa returned to his kingdom, the Raksasa's brother came to king's palace and entered his kitchen in the disguise of a cook. One day, Saudāsa invited his guru Vasistha for dinner. The Raksasa cook then intentionally served sage Vasistha human flesh. Seeing that, Vasistha Muni became offended. He angrily spoke to Saudāsa, O King, you have invited me to take meals at your home, and you are feeding me human flesh! I am a brāhmana! Do you think I'm a Raksasa who eats human flesh? For this grave offense of yours, I curse you to become a man-eating Raksasa. Saudāsa never had the intention to insult Vasistha. The human flesh was served by the Rākṣasa and not by Saudāsa. But considering the facts and not even inquiring, Vasistha impulsively cursed Saudāsa. Saudāsa became angry at Vasistha Muni's curse. Intending to curse Vasistha in return, he took water in his hands and chanted the śapa-mantra, the hymns of the curse. Then his wife Damayanti immediately stopped him saying, It's not proper to curse a brāhmaņa and guru. Hearing his wife's advice, Saudāsa restrained himself from cursing Vasistha. He threw the water on his own feet because if he had thrown that water anywhere else, it would harm the living beings in that direction. The curse-water that Saudāsa threw on his feet created a black spot on his feet. Therefore, Saudāsa was also called Kalmāşapāda. Realizing his mistake, Vasistha Muni made the curse on Saudāsa last only for twelve years. Also, as an atonement for cursing the innocent King, he undertook severe austerities for twelve years.Because of Vasistha's curse, Saudāsa acquired the nature of a man-eating Raksasa and wandered in the forest. One day, he saw a brāhmaṇa couple in the forest, and wanted to eat the flesh of the brahmaņa. Then the wife of the brahmaņa begged Saudāsa, O King, you are the endant of the disyaku dynasty. You are not a Rākṣasa. Please do not act cruelly. Please return my husband. He's a learned brahmaņa performing devotional austerities for Lord Hari's pleasure. A saintly king must protect brāhmaņas and not act harm them. In this way, the wife of the brahmaņa's wife piteously requested Saudāsa not to kill her husband. But because of the power of Vasistha's curse, Saudāsa exhibited the nature of a Rākṣasa and ate the brahmaņa. Overwhelmed with grief, the chaste brāhmaṇī cursed Saudāsa, O fool, O sinful man, you have separated me from my husband. Because you have eaten him up, I will not have a child now. I curse you that you will die whenever you go near your wife, and you cannot have a child. Then the brahmaņa's wife set fire to her husband's bones, and out of intense separation from him, she also fell into the fire herself. She thus attained the same destination as her husband. After living like a Rākṣasa for twelve years, Saudāsa was released from Vasistha's curse. Because of the curse of the brahmana's wife, Saudāsa could not get a child. Later, by the power of Vasistha, Saudāsa's wife Damayanti begot a child after seven years. There were celebrations in all corners of the kingdom when the king begot a child.
quotes: Even sages sometimes become angry and impulsive and unnecessarily curse innocent people.
lesson: A LESSON ON ANGER: Since time immemorial, uncontrolled anger has only led to unpleasant outcomes and never to noble results. Even great personalities are victimized by anger. For example, Vasistha, although a sage, impulsively cursed his innocent disciple Saudāsa although, in truth, it was the Rākṣasa, not Saudāsa, who had served Vasistha human flesh. As a result, the anger in Saudāsa also erupted. He, too was about to counter-curse his guru! But he abstained from doing so due to the timely intervention of his wife, Damayanti.

title: Khatvanga: The Best User of Time!
story: In the dynasty of Saudāsa, there was an unconquerable king named Khatvānga. Once, the devatās from the heavens requested Khatvānga for his help in a fight with the asuras. Khatvānga agreed, and just with little effort, he easily defeated all the fierce asuras. The devatās became very happy and told him, Dear King, we are very pleased with your selfless service. We wish to offer you a boon. Please ask for a boon. Khatvānga replied, Dear devatās, can you please tell me how much more time I will live? The devatās replied, Dear Khatvānga, you only have one muhūrtā (48 minutes) more to live. Hearing this, Khatvanga immediately went to his palace. He wanted to utilize whatever little time he had to think of the Lord Vasudeva without any distractions. Khaṭvānga prayed, Dear Lord, no one and nothing is more dear to me than Your beloved devotees. My kingdom, land, wife, children, and wealth are not attractive to me. I haven't found anything more satisfying than devotion unto You. I am not interested in any material boons. I could have asked anything from the devatās, but when they offered me a boon, I did not wish to take anything from them. I only want to take Your shelter with full devotion. Thus, firmly deciding, Khatvānga gave up his body and attained Lord Vasudeva in the spiritual world. In the dynasty of Khatvanga, there were several great kings, of whom Daśaratha was one. Daśaratha had four sons who were the expansions of Lord Visnu. The eldes of them was Lord Ramacandra, whose heart-wrenching activities are a feast for the ears to hear and touch the devotees' hearts. Read His exciting pastimes in the next chapter.
quotes: Even a moment of focused absorption in the Lord makes one attain the highest goal of life.
activity: 1. If someone tells you that you have only one more week for your final exams, how would you spend those seven days? 2. With time everything gets destroyed. Identify a few things around you that are speedily getting detoriated.
lesson: A LESSON ON TIME MANAGEMENT: Don't you have timetables at school? How do they help? Well, they organize the time you spend at school in a way that enables you to get the most out of your time. Unfortunately, no one knows how long one can live. As soon as Khațvänga realized that he had only 48 minutes of life remaining, he immediately began meditating on the Lord. It is possible to reach the Lord only if one remembers Him while leaving their body. This is possible only by the regular cultivation of bhakti. So let's ensure we don't miss out on our daily dose of bhakti and make the best use of our time!

title: Rāma, The Jewel of the Sun Dynasty
story: Once, when demoniac people overburdened the earth, all the devatās approached Lord Visnu. They offered prayers for His appearance on the earth. Pleased by their devotion and concerned about their condition, Lord Visnu appeared as Rāmacandra in the Sun dynasty, as the son of King Daśaratha. Accompanied by His divine brothers, Laksmana, Bharata and Satrughna, Lord Rama resided in Ayodhya. Once, sage Viśvāmitra came to Ayodhya and requested Daśaratha, I am performing a sacrifice in the forest, and some mischievous asuras named Marica and Subāhu are disturbing it. Please send Rāma to protect my sacrifice. Although Daśaratha hesitated in the beginning, he finally sent Rāma and Laksmaņa with Viśvāmitra. Lord Rama effortlessly slashed and defeated the demons who disturbed Viśvāmitra's sacrifice. After that, Lord Rama went to Mithila along with Viśvāmitra. Janaka, the King of Mithila, had set the condition that he would give his daughter Sītādevī in marriage only to that prince who could lift Lord Śiva's humongous bow. This bow was so heavy that even 300 powerful men would struggle to lift it together. Young Rama effortlessly lifted the bow, tried to string it, and broke it into two pieces, just as a baby elephant would break apart sugarcane. King Janaka became extremely joyful and conducted the marriage of Sīta and Rama. Sītādevī was an embodiment of beauty and good character. She was an expansion of Lakṣmīdevi. Lord Rama happily stayed in Ayodhyā along with Sītādevi. Considering his advancing age, one day, Daśaratha decided to retire after enthroning Lord Rama as the King. At that time, his wife Kaikeyi, influenced by her evil maidservant Mantharā, asked King Daśaratha for a boon. She said, Dear King please fulfill my wish. I want you to enthrone my son, Bharata as the King of Ayodhyā, and send Lord Rama on exile to the forest for fourteen years. Although Daśaratha was not happy to do this, he was obliged due to his promise to Kaikeyī in the past. To fulfill the obligation of King Daśaratha, Lord Rāma being an ideal son, at once went to the forest along with Sītā and Laksmana. He wasn't disappointed, even to the least. All the residents of Ayodhyā were immersed in an ocean of tears as Rāma was leaving. While Lord Ramacandra lived with Laksmana and Sitä in the forest, one day, a woman approached Him with a proposal. She was Sürpanakhā, the sister of the King of the demons, Rāvana. Attracted by Rama's beauty, she wished to marry Him, but Rāma rejected her proposal. She then approached Laksmaņa, who also rejected her. Infuriated, Sürpanakhā attacked Sītādevī and tried to devour her. Seeing this, Laksmana cut her nose and ears and sent her away. To avenge this insult, Sürpanakhā brought fourteen thousand Räkşasa soldiers headed by Khara and Dūsana, to destroy Rāma and Laksmaņa. Rāma singlehandedly killed all of them within no time. Śūrpaņakhā then went to her brother Rāvana and described Sītādevi's extraordinary beauty. Hearing this, Rāvana desired to kidnap and marry Sītādevi. To lure Rāma away from Sita, Rāvana had sent a demon named Mārīca in the disguise of a beautiful golden deer. Sītādevī saw the deer and pleaded with Rāma to bring that deer to her. Rāma agreed and asked Laksmana to protect Sītā while He pursued the deer. Lord Rama followed the mystical golden deer for some time and finally shot an arrow. Pierced by the arrow, the deer, demon Mārīca, shouted for protection while imitating Rāma's voice. Hearing that, Sītā became anxious for Lord Rama's safety and sent Laksmaņa to help Rāma. While both Rama and Laksmana were thus away, Rāvana appeared there in the disguise of a saintly brāhmaņa. Standing before Sītā's cottage, he begged for some food. Sītā innocently came out to offer alms to the so-called saint at her doorstep. Rāvaņa then showed his true form and kidnapped Sitä. As Rāvana was taking Sītā on his airplane, she piteously cried out for help. Then a vulture named Jațāyu came and fought with Rāvana in the sky. After a brief yet intense fight, Rāvana killed Jatāyu, who then fell to the ground. Meanwhile, Rāma and Laksmaņa came back to their home, only to find Sītādevī missing. Searching for her everywhere, they finally saw Jaţāyu lying dead. Pleased with the vulture's devotion, Rāma performed Jațāyu's last rites just like a son performs the father's last rights. Continuing Their search for Sītādevī, Rama met the monkey warriors Sugrīva and Hanuman. Rāma made friendship with Sugrīva and helped him regain his kingdom by killing his brother Väli. After that, Sugrīva sent many of his monkey soldiers in different directions to search for mother Sītā. Finally, mighty Hanuman found Sītādevī in Rāvana's kingdom Lańkā and informed Lord Rama about her. Eager to rescue Sītā at once, Rāma decided to go to Lanka. Accompanied by Laksmana, Hanuman, Sugrīva, and innumerable monkey soldiers, He soon reached the shores of the vast Lankā ocean. Rāma wanted the help of the ocean god, Samudra, to cross the ocean. He fasted for three days waiting for Samudra's help, but the ocean god didn't respond. Lord Rama then became furious. Just by His mere angry glance, all the aquatics in the ocean became frightened. Seeing Lord Rama's rage, the ocean god immediately came and fell at Rāma's feet and prayed, O Lord, being so ignorant, I didn't understand that You are the Supreme Lord. You may cross the ocean easily, but I have one request for You. Please construct a bridge on my waters only so future generations can glorify You for this uncommon deed. Lord Ramacandra agreed and started constructing a stone bridge over the ocean with the help of His innumerable monkey soldiers. The monkeys enthusiastically threw the rocks into the ocean, and by the Lord's divine power and presence, the stones floated, and a huge bridge was made quickly, and everyone reached Laikā. A fierce battle ensued between Lord Rama's monkey army and Rāvana's Rākṣasa army. The Raksasas held invincible weapons like swords, lances, bows and arrows. But the monkeys only had boulders, and trees that they hurled against the Raksasas. Still, the monkeys easily killed the Raksasas only because they had the blessings of mother Sītā. Finally, Rāvaņa appeared on the scene to fight Rama. An intense and intriguing war took place between both powerful personalities. Finally, Lord Rama shot a fierce arrow that pierced Rāvana, who helplessly fell from his airplane while vomiting blood from his ten mouths. Lord Rama finally met Sītā in the Aśoka garden. She was very emaciated in separation from Rāma. Seeing her condition, Rāma became emotional and compassionate. Seeing Rāma, Sītā's face blossomed like a lotus in joy. After the divine reunion of Sītā and Rāma, Rāma enthroned Vibhīṣana as the King of Lankā. He then returned to Ayodhyā along with Sītādevī, Laksmana, Hanuman, and Sugrīva in an airplane. His period of living in the forest had ended by that time. At Ayodhyā, Rāma was greeted by His mothers, brothers and other residents in great joy. Sage Vasistha enthroned Rama as the King of Ayodhyā. All the citizens of Ayodhyā lived happily under the loving protection of Lord Ramacandra. By attentively hearing the story of Lord Rama, one will be relieved from the disease of envy.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? ILLUSORY SĪTĀ: It was impossible for demon Rāvaņa to kidnap Sītādevī. The form of Sītā that he had taken away was not the real Sītā, but an illusory Sītā or māyā Sītā.
lesson: A LESSON ON RIENDSHIP: Even the Lord loves making friends with His devotees who so desire. Lord Rama made friends with Sugriva, and helped him get his kingdom back. And Sugriva equipped Rama with monkey troops in the Lanka war. In this way the Lord demonstrated loyal friendship in His pastimes. We too can imbibe this quality of loyal friendship and see our relationship with our friends transform.

title: Nimi: A Bodyless Emperor
story: In the sun dynasty, there was another great king named Nimi. Once, he wanted to perform a sacrifice and requested Vasistha Muni to be the chief priest. Vasistha then told him, Dear Nimi, I have already accepted the duty of a chief priest in another sacrifice conducted by Indra. Please wait till I perform that sacrifice and come back. Nimi became silent as Vasistha left. Nimi then thought to himself, Life is temporary. Why should I delay my sacrifice and waste time? Moreover, there are many other priests. Let me ask them to conduct the sacrifice. Thinking thus, Nimi performed the sacrifice with other priests without waiting for Vasistha. After Vasistha completed Indra's sacrifice and returned, he found that Nimi had already completed the sacrifice. So, he became outraged and cursed Nimi, Being so arrogant, you considered yourself very learned and didn't follow my orders. So, may your body fall. King Nimi replied, O sage, you're so greedy for the donations from the heavenly king Indra. You have lost your intelligence just for some little wealth. May your body also fall. Due to Vasistha's curse, Nimi gave up his body. However, the brahmaņas preserved it using fragrant substances. After the successful completion of the sacrifice, the brāhmaņas requested the devatās, O devatās, if you are pleased by our sacrifice, kindly bring Nimi back to life. The devatās immediately agreed. But Nimi said, Respectable devatās, Please don't imprison me in a material body again. Staying in a body is just like staying within a prison cell. I'd rather stay in my spiritual body and meditate on the Lord Hari's form and pastimes. The devatās replied, As Nimi wishes, may he not have a material body. Let him live in a spiritual body as a personal associate of Lord Visnu We bless him with a boon to become visible or invisible to common people whenever he wishes. In this way, Nimi continued to stay in a spiritual body and always meditated on Lord Visnu. The Lord can decide whenever He wants to reveal Himself to us and whenever He doesn't want to. This same privilege of being seen or unseen, according to one's wish, was also bestowed upon Nimi. Thus, Nimi lived in his original spiritual body as an associate of Lord Visnu. According to Nimi's curse, Vasistha also gave up his body and later, again, was born through the heavenly damsel Urvaśī. These were the stories of the great kings of the sun dynasty. Read on to know the exciting stories of the kings in the moon dynasty.
activity: 1. Is greed completely bad? Explain. 2. If one can be greedy, what should a devotee be greedy for?
lesson: A LESSON ON GREED: A brāhmaņa conducts a sacrifice for the pleasure of Lord Vişnu, but sage Vasistha wanted to conduct sacrifices for both Indra and Nimi out of greed for their dakșiņas (remuneration). One can acquire money and facilities as much as required for one's maintenance, but one shouldn't be exceedingly greedy. Even a brāhmaņa falls from his position if he is afflicted by vices like greed.

title: The Story of Satyavati & Acīka
story: King Purūravā was the grandson of Soma, the moon god. He was very handsome and powerful. He married the heavenly damsel named Urvaśī. At one point in time, Urvaśī left Purūravā and went back to heaven. Then Purūravā performed a sacrifice and attained Urvaśī in the Gandharvaloka. After spending a long time with Urvaśi, he realized he was getting lost in temporary enjoyment. He then sincerely worshiped Lord Vişnu and ultimately attained the Lord. In the dynasty of Purürava, there was a king named Gadhi. He had a beautiful daughter named Satyavati. Once, sage Rcika approached King Gadhi and said, I would like to marry your daughter Satyavati. Gadhi saw the sage and felt he was an unfit husband for his young daughter. So, Gādhi asked Rcīka for an uncommon dowry, Dear sage, I shall get my daughter married to you, but on one condition. You should bring one thousand shining white horses, each having one black ear, either left or right. Rcīka could understand Gādhi's mind. So, being a powerful mystic, he went to Varunadeva, the master of oceans, and brought the thousand horses that Gadhi wanted. King Gādhi was surprised, and then happily conducted the marriage of sage Rcīka and his daughter Satyavati. After some time, Satyavati wanted a son. Her mother desired a son too. So, sage Rcīka conducted a sacrifice so that they both could give birth to glorious sons. In the sacrifice, Rcīka prepared two oblations of rice, one for his wife with a brāhmaņa mantra and another for his mother-in-law with a ksatriya mantra. Because sage Satyavati was living in a hermitage as the wife of a brāhmaņa sage, it would be more appropriate for her to become the mother of a brahminical son. And because Satyavati's mother was the wife of king Gadhi, she was more fit to give birth to a ksatriya son who could fight and rule. After preparing the two oblations, sage Rcīka went out to bathe. Meanwhile, Satyavati's mother approached Satyavati and said, My dear daughter, can you please give your oblation to me and accept mine? Because your husband loves you, he must have prepared a special oblation for you. I wish to have it. Satyavati loved her mother and happily exchanged oblations with her mother. After some time, sage Rcīka returned. He understood what had happened in his absence. He then spoke to his wife Satyavati, Because you have exchanged the oblations with your mother, your son will be a fierce kṣatriya who punishes everyone. And your mother's son will be a scholarly brāhmaņa. Satyavati was surprised, and felt guilty that she could not understand her wise husband's impartial nature. She then begged forgiveness from Rcīka and requested him, Please let my son not become a kṣatriya for my mistake. I'm a brāhmaṇa's wife. It would be more appropriate to give birth to a son with brahminical qualities like tolerance, forgiveness, scholarship, and self-control. Rcīka kindly replied, It is impossible to change the effects of what you have done. But seeing your repentance, I can postpone the effects of the oblations you drank. I bless that your son will be a brāhmana, but your grandson will become a courageous ksatriya. After some time, Satyavati's mother gave birth to a son named Viśvāmitra. Although Viśvāmitra was born as a kṣatriya, later he became a brāhmaņa sage. Satyavati gave birth to a son named Jamadagni, a great brāhmaņa. Later, Jamadagni married Reņukā and gave birth to many sons, of whom the youngest was Paraśurāma. Born with kṣatriya qualities, Paraśurāma was an incarnation of Lord Krsna. He destroyed the unrighteous and proud kṣatriyas twenty-one times and thus reduced the earth's burden. Know more about His adventures in the next chapter.

title: Paraśurāma: The Warrior Brahmana
story: Kārtavīryārjuna was the powerful king of the Haihaya dynasty. He lived in Māhişmatī, his mighty capital, with his ten thousand sons. He worshiped Lord Dattatreya by performing severe austerities and received the rare boon of possessing a thousand arms. Undefeatable and endowed with astonishing mystic powers, the king roamed the universe without any opposition. Once, proud Kārtavīryārjuna went to river Narmadā. Desiting to enjoy water sports in the river, he stopped the flow of Narmada with his thousand arms. Because of this, the river flowed in the opposite direction and inundated the camp of the King of demons, Rāvana. At that time, Rāvaņa was worshipping the devatās near the city of Māhişmatī, the capital of Kārtavīryārjuna. The ten-headed demon Rāvana became furious and went to fight with Kārtavīryārjuna. But Kārtavīryārjuna easily defeated and arrested Rāvana as if he were a small monkey. Later, he released Rāvana in a neglectful manner to prove his superiority. Once, Kārtavīryārjuna went to the forest to hunt. Wandering in the forest, he came to the hermitage of sage Jamadagni. Jamadagni was performing his meditation in that forest. Seeing the king coming to his home, the sage respectfully welcomed him and his associates. Whatever his guests needed, Jamadagni could provide very easily. Kārtavīryārjuna was surprised at Jamadagni's hospitality. He thought, How does this simple sage living in a forest provide my soldiers and me with so many lavish Macilities pusomething seems to be suspicious. Kārtavīryārjuna found out that sage Jamadagni had Kämadhenu, a mystical cow that could supply anything that the sage wanted. Kārtavīryārjuna felt envious of Jamadagni. He couldn't tolerate that a simple sage could be more powerful and opulent than himself. Kärtavīryārjuna then rudely demanded Jamadagni, You are a mere sage in the forest. This exquisite cow is of no use to you. I want your Kämadhenu cow! Jamadagni politely replied, You cannot ask for a brāhmana's property. My Kāmadhenu cow provides all the ingredients for my regular sacrifices and worship. Without this cow, I won't be able to conduct my devotional ceremonies. Despite the sage's humble request, arrogant Kärtavīryārjuna ordered his soldiers, Bring that cow along with her calf to my capital Māhismati. Following the order, the soldiers of Kärtavīryārjuna forcefully dragged Kāmadhenu and her calf. Jamadagni helplessly watched his cow being taken away. Hearing about this nefarious activity of the King, Jamadagni's son, Paraśurāma became furious like a trampled snake. He took up his weapons and chased Kārtavīryārjuna just as a lion chases an elephant. Seeing raging Paraśurāma in a black deerskin with matted locks of hair that shone like the sun, Kārtavīryārjuna became fearful. He then sent his seventeen akşauhinīs of armies equipped with elephants, swords, arrows, and other weapons to fight against Paraśurāma. As soon as these soldiers came in front of Him, the Lord sliced off their legs, arms, and shoulders with his axe at the speed of the mind and wind. He killed the soldiers, their drivers, elephants, and horses effortlessly. The battlefield became drenched with blood as Paraśurāma singlehandedly killed all the warriors. Then, Kärtavīryārjuna rushed onto the battlefield personally. He fixed arrows on five hundred bows with his thousand arms to kill Paraśurāma. However, heroic Paraśurāma released enough arrows with only one bow that cut down to pieces all the weapons of Kārtavīryārjuna. Kärtavīryārjuna then uprooted many trees and mountain peaks and threw them towards the Lord. However, Paraśurāma slashed down all those rocks simply with his powerful axe. Finally, Paraśurāma cut off all the thousand hands and the head of Kärtavīryārjuna. He then gloriously brought back the Kāmadhenu cow with her calf and gave her to Jamadagni. Jamadagni didn't appreciate his son's act. So, he spoke to Paraśurāma, Dear son, you are a great hero, but you have unnecessarily killed the King. A King is supposed to be the embodiment of all the devatās. He is the protector of all the citizens. He should not be killed this way, even if he has committed an offense. My dear son, we brāhmaņas have become worshipable by people because of our quality of forgiveness. Lord Hari is pleased by those who are forgiving. As brāhmaņas, we are supposed to forgive and not punish. Ksatriyas are recognized by their heroism, but brāhmaņas are recognized by their forgiveness. To atone for this sinful act of killing the king, I suggest you visit different holy places for a year. Paraśurāma didn't argue with his father. He took the advice, travelled to different holy places for one full year, and then returned to his father's house. The ten thousand sons of Kārtavīryārjuna became very sad after their father's death. To seek revenge, they all came to Jamadagni's hermitage in the absence of Paraśurāma and his brothers. They saw Jamadagni sitting by the side of the sacrificial fire and meditating upon Lord Visnu. Then, those most sinful and cruel people cut off Jamadagni's head mercilessly. Although the sage's wife, Renukā, cried piteously, they didn't care to show a ray of compassion. Renuka then called out loudly in pain, O Paraśurāma, my dear son! Where are you? Hearing her loud cries, Paraśurāma, who was far away, immediately rushed towards her. When he hastily came to the hermitage, he saw his father's dead body. He became furious with mixed feelings of sorrow. He then entrusted his father's dead body to his brothers and took up his axe. Deciding to put an end to all the proud and cruel kṣatriyas, he went to the city of Māhişmati. Paraśurāma effortlessly killed the ten thousand sons of Kārtavīryārjuna and made a mountain of their heads in the middle of the city of Māhismati. A river of blood flowed there, causing fear in all those who disrespected brāhmaņas. After that, Paraśurāma wanted to make the entire earth devoid of polluted kṣatriyas who were disrespectful to brāhmaņas. Twenty-one times consecutively, he had killed several kṣatriyas and created nine lakes with their blood at a place called Samanta-pañcaka. Paraśurama then joined his father's head to his dead body, placed it upon kuśa grass, and worshiped Lord Krsna with a sacrifice. Thus he brought his father back to life. Jamadagni, who regained his life, became one of the seven great sages in the group of seven stars. Lord Paraśurāma still lives in the Mahendra mountains. In this way, the Supreme Lord descended as Paraśurāma avatar in the Bhrgu dynasty and released the universe from the burden of undesirable kings by killing them many times.
quotes: The Lord is especially known as the protector of cows and brahmanas. Those who trouble them become an object of His anger.,The ruling class is responsible for the overall welfare of humanity. But if kings become demoniac and burden the earth, the Lord subdues them.
trivia: DID YOU KNOW? AKŞAUHIŅĪ: The word Akşauhiņi refers to a military phalanx consisting of 21, 870 chariots & elephants, 109, 350 infantry soldiers, and 65,610 horses.  DID YOU KNOW? THE SEVEN STARS: The seven stars revolving around the pole star are together called saptarși-mandala. On these seven stars reside seven great sages named Kaśyapa, Atri, Vasistha, Viśvāmitra, Gautama, Jamadagni, and Bharadvāja. These seven stars are seen every night, and each make a complete orbit around the pole star within 24 hours.
activity: 1. Name some forms of the Lord who incarnated to punish the wicked and establish dharma. 2. Why should one cultivate the quality of forgiveness? List some advantages of forgiveness. 3. Envy is a terrible weapon for self-destruction. Contemplate and find out ways to develop the quality of non-envy.
lesson: A LESSON ON RESPONSIBILITY: The ruling class is responsible for humanity's peace, prosperity, security, and spiritual lives. But sometimes, the kings become demoniac, tormenting the citizens and disrespecting the brahmaņas. Thus, they become a great burden to the earth. In such cases, the Lord takes responsibility for punishing irresponsible kings, protecting the innocent, and establishing dharma on the earth. This is exactly what Lord Paraśurāma did.

title: The Story of Devayānī & Yayāti
story: Vrsaparva was the King of asuras. He had a beautiful young daughter named Sarmisthā. She was innocent but angry by nature. Vrsaparva's guru was Sukrācārya, who had a lovely daughter named Devayani. Devayānī and Śarmisthā were good friends. Once, Devayānī, Śarmisthā, and other girls went to a lake to bathe. They left their clothing on the bank, and entered the lake to enjoy its cool waters. They happily swam and bathed for some time. Suddenly, Lord Śiva and Pārvatī came there on a bull carrier. Seeing Śiva and Pārvatī passing by, the girls felt shy. They quickly got out of the water and started wearing their dresses hastily. Śarmisthā unknowingly wore Devayānī's dress. This made Devayānī angry. Devayānī was a brāhmana girl and Śarmisthā was a kṣatriya girl. So, Devayānī rebuked Śarmisthā, Śarmisthā, why did you wear my dress? I come from a brāhmaņa family, and I'm superior to you. You are like my maidservant. You have put on my dress just like a dog snatches the ghee meant for a sacrifice. You have no etiquette. The brahmanas created this universe by their austerities. They are the face of Lord Visnu, and they always keep the Lord within their hearts. They are natural teachers of the entire world and are worshippable even by the devatās. Among the brāhmaņas, we are even more respectable because we come from the Bhrgu dynasty. Your father is our disciple. Yet, you dare to put on my dress. Hearing Devayānī's harsh words, Śarmisthā became angry and said, You beggar! You boast about yourself even without understanding your position. Don't you brāhmaņas wait at our house for your livelihood like crows? My father gives charity to your father, and thus you people survive. Without we ksatriyas, you brāhmaņas cannot even live. Thus, Sarmisthā ragingly scolded Devayānī. Snatching away her garments, she pushed Devayānī into a well. Śarmisthā just went home. Meanwhile, a King named Yayati in the moon dynasty happened to pass by that well. He was on a hunting excursion. He came to that well to drink water and saw Devayānī inside the well. He immediately gave his upper cloth, kindly caught her hand, and lifted her out of the well. Devayānī became very grateful to Yayāti and said, O King, thank you for saving me. By holding my hand, you have accepted me as your married wife. Our relationship has been arranged by destiny. Although I come from a brahmana family and you are a ksatriya, I would like to marry you. Once, I was cursed by Kaca, the son of Bṛhaspati, that I would not get a brāhmaņa husband. Kaca was the son of Brhaspati. Once, Kaca came to Sukrācārya to learn mrta-sañjīvanī, the art of reviving a person who has died untimely. Seeing Kaca's extraordinary qualities, Devayānī wanted Kaca as her husband. So she went to him and expressed her wish. But Kaca refused to say, You are the daughter of my guru. Therefore, I cannot marry you. Devayānī became angry and cursed him, Your knowledge would become useless. Kaca also became angry and cursed her, You will never get a brāhmaņa husband. Remembering this incident, Devayānī requested Yayāti to marry her. Accepting Devayānī's request, Yayāti returned to his palace. Devayānī went back to her home. Crying, she told her father Śukrācārya how she had been thrown into the well by Śarmisthä and was saved by Yayāti. Śukrācārya became aggrieved. He took her daughter and met his disciple Vrsaparvä to settle the grievance. Meanwhile, Vrşaparvä understood that Sukrācārya was coming to him in anger. So, he fell at Sukrācārya's feet, trying to pacify him. Šukrācārya spoke to Vrsaparvā, O King, your daughter has insulted my daughter. Now, you must please my daughter and fulfill whatever she asks from you. Vrsaparvä immediately agreed. Then Devayani said, Whenever I marry, Śarmisthā must come with me as my maidservant along with her friends. Vrsaparvā was surprised to hear this, but he was also afraid of Sukrācārya's curse. So, he allowed his daughter Sarmisthā to become a maidservant of Devayāni. Śarmisthā now had to serve Devayānī like a slave. Later, Devayānī married Yayāti and took Śarmisthā as a maidservant. Eventually, Devayānī gave birth to two sons. Yayāti also accepted Šarmisthā as his wife, and through her, he begot three sons. Devayānī came to know that her husband, Yayāti, also had sons through Sarmisthā. She then angrily complained to her father. Šukrācārya became angry and cursed Yayāti, You fool, I curse you to become disfigured by old age and invalidity. Because of Sukrācārya's curse, Yayāti became old. Seeing him. Šukrācārya calmed down and said, You may exchange your old age with someone who agrees to give you his youth. Yayāti then asked his eldest son Yadu, My dear son, can you take my old age and give me your youth? Yadu didn't agree, because he knew that in his dynasty, the Supreme Lord Krsna would be taking birth in the future. So, he did not want to give his youth to his father, thus delaying Krsna's appearance. Then, Yayāti asked his other sons, but they all refused to accept his old age. Finally, Yayati asked his last son Pūru. Pūru replied, My dear father, who can repay a father's debt? By your mercy, I got this human life. If giving my youth to you satisfies you, I will happily do that. In this way, Pūru accepted Yayätí's old age, and Yayāti took Pūru's youth and enjoyed this world for a long time. Despite enjoying the kingdom for a thousand years, Yayāti was not satisfied at his heart. He thus became detached from all his wealth. One day, he called his wife Devayānī and shared his realization, This world is a temporary place filled with miseries. Whatever enjoyment we have here is also temporary. Hence, we must always worship Lord Hari fully and then aim to reach His eternal abode. Deciding thus, Yayāti returned his youth to his son Pūru and accepted his old age. He divided his kingdom amongst his sons and retired. He sincerely worshiped Lord Vasudeva with devotion. By the Lord's mercy, he entered the spiritual world. Devayānī also fixed her mind on Lord Krsna and attained liberation. Thus, both husband and wife made their lives successful by surrendering them to the Lord.
quotes: Pride and false ego include one into such petty quarrels, even among friends., Momentary ego clashes can make even friends into lifelong enemies.
lesson: A LESSON ON DETACHMENT: Supplying butter to a fire doesn't diminish the fire but increases it. Similarly, allowing oneself to enjoy this world doesn't decrease one's desires but increases them. Material pleasures remain attractive until one truly realizes their uselessness, and experiences the higher spiritual pleasure. The Bhāgavatam presents the stories of great people like Purūrava, Yayāti and Indra, who desired material joys and got frustrated. Ultimately, they took shelter of the Lord. Learning from their realizations, let us also take the Lord's shelter.

title: The Story of Duşmanta & Sakuntalā
story: In the glorious dynasty of King Pūru, there was a powerful King named Duşmanta. One day, Duşmanta went to the forest to hunt. Wandering in the forest, he became tired and came to the hermitage of sage Kanva. There he saw a beautiful woman named Śakuntalā. Duşmanta asked her, Whose daughter are you? Why are you living in this forest alone? It appears that you are a princess, a ksatriya's daughter. I am Dusmanta, from the Pūru Dynasty. Śakuntalā replied, O King, I am the daughter of Viśvāmitra. My mother is Menakā, a damsel from heaven. I personally never saw or knew my parents. Now, I am growing under the protection of Kanva Muni. I welcome you to our humble hermitage. Please tell me how I can serve you. Would you like to eat some wild rice? You can stay here as long as you want. Impressed with the hospitality and good culture of Śakuntalā, Dusmanta said, O Śakuntalā, your words, and reception are quite worthy of your great family. The daughters of a king generally select their husbands. If you wish so, you can choose me as your husband. Hearing Dusmanta's proposal, Śakuntalā kept silent. Her silence indicated her agreement. Duşmanta then married her right in the forest by chanting oṁkāra by the Gandharva style of marriage. After that, Duşmanta stayed at the hermitage of Śakuntala for some time and returned to his palace. In due course of time, Śakuntalā gave birth to a beautiful son named Bharata. Kanva Muni performed the prescribed rituals for the child. The boy became so powerful that he would capture a lion and play with it. This boy was an incarnation of Lord Vişnu. After some time, when the boy was a little grown-up, Sakuntalā and her son went to the Kingdom of Duşmanta. Seeing Sakuntalā and the child, Duşmanta refused to accept them initially. Then an unembodied voice spoke from the sky, O Duşmanta, Śakuntalā is your wife, and that boy is your son. His name is Bharata. You should accept your wife and son without any hesitation. Dusmanta knew that Śakuntala and the boys were his wife and son, but because they came from outside and were unknown to the citizens, he initially didn't accept them. But Śakuntala was so chaste that an omen declared the truth so everyone could know her chastity. So then Dusmanta gladly accepted them. After Duşmanta passed away, his son Bharata was enthroned as the world's emperor. An incarnation of Lord Visnu, Bharata had a mark of Krsna's cakra on his right palm. In addition, he had a mark of lotus whorl on the soles of his feet. He performed fifty-five aśvamedha-yajñas on the bank of the river Ganges and seventy-eight aśvamedha yajñas on the bank of river Yamuna. His opulence and power surpassed even the greatest of devatās. No one could imitate the Lord's extraordinary wonderful activities in the past, nor will anyone be able to do so in the future.

title: Rantideva's Selfless Charity
story: In the moon dynasty, there once lived a righteous king named Rantideva. He was an embodiment of kindness. He was known for his great acts of charity. He would even take up difficulties upon himself to help others. Unsurprisingly, his name and fame spread to every corner of the earth and in heaven. Rantideva was never greedy to earn a lot of wealth. He would be happy with whatever came by the Lord's arrangement. When guests would come to his home, without a second thought, he would give them everything in charity. Sometimes when he donated everything he had, he and his family would fast for days because of no food! Once, Rantideva fasted for forty-eight days. Then, on the forty-ninth morning, he was about to break his fast with little food made with milk and ghee. Then, a brāhmaņa guest arrived. Seeing the Lord within every living being, Rantideva received the guest respectfully and gave him a share of his food. Pleased with Rantideva's offering, the brahmana ate the food happily and went away. After that, Rantideva split the remaining food among his family members. As he was just about to eat his share, a poor beggar arrived. Considering him also to be a child of God, Rantideva gave him another share of his food. Rantideva knew that everyone is a child of God, whether a brāhmaņa or a beggar, poor or rich. When the beggar went away, another guest came, surrounded by dogs, and said, O King, I and my dogs are very hungry. Can you give us something to eat? Without any hesitation, Rantideva offered the balance of his food to the dogs and the master of the dogs. Thus, he exhibited great patience and tolerance. By then, only little drinking water was remaining. Even that water was enough only to satisfy one person. When Rantideva was about to drink that water, a weak and fatigued man came. Struggling to maintain his life, he begged desperately, O King, kindly give me some drinking water. I am on the verge of falling unconscious. Rantideva felt pity for him, and offered a prayer to the Lord, O Lord, I am unable to see the suffering of these people. Please free them from all miseries. I am willing to suffer on their behalf. I am freed from all hunger, thirst, and fatigue by offering my water to maintain this poor man's life, who is struggling to live. Rantideva, although on the verge of death due to fasting for forty-eight days, gave his water to that poor man. The man was thus satisfied. All the people who had come to Rantideva to beg for food and water were the devas, including Lord Brahma and Lord Shiva. They had come to test Rantideva, who wonderfully passed the test. Brahma and Shiva then revealed their real forms. Rantideva became extremely happy and bowed in front of the devas, who blessed him. The Lord wants to reveal their greatness to all of us by putting noble devotees through such tests. By the example of Rantideva, we understand that all living beings are children of God and must be treated equally.
lesson: A LESSON ON SPIRITUAL VISION: Wise people do not just see the bodily differences of living beings. They see everyone as a spirit soul, a loving child of God, despite their external differences. Knowing that God resides in everyone's hearts, they treat everyone with respect and love.
